headline: People are good, performance culture and work are poor
pros: The people at Capital One are great.
cons:
The perforamce stucture relies heavily on manager favourtism and popularity. This can be hard for people who are favoured and those who are not. A lot of emphasis is put on presenting work publically to be 'seen' and feels like a zero sum game, you have to compete with the people you work with to 'own' the work.

The work is also limited in scope. The only product is credit cards, and after a couple of years this can get very tiresome.

headline: Glacially Slow Progress, but Progress
pros: Capital One is a progressive company in terms of their diversity, inclusion, and belonging initiatives and from an engineering and architecture standpoint, they're very tech-centric, finding tech not only as a means to an end in growing their business, but as core to delivering on their intents and audacious goals.
cons:
Like many large, well-established companies, especially in the financial services space, the pace of change and innovation here feels glacial at times.
Making changes feels like moving mountains and while we profess to have many moving independent parts, we quickly find that one wheel cannot turn without the explicit written consent of other wheels which feel affected by the turning of the other wheel.
Decisions by committee and a convoluted hierarchy of decision making and bureaucracy are stifling for innovative tech thinkers here.

headline: Exodus of tech talent doesn't faze management
pros:
- company can still get things done when upper management deems it necessary and throws people together to make it happen. When the pandemic started, there were lots of such initiatives to make it easier for customers and employees.
- good work/life balance
- great 401k match and benefits
- great place to learn about AWS tech
- company really values customer feedback and tries to do right by them
cons:
- RSUs are only for master software engineers and above. CEO likes to include C1 in the ranks of netflix, amazon and other companies that have crossed the digital canyon. But compensation structure is nowhere near them.

- extremely tough to get promoted unless you are willing to spend 50% of your time in networking with other teams and know all the right people. The bar for promotion keeps raising every cycle even though the managers promise that you are next in line.

- recruiters constantly try to down-level qualified candidates and convince them that they should be promoted within six months, which sadly never happens. 

- the CTO launched the TDP program to get new college grads into C1 and give them the best training among employee groups. TDPs get the plum assignments and get promoted faster than people who came through regular channels. But TDPs use the time to brush up on leetCode skills and move on to bigger tech companies. As a way to stop such churn, CTO seems to have asked managers to promote them even faster :eyeroll:

- new people managers leave within 6-10 months since they get sick of the games that they have to play to get their employees promoted. Old-timers can play the cross-calibration games that are used to stack-rank employees better than newbies.

- even though lots of companies have abandoned stack-ranking, C1 seems intent on making it work. Out of 74 possible candidates for a job category in the last cycle, only 4 got promoted, supposedly due to stack ranking. This leads to a lot of good engineers leaving for better pay. If you are interviewing for a position, ask the recruiter for the list of people promoted in the last cycle. The shortness of the list should help you decide if you want to play the game. 

- every team has 30-40% contractors and their talent level has dropped considerably during the pandemic. Full-time engineers spend a lot of time coaching these contractors in addition to their regular work. Managers seem to be not willing to remediate the situation, since its tough to get any contractors in the first place.

headline: COAF does attempt to go above and beyond for its employees.

cons: COAF sold me on the ability to migrate into any industry CO is in. I found it quite difficult to break into roles I was eyeing for years. Promoting up on a pace that you see for your own career I view as a con. As well as diversity as a con. This company isn't as diverse as it claims. That hasn't changed much over my tenure either.

headline: Nice place to work, BUT Stack ranking ouch
pros:
It's a nice place with tons of perks, and I loved them.

WLB, is said a lot, but if you take advantage of it your rating will drop and stack ranking will bite you.
cons:
You have to stack rank your staff. So as a manager, you need to always hire someone that will be cut. So unlike other places, if you do a good job as a manager all of your staff should be average or above, or issues dealt with ASAP.

At C1, you need those people to stick around till December, every year, that way you have someone at below average. And if you don't, then you are tagged as below average for having an above average team.

headline: Do Your Due Dilligence
pros: Incredibly smart co-workers who will help whenever asked, exciting projects and initiatives, lots of gift boxes and team building activities, there are probably snacks around somewhere if you look hard enough, associates are kept just comfortable enough that they're hesitant to leave.
cons: Performance management process appears to be designed to be weaponized against employees, along with "assume positive intent," which you hear frequently due to... managers who are smart but not competent managing others. There are favorites, so you better focus on managing up; failure to live up to mission and values in terms of DEI, mental health, and overall associate wellness (lip service only); few Black and brown associates in executive roles throughout company; meeting heavy, so actual work often takes place outside regular work hours; diversity is not truly prioritized by those able to implement change--true work takes place many levels below and is not well supported; the straight white males who make up the company's upper ranks, including corporate communications, are allowed to be on their own "journey" with diversity and inclusion, but this journey has no end in sight and they're traveling on a first class ticket; lack of diversity of thought and work styles (templated approach to both); white women are provided many opportunities, which is great, but they are allowed to manage with little apparent oversight while the same is not true of other groups; suggestions for change fall on deaf ears; executives are idealized and rarely questioned, access to them is limited, and they are often surrounded by sycophants; team is kept extremely young and older workers are culled regularly. Overall, associates can have a completely different experience based on their age, race, sexual orientation, personality type.

headline: Good benefits. Environment can be toxic.
pros: Good benefit package. Good WLB.
cons:
It is a bank - meaning that c1 does NOT have a good tech culture that they are bragging about.  If you decide to join, you might want to be mindful of selecting a good group. Talk to your future coworkers before you join. It will help. 

For me, it had been the worst experience in my career so far. I happened to experience organizational changes few months later after I joined. I can write a book to rant about my experience with C1 but I would like my review to be served as an informational guide for people who are considering to accept an offer:

1)  The work is easy. The majority of the time I spent here is at meetings listening other people to argue about some nonsense and work that the manager tries to put the team through in order to make us look busy. 

2) There are some chance that you can fall under a horrible manager.  It depends on how “lucky” you are because reorg happens often. Btw, the definition of an “incompetent leader” to me: full of ego, hollow in knowledge, insecure, micromanaging, bossy, couldn’t care less about emoloyee’s wellbeing. It was my first time encountering toxic people in my life, so take my opinion with a grain of salt. 

3) Stack ranking at a bank? As many of the other reviews have mentioned, your performance is evaluated against people at the same level as you. If you get a manager who is willing to advocate for you, then you are the lucky one. Although it is not guaranteed that you will get a “above strong” rating, your life will still be easier.  If you happen to get a bad manager who only cares about the time you put into nonsense work because they don’t know much about tech, you will be as miserable as me :). Choose wisely.

headline: Pretty good place if you know how to play politics
pros: The salary is a little lower if not middle of the pack for the industry; CEO and senior executives seem to really understand remote work is a big draw for many of us staying here; when you get a good manager/boss who cares, it makes you want to stay.
cons: At the senior executive level, it seems they genuinely care about people retention and what the industry is doing. At the lower levels, People managers can be dismissive of BIPOC issues and while they will listen to you complain about being bullied, they will also use corporate speak to say it’s your own fault. This happened to me twice, with one of the times making it into my performance review as something I should improve. I was so mad about this, but luckily changing teams is not too hard to do! The flexibility in changing teams and moving to a nicer team are why I stayed. I will say also that it’s almost impossible to give reviews about your own people manager anonymously so my old people manager is sadly still there.

headline: Toxic performance culture
pros: Work life balance is extremely good at Capital One. Families are the norm and are very well supported with decent leave policies and flexible work arrangements. They are in no rush to return to the office, and leaders as well as associates extol the benefits of working from home. Compensation is quite high for certain job families (ie. software engineering), but uneven for other groups.
cons:
Meeting culture can be paralyzing due to personnel bloat at the bank. Leadership and steering meetings often involve 30+ people, which makes it difficult to generate decision or have meaningful conversation. 

Performance culture forcing PIP quotas breeds a climate where bootlickers are rewarded and independent thinkers are punished. In the end, calibration boils down to a popularity contest where people who are well liked by leadership get promoted and those who challenge leadership are voted into weak performance and managed out.

You will find that there are two classes of employees at Capital One, lifelong veterans who have been with the bank for 20 or more years, have never worked anywhere else and are -deeply- invested in the way things are, and folks who've been around for 2 or 3 years deciding if it's worthwhile to stick it out. The former class are entrenched and know how to use the performance management system to reward each other and cement power. The second class are prey and fodder for the veterans.

headline: The Good, The Bad and The Ugly...
pros: Great core benefits, care about their employees, felt very lucky to work here during the last 2 years in a pandemic. Get to work with great, motivated and inspiring people. Always receive bonus and pay increase annually.
cons: Slow to change systems, processes and outlook, want to be a forward thinking FinTech but US constraints make it almost impossible to improve our systems and processes and the UK 'poorer cousin' is often forgotten or not consulted with so decisions are made and we are told afterwards. Now a Hybrid organisation but wanting to mandate 3 days in the office to get the culture back to 'how it was' pre-pandemic.

headline: Potential for development is there, most Cafe leaders are too inexperienced in leadership though
pros:
- Plenty of opportunities for development and internal mobility
- Big focus on Diversity and Inclusion
- Open door policy even with upper management
- Generally, you get to decide what you want to work on (aside from the basic job duties) 
- Volunteering opportunities (on halt because of Covid-19)
- Relatively generous PTO program
- Decent benefits
cons:
- A lot of Cafe Leadership is inexperienced, not many are true leaders - most are just playing boss
- There are minimal to no actions taken by HR and leadership against reports of hostile co-workers/work environment
- No Covid-19 sick leave - you have to use your own PTO if you need to quarantine, even if the exposure happened at work
- Depending on the leader you get, well-being and work-life-balance will be an afterthought, even though the company overall constantly speaks on the importance of work-life-balance and encourages doing what you need for your own well being.

headline: Don't join
pros:
- Pay is nice if you are being hired out of college
- HSA is pretty nice
- Stock Purchase Program. Stock is bought at the end of the month and can be sold once they hit your account.
- Work life balance can be great depending on team
cons:
- If you are experienced hire you will be paid less than an entry level college hire
- Company will make you lazy. Coding is secondary here. AWS and buggy enterprise tools is all you will deal with.
- Performance Management Process is absolutely horrendous. Stack ranking makes performance management a popularity contest. You need to know how to play office politics.
- No COL raises. Only merit raises. They will only give non merit based raises to TDPs (entry level college hires)
- Work life balance can be horrible depending on team.
- Getting promotions is heavily dependent on the organization you get hired to.

headline: Overall good but not without its issues
pros: Great place to learn latest tech particularly AWS, work machine is a high spec MacBook, Diversity & Inclusion is great, Overall pay & benefits package pretty good, good attitude to flexible working, informal, friendly, positive workplace. 1st class train trips to London office, sometimes free food. Rapid career progression if you're seen to be performing well. Company does value its tech staff and tries to reward them that's for sure.
cons: Sometimes spend as much effort trying not to get screwed by the performance management system as doing your job well. Performance management disincentivises team-working, turns friends into rivals, makes people pushy or stressed. A slight element of "up or out" culture. Not a place you can stand still in your career, which you may wish to do at some point if you've got young kids for example. Lending at 40% interest to customers some of whom possibly shouldn't be borrowing. Very complex internal systems to learn, which have little career value outside.

headline: A complete package
pros: Cap One is a fun place to work where there are opportunities for learning and growth. Salaries are on a pretty even match with other companies of this caliber. They offer their employees a great range of benefits, from Adoption Assistance to a great matching program for their 401K. Open plan seating and private spaces for meeting are both available as is an amazing lunch room and a beautiful gym right in the building. And then after a good day, you can get right on the highway to zip on home.
cons: Open plan seating during conference calls with both coasts means not being able to really hear the call if people get loud, which they do. A bit of a drawback. While it promotes idea creating from the ease to chat, it also gets loud fast.

headline: Great if you belong to the right group
pros:
If you’re experienced or skilled it’s a great place as you can do the work half closed. Standards are pretty low and most of the work is done just to look busy.

For certain “groups” it’s a great place. From exec team to juniors it’s opportunity, promotion and rewards galore. Everyone else unfortunately just looks on.
cons:
In the risk space you’re unlikely to learn much as it’s not taken seriously and many of the leaders are there because they fit the desired racial requirement rather than any experience or knowledge. 

This isn’t an exaggeration. Just have a look at LinkedIn. Some individuals have very senior posts with literally NO experience.

headline: Like being at a consulting firm, but with better hours
pros:
-Up-to-date MacBook Pro and iPhone with hotspot (you can upgrade every two years)
-Decent hours if you’re not a people leader
-Good 401k match with some immediate vesting, cheap health insurance and some FSA matching $
-Coworkers are competent
-Friends/family think you have a prestigious employer (unless they are in true Silicon Valley-level tech or are far-left and think credit cards prey on the poor and uneducated)
-Gift card points handed out like candy
-Monthly “no meetings” days
-Founder/CEO explains his strategy in detail every year
-Pays well for Plano, Chicago, and Richmond
-Good on-site amenities before COVID
-Meetings have 5-10 minute breaks in between
-You get a couple extra national holidays since it is a bank. People are dismissed after lunch on Fridays heading into 3-day weekends
cons:
-Every employee is stack-ranked, with ~5-10% of people getting punished with half bonuses, half raises, and being put on a PIP (fast track to being let go) each year. HR glides over all this when you join, but the fear of this by itself changes a lot of behaviors and internal politics. For example, everyone is obsessed with working on projects that look good when reported to higher-ups, sometimes at the cost of doing what they think really should be done. Perception is everything at Capital One, even if it is not the only place like this in the job market
-Only two weeks’ vacation when you join (and it gets prorated)
-No stock grants in most cases unless you’re a director+, very unusual for a self-proclaimed tech company
-The salaries look high at each title, but there’s down-leveling and title deflation, so set your expectations conservatively. At an IC level, you are told you could get promoted at any time to encourage you to work harder for free (they will not remind you there’s a cap on promotions each cycle until you don’t get the promotion)
-No more Excel, everyone uses Google Sheets now
-Personal email is blocked on work computers, and you’ll be doing two-factor authentication at least half a dozen times a day
-Contractors and fresh college grads constantly joining and leaving teams, requiring a lot of training, explaining, and finding replacements. These less efficient newbies are often paid close to what much more experienced/FT hires make
-A culture of forced optimism (even printed on shirts and mugs) where instead of saying there’s a problem or a weakness, everyone says you have an “opportunity” 😀
-Pay is not competitive in NY or SF
-Constant mandatory training courses (the acronym is CBT, and the joke writes itself if you look it up) and reminders from your VP that your department looks bad if anyone is late completing the courses
-Extremely hierarchical culture — be prepared to be discouraged from initiating a 1:1 meeting with anyone more than a bit higher than you in title/scope 
-You cannot work remotely from anywhere outside the US even during COVID (most places will only ban a few countries) 
-Before COVID working from home was heavily discouraged though office crowding was an issue

headline: Best company ever

headline: Good Pay But Experience Won't Be Fulfilling
pros:
Good salary
The company does well and if you do your work right, there is job security
You can have a good work/life balance if you navigate and find the right team
Pleasant people at the associate and manager level
If you are in one of the hubs like Clarendon/Richmond there are a lot of onsite perks. Lots of meals and food.
cons:
Being a minority here will be a challenging experience. The company has a performance management system that really favors how friendly you are with your manager. Usually this benefits buddy-buddy relationships. I've seen managers and higher-ups favor their online gaming friends, intentionally punish/target a team with a minoritized racial identity. You can read the comments in other posts, there are a lot of jabs at non-white members within the company, people complaining about the company focusing on hiring or promoting women. The senior leadership is pretty racially and gender homogenous and if trickle down was ever a real, its how this company works.

As a PM, your experience will be a lot of meetings and managing up. Which may not be unique to the role at any place. In my experience, I found that due to the need to impress people with decks or "influence" over working product or code, people invite everyone senior to meetings to voice their opinion. It's a very hierarchical company, so before any decision gets made you will be talking to every co product owner and their boss and bosses boss and boss on boss to make any type of decision. This all means you likely won't get much done.

There's a lot of politics at Capital One. A Lot. So be prepared to undertake in all these games. It's a bit toxic really and probably the worst part of the job.

I don't think you will gain much technical product experience. Capital One is a very product risk averse company. There really isn't a culture of testing and learning you may get at other software companies. You will hopefully get a very specific idea/product the company wants to build. Pray that the company fully invests in it, and if you are lucky within two or three years it may come to life. Within that time you will likely get reorg-ed and your project may go dead. You won't easily get access to the data of products or even company market research/strategy.

Another tension at Capital One is balancing your personal sanity with the desire to perform the Capital One Way. To maintain sanity, you will want to avoid as many meetings, interactions with senior leadership that don't go anywhere, and find a core team that you are highly efficient with. Unfortunately, the stacked ranking system benefits you interacting with lots of managers, showboating that you are influential across multiple organizations or teams, and networking. This will likely stretch you thin and just be present to too many ineffective meetings and obnoxious politics or power dynamics within the company. You will start to think about these relationships and dynamics all the time. Your life will blend into Capital One. At some point, you will probably need a therapist to remind you that all these stressors are only at the office. However, you will fill a strong need/desire to be in with the "in-crowds" at Capital One. 

My advice is if you take a junior/principal role here, find a product in later life cycle/in market one that's critical to the company, learn the basics of managing a product in market, working with an engineering team and design group then peace out. There's not much here for building/launching/improving. It's NOT a technology company despite whatever HR /company site tells you.

headline: Experienced Hires Beware
pros:
- Large corporate option in the DC area with strong brand 
- Typically good work-life balance relative to pay
- Great benefits package for healthcare, parental benefits, etc. 
- Attractive Tysons campus, especially with new additions of Wegmans, Capital One Hall, etc.
- Generally nice and hardworking colleagues
cons:
- For the Business Analysis job family, it's extremely difficult for experienced hires at any level to be successful and especially to get promoted. That's based on hundreds of associate observations in talent conversations across multiple years and lines of business. Powerful transferrable skills and extremely hardwork are no substitute for leaders actually seeing an individual do the work since they were 22 years old. (Analyst Development Program is the preferred entry point.) 
- Re-organizations multiple times per year, which can be demoralizing and frustrating for everyone involved. 
- Organizational politics especially at the Director plus levels. I spent a significant amount of time trying to understand what leaders wanted and working to influence them (and still wasn't successful).

headline: Incompetent, egocentric middle management in Enterprise Digital group
pros:
+ Nice campus and office environment (prior to offices closed due to COVID)
+ Relatively good pay
+ CEO with good vision and willingness to invest in technical innovation
+ Senior leadership in Enterprise Digital group are very thoughtful and caring (but overshadowed by the incompetent middle management sycophants)
cons:
- Performance and promotions are based on who likes you -- not whether you delivered significant business value
- Managers promoted to their own level of *incompetence*
- Everyone out for themselves
- Managers take credit for what their team delivers
- You only get a good review if someone else gets a bad one (bell curve)
- Managers are limited to how many top performance or promotions they can put forward; so, others get left behind (even if they're doing a good job)
- Incompetent managers are never fired -- only their victims that work for them
- Improper conduct (harassment) by management only results in a slap on the wrist
- Managers don't care if you succeed or fail; employee failure is never seen as a potential reflection on poor management / leadership

headline: Best corporate company I have ever worked for
pros: Capital One gives amazing benefits. A generous amount of PTO, Paid Holidays, Flexible scheduling, and great health benefits. Everyone I have ever interacted with at Capital One wants us to succeed as a team.
cons: If you are committed to your job and do your best, it is easy to succeed. However, growing in the company can take years and if you are not networking that can be a problem as well. I feel as if you have to know the right people in order to grow since the company is so large. There are plenty of opportunities for lateral movements within the company, but to work your way up I would say you have to put in at least 5-10 years first to expect any higher positions to start opening up.

headline: GREAT OPPORTUNITY
pros:
Lots of pros to list here: 
Culture of people that I was surrounded by was always positive and uplifting
C1 takes the time to empower you to make decisions and present ideas
cons:
Yearly reviews, based on performance, is lacking. It really leaves a lot to be desired. 

As someone who was rated Strong/Very Strong, year over year, it became frustrating that I was not seeing promotions. Especially after I learned that the only reason I was being held back, was because HR didn't see the value in the team and it would raise too many questions if there were to be a promotion. This was after being told that I had been ready for the next step/promotion for a long time. There's too much to write to truly explain to this story, but that is main idea behind it all. It's unfortunate, but sometimes, we recognize bad decisions and move forward with life.

Oh, and last thing, I wish that you had more of a voice when presenting these issues, but the reality is- the company is so large that it is hard to get your voice heard on an issue like this particular one. It's unfortunate, really, but overall a fantastic place to work. 

Chances are, most people will not experience this same type of event. This was strictly within the organization that I worked within, and they are not actively hiring Visual Artists any longer.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
1. Awesome culture:
Peoples are genuinely very smart, friendly, and outgoing. Management respects work-life balance and is very respectful of employee's personal lives. Although some people chose to work past five, there is definitely no pressure to do so (unless there is a pressing deadline).

2. Investment in people:
I've also found that managers at Capital One are incentivized to highlight the achievements of their team members instead of promoting themselves. Even at the most junior levels, analysts will almost always present their own work unless it is to someone at or close to the C-Suite level. Managers also invest a fair amount in developing their employees, and it is typical to have regular 'development meetings' with your manager and your manager's manager to ensure that you are learning and that you are staffed on projects that are meeting your goals.

3. Internal Mobility (Vertically and Horizontally):
At the lower levels (Analyst - Sr. Manager), people can typically expect to get promoted every 1-2 years (in larger parts of the business). There is also a culture of people switching teams, and it is not uncommon for people to take new roles in completely new parts of the company with very little friction.

4. Great Internal Resources (see cons as well)
Capital One has a great set of internal tools and resources to help people manage the day to day functions of their jobs (managing data, doing analysis etc). This is especially in the larger parts of the company. As a result, people here spend very little time doing 'grunt work' and are instead dedicated to very substantive projects. As a new employee, I was quickly able to build a robust profile of work, and genuinely feel that I have developed a strong cross-functional skillset (data analysis, presenting, project management etc).
cons:
1. Lack of input in the rotation process (for campus hires)
Many business analysts joining out of college will be put in C1s rotational program (the ADP program), where you are assigned one role for your first year and then join a new team for your second role. The first rotation essentially random, while analysts get a larger degree of input into their second role (although the final decision is made by the program). Many people like this because it lets them work in diverse parts of the company, but inevitably a number of people will be placed into roles they are very unhappy with.

2. Frequent Organizational Shifts
As Sr. Executives come and go, they will restructure their subordinate teams. As a result, entire teams, and also individual analysts, are often move into new chains of command and may have to pick up an entirely new body of work. This happens quite often and with very little notice (maybe once per year).

3. Differing experiences across lines of business
In my experience, the largest parts of the company (Mainstreet and Upmarket) tend to have higher levels of technical support and better promotion rates than other parts of the company. The higher level of technical support often means that these LOBs have staff dedicated to making your job easier by automating repetitive tasks, ensuring data is easily available, and by building tools to simplify your work. In smaller LOBs, analysts will often have to do this work on their own, limiting the amount of time you can spend on important projects.

headline: Stay away from this sinking ship especially if you are in Product or Tech
pros:
Only pro this company has is that they pay well as you enter the company. While that is a positive that fact that they will never let you grow outright undoes the positive
Flexible team schedule 
Descent perks
cons:
Rampant favouritism 
As someone who has personally played a part in the company’s leadership team I was blown away with the rampant favouritism and clan mentality that is deep rooted within this company. There are literally 6/7 families that control the leadership (cause both husband and wife are in leadership positions). And it all starts at the top and then trickles down into every level. First you have to be white, then in their in group, then be their favourite and then if you can present yourself well and if all the stars align there is scope for you to move up in this company. If you are person of minority or a hard worker you are doomed.

Re-orgs and promotions are rigged
Every re-Org in this company is a chance for people at the top to give positions of power to their faithful. Also you can literally predict who will get promoted by looking at the org structure. It has got nothing to do with skill or work it’s all based on groupism. 30-35 year old people (husband and wife) are Directors and Senior directors and run this company like a Sorority. The sad part it everyone knows and plays a part in this toxic world. You can work hard and move mountains and your promo will be delayed caused you sneezed in a meeting and did not say excuse me while people who did nothing continue to move up and will eventually become your boss.

US vs Canada madness
The company is a sister concern of their US parent and everything they do comes from the US. The last this this company did which was of any use was building a guranteed product for sub-prime customers and now they milk it for decades. All the folks at the top do is the same 5-6 campaigns and high five each other. The US parent however is actually very very good but Canada leadership has massively lost its way. The only time I felt motivated was listening to Rich Fairbanks and then a month later I realized how different the ground reality in Canada is to his vision.

No tech innovation 
While the US parent has done a ton of innovation in product and tech in Canada it is a mockery of Tech innovation. The company claims to operate like a nimble tech company which happens to be a bank but they are exactly the opposite. Nothing is done in name of innovation and lip service keeps you in the job.
Nothing you do here adds to the resume other than the company name.

Leadership is self obsessed
This is the weirdest thing I have seen in a company and I have been in a lot of them in my career. People who are frankly kids love to talk about themselves that try to be comically vulnerable and personal with employees and because it is far from genuine people literally laugh at them in the background. They try to copy the US leadership which backs emotions by work but in Canada all you have to do is talk. Pretty funny actually to watch!

headline: Great Place to work!
pros: Capital One is very employee focused and an amazing place to work. Everyone is very focused on customer experience and employee satisfaction. They give avenues to give feedback and process improvements and find ways to inject fun and entertainment into the work day. Every manager I had there was great and it was a very tough decision to leave. Benefits are awesome, 6 weeks PTO after 5 years, up to 7.5% 401k match, paternity leave, fun days and so much more.
cons: The sacrifice for work life balance is a little bit less competitive pay. You can make more money with a competitor but the work life balance won’t be as good.

headline: It was great at first
pros: Working here was great at first. I started out as a bank teller, and wanted to evenutally work my way up to and operations roll. Benefits are good though, and pay is decent.
cons: Management is terrible, operations specialists ask for unecessary things, and there is no room to move up positions. Once Capital One got rid of individual rolls and made everyone Branch Ambassadors, that's when things started to go down. They got rid of people who actually cared, they ask and grade us on things during audits that are not necessary anymore, and they do not care about you. Management thinks they have to know everything going on in your personal life, and will still try to make you come in when you call out or even on bereavement. They expect you to break your back over this job when they don't pay you to do that. I got sick and tired of working for them. They try to be inclusive by giving us shirts with inspirational quotes on them instead of actually doing things to support causes.

headline: Worst service job I ever had
pros:
- you can easily pick up hours depending on which market you're in
- when your manager is good, they're really good
- the pay throughout the pandemic was excellent. Industry leading
- benefits were fantastic, industry leading
cons:
- banks have the RUDEST customers, easily. Worse than food service. It is insane the ways people will talk to you. Be warned.
- things change way too often and for no reason.
- absolutely NO GROWTH when i worked here. You are a branch ambassador. Thats it. Theres branch ambassador and then theres market manager. I was there over 2 years and heard of one true promotion - everything else were lateral changes (sorry, branch ambassador to call center is not a promotion)
- the work they had us do during development (for reviews and such) were childish.
- you are not seen as capable adults. You will be micromanaged
- branches closing left and right, adds to angry customers and will leave you not feeling secure about your job
- they are cheap and slow with giving security guards, even when the entire branch feels its needed. They are cheap.
- not a knock on capital one, its banking, but you are on camera, you are being watched. I worked in NY so no audio but if you are in other states where audio without consent is legal, becareful about what you say..
- the "culture" is to brown nose...

headline: Incremental change, not all good
pros:
Working for Capital One was something I aspired to, and it took several years to finally get hired. This was not an unusual story, especially because it is one of the largest and most well-known employers in the area. I worked at a now-defunct call center outside of Richmond, and there was a clear "have and have-nots" delineation between those who worked at West Creek and those who worked at my location. The site was often looked down on, or completely unknown, to the people at West Creek making five times our salary, but we were collecting the money that allowed them to have fancy perks like bicycles to ride between buildings and a butterfly garden. I can't speak to the experience at the Glen Allen locations, but it seemed that folks could much more easily move from working there to West Creek than from our site. I don't know if the site going permanently remote has impacted the career opportunities for those employees, but when I worked there you still had to be within a 100 mile radius of the site you worked from, meaning you couldn't apply for remote roles in other states. 

The people I worked with were amazing and getting to know them was the best part of my job. Management supported career growth for their team members, and we were given lots of opportunities for professional development (pre-pandemic.) Having access to support groups for many different types of identities was a unifying experience that made the widely dispersed company feel a bit more familiar. I was able to gain experience in many different areas that boosted my personal and professional growth. However, I do believe that privilege plays a big part in that, as many of the other folks I worked with were passed up for opportunities time and time again. 

Benefits were good, with affordable healthcare options, 401k (regardless of if you contribute), parental leave, short- and long-term disability, EAP, tuition reimbursement, and occasional perks like gift cards and swag. The managers of the front line workers really care about their employees and do the best they can with the resources they have. We often had potlucks, parties, and events on site, which made work very fun and enjoyable. I didn't know everyone I worked with, but they all felt like friends. Unfortunately, this experience didn't translate to work from home, although many other sites had been remote long before and therefore had the infrastructure in place to support employees in that way virtually. 

Finally, learning about credit and financial well-being was one of the most valuable things I gained from my experience. I have been able to help my family and friends build their credit and feel more secure in their finances from what I learned during my time at the company. There are lots of resources available to learn and even help your community. Volunteer time is allotted each quarter, and the company matches your volunteered hours with donations. Most of the employees truly care about others, which makes for a very welcoming, friendly environment.
cons:
Once the pandemic hit, my role began to shift drastically. We went from an "empathy-based" approach to "results-based." It completely ruined morale, and that was before the layoffs and department closures began. People were desperately trying to leave the department and company due to the massive shift in business objectives. It became very difficult to get promoted, which was one of the biggest perks before 2020. The future went from looking bright to very, very bleak. At times, half of my department was on leave for mental health (which is understandable during a pandemic), but this trend began well before then. With everyone struggling to make it through the day and burning PTO to take care of themselves, more and more pressure was put on those who were still working. Metrics became stricter, performance reviews were graded more harshly, and everyone at the bottom of the food chain felt the pressure bearing down from the top. Needless to say, it became a pressure cooker, and most folks couldn't take it. 

Unfortunately, a lot of my coworkers (including myself) were going through very tough times during the pandemic, and our jobs involved talking to customers who were going through the same things. It was like living in a never-ending hellscape of sad stories. There was no relief, and we were often told to just "focus on the positive." Pretty hard to do when you are literally cold-calling people who are in the hospital with covid, fighting for their life, and telling them they need to make their minimum payment on their credit card or they will be charged more fees. We had some hardship programs to offer customers at first, but there was a cap, which enraged many people who would then take it out on the phone agents. I don't know what the department is like now, but I hope things have changed for the better. 

Culturally, the company has lots of grand ideals about how it is changing banking for good. However, during the pandemic, I saw a complete loss of humanity in this regard. The biggest indicator of this was the cafe employees who were pretty much hung out to dry. Pay equity is something that is not discussed on any level, and when some employees tried to ask for an objective review of their team's pay and raises, the company essentially told them they should be grateful for what they are making. Complete lack of transparency from upper management and age-old tactics to keep workers submissive and hopeless bred massive distrust and disdain for a company that workers previously evangelized. 

Many employees were often put into stretch roles or internships, which builds great experience, but is essentially the company saving money on labor by having someone do the role without receiving the pay. There should be a bonus or differential for employees that temporarily are working more senior roles. Getting one of these internships or stretch roles was often the only way to move up, and you usually had to be hand-selected rather than apply. If you weren't a golden child or friends with management, good luck trying to get a new role. I was considered both at one time and still couldn't get hired in any other department once the hiring freeze was lifted. 

This can be a great starter job or a long-lasting career. It is all circumstantial, and each department and line of business is very different. Do your research, ask lots of questions during the interview process, and make sure that you are confident of what the expectations are for your role and if it will change over time. Take advantage of all the resources the company has to offer and learn as much as you can. 

My experiences are all subjective, and many of my former coworkers are still very happy and love their job. I would take any review you read on this site with several grains of salt because there is no guarantee that your experience would be any better or worse. If you are considering applying here, I highly recommend finding someone who can give you the inside scoop, and hopefully a referral.

headline: Good place for some
pros: Work life balance is reasonable most of the time. Some teams get to solve interesting problems. Possible to grow if you stay with the company for a while.
cons:
Bloated middle management leads to a lack of technical direction. They are not close enough to the ground truth to focus on solving the real problems. For a company that wants to be "all in" on AWS, the cloud controls are ridiculously opaque and Kafka-esque. Many times people just won't know how to be productive with AWS because the best practices aren't clearly communicated. 
Performance management is an absolute mess, retaliatory behavior goes unpunished, so talent leaks like a sieve.

headline: Short-staffed with back-to-back calls (feels like a call center), skills learned do not qualify you for other positions
pros:
Good company benefits (healthcare, dental/vision, 401k match, PTO, etc)
Decent pay
Work-life balance overall for the company is very good compared to other companies (notice how I said for the company, not for this particular position in terms of the everyday workload. The one positive is there is no on-call for this position, and once you complete your 8 hours you can forget about work for the rest of the day)
cons:
Since the pandemic stated in 2020, call queues have been a complete disaster. Most days it takes hours for users to get a hold of an IT Service Desk agent. I'm talking 100-200+ calls in the queue, with no end in sight for the agents who handle this for 8 hours every day. Between each call, there are only 45 seconds before another call comes in, which quickly leads to mental exhaustion after talking for 8 hours straight. This has been an issue for pretty much 2 years now!....2 years! To have it happen for a couple of months, fine, but any longer than that and you really can see where this item is on upper managements priority list/recognition of the dire reality of the situation. I understand it's a tough issue that's multi-facted, but 2 years is completely unacceptable in terms of the mental effects it has had on current employees.

Pay increases every 6 month period are usually a miniscule 1.5-3%, which as everyone knows, does not keep up with inflation (especially the 6% inflation in 2021). You can most likely get paid more by working for a fully-remote friendly company based in another high COL state, especially for a role such as this one that should already be fully-remote since it's completely over the phone. 

Morale is at an all-time low with most team members I speak with, people are just burned out and dread going to work in the morning, which is quite sad. Life is too short to be feeling this way, and to see it at a company like Capital One is very disappointing.

My biggest gripe is by far the lack of growth opportunities here in this particular position. Now, I want to preface this by saying yes some users have moved out of this position into other departments. For the overwhelming majority of agents however, this has not been the case. The users who did move into other positions usually had a lucky break with knowing the right person at the right time, or having experience that was gained outside of Capital One and thus could make them a stronger candidate. For those whos first IT experience was here however, even with earning certifications, it's very hard to move out of this department into other IT positions within the company. Part of the reason for this is that Capital One has a job hierarchy that restricts users from applying for other job positions unless you are currently at a certain job level. For instance, if you are Sr. Coordinator (which is what this role starts at), you cannot be considered for a role that's 2 levels above your current level due to HR policy. The company recently made it so you could apply for 1 job level above your current level, which is an improvement in terms of upward mobility for people. However, the kicker is most tech roles within the company start at Senior Associate or above, which compared to the Sr. Coordinator level, is 3 levels above that. The levels break down like this:

Sr. Coodinator
Prin. Coordinator
Associate
Senior Associate

So with this hierarchical system in place, you are destined to be in the IT Service Desk position for a long time, which I believe is by design to keep people in the position. Promotions can take anywhere from 1-3 years, and there's no guarantee when it's going to happen for you as it takes longer with each promotion. Upon getting a promotion, you do not learn any additional skills that you didn't already know at your previous level for the most part. The job responsibilities stay the same, and thus so do your skills and employability for other positions within and outside the company. 

Generally, industry-wide it's often recommended to stay in Helpdesk/Service Desk no longer than a year or two so you can specialize in other areas (unless you really enjoy it). The other areas are things like System Administration, Cloud/Networking, Security, Data, etc. The problem is, you do not gain the necessary skills within this position to move into those particular areas within the company, and are left to get certifications or outside education to fill this gap. This isn't an issue unique to Capital One, but the problem is a lot of internal company positions will want at least a year or two of experience with the technologies themselves in an actual job position. Not having this experience, but having certifications and outside education will look good, and may even provide an opportunity for a lucky break as I mentioned some people above had, but overall when applying for other positions you will get denied for not having the direct job experience a lot of times. Outside the company, your predicament is just as bad as even if you do have certs/education, the position itself does not give you access to skills that can get you more than another help-desk job unless you get lucky with a company willing to view your certs/homelab as experience. You don't get your hands on managing users/groups in Active Directory, group policy configuration, Windows Server, automation/scripting, AWS/Azure, or SQL. When you look outside the company, you'll see and realize how a lot of even other Help Desk positions within large companies require these skills.

headline: Product Owner
pros:
Great health benefits, 401k matching, bonuses
They are trying to make things more equitable for women and minorities but have a way to go.
I do like the CEO and CIO. They make good decisions and drive the business/technology to the leading edge.
cons:
The performance management process is brutal for managers trying their best to take care of their people and represent them in a "cross-calibration" process. For employees, there's a forced distribution with very high numbers on the bottom end. Those being forced into the bottom rating will not receive a raise and a nominal bonus. For this reason, I would not recommend working for the company. It's not a great way to treat employees who work hard and are loyal.

While I do appreciate the CEO and CIO, I do question their judgment in continuing the performance management process they just won't let go of. It's a completely demoralizing process. For this reason, I have marked the Culture & Values at 3 stars.

headline: Lots of Opportunity for Professional Growth
pros: Capital One marshals vast resources to make professional development available to their associates in the form of conferences, technical learning resources (aCloud Guru, Udemy, etc), and opportunities to build and try new things. They emphasize addressing unconscious bias in decision making and open leader / subordinate relationships in a culture of advancement. They target paying higher than the regional median for tech talent, and are aware of the current tight labor market and have made appropriate adjustments for that. 401k matching is competitive. They're health insurance plan is self-funded, which works well for the associates because they have a pretty large risk pool that skews healthier and younger, which keeps premiums pretty low for very competitive coverage.
cons: Large tech stack with a fair amount of duplication means it takes too long to build and deliver new systems. Internal documentation is often difficult to find, and is sometimes out of date. Reliance on internal interfaces to gatekeep cloud deployment means that learning and using "X" cloud service at Capital One is not the same as learning and using "X" cloud service generally or elsewhere. "Meeting Culture"

headline: A great place to start
pros:
- Great culture and great people

- The campus in Northern Virginia is shaping up to be an incredible one after all the construction, but traffic is going to be a massive headache

- Most of the perks you could possibly want, including paid leave for both parents (much less for fathers than for mothers), 401K match, and wellness reimbursements
cons:
- Work delivery is slow, with some projects taking a year or dragging on for months before getting killed, so your rating / promotion can get political, with how you're perceived being more important than what you actually deliver

- Company has a mission of doing right by its customers that it preaches regularly, but it's hard to see how Capital One has differentiated itself from major competitors in that regard

- You're largely on your own in terms of development and career progression and your mileage varies significantly by your direct manager. There are a lot of great people leaders at Capital One, but there's a constant shuffle, and you need to manage this process proactively

- The company is not supportive of remote work. You can, but this is your last step on the corporate ladder.

headline: Pros and Cons of a Senior Data Analyst at Capital One
pros: You will have full Access to udemy, Coursera, O'reilly, Acloud guru. . What is the tech stack. Databricks for scripting, some snowflake computing and almost no AWS. (may be S3 for storing). Richmond Campus is nice, has a gym, a college like campus. A great and a terrific CEO for a bank
cons: I was in the Data Analyst Job family and it is not the most exciting one to be in. What you do. Some basic scripting in sql, python, build some charts. All you have to do is query sql and put them in a chart or build some monitoring controls for tracking some KPIs or you will be slammed with Audits, audits and audits which is the most horrible part if you don't enjoy it. That is it. If you like do to cool stuff in cloud, build some real world applications, do something meaningful, Stay away from DA family within Capital one. You got to be in Engineering Family which unfortunately they don't sponsor for internationals

headline: Amazing company -- with the right manager

Opportunities to work on a ton of different initiatives and areas — whether you know a ton about finance, or very little. You can grow on the job and shift to so many areas internally.
cons: Performance reviews create a cutthroat culture , with folks focused on claiming ownership of results rather than on collaboration to achieve the best end goal for the business and the customer. If you have a horrible manager, well ... they have a lot of power over your performance ratings, job opportunities, pay etc. If you land a great one, sky's the limit on the places you can grow within the company.

headline: Relaxed, But Pay Low...
pros: This is an amazing bank to start off with. The environment is relaxed. Sales and quotas are not pushed here with is an amazing tradeoff considering other banks that are sales driven. Management is amazing, it is nice to get along with with the team as well as management. Capital One a very laid back company and its a great company if you are looking to start off somewhere to grow in banking knowledge without the hassle of sales.
cons: The pay is not good. Sorry not sorry. We are universal bankers meaning we do it all opening/closing accounts, business accounts, maintenance on accounts, on the phone with back office all day long, ATMs, rude customers, updating accounts, random trainings, and so much more. It sucks to be at work all day and look at your paycheck and think... this aint it honey...

headline: Customer focus, constant change
pros:
True customer focus through all levels of management. Everyone is collaborating with the customers' best interests at heart. As a product manager I got to partner with designers, business analysts, data engineers, and of course my tech teams of 4-7 software engineers. 
Auto loans is organized into "experiences," each focused on a different phase of the customer's journey, and product managers get a high level of autonomy to develop new features and improve processes. 
My projects were engaging. People across job families were engaged in their work, smart, collaborative, and really nice.
Also we're a good mix of a tech company and a bank: product and technology are at the focus of the company, but you still get banking holidays and log out at 5pm every day.
I was in auto loans in the Plano campus.
cons:
There is a high level of change: I had 5 managers in the last 12 months. That's higher than average, but everyone seems to change managers at least once a year if not twice; either because the manager gets moved to a different team or because you do. 
My projects tended to get changed frequently as well: partway through a project, leadership would change the objective and ask us to focus on a different goal, abruptly stopping a 6- or 12-month project halfway through without us delivering anything. That happened enough to my projects and other product managers' to become a pattern. 
This all combines to a frustrating level of change when you have really interesting projects and would love to get them out to customers. My advice would be to start coding an MVP as quickly as possible so you can at least deliver something before priorities shift.

headline: Works great for me

cons: Its customer service, there will be times you will have to put up with some awful people and situations.

headline: Great Company, but…
pros: It was exciting to work for such an innovative company that prioritized a “digital first” approach. Like all customer relations positions, this is an ideal stepping stone.
cons: Your excitement and enthusiasm dulls pretty quickly with the sales expectations and, if you have a manager that only “talked the talk” but never “walked the walk,” don’t be surprised there will be resentment buildup. The salary also needs to be commensurate with the operational workload required. I left in early 2017 so hopefully that aspect has improved. On a corporate level, the culture and values touted are admirable, but the culture of your own team in your own branch is the one that will determine whether you want to stay or leave.

headline: Your mileage may vary
pros: Great compensation for new grads, especially in the Richmond area. Campus was nice with plenty of amenities, such as a discounted pharmacy and excellent, discounted dining areas. You can definitely find some nice people here just like any job. Hell, you might even enjoy your job if you're lucky.
cons:
If you're not lucky, you'll be working on something boring or in a tech stack that's a pain to work with. Even worse, you might get stuck with team members who make you question your own sanity. It's such a huge company that nearly the entire spectrum of experiences is possible here.

Internal politics are a big thing here. Advancement is not a question of what you do; it's who you know. You could be the hardest working developer on the team, but if you haven't been doing side of desk work or giving demos or presentations (those are *huge*), you're out of luck.

Finally, being that it's a Big Financial Company, there's a lot of regulation and bureaucracy and overhead. The amount of hoops you need to jump through just to get a static webpage available internally is mind boggling. If you're someone who sees impediments like that as a nuisance rather than a challenge, you're likely to get annoyed.

Ultimately, the pay and WLB have been great, but I've not done anything genuinely fulfilling here. On top of that, I've had to deal with some real jerks (ones who are classist and lack any self awareness, at that). The only reason I haven't quit yet is that there are hardly any other tech jobs in Richmond, let alone ones that pay as well.

headline: Opportunities to evolve through the business but lots of meetings
pros:
. Friendly, highly skilled workmates
. On-site gym
. Convenient location close to train station
. Great cantine
. Lots of training available to upskill.
cons: Lots of sprint ceremonies / processes / meetings mean time to focus on actual project work is hindered. Focus time is needed i.e. it take 15 mintues to prep for a meeting, 15 minutes to refocus on task afterward. A 30 minute meeting turns into an hour and having these scattered throughout the day really does hinder efficiency. During my first few weeks I caught glimpse of someones google calendar and saw it bursting with multi-coloured meeting events (sometimes overlapping 3-fold) to the extent it resembled a picasso painting.

headline: Great culture, high pay per work/life balance
pros: Highest pay per hour worked of anywhere I've heard of for this type of general business analyst role for all levels. Culture promotes candor and empathy and chill vibes. Lots of brilliant people who know how to work smart; surrounding yourself with people like this will make you learn and grow fast. High level of professionalism. Most managers actually care about your development or at least act like it. In the credit card part of the company, your work actually has an immediate impact (for better or worse).
cons: They push you into management once you hit Sr. Manager, it's not for everyone and they lose talented people this way. Huge company with many parts, it's easy to feel siloed. In commercial bank, you are essentially an internal consultant and the "bankers" make the real business decisions.

headline: Amazing company but DO NOT JOIN COMMERCIAL
pros:
1. The company is phenomenal. Really clean processes, sites, and data. And just wonderful people and culture. BUT only in CARD. Card teams are the core of the bank. If you join anywhere else it's hit or miss, but you will be absolutely exploited in commercial - especially in portfolio analytics - and it will set your career back a good 2-3 years. Turnover is extremely high. If you join, just move internally within a year.
2. Rich is an incredible CEO. His annual meetings are nothing short of inspirational and the company really lives the values.
3. Salary transparency. You can see your salary range in workday. Really shocking as no other company does this. Salaries aren't bad for a bank either.
4. Management training. You can be a manager 2-3 years after graduating if you want. It's a great start for the rest of your career.
cons:
1. Commercial bank is one big con. Lots of ego tripping, 16 hour days for weeks, and then no recognition.
2. Bonuses are not great.
3. HR is great but has some room to be more active on hiring and promotion practices on the company. X-cals are extremely inconsistent across teams.

headline: Great if you’re not an essential worker
pros: Benefits, great medical insurance, paid disability, 5 month long maternity leave, back-up care, LiveHealth app access.
cons: A lot of cushy benefits, but the pandemic has shed a lot of light on us essential workers, we’ve had to work in office during the pandemic, not able to work from home, not paid anything extra, and Covid doesn’t fall into disability so expect to use your PTO, at this point it’s just another job, comparable to working in the food business. Minimal raises if you department isn’t meeting shareholders expectations. Too much pressure on employees to problem solve for upper management. Managers try and take credit for their employees suggestions. Managers out of touch with employee work, not a lot of in department promotion, and creates a toxic environment. You can get trapped into your role with a poor end of year review. Feels like an abusive relationship, since you’re judged on attitude, and not supposed to vent about your struggles, and they expect you to always have a positive attitude. Would not suggest my department to my worst enemy.

headline: Ambiguous Performance Ratings and Rewards for Yes People
pros: Very nice facilities and a liberal travel reimbursement plan.
cons: An ambiguous and extremely subjective performance rating system leverages peer pressure to force managers into a rating system that rewards associates for aligning themselves with management objectives with little regard for actually protecting the company or working in its best interest. Senior Leadership leverages "yes" people to carry out agendas that reward self-promotion over doing what is right for the company or the associates on the front lines. Associates who identify actual risk to the organization are routinely penalized if doing so runs contrary to senior leadership's overarching agenda. The leader of the AML organization often boasted about having "never filed a single SAR (suspicious activity report), the fundamental work of the front line associate within his organization. Leadership fears competency and rewards compliance. Stay away from this company if you are highly-confident and comfortable challenging the status quo. One of their mantra's is "disrupt" - but when you actually do so, you are summarily demoted and removed.

headline: Steer clear - Toxic culture & unhealthy environment
pros:
Free coffee - (you'll need it)
Nice building with good links to public transport 
Gym, games room, music room & nice restaurant
Fun days &opportunities to volunteer in local community projects
Private healthcare scheme
cons:
VALUES - Their values of "Excellence" &"Do the Right Thing" do not apply to their employees. Capital One used to be a Great Place to Work - voted the Best Place to Work several years running - this is definitely no longer the case. 

MANAGEMENT - The management overload their employees with ridiculous amount of work and deadlines, yet they seem to leave on time every night without a care. Managers are often inexperienced and of short tenure and consequently give employees unrealistic time-frames as they have little understanding of the tasks they are asking employees to do. Incompetent managers never seem to be brought to task, they just blame their team. Questionable morals  also appear to go unchallenged 


BONUS - Employees used to receive a good annual bonus which was a great incentive to work really hard to the best of your ability as you were rewarded for your efforts. Management made the decision to take this away from the lower grades yet kept an annual bonus for their own grades. This was counter productive as why should you consistently go the extra mile for very little reward. It also doesn't make employees feel valued as it made a split between management and lower levels which didn't seem to be there as much before.

CULTURE - The culture is political and toxic, its very much if your manager likes you then you will do well but if they don't you will have limited chance of progression. 

PERFORMANCE REVIEW STRUCTURE - This is brutal. Your pay rise is based on you being ranked against your peers even if you do a totally different role. This encourages a toxic and political environment which encourages the wrong behaviours and a blame culture as people climb over each other to improve their rating . It does not encourage collaboration. Good old fashioned hard work and being good at the job you are employed to do is not rewarded, your performance rating is based on the things that you do over and above your core role. If you are not given the opportunities by your manager to get involved in other things in the first place, you will never do well on the performance curve. Employees who do well are the outspoken type who make themselves heard, it's irrelevant if what they are saying makes no sense at all. The more introverted types with standards might not fair so well here

headline: Strong work-life balance
pros:
* Managers place great focus on not taking on extra hours and setting aside time for personal development and getting certifications
* "You build it, you own it" work stream gives each team or cluster of teams a valuable product that they own the life-cycle of
* Many interesting ways that the company is modernizing the data space which is allowing for collaborations across teams that is not possible in traditional bank tech stacks
* Was great with in-person team events and happy hours pre-covid, and has continued with equivalent fun nights and meal credits while working remotely
cons: * Some recurring tasks require engineers to take on weeks/months of red tape for things that only requires a day of active time, so there is often a story on the back burner that myself or a teammate is hopping back to, in between stories

headline: Solid place, but not without challenges
pros:
Capital One really cares about its associates, especially compared to others in the industry. The benefits are great, and they've really put associates over profits during the pandemic. They've also been more cognizant about work-life balance.

Almost everyone who works here is smart, ambitious, and friendly. Development is also encouraged through trainings, lateral moves, and taking on additional work.
cons:
Like others have said, the performance management system can be frustrating and promotions difficult to come by. Depending on your manager, those you're ranked against, and open roles, you may have to wait a while for a promotion, even if you are ready. 

There are lots of people that stay with the company for years, but it seems when people leave, it's because they can get a promotion and pay raise by leaving.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Since the pandemic, Capital One has become a great place to work. Extremely great work life balance. They have taken great care of their employees throughout the pandemic. Nobody even took a paycut,

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
-By far the best company culture I’ve been a part of, genuinely cares about agent development and well-being
- Generous sick allowance after 1 year
- Several ways to earn extra rewards/money throughout the year
- Thorough training 
- Great people
- Lots to get involved in if you want to
cons:
- Just announced permanent working from home for front line agents, only 2 core office days a month
- You can feel very distant from the company and department working from home, difficult to get to know colleagues 
- Complaints don’t get a lot of recognition as a front line department, by far the most demanding department to be in, especially as we need to know so much about everything and get it right for customers. The pay shouldn’t be the same as UK Collections and Fraud considering how much we deal with and how many people are leaving at the moment, it’s kind of a kick in the teeth.

headline: Poor for Mobile Engineers
pros:
• Friendly people and some brilliant engineers to work with
• Financially stable through these tough times
• Decent benefits and learning resources
cons:
• For any small piece of work there's twice as much process. You want to refactor a screen? Speak to 10 different people and you might be able to do it in 1-3 months' time. This means that, as an engineer, you stagnate the moment you join the company - especially for senior engineers
• Even when work gets done, it's usually very basic. No boundaries are pushed and generally it's difficult to be proud of anything you build
• The processes, despite costing a lot in terms of time, are simply ineffective. The tools used to support these processes are often buggy and completely block work for days and even weeks sometimes
• Mobile engineers rarely work on mobile - their time is spent between service work in Java, infrastructure work on AWS, AMI refreshes, debugging buggy pipelines and services, creating change requests, attending community of practice meetings and team/tribe ceremonies
• Lastly, managers' responsibilities are stretched, meaning they can't enact much change. Senior managers seem to be under-stressed and generally are a hinderance rather than helping with anything
• The only people who understand mobile are the mobile engineers - most other people, from QEs and product to managers and above have no experience with mobile. This leads to lots of confusion, unnecessary questions and generally lack of clear direction

headline: If you're a Marketer, make sure to do your research and talk to former employees to get full picture
pros:
The company really does care for its employees and offers great benefits and comps. We used to joke people stay longer just because of that even though the work might not be great. Great campuses and amenities, you have all the resources and equipment at your disposal. 

The recruiting process was by far one of the best and seamless processes I've ever been through, I was thoroughly impressed. 

Surrounded by a lot of very intelligent people with high IQ (but maybe not so much EQ). Incredibly competitive environment because everyone is super smart.
cons:
Their marketing department is not like traditional marketing - it's more Operations and Performance. If you are coming from the outside and are considering a Marketing role within Capital One, I HIGHLY recommend you search for former Capital One Marketing employees and get their perspectives, whether positive or negative. Word of mouth feedback from former employees is usually the most valuable. I'm sure you've heard reputational things already about Capital One (not saying good or bad), but the way Capital One operates/markets and their way of work is VERY unique and specific to them, and not typical of other marketing environments so make sure you talk to former employees before making a decision. 

 Not everyone fits into their culture; if you don't fit in it's identified pretty quickly (both from cultural and work standpoint). Like I said, they have a unique way of doing work that is specific to them and you're expected to do it. I was disappointed with the fact that they hire a lot of outside talent but I felt they didn't take advantage of the value they're bringing (I'm not saying this about myself, more my general observations which are unique to me). 

You're either in or you're out. Once you're out, you're really out. I had a benefits issue after leaving and have literally been ignored and ghosted entirely by their HR department despite multiple follow-up attempts and reaching out to other contacts in the org, which is unprofessional. I have the paper chain to prove it. Literally no responses or acknowledgements whatsoever. I would expect more from a company the size of Capital One. I would say a lot more in this review but don't want them coming after me!
