headline: Tech pivot stumbles; your experience really depends on which Division you are in
pros:
- Salary and benefits are great (for engineers). Full-time Engineers were given a huge pay bump this year to compete with other large tech companies (time will tell if this was only due to inflation). 401k match is the best I have seen anywhere (up to 6%). Health plan is just OK.
- Company appears to be doing pretty well. However, there is a dark side to this that I will get to.
- Lots of free and easily accessible learning resources. They will pay for all sorts of things, from certification exams to degree programs. There are also tons of opportunities to present about various topics to large swaths of the organization.
- Internal mobility is highly encouraged. Employees routinely jump from team to team and division to division. Internal job board allows you to easily find and apply for roles around the company.
- Engineers are given a lot of say within the company. As much as I will complain about the tech org later, CapOne does seem to be genuinely trying to encourage a strong engineering culture and giving them the power they need to succeed.
- Heavy focus on their TDP program, which aims to attract graduates straight out of college and give them lots of training inside of the company. Sounds like the TDP experience can vary widely depending on what kind of teams you get placed on.
cons:
- CapOne wants be a tech company soooo bad, but it doesn't seem to understand what that means or how to do that. They hired a bazillion software engineers, designers, project, and product people, but have no idea what to do with them. Lots of engineers spend all day just updating libraries and re-hydrating VM images. Internal product teams get more love and resources than the public-facing products that actually make the company money. But hey, this message seems to be making investors excited.
- Some divisions have strong products, talent, and culture (*cough* Card). Some divisions are really floundering from both a talent and business perspective. This creates a self-reinforcing loop where good people constantly flee to the already-capable teams and everyone else gets left with the lesser performers. Credit cards are still hands-down their cash cow, so everything else plays second fiddle.
- Lots of power jockeying between teams and senior leaders. Typically this comes in the form of creating processes that make a team a gate-keeper for the rest of the company, such as requiring everyone to get their approval for something as simple as adding a column to a database. More and more decision-making authority is being given to HQ teams like Cyber and Change Management, while the engineering teams on the front lines building the actual products have little to no say in how they are allowed to develop things. Little trust is extended to engineers throughout the company; instead, HQ teams try to micro-manage product teams and force them into supposed best practices despite not knowing anything about their products or code bases. This is made all the worse by people with little to no engineering background repeatedly being put in senior engineering leadership roles. These internal tools and processes that lock everything down are more often than not half-baked and have all sorts of functional issues. There is a lot of bureaucracy even compared to other financial services companies that I have worked at.
- Their well-known cyber security incident in 2019 was CapOne's 9/11 moment. At first there was a real drive to fix systemic issues that led to the incident, but as time goes on this initiative has driven the tech organization to the brink of madness and self-destruction. Crazy amounts of engineers are being used to do lots of BS work in the name of "cyber security" and "compliance" at the expense of improving their products, but very little of it actually helps their security posture. This is driving away tons of talented tech folks who don't want to spend their entire days working on nonsense like filling out paperwork rather than building products.
- Their Diversity, Inclusion, and Belonging program is borderline toxic. Race and gender is brought up constantly and seems to be the only thing that matters to most people. If you fall into one of the in-vogue demographics (and don't work at a branch), you will be given several speaking and leadership opportunities. If you aren't, prepare to be berated either implicitly or explicitly on a daily basis. Some company policies and mandatory trainings are created and run exclusively by the EmpowHER and Black Leadership Council groups. Whenever I wanted to hire someone of certain ethnicities on my team, HR always demanded a written explanation due to "diversity concerns", but never did the same for other ethnicities. The sad part is Asians (east and central) get crapped on the most despite making up half of the company's software engineers; lots of H1Bs that are bullied into long hours and low pay increases under threat of losing their visas. The company should do its best to respect people regardless of things they can't control like sex, but this DIB program isn't the way to deal with that topic.

Some things I saw related to their DIB efforts: a woman muting all of the men at the start of a conference call because they "already got to speak enough," to lots of cheering. A Division President highlighting the "white" data point on an employee demographics chart during an all-hands meeting and saying "This is the problem right here with our diversity efforts..." despite the numbers showing that Caucasians were under-represented relative to national demographics. A recruiter got drunk at a company event and spilled that a lot of them dig through candidates' public profiles to see if they might be Republican supporters and reject anyone that they suspect of this. A very active member of the DIB program on my team repeatedly complaining in private about "all of the Indians" that worked at CapOne.

Multiple managers have been fired for very bad things from Sexual Harassment to fraud and money laundering. Company expects perfection from employees but employees aren't given the right tools. The HR department is a confused mess. It may take them multiple years to fully train you but they will still hold you accountable or they will put very little effort into training you but will expect perfection. Higher ups constantly changing rules without worrying about the impact on employees. They will hold you to accomplish ridiculous goals without incentives. Very little opportunity to move up. You either have to stay on at the same position for years and hope a position opens up or move to another department. Work environment is very much about who you know, so get ready to kiss some A for a promotion.

headline: Not as disability friendly as I had heard
pros: There are no pros. I have never worked there but had such a bad experience applying as a disabled woman in STEM that I wanted to share.
cons:
I had connected with Capital One through a disability career fair. I have two psychiatric Disabilities. I got in contact with a woman named Heather asking for help in applying for a few jobs—she never got back to me. Her responses before that were also vague and unhelpful and she told me I was unqualified even though I have a B.S. in Cybersecurity and 2 disabilities—newsflash—a lot of people with psychiatric disabilities have to try much harder to get a college degree, and even acquiring that degree was a miracle for me. 
What the hell do they think a disability is? Just a little nuisance like a cold?
Bottom line, she never got back. Even after I emailed her asking for help a second time. Essentially my disabilities made me unqualified in their eyes even though I went through living hell to get that degree.
Yet Capital One has a 100% rating on the DEI. I didn’t get that experience—no friendliness, no inclusivity, and no compassion.

headline: Excellent for seasoned pros to chill mid/late career, not for yuppies to ascend ladder
pros: great quality of life, work life balance, and pay is good. Campuses are gorgeous too, if we ever go back to the office. Overall standup corporation with modern tech stack.
cons: Highly matrixed reporting structure, forced stacked ranking, favoritism, lack of "grind" mentality, work-from-home limbo status, main campuses are located far in the suburbs. Promotions are based on "show and tell" not true competency.

headline: Capital One
pros: Excellent benefits and pay for part time and full time employees
cons: High turn over, to many policy changes on day to day basis, constantly walking on egg shells because one day you will have a job next day you may not. Branches closing all over the US for re-evaluation of staffing and branch consolidation. Capital one is in it to WIN it for the company. They make it seem like they care, but its to cover their butt. I've been through 5 branch closures and when I started working for Capital One 10 years ago they had 9 Full service Capital One Branches within 10 miles radius. Now, since 2019, one full service and one Select service, now its 2021 one full service within 40 miles radius. Capital one is all about making money for Capital One they force customers to bank digital and enforce employees to bribe and make customers to bank how capital one wants them to bank. Its not all about that special connection with the customer any longer. Capital One wants banking made easier for Cap One. So they will have less ovee head and use the excuse we don't have customers coming in because they are digital this is BS! So they use the excuse to let higher paid dedicated 10-55 year employees go and then hire new hires starting them out at $15 hr. You are promised tomorrow at capital one and you are constantly being watched,threatened to be fired,written up for any and everything because of new policy/ procedure guidelines changing back and forth. Even they can't keep up with the policy changing because it literally changes daily. Good luck if you consider working here. Please take my advise! Beware of what you are getting yourself into. They have excellent benefits, but it will not last forever! Very stressful job!

headline: Cares and Trys
pros: Capital One treats you right and follows one of their own competency requirements for its associates of "Do the Right Thing". From compensation to benefits to people management to transparency to empowerment to opportunities to competent workmates to flexibility to great work environment, Capital One works hard to get it right for their employees.
cons: Most employees in most years, even if you are a hard worker used to being the cream of the crop, are going to get the middle rating of "Strong" in their competitive performance management rating system. If that will hurt your feelings Cap One might not be the place for you. Getting a higher rating with the additional monies that come with that requires a combination of hard work, right project at the right time, a little bit of politics, and a little bit of luck. That said, the compensation and bonuses with "Strong" or significant and if you can handle getting that, even some years when you felt you deserved more, then you will probably be the one to stay and enjoy the significant pros of working here.

headline: Still a great place to work but they need to rebuild well
pros:
Diversity and inclusion is some of the best you will ever find and there are genuinely empathetic people there who want you to do well.

Teams are given great flexibility in how they work (as long as it is scrum with 2 week sprints).

The company generally tries to do software "the right way". Well tested code is only par for the course. There is heavy emphasis on standardisation to help with delivery as well as removing blockers and tedious change requests going forward.

There are good communities there and you are encouraged to make a difference and make changes. Success is celebrated well.

The graduate and young careers paths are very good and provide a genuine spring board into mid level and senior positions.

Work life balance and employee well being is outstanding.

COVID specific: They sent staff home before the government ordered lock down and ensured there was next to no disruption to work. Bravo!
cons:
Far too little "real" technical or actual coding work. Lots of goal setting and retros with very little substance behind either.

Some managers generally don't seem that interested in developing their staff and would prefer to resolve conflicts of interest with hand waving.

Unsure of who the tribe structure suits. Finance presumably. You will spend a long time working with teams in totally separate departments rather than collaborating with your tribe which was the intention.

The performance review system seems outdated and is loathed by everyone. Far too much emphasis on what the specifics of what you have achieved rather than how you are actually doing day to day.

Don't expect pay rises to keep pace with the industry. Promotion is the only way to ensure you stay fairly compensated.

The requests from the US are usually planned badly and are often unwelcome.

The company preach about technology and the transformation it can bring however recently there has been more than a lot of lip service paid to tech debt/platform investment rather than actually finding time for this work.

headline: Capital One cares about its customers and employees
pros: Capital One offers competitive pay and benefits to employees. Capital one has management that stresses flexibility and fulfillment in your role  and works with you to find the right fit. You have a lot of opportunity to grow and develop with the company. Capital One has a high focus on customer satisfaction and most employees are also customers.
cons: The culture can be foreign for an outsider to navigate at first. Capital One adjusts quickly to outside (and internal) factors and reorgs can be common.

headline: Great people but bad work politics.
pros:
Pay is pretty good for new grads. Salary has steadily increased as the demand for SWEs increases. Two base salary increases across the board in the last 1.5 years, but not everyone gets it (more on that in cons).
Work-life balance is great, but this can vary by what team you're on and management.
cons:
Stack rankings. Even if you're a hard worker, if you have stellar coworkers/teammates, good luck. You'll get rated poorly and get blindsided because you weren't given any feedback throughout the year, hence no real opportunities to improve. If you're rated below strong, aka "performing as expected," you will not get a salary bump, even if the people who've been at the company for 3 months get the bump by default because they're "too new to rate." 
Work politics are clearly at play when it comes to performance reviews at mid-year and year-end. If you're placed on a team with a manager whose expectations are too high, good luck.

headline: They will use you, abuse you, and throw you out when the branch lease expires.
pros: You get tortured, you get insulted, and you get no raise.
cons: You get no respect, they pay you in peanuts, and they make you work like a dog.

headline: A unique culture
pros: People are smart, mostly nice and good 401K match and I enjoy working remotely.
cons:
Culture is very two faced, they love everyone to their face, but watch out when it comes time for midyear and annual evaluations. It is like a cross between the TV show Survivor and Real Housewives. The amount of passive aggressive behind your back activities is stunning. Someone is going to end up in the bad review bucket so people do what they have to in order to stay safe.

And they are very big into diversity and inclusion, it is woven into everything as if race and gender identity are the only things that matter. If you fall into one of the correct victim groups you are safe, if not then keep your head down because as I said someone has to be labeled as underperforming.

headline: Pretty on the surface, still just another call center underneath
pros:
You have a lot of say in choosing your shift / hours. Making changes after you start is difficult to impossible, but if you go into it with a preferred shift in mind(mornings / nights, 10 hour days 4 days a week, 7 hour days to avoid a mandatory lunch, etc) there's a good chance they'll be willing to work with you.
The benefits package is great, but it kind of has to be to makeup for being a call center.
Very inclusive team. Everybody is treated as an equal within the department regardless of race, sexual orientation, or other background characteristics. If you're a social person, you'll probably make a lot of friends working here. 
The pay may seem competitive for the area, and in some ways it is, but for the work/effort required there's many places you could be working for significantly more money.
cons:
Underneath the pretty paint and great benefits package, Capital One is much like any other call center. 
There's very little room for advancement. Most moves within the company would be lateral, requiring 9 months of investment and zero pay increase. The one promotion up from entry level is to the escalations line. What a customer would call a "manager" but really you're just doing the same job you were already doing, and now also taking escalated calls. This comes with a nice pay raise, but the work becomes more toxic and you'll need a very thick skin to get by. 
Beyond the first promotion to level Two, level Three has a very low turnover rate and you may be waiting YEARS taking escalations calls before you're even considered for the next level. If you want to reach a position in the company that will afford you a comfortable living, expect to put in upwards of a decade of your life waiting for it. 
Missing work / calling in sick is a big deal, one that WILL get you fired if you do it enough. 
Every month you will have a certain number of calls pulled by several different people, some you've met, many you never have and never will. These people will critique your calls and give you a score that may or may not depend on their mood at the time.
You will also be held to very strict, often impossible to meet KPI 'goals'. These goals will be purposefully set at unrealistic levels so that when you inevitably fail to meet them, they can use it as a reason to withhold bonuses, offer a less attractive raise, or put you on the chopping block depending on your personal relationship with your manager.
Every month you WILL be told that you're spending too much time talking to your customers, and you will be asked to reduce your AHT (Average handle time) or you risk termination, even though AHT is largely out of your control. You may get lucky and all of your calls are simple 2 minute balance transfers, or you may get unlucky and have a complicated array of technical issues you're chasing on end. 
Either way, LUCK is more important here than talent or effort.

headline: Awesome place to start - nowhere to grow
pros:
Capital One tries to care about their employees mental / emotional well being, which I have always appreciated. They are empathetic in their leadership style. Work/life balance is good. Benefits like 401K and vacation time are fantastic. 

They are trying hard to move forward and be a top contender in the FinTech industry. It’s a slow process, but compared to other banks they are pretty innovative and have made big steps since I’ve been there.
cons:
They sell that it’s like a start-up environment - it is not. It is a bank, audited by the OFFCP, with a lot of red tape surrounding anything we do. They have to be 1000% risk averse, so it feels like you have to go through 10 pipelines of approval to get anything done. 

The performance management system is horrible. Metrics for hiring numbers or anything actually related to your job description are not considered when giving out promotions. Instead, it is a popularity contest or about who received the attractive projects that gets recognized from leadership. At times, this is unfair as not all recruiters get shoulder tapped for projects. 

Some direct managers (not all) are very disconnected from the perspective of “in the weeds” recruiting, as many managers are not promoted from within but hired externally. This is frustrating for lower level associates having to teach managers how to do their jobs.

headline: Call Center Job that is a Dead End in Auto
pros: Time off is great, benefits and retirement package are good too. Cap One is very supportive in diversity
cons: There aren't many places to go other than being a Relationship Manager or an Area Sales Manager. THAT'S IT which makes the competition hard to move into management bc people won't want to leave management if that is a goal of yours. If you are not interested in management then you are stuck in your sales role so you can't move around and learn other interesting skills or job functions. It's a dead-end job sadly and Cap One Auto has made no improvements in trying to create new jobs other than just sales or management. So BE WARNED, if you are lucky to be chosen as a Relationship Manager or Area Sales Manager get comfortable. It definitely can cause burnout doing the same thing day in and day out with no prospects of learning new skills for new roles within the auto division. Do not be deceived, Relationship Manager is a call center role-if you are not a call center type this job isn't for you,if you plan to come in and move around don't come into Capital One Auto Finance--find another way into Capital One. I cannot stress enough that this is a DEAD END JOB and in NO way a Career.

There's some exciting teams/projects but also quite a few doing really mundane work. Offices are nice, modern and have plenty of snacks. There's plenty of non-work related things to get involved in. Generally speaking culture is great - there are still some horror stories about bad managers that I hear but I've only experienced the better ones.
cons: Some teams have really mundane work - even still the managers could do a better job of embracing opportunities to improve life for developers. Pay certainly not competitive and this has led to many people leaving as well as offers turned down from those that passed the interviews.

headline: Great company but easy to get lost in politics even in Tech
pros: Some really talented people work at C1, the company is very forward-facing and willing to make investments that take (sometimes) years to pay off. Lots of chances for advancement. If you're willing to network, there are lots of chances to move around and work on interesting projects.
cons: Internal politics are really strange at times with folks staking out technical positions that seem purist and are likely driven by career optimizing rather than solving problems for customers. A lot of productivity theatre as well, teams doing redundant work. I'm sure this happens in most large companies but it seemed more frequent at C1. Product management was either brilliant or terrible, not really consistent from team to team. Its been a few years so this may have improved. Bonus and incentives structure seemed to cause a lot of churn and fueled some of the above behavior. All that being said, one of the best companies I've worked for.

headline: Great Place to Learn and Grow If You can Play Politics
pros:
Great respect for work/life balance. Managers, at least seem, to care about the happiness of their reports and definitely want to try and make sure you're doing work that you enjoy.
Company implemented "Invest in Yourself Days" where we were allowed to essentially do whatever in order to focus on ourselves. Some people literally used the day to meditate or have a good work out. Others used it to learn something new that they wouldn't usually get to use in their typical day-to-day.
Definitely a place where you can come and retire. Competitive pay and job security as long as you do your job of course.
Extremely smart people work here and you can learn a lot from the people around you.
cons:
Like any corporate company, the politics game is heavy here. 
If you want a promotion you have to practice "influence" instead of just showing strong competency and results.
The loudest and most vocal person is generally the one driving the discussion which I think leads to other team members from not wanting to participate or even caring to.

Used to be amazing. Really felt like innovation was encouraged. Engineering was fun. It isn't as good now. 

A lot of managers aren't that technical any more. Senior managers not really listening to engineers and are more interested in process than building cool stuff.

Product don't know what they want to build.

Far too much time wasted on dev ops tasks and pipelines. 

Too much focus on filling teams with junior members of staff. It's great for new starters but pretty rubbish for more experienced engineers.

Tribes make tech ownership difficult.

headline: Stable job in modern technologies that can just be a job
pros: Agile & cloud-focused (although legacy systems still exist, there is massive buy-in from the CEO down on focusing on using modern cloud-native architectures and cloud platforms); Large company (never concerns about there being work to do, ability to move around different teams and departments can help keep things fresh); Work-life balance (both including expected working hours/time-off, as well as the ability to be involved in volunteering, learning opportunities, or side-of-desk projects during work hours); Benefits (very competitive salary for the area + good financial/retirement benefits, good healthcare and personal options)
cons: Performance rating system (a certain percentage of employees must be ranked at certain performance ratings, including negative ratings, & promotion standards and opportunities seem to vary widely depending on your part of the company); Large company (decision-making and coordination between parts can feel cumbersome depending on the scope of the project you're working on); Beyond being a large company, the financial industry has steep regulations which further govern what is and isn't possible (making it hard at times to scope down MVPs to quick releases on the way to an incrementally more robust build out)

headline: Not what it sees
pros: Benefits. Can count on the paycheck. Resume builder.
cons:
You can take on more higher level work/projects, stretch roles and not get paid for it or get promoted.
Although forced rankings for performance management is still common for many financial services companies, Capital One takes it a step further and quietly fires then bottom 5-10% each year. This creates a toxic culture with a lot of fake over-friendly people who will stab you in the back. Performance management should be called ‘popularity management’ instead, as that is a more accurate label of what it is. I saw someone get promoted from Director to Sr Director and they only worked/came in to the office from 10-4 on office days—you can’t make this up!

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: I really enjoyed the Capital One work environment before leaving for business school. The company emphasizes collaboration, allowing everyone to speak their minds, and assuming positive intent in your coworkers so that you all feel like you’re working together towards common goals. Additionally, the Business Analyst and Business Manager roles are very quant-focused in a way that allowed me to grow in the rigor of my data analyses. Finally, managers are encouraged to regularly ask how you want to grow, so there are frequent opportunities to shift your job functions to better fit your goals and desires.
cons: I didn’t experience many downsides at Capital One. The reason I left was because I wanted to shift into a different industry from finance, but I would have stayed if I wanted to remain in that industry.

headline: Where you are in the organization makes a difference
pros: Work/life balance is a real thing here. No judgement included when you need the time and flexibility for your family. On the product side they truly live by their values and work towards the mission. The pay and benefits are highly competitive for certain roles. They consistently hire outstanding talent so you get to work with a lot of great people.
cons: They don't hold senior leaders accountable for their actions. The internal politics at the senior level is beyond ridiculous. It feels like you're back in high school and you have to watch out for the "mean girls". In certain staff groups living the values and the mission falls a little flat. Specifically, questioning the status quo is not supported everywhere.

Promotions are really blurred and nothing makes sense. A lot of it is based on who you know.

Instead of squeezing customers, why not actually innovate better for them to scale the business instead.

headline: Good company with some annoying policies
pros: Good company. They really try to do the right thing for both customers and employees. Most managers are flexible and do what they can to help. Pay is pretty good and benefits are decent as well. 401k match is great, ESPP is also great.
cons:
Performance management is on a curve. Your rating may not match your performance expectation in order to fit a distribution. Managers do not have as much discretion as it appears. 


Also, expect your leadership to change a LOT. I've had 7 direct managers in 10 years and about a dozen dotted line managers. Priorities shift a few times per year. Because of the frequent changing, any goals that your group has set will likely be irrelevant within a few months.

Most teams are on-call. Work/life balance can be difficult depending on the team and system(s) supported.

headline: Get your ~2 years of experience then get out
pros:
- If you're coming straight from school, you may meet your best friends here
- Good benefits (relatively)
- If you luck into one of the ~5 good managers at the company, you'll have a good time until you rotate
- Good tech to learn and gain experience on
cons:
I think the worst part about this company is how disingenuous it is. They are really good at paying lip service to important issues such as Diversity, Empathy, Transparency, Work/Life balance, but then try to find any evidence of progress within any of these areas (if you're truly data-driven, then this is a no-brainer), and you won't find any.

Diversity: They recruit from the same 4 schools in Canada, from the same 3 programs, which have the same type of students and people from similar backgrounds (McGill, Queens, UofT, Waterloo..). Where is your diversity? When asked about why we don't recruit from other schools, you'll get some bs answer that boils down to "we are biased and we like our bias so we won't change".

Empathy: The amount of associates who have left purely because of their manager's emotional incompetence is absurd. The managers here are promoted not for their ability to manage people, but for their ability to deliver "results", which means that if your whole team is burnt out and depressed, but your manager appears to have reached some goal (emphasis on APPEAR), then they will get promoted and you'll be left with nothing but emotional trauma. 

What do they do about this? An optional 2 hour empathy training.

Transparency: If you directly ask senior leadership anything that isn't a set up for an ego stroke then you will get a vague, standard PR answer that is of no substance. "What are you doing about the absurdly high attrition?" "Why won't you pay us more?" "What is this business trying to do exactly? Other an exploit poor people". 
Answer? "Great question! We are excited about the future of Capital One Canada! What you're asking is important to us, and we will continue to work hard on providing those answers :)"

WLB: Mixed bag, you may luck into a team that isn't doing anything, so you're free to spend the day on Reddit or applying to other jobs, or you may be absurdly busy. In any case, you will have way more meetings than you care for.

Other notable issues:
- They cannot retain top talent they have nothing to offer to anyone with skill and ambition. The pay isn't good, the work gets boring, the company is stagnant, the managers are bad
- Senior leadership loves to talk about themselves and what hobbies they have, etc. at every meeting.... Who told them this was a good idea?
- Leadership is extremely biased, but will constantly tell you how unbiased they try to be. Yet, if you don't think like them, you will not get far.
- Titles are inflated. When you eventually leave, if you go to a REAL tech company, your title will decrease, but you'll be paid minimum 30%-50% more. Capital One is obsessed with titles and hierarchy, so don't get too attached to that "senior" next to your role.
- Once you hit senior, you are not paid well if you are in a technical/analytical role.
- If you're an external hire coming into a senior role, you will not get promoted unless you completely conform to their way of doing things. Again, absurdly biased
- So many people who have never worked elsewhere saying how great it is comparatively....
- Our business model is literally charge poor people for being poor

headline: If you value yourself, skip the Capital One pit stop
pros: They use the the latest & greatest technology. Extracurricular learning is encouraged & funded (in tech at least, not so much in Commercial or the Retail Bank)
cons: Performance management is absolutely senseless. "Differentiators" are essentially decided in year-end meetings and are not achievable by all jobs within the level due to their written job descriptions and duties. Leadership changes at the drop of the hat. Extremely passive aggressive environment where the smallest things are held against you and people are persecuted for it at year-end. You will never get your full bonus. You lose a substantial amount of industry dollars the longer you stay at this company. They would rather hire someone new at an outrageous amount than give existing employees competitive increases & promotions. Do not believe the 'best company to work for' articles. Those are all performative metrics that are not reflective of the WHOLE company

headline: Poor talent acquisition and management
pros: Flexible schedule and good benefits
cons: Many teams and departments have no idea how to identify talent and retain it. Developers are hired with no actual vetting of their skills, to the point you wonder if they have ever written software before. The appearance of results is more important than actual results, so a lot of people move up through the ranks simply knowing how to sound like they know what they are doing regardless of actual ability. Many managers and team leads are poor at mentoring or coaching their hires, giving them unrealistic tasks with no guidance and expecting other teams to provide support and problem solving. Senior company leadership is completely out of touch of what actually goes on, only hearing about issues after they have been filtered through multiple levels of management.

headline: I feel like I was bait and switched
pros: you could work here for the rest of your life
cons: This place is absolute garbage. The culture is unbelievably toxic - people stopped addressing me in the 3rd person and just started addressing me in the 2nd person, e.g., "You will work 22 hours tomorrow" or "you will work 14 hours every saturday for the next 6 months, with no possiblity of vacation". The work life balance is non existent to say the least. I was promised I would be a software engineer and get to do what I love, but instead I'm just a janitor to work through these terrible internal processes and tools that are poorly defined and don't work 90% of the time. Literally everything I'm told to do is high priority fire drills that need to be resolved yesterday. This has been a complete waste of my life and is nothing but a red mark on my resume. I'm getting a raise with my next job, and cap 1 is even taking back my sign on bonus, so monetarily there's no reason to work here.

headline: Exciting work / Constant change / Peter Principle
pros:
AWS! A true modern bank!
Culture embraces change and innovation - very unusual for a financial institution of its size.
Work-life balance is great, as are benefits.
cons:
Lots of "Capital One lifers", who joined the company in its growth years, and seem to have been promoted because they were the most most senior (only) person in their job function. 
This leads to a mid-senior level group of individuals that lack external industry experience and are often mediocre talents that are somewhat stuck at Capital One because nobody else will compensate them for their unexciting skillset. 
This can cap high-potential individuals as they get stuck under an immediate manager that is neither moving up nor moving on.

headline: Not great.. Wouldn’t recommend after a year in
pros:
Decent Pay
Hours are 9-5

cons: Everyone is nice until you realize it is actually a bit of a toxic work environment. Coworkers seem nice but are actually quite competitive and will tell on you to management using any little thing they see or hear from you during hubs (have to be extremely careful what you say). Im in a situation where although results focused, if the manager doesn’t really care about you your career growth is completely stunted. It really is about how a manager sees you and how much you suck up to them. I am finding my role to be more about pleasing my manager and completely ignoring my own development. I also find that I am bot allowed to challenge management on any ideas as they see this as a challenge to their intelligence/ hierarchy. Work overall is also very boring. I am definitely feeling underchallenged burnout. Just avoid this place - there are definitely better opportunities elsewhere if you are looking to grow.

headline: Okay Company with terrible performance management
pros:
1) Gives back to the community through volunteer/ coders program
2) Compensation is above average, and raises are fair. My salary more than doubled after working here 6 years.
3) Work life balance is pretty good, aside from late night releases
4) Has better values than most other banks. Yeah C1 gets fined from time to time for violating regulations, but it's no Wells Fargo
5) Much farther ahead technology wise than similar financial companies
6) Strong push for diversity
7) Pretty good benefits
8) Invest in yourself days
cons:
1) Uses stacked ranking for performance management. 

 How will you be evaluated as a developer you ask? This will determine not only your bonus, but also when you will likely be promoted next and salary increases, so it's pretty important. 

At Capital One, this is process is known as calibration sessions. All the managers under a senior director get in a room and they are given a certain percentage of who can be rated as exceptional, very strong, strong, and needs improvement. . 

There is little regard for the reality of how the employees are actually performing objectively. Astonishingly, the managers work backwards from the same distribution no matter where you are in the company (no I'm not joking) and try to fit all the employees into that, leading to some cases of exceptional employees being under rated, or struggling employees being rated as strong. 

 Your rating will be determined by other managers who you have little opportunity to interact with on a daily basis, and will heavily depend on how much political clout your manager has. Astoundingly, there is little to no consideration put on the opinion of your teammates who would know the most about your contributions.

What this results in is a sort of hunger games culture where you can only do better by having those who work closely with you to do poorly. As you can imagine pitting teams and employees against each other in this manner is a huge drain on productivity.

2) Work is not interesting and doesn't build your developer skill set

The data breach has created a very shortsighted culture. There is a cyber initiative that in theory would be important work to safeguard customer data, but as an initiative it's not very well managed. Don't get me wrong, securing platforms and customer data is and always should be the number one priority. But the kinds of things they have developers doing aren't making the platforms any more secure, and are largely dictated by non-technical types. There's teams of developers (a significant portion of devs) that are spending months doing nothing but continually upgrading versions of libraries of internal systems and filling out endless google sheets. 

This work is the height of tedium and you can expect your developer skills to slowly degrade if you find yourselves in one of these nightmare positions. 

3) Lots of late night releases

More so than other places that I've worked, you likely expect to be up on late night releases 2 to 3 nights per week. This is a drain on your work life balance and one of parts of the job that are actually not conducive to work life balance, otherwise the work load is pretty fair.

4) High turnover (and loads of technical debt)

This may vary with team, but almost every platform I've encountered is understaffed and filled with technical debt. It's a vicious cycle where developers are leaving because the platforms are unmaintainable, which leads to new developers going through the same burnout and leaving. You can't under-staff a platform and continually put off refactoring and listening to developers without paying a price.

5) The hiring process leaves a lot to be desired. 

Applicants for software developer positions are given questions out of a pool that interviewers are mandated to pick form and are frankly... awful. They're solving a small coding challenge that has no resemblance to the kind of work that we do on a day to day basis. It's no surprise that with this hiring process we get a fair amount of developers that can't contribute to the team in any meaningful way and are rarely fired, but merely moved from team to team forever.

6) Company politics are rampant

I've personally seen managers straight up lie to another to get ahead. On one occasion one manager said he would give a developer to the other if they could transition a platform, and then went back on his word and pretended he never said this. I was shocked. Some of these managers directors are so without moral compass and scheming they make Machiavelli's characters look like Fred Rogers.

headline: Capital One Canada is a sinking ship
pros:
- Great culture and good work life balance
- Good tech stack
cons:
- Compensation (salary, bonus, annual raise) is way below market for software engineering
- Lots of lip service and "swag" but they don't put the money where their mouth is
- If you're a software engineer, you will spend a big chunk of your time dealing with vulnerabilities remediation, adopting/onboarding to enterprise in-house tools/monitoring, and much less time engineering actual products
- Title inflation, recent grad one year out of school can be promoted to "Senior" Software Engineer. This is an insult to actual senior engineers.
- Terrible performance management process
- Promotion process is muddy and the goal post shifts every year
- Canada business has been on a downhill trend for years (lost two partnerships, lack of competitive branded products, can't retain customers that graduate from the secured cards)
- Company townhalls turned into personal story time from senior leadership and less about the business.

headline: Popularity Over Quality
pros: They provide a macbook, some colleagues haven't drank the full bowl of koolade mentality.
cons:
Huge popularity contest in Tech Recruitment at Capital One. Beyond Principal Associate, not a single thing they sell you in the interview is true about growth or support, there is no upward momentum - immediately a glass ceiling unless you are a home grown HR rotational not a professional recruiter with actual ideas.

This is likely the single most political company of truly unqualified managers I have ever worked for. I have been here just over 3 years and have had 7 different bosses because of inconsistent reorgs - you are a placeholder they toss around and throw reqs at.

Avoid this company for corporate recrutiment. You are expendable, you will feel put down and alone in your career here, management won't support you unless you fit the mold of popularity they see fit, and promotion (unless out of tech recruiting) is a pipe dream.

Also so much fake positiviti (like the grouping) it's awful.

headline: Thick skin required
pros: Better benefits than almost any other call center
cons: New employees are constantly being training because most of them get fired shortly after starting. You need to fully understand which policies can get you fired and make sure you follow them. If you ask a manager about policy there is a good chance they won't know it either and if you follow what they say and its wrong you will be fired. Since managers are free to lie about what they say (since its not recorded) you should figure out a way to record it (hard to do on Zoom calls). The worst mistake you can make is to take as gospel what a manager tells you. In early 2020 they fired every temp in the last 3 groups of new hires because they made too many mistakes. So rather than find out what they needed and properly train them they just fired that many people at once rather than hold the trainer accountable.

headline: Hit or Miss
pros:
- Generous 401K match.
- Extensive paid parental leave option.
- Myriad additional benefits depending on your situation.
- If you're looking for a place to 'park' fora few years, this isn't a terrible option. Depending on your role and department, work/life balance is recognized and this can very much be a strictly 9-5 position for those seeking that.
cons:
- I'll preface by saying - given Capital One's size as an organization - employee experience will inevitably be both team and manager-specific.
- If you're based outside of Virginia (McLean, Richmond) or Texas (Plano), you'll end up feeling like an outsider. This may be changing due to the increasingly virtual nature of employment, but pre-pandemic this was certainly the case.
- The performance review cycle - while not uncommon among enterprise organizations of Capital One's size - rewards those who know and schmooze the right people and have a well-positioned manager. The unfortunate reality is that individual performance metrics are not weighed heavily; it's more or less a popularity contest.
- While internal mobility is encouraged and stands as a reality, the organization leads with selling that option to prospective employees. This begs the question: why are employees constantly shuffling throughout the organization and what are they running from?
- Largely a culture of blame. With an organization this size, it's easy to pass off errors to someone else, hide your tracks and refuse to accept responsibility.
- If you don't start working at Capital One straight out of college in one of their rotation programs, you'll never truly be treated as a superstar employee; it's very much a 'home-grown' environment for leadership.
- Along the same lines as the above point, much of the leadership within the organization has spent the majority (if not the entirety) of their career at Capital One. This lends to blindspots, a lack of diversity in experience and a refusal to adapt to outside points of view.
- Generally speaking, Capital One (purposely) does not pay as competitively as organizations in the same space. If you're going to sell your soul to a bank, you may as well get paid for it.

headline: Great while it lasted
pros: Great benefits, felt seen and supported by higher ups, I had a great direct manager who encouraged and supported our personal growth and personal projects. There were no personal sales goals or calls and the focus was genuinely on a positive customer experience. Compensation was good.
cons: You spend most of your time showing older people how to use technology and walking people through doing things online they could have done at home. The rest of your time is spent doing teller transactions, or if a customer has a legitimate request or issue that requires some actual knowledge and assistance, then you don't get to help them yourself, you just call someone from another department and put them on the phone with your customer. There's very little opportunity to learn about other departments for even lateral movement.

headline: Progressive Big Company
pros: Often times finding that company that provides challenging work, progressive thinking and a balanced work/life schedule is tough. Capital One gives you all 3. With the company being larger you get great pay, benefits and a comfortable work environment (especially at the McLean, Richmond or Plano campuses). With a variety of lines of businesses you can find new opportunities which aligns you with brand new work and teams. There are soooooo many training resources and sessions that you always feel like they are helping you grow if you want.
cons: With so many lines of businesses it sometimes gets tough working with other teams since they have their own processes and management. Diversity in certain areas of the business can be improved.

headline: Avoid at all costs
pros: If you like coasting, this is the perfect place for you.
cons:
If you are a TDP, your future career depends on the random placement. If you are one of the lucky few who get into a great team where they actually do development work, great! But there is a higher chance that you will get placed into a team that does "development" work and by that I mean do nothing that is remotely close to development. There is a reason why a lot of TDPs don't make it through their 2 years in the program. Management won't listen if you complain. They might make you rotate off the team early but no guarantee so you can waste your first year doing no development work. 

Also, like mentioned above, people love to coast at this place. Something that should take couple days can take anywhere from 1 to 2 weeks. There is no sense of urgency when it comes to completing stories. Or if the devs are working hard, they are impeded by the many hoops they have to get through to get their story completed.

Base pay is generally in line with market so you’re just getting short-changed on the bonus side.

headline: They really care about their employees, however hard to advance
pros:
Benefits on day 1 including healthcare, 401k match, FSA, 3 weeks PTO (option to buy another week after 1 year of tenure) plus certain holidays. 

Great company to work for. Really cares for employees. Resource groups to help build connections, mental health resources,will pay for development opportunities (there is a Career Center onsite with a dedicated career coach that is a 3rd party so you don't have to worry about what you share in the meeting).

Makes a big impact in the community by contributing to charities, sponsorships, and volunteerism.
cons:
Hard to advance in the company. I go above & beyond in my role by taking on extra projects with minimal advance notice. It's difficult to move to other positions even when you're doing all the right things & making the right connnections-which can be discouraging.

Lack of communication in department at times.

pros:
-I genuinely always felt the company cared about work-life balance. 
-SOOOOOO many options to move your career in any direction you want, and it's encouraged to move around in the company!
-Great people to work with, all very smart
-The downtown Chicago location is in a great spot if you take public transit
-I appreciated the varied challenges and problems that I was able to solve, it was often the work got stale.
-Learning and development are super encouraged. There are many internal training tracks and external classes and speakers are regularly brought in.
cons:
-There were different promotion tracks for different job families. Meaning, if you're a business analyst you inherently get to a higher level and pay grade than some other jobs. Really was demoralizing when I discovered that, as it felt like it put a pallor of being undervalued on the role I was hired into. 
-The annual and mid year review process was always changing and each manager had significant leeway in how they approached the process. I'm certain they were always trying to improve the model, but it made it feel like a bit of a moving target.

headline: Good company with poor performance management
pros:
- Up to date technology
- Tries to be on the forefront
- Very smart people
- Good home/work balance
- Good amenities: pharmacy, gym, cafeterias, doctors, etc.
cons:
- Big company politics
- Development plans for employees are optional and most managers don't have the time to use them yourself. You need to keep track of your own development. Managers will usually help achieve your goals if you tell them what you want.
- Rating is on a curve and how you will be rated is determined at the end of the year, so you can manipulate the system. The trick is to talk first when they ask for an "exceptional" employee. Once you are established, you usually aren't questioned again. You can also get people a higher rating than they deserve by talking about your average/strong employee when they ask for exceptional. Just be the first person or two to talk and even if they bump you down a notch to meet the bell curve, you're still ahead. Likewise, if you don't talk about someone, they will likely be rated in the lower tiers, so try to talk first. You rarely need to talk about middle-of-the-road employees.

headline: Incredibly Stable
pros: Incredibly stable place to work, things just hum along. Contribute to your projects and enjoy a good work life balance when you do so. Good pay for the area. Fairly modern stack, really just leans on AWS for the most part
cons: We keep trying to internally build tools internally that AWS offers (or maybe they offer 6 months after we start work), that are poorly documented and honestly just don't work as well. We are a bank so there are definitely important places to pump the breaks and optimize for security and stability, but sometimes I think we build stuff in places that aren't in the interest of either of those things.

headline: A Red Queen workplace- work as hard as you can to stay where you are
pros:
- Remote work (at least until Sept.2021)
- Decent requisition system for office supplies (can easily get monitors, chairs, etc.)
- Decent pay for entry-level/mid-tier jobs.
- A lot of training if you're straight out of college with a bunch of peers
- Tuition reimbursement for college courses up to 5250 a year, along with access to coursera and pluralsight.
cons:
- Be prepared to have to suck up to your manager. The way the evaluations work, you are compared against all your peers, and the only person speaking on your behalf is your direct manager. So if they have a bad opinion of you, you will languish.

- Get ready for vague job responsibilities and milestones. I was specifically told that senior business analysts are required to do what is necessary to finish a project, and that you will be subjectively judged based on how well you did whatever was necessary. This ties in with the previous point, in that you never really know how well you are doing until year end.

- Prepare for a lot of "80/20" corner cutting. Timelines are very aggressive (one could say unrealistic), and management does not like delays. Therefore, shoddy analysis has to be done, and covered up with pretty Powerpoints. Discrepancies are not looked into closely unless they don't "fit the story". 

- Expect people to be selfish. Because this is a "results focused" company, anything that does not contribute directly to your results will be ignored. That means that there is no incentive for others to help you unless it benefits them or they have a kind heart (and thankfully, there were a lot of kind hearted people). Collaboration is rare unless it is mandated from above.

- There is no training if you are not straight out of college. "Professional" hires are given a 3 day orientation, then thrown right in. You will definitely notice this, as you realize that hires straight out of college seem to know how to talk the talk, and have better connections.

- You don't get to choose the team you are hired to, you are assigned randomly to teams that need people.

headline: Great intentions, still some ways to go
pros: Great time off culture, good tech stack, great workplace variety. C1 also pays very competitively for software engineers compared to other financial companies. The company itself has lots of engineering opportunities due to the huge technology variety, you just have to cut through the red tape to get to them.
cons: Still a bank at the end of the day. They are transforming into a technology "first" company, but their growth is dependent on a lot of outside contracting, which means some applications are built, deployed, and forgotten. In house tech has grown considerably to combat this, but the ramifications are still felt. Senior management is business-minded, and has more interest in shiny technology than sound engineering fundamentals.

pros: Overall a decent place to work. People are generally nice and the tech is forward looking. Company is trying to emulate a tech first environment and culture which really helps mask the fin-tech foundations. Product teams handle a lot of the boring paper work and meetings so engineers can do more tech. I found that the people here really able to express themselves at work, which is great!
cons: Quality and quantity of work may be team dependent. Product has much more power over direction of projects than engineers. Pay is around average, maybe a little above average, but many other “cooler” tech companies pay more so the good engineers often get poached away.

headline: They're trying but it's a mess
pros: There are some really friendly people working here, and work life balance is amazing. I got lucky, and landed in a good pocket of Capital One.  The pay is extremely good for the relative amount of work you put in though.
cons:
Tech is an absolute mess. The information architecture and red tape makes it impossible to get anything done in a timely manner. There's a significant amount of bad teams, and concerning company culture. I feel like I haven't learned much about tech, but rather - how to deal with all the messes of processes that make it near impossible to get anything done here.

As friendly as the people are, most people are just here for a job, and aren't truly passionate about CS.  The vast majority of work available is: web dev, devops, or cloud - nothing innovative or cutting edge.

pros:
•	Clean data and processed third-party spending data into maneuverable deliverables within a specific format with Excel macros and python libraries such as NumPy, SciPy, and Matplotlib.
•	Worked on data that was a combination of unstructured and structured data from multiple sources and automated the cleaning using Python scripts.
cons:
•	Worked in using collections in Python for manipulating and looping through different user-defined objects.
•	Design and deploy rich Graphic visualizations with Drill Down and Drop-down menu option and Parameterized using Tableau.
•	Administered user, user groups, and scheduled instances for reports in Tableau.
•	Created action filters, parameters, and calculated sets for preparing dashboards and worksheets in Tableau.
•	Written complex SQL queries using joins and OLAP functions like CSUM, Count and Rank, etc.
•	Used Hadoop, Hive, Pig, and Spark to manage data processing and storage for big data applications running in the clustered system.

headline: Great Company

headline: Fast Moving Tech Organization Who Happens to Be a Bank
pros: New technologies, challenging initiatives with a constant focus on the customer. Plenty going on within the company such that you have different areas to move around and work on different innovations. Capital One is constantly transforming how it looks at banking and its customers. Tech is partnered with AWS and the opportunities to rethink and rebuild new things are what excites my teams.
cons: Very competitive environment where pay for performance is prominent. Change is constant and if you can ride that wave, you are in the right place. If constant change and pivoting everyone couple of months is something that unnerves you rather than excites you, this might not be a good fit for you.

headline: food court > the code
pros: The campus (West Creek) is incredible. Pay is relatively high for the area. The bar on hard skills is really low for engineers for comparable positions, so it makes this a great place to learn. Ton of volunteering positions for giving back to the community.
cons: From the shared tech side of house- If you want a tech heavy, forward leaning programming job this ain't it chief. This is an "argue with the tech lead about why unit tests are important" type of job. If you try to improve the quality of programming, the populist hordes will scorn you. Adding tests and implementing design patterns takes too long, silly! You Build It You Own It culture translates internally to software developers that ship things without giving it any testing other than a quick, manual happy path. I never saw a solution get off the ground here. I consistently saw products being created that didn't meet the needs of our users, but did meet the political needs of certain managers. Inevitably, one crew of management would be fired or reorganized and another team would shepherd the product to its next phase. Be prepared to come in one day and have all your work cancelled or reorged away from you.

headline: If I could do it all over again, I would have never accepted a job here
pros: Decent pay, very easy to get promoted if you lack any skill and just know the right way to signal that you are doing way more work than you actually are doing on a daya to day basis; Good new hire program from a social standpoint
cons: Very hit or miss; If you get placed in a bad team, there will not be enough work. You will not develop any skills. You will get punished for having any views different than the herd. Obscure belief that "everyone produces the same amount of work" and the only thing that matters for promotions is anything besides your actual job. Work life balance is too good in the sense that 50% of the employees work about 5-10 hours a week total. Its great if youre a parent with 4 kids and dont care about growing your career. Otherwise, it sucks

headline: Great company with great people
pros: Capital One has tons of very smart people who work for them and, in general, they are a company that does a lot for its employees (is generous with time off, gives benefits and support.) Capital One also pays well and is mission-driven which is great.
cons: Capital One sometimes stresses the work-life balance aspect of the company without enforcing it. At times, I had to work significant overtime to complete last-minute tasks. Also, as with most banking companies, Capital One is made up of predominately white men. Diversity is limited especially as you start going up the corporate hierarchy. They are trying to change that and increase diversity which I applaud them for but they still have a long way to go.

headline: Great Company for employees. Not good for customers
pros: They treat their employees well. Team outings and innings. Team leaders have budgets every quarter for things they can spend on us. They have big events and invite all the employees and have dj’s and great food etc. they know how to make you feel appreciated
cons: The job itself is MENTALLY EXHAUSTING. Having to try to collect money from people struggling especially during a pandemic is heartbreaking. I get tired of telling people that we can’t do much for them. Capital one made very minimal effort to assist in this pandemic even though I’m sure they benefitted from corporate bailouts. The only help they provided was not charging late fees IF a person calls every month to tell them they’ve been affected by COVID. If they don’t mention COVID they get no help. And if they forget to call one month we’ll charge them late fees and can’t waive them. Also we keep charging interest every month so someone who owes 300 dollars ends up deferring because of the pandemic and losing their jobs and by the time they get a new job they owe 500 dollars. And I’ve seen it on large scales too where people go THOUSANDS of dollars over their credit limit from interest alone. And they will NOT give any offers to lower ANYONES interest rate. No matter what. So it’s very hard to work for a company that treats its employees great and their customers terribly. If you have a conscience you wouldn’t be able to take this job for long

headline: San Francisco location is like working near an airport runway
pros: Great benefits, including 401k unmatched and matched, lots of holidays including bank holidays, annual bonus, vacation buyin, flexible hours, good snacks and coffee. Culture tries to be employee-centered and practice good ethics. Compensation is good but not great.
cons: San Francisco location is really noisy: high ceilings and wide open spaces make it an echo chamber. There are small rooms along the edge where employees may sequester themselves, but  those rooms are always full. Decentralized management and week Scrum Masters means results in lots of bullying in the scrum. The company decided all software developers are engineers, so QA engineers are expected to become full-stack developers. But there is no plan or support that allows the transition, other then spending 20 hours/week outside of work to attend community college or take courses through Lynda.com . Traditional developers are balking at doing real QA, so quality suffers. Women are encouraged to participate in numerous conferences and conventions for women in tech, while the men stay at the office an work. As a result, the guys gain more experience and deliver more output in the same period. In the bigger picture, more new hires that are men are moving on to higher paying jobs. the company emphasis on diversity is at the expense of productivity. High achievers are not rewarded in the first few years out of college. "Diverse" groups with little background in software development recieve a small amount of training and made into Scrum Masters, and many look like deer in the headlights.

headline: Great Culture, Didn't reward loyalty
pros:
I will never find another work family like this one. We truly cared for each other. My favorite way to explain this is when I tried to find someone to invite to a work function when my partner couldn't make it with me. As I was listing people off in my head, every single one of them was a co-worker that would already be there. I did end up bringing a co-worker that might otherwise not have come, but still...it was another co-worker. 

After over 10 years, 3 departments, and countless positions, I'm still friends with many of my former co-workers. I enjoyed going to work to see my friends and work with them.

I had one boss that fought tooth and nail to get me a worthy raise due to my hard work and the fact that I was grossly underpaid for what I did and my "title" within the company (and I really don't care about titles).

Depending on your location - great snacks and paid or subsidized gym membership. They really do care about employee health.
cons:
Stack-ranking for promotions and raises. The higher everyone is ranked, the worse off everyone is because "Very Strong" becomes the new norm and lowers everyone to "Strong." 
Gaining licenses and certs rarely counts for anything other than prestige and additional responsibility and opportunity, but definitely not guaranteed promotions or raises.
Long-term employment means no salary adjustment. The only way to get paid what you are worth is to leave and come back (and yes, I know people who did this and made a lot more money, mainly on the tech side of things).

headline: Game of thrones: Cap1 edition
pros: Great Benefits and surrounded by smart people
cons:
Cap1 culture revolves around hiring young people and having a high attrition rate. They push 10-15% of associates out every year. Doesn't matter if they have great performance, someone has to go. So if you are a team of 8 BAs in one department, at least one of you is leaving at the end of the year. That creates a very toxic environment where people are competing rather than collaborating. This is not an agile environment this is an 1980 policy of ranking people that no one uses anymore. There is a reason a lot of people come in and leave at the 2 year mark, and cap1 is ok with that, they actually designed it like that. Same for senior level same for management level.
It is very common for people to steal your ideas/work/projects to get the recognition. The louder you are the better off you are during the "calibration" hunger games eliminations process. 
Moving on to middle management, you have a bunch of 28-29 year old "managers'' running the show. People with as little as 3 years work experience are managing people's career. Your manager is your god. They simply control everything, your career, your projects, your bonus, your calibration, your performance. If your boss doesn't agree with you or you both aren't compatible, well guess what will happen to your calibration, yup bottom of the curve. 
The work can be exciting but recently they announced the partnerships exit, I wouldn't be surprised if they start laying off analysts or shall I say be more aggressive in their "elimination" game. 

For current and future employees, Know that their performance rating is nothing but a politics game between managers. You are just pawns they are manipulating. If you feel stuck and you aren't on top of the curve, leave! The way they push employees to quit rather then firing them is brutal to your self esteem and mental health. Why won't they fire you? well they will at the end if you just won't quit, but mainly cause they want to maintain a good team morale. 
Oh and that is the HR policy, no one will admit it, but it is: Fast in fast out. Hire a lot and push out 10-15% at each cycle out.

Extra tips to win the game of thrones:
- If you work extra hours, you will skew the curve. Now you guarantee you are ahead of the curve. Other associates either have to match your work or they are out. See how the toxic culture starts developing?
- Agree with everything your boss says. DON'T trust your boss. Never be honest with them . They will use whatever you say against you. 
- Don't help other associates in the same family group if you aren't getting anything out of it. Wasting a couple of hours here and there will push you down the curve. If you help, make sure everybody knows! Even better tell your boss you did half the work why not. 
- Leave. Because everything I mentioned above will make you a bad toxic person. Constantly apply for other jobs.

headline: Not Really a Tech Company
pros: Aside from the product owners, the engineering group were very professional, easy to work with, and had some definite talent.
cons: The management structure is very dated. Essentially all engineering teams are run by a Product Owner. The product owners sit in meetings and groom backlogs; they're not capable of contributing to meaningfully to technical discussions. Some have a technical background, but within a few months they're completely out of date on any given stack, and are functionally unable to manage an engineering team. At that point there's a real problem- software decision-making is entirely driven by a non-technical staff. This of course is a perverse incentive- instead of an engineer driving technical decisions, designing software and innovating, the engineers have to effectively beg product owners for tasking, ("please let me solve this issue the right way"). Any incentive an engineer had to excel in their trade will quickly be exhausted by this poor organizational structure.

headline: Just another bank
pros: The pay for the current position that i'm in is not bad compared to other banks, the balance between work and home is pretty good and when we were in the office before the pandemic the enviroment was pretty chill. My position is a M-F position and all major holidays off and there are time where overtime is available.
cons: The wrong people in the right position! Capital One or at least the site that i'm in has a trend of hiring people in management that have no previous experience in fraud or does not have the aptitude for fraud. This is an issue if you yourself have fraud experience or are a seasoned veteran, management does not like to be corrected or challenged, if they say 2+2=8 and you don't go with that then you're going to have a hard time. It's all about PERCEPTION with these people, once you go against the grain they will retaliate against you no matter how good of a performer you are and the HR or associate relations route will not help you and they will side with management automatically. My current manager is a complete ding bat and does not like to be corrected and has no experience nor the aptitude for the work, trying to have a conversation or explain things to a person like this is like trying to ice skate uphill on a sunny day. The rating system for promotions and raises are trash and it may not reflect the work you've actually done.

headline: GREAT CULTURE AND BENEFITS
pros: You feel valued and rewarded for your hard work. The schedules are regular business hours with a short day on some weekends, I appreciate how it allows me to have a great balance of work and personal life. You get great internal mobility opportunities, health insurance, very great PTO, career counseling, wellness incentives, tuition reimbursement and many more perks. The work environment is often great and you don't have the annoying pressure that other banks have to meet certain number of sales goals (I really love that about Capital One). You get to focus on helping customers without having to push them on getting certain product just to meet your monthly goals.
cons: Management needs some improvement. Nobody appreciates a manager who's too soft to overlook certain associate behaviors that affect the team as a whole.

headline: Sr. AML Investigator I
pros:
• Work Life Balance
• Benefits are great
• Relaxed Dress Code on Campus Office
• Work From Home opportunities (Pre-COVID). 
• Tuition Reimbursement without having to stay at the company for a certain period of time.
• 401-K match is up to 5%
• PTO and company holidays are extravagant 
• Company mimics everything Google is doing, so they’re trying to get there. Not quite the Google environment. Maybe one day if they keep following.
cons:
• Terrible Diversity and Inclusion
• The little diversity the company has is at the bottom of the hierarchy: Document pusher, call center, production-based jobs, customer service, security, etc. 
• Terrible all performance review 
• Promotion s are based on politics
• Lack of educated and skilled managers and supervisors 
• Strong, strong office politics
• Anyone can learn the job, the job posting qualifications asks for things that management don’t have - degrees and certifications
• Title seekers: Associate, Sr. Associate, Principal Associate - Title don’t matter, salary does. A promotion from one position to the next is approximately 5-10% raise, which isn’t a lot at all. That pay range for an associate starts at 53K and Sr associate starts at 60K - 10% is not a lot over the course of a year.

headline: Experience varies by team

headline: Inconsistent management. Toxic sub cultures.
pros: Salaries and benefits are very good.
cons: This is a place you want to love and enjoy working but middle management makes it very hard. There is a lot of talk about development opportunities but that is only true for friends of directors. The company doesn't value experience, it values new grads and new people so turnover is high and you end up with people with a couple of years into their working lives at the same level as very experienced people.  Its hard to know who works there from one day to the next. Each part of the business is run by somebody on the leadership team, they believe their business area is their own fiefdom and every area has a very different culture, so  the experience as an employee is wildly different depending on where you work. The middle "director" level fear making decisions, don't appear to trust the people in their teams, and every decision gets escalated right to the top, so if you're far down the pecking order it is very hard to get any work done. There is little psycholgical safety because senior people recruit their friends. The performance management system is used as a stick.

headline: Very Demanding, work life balance suffers
pros: Great place to learn and grow. Opportunities to learn are many and awesome. You ca get exposure to different technologies and huge investments for learning. Nice tools and support for certifications and learning.
cons: Very Competitive, cut throat. Expected to put in long working hours and not easy to balance family and work. Compensation takes a hit with performance reviews which are very strict with impractical expectations. Not for people who want to spend time with family or take care of kids/adults.

headline: Management have their head in the sand
pros:
Used to be a great place to work; could still be with some honest introspection.
There are still some very talented technical associates.
cons:
Performance management and promotion nomination is extremely subjective and inconsistent.
Frequent staff turnover makes it difficult to get things done.
The superficial Fintech attitude and aspirations are doing more harm than good.
Capital One's good reputation is no longer deserved in mine and a few of my colleague's opinions.
Blame culture with simultaneous lack of accountability from management.
Insincere public messaging.
Poor work life balance.
Communication between different departments and teams is abysmal.
The job you applied for is not what you will be doing, ever.
Incentives, like training, never materialise.

headline: W/L balance dropped post-COVID
pros: I worked at Capital One for a number of years and loved my experience while I was there. If you worked hard and was motivated you could get promoted (or at least get a 5+% salary adjustment in non-promotion years). Bonuses were generous compared to other companies in the region. I went to the gym every day, took advantage of personal training and free career coaching, would often frequent the #freefood slack channel rooms to score free lunches, etc. It was a great experience aside from the standard petty office politics.
cons: The culture has gone down the drain post-COVID, especially with regards to work life balance, based on what my partner (still at Capital One) says. I asked my partner to take one day off of work to come with me to close on a house and he refused because taking a non-Friday off would be a red flag in his group. I then asked if he could take the Friday off to help move and he said that might also be a red flag. He also made it clear that based on the way his team functions, he's not planning to take more than 1 week of paternity leave next year because he doesn't want his team to use that against him in perf. I'm going to be honest, I don't even recognize this company anymore.
