headline: An alright place to be--but there are plenty of opportunities for improvement
pros:
-Pay is reasonable
-401k match is decent
-Management has generally been not overbearing/easy to work for and with
-Decent corporate culture
cons:
-Tuition reimbursement plan is pretty poor--seriously, Taco Bell pays up front and more per calendar year. Taco Bell.
-Management plays musical chairs every year leaving employees without a lot of direction until new management establishes goals and plans.
-Very evident that they take much advantage of the H1B Visa program to hire/underpay many foreign workers.
-Performance review process is poor, making managers fight for why their employee is better, and when added with musical management, I've had years where I've been reviewed by a manager I had for only two months of the previous year. Or have been reviewed by a manager who is no longer my manager--why would he fight for me?
-Benefits aren't anything special. 
-Raises are tiny when you are anywhere near the salary cap for your position. Salary cap isn't floated with cost of living.
-Social events (eg employee appreciate parties) are pretty poor. Related perks (eg they sponsor lots of stadiums) are pretty non-existent.
-Not lots of opportunities for promotion within.

headline: Supervisor- Customer Service rep

cons: Customer service is always a challenge

headline: Don't work here if you aren't of a certain background . . .
pros: They pay you money I guess
cons: I was a data analyst for about a year, but left as soon as I possibly could.  I'll just be upfront here - I'm a white woman, and this was a place for Indian men.  Almost my entire department was Indian.  Really set the culture of the place - I was supposed to be a super meek little woman, without opinions.  Racist (against white people) and sexist place - at least in the data analyst sphere.  Yikes - stay away!  This was such a shock - this was my second job and my previous company had been wonderfully supportive of women, so this was just so weird to me.   I was specifically told to hang back, not speak in meetings, not take initiative, etc.   When I had the experience, creativity, and intelligence to really make a difference.  Such a weird place, the data analyst environment.  A real blip on my resume - haven't had any other issues in my career, so I do think it's them, not me.

headline: Employ friendly

headline: Great Benefits, low job security
pros: Best benefits around.  401k match with automatic 3% employer contribution.  Medical, dental, vision benefits are amazing with low premiums and high coverage.  FSA match.  Amazing PTO package and paid maternity leave (5 months) also best paid parental leave (father leave or secondary parent leave) around (8 weeks).  Adoption costs reimbursement (10k).  Relaxed work environment and casual dress code.
cons:
In order to move up in the company you have to know the right people.  Cliques are they way of the land and if you're not in one, you will become the scapegoat and management will rate you at the bottom.

Forced ranking is horrible.  They want to encourage "thinking outside of the box" but not to the point of out shinning the favorite.  Projects that can help you rank higher are not awarded fairly, as usually the management's favorite or close friends usually end up with the projects.  There is no opportunity for process improvement and implementing new ideas in the work environment.  New and innovative thinking is not encouraged.  The old way of managing is still very present and is hard to change even with new managers coming in and attempting to change the old school ineffective ways.

Constant layoffs make it hard to trust in the CEO and upper management.

Excessive micromanagement that creates a peculiar type of "hostile" work environment where everyone senses that they are walking on eggshells.

There is the common practice of "Wage Downgrading" where there are job postings on various websites and, when applicants accept a considerable lower wage job offer, the permanent or contract employees are soon "let go" after they have trained the new contractors.  This is evidenced by a very high workforce turnover.

headline: Business manager

Pay is good as long as you get promoted frequently. The company takes its mission and culture seriously.

headline: Office politics - avoid judgmental underwriting department aka Highline Underwriting
pros: campus has a pond with  a fountain
cons:
1) infighting amongst senior management.  They clash publicly
2)  you are expected to choose a side. If you don't you will be bullied by all sides and their minions
3) objective criteria for performance measurement are a smokescreen. It all comes down to your loyalty to one or the other manager
4) a call center like environment ( capital one is new to the business card space). You will be able to tell based on the type of metrics used to judge performance. Primarily scorecard based risk assesment as opposed to a more sophisticated approach that considers client financials and industry
5) Antiquated technology, which is surprising for a company that prides itself on being ahead in tech
6) the type of work can easily be automated, so I don't see long term job security
7) You will be offered a job saying that there will be a test. What you may not be told is that the test will be at the end of a three month training period and will not be relevant to anything you will be doing in your job and will be entirely subjective. The only point will be to determine which senior managers you are allied to. The trainer will try to recruit you during training to one side. "Mentors" will come during the training session and try to recruit you to another side. The recruitment can begin even during the interview process. Some interviewers may actively discourage you from accepting a position using phrases like " you have such a great resume, I don't think you will like it here". Or "don't worry about this interview, it's the next one you should worry about"
8) asking modestly thought provoking questions will be deemed as acting pompous
9) expect politically incorrect/ borderline racist remarks or attitudes during training and beyond
10) if after " training" and after a very subjective "review board" and after being demoted from the position you were originally hired at, you find yourself sitting at a tiny desk facing the wall, start looking for other work because you haven't allied yourself with anyone that matters. You will find yourself being a pariah and no one will talk to you lest your toxic professionalism  and integrity rubs off on them
11) if at any time you think you want to go above and beyond your responsibilities. Please don't. No good deed goes unpunished. You will be either thought of as pompous or as a threat.

headline: If you are talented, be careful
pros:
Great people, great learning, great experience getting to your goals with a catch.  Has helped me wonderfully achieve many personal goals.  Great chance to “lead” others without authority. 

Great first company for anyone coming out of college. 

The people have great attitude and are kind.  The culture shock will be very positive after arrival. 

Workspaces are innovative and well designed.  Whiteboards galore depending on what building your at.
cons:
Managers are honest to the fault of being petty and the performance management system will weed out super performers and those with diversity (yes, me).  The funny thing is for the poor performance management system and poor bonuses (you most likely will not get what they tell you), it suffocates talent and we leave daily to better opportunities.  Yes, people grow, but for a company I love and would rather stay with, the bell-curved talent distribution doesn’t work.  Pay could also be about 20-30% higher for mid-career folks.  

Leadership is split between directors and above who play politics and make decisions slowly to senior managers and below who feel like they are on a ship without a captain.  

Promotions tend to go to like-minded people as disruption or a different way of working is frowned upon.  

Benefits have reduced over the last few months.  Not sure why when the company is handsomely profitable. 

Would I return?  Neutral, and I would consider based on updates made to manage talent and some of the items above.

headline: Smart people, competitive pay, good upward mobility
pros:
- Consistently worked with smart and capable people.  
- There's a pretty good amount of openness and transparency in general and leadership tends to include their teams in decisions.  -
 - Offer competitive pay, great benefits (cheap, high quality healthcare, 7.5% 401k match when you put in 6%, 15% discount on stock purchase up to 15% of your salary).  
- It's great to have a gym ($15/month) and primary care facility (for free) right at the headquarters.  
- They do a pretty good job promoting from within, especially at the junior and mid-senior levels (good upward mobility)
- Really nice facilities in general (bright, open, colorful, fun, good food)
- Focus on doing the right thing for customers instead of squeezing every dollar of profit out of the company
- Founder-led approach results in a focus on long term investment vs. just trying to hit investor goals
cons:
- Can be political (both corporate politics and insertion of national politics into the workplace).  From a corporate politics perspective, advancement can be highly dependent on who you work for and what projects you end up working on.  From a national politics perspective, with the HQ being just outside of DC, employees tend to lean pretty far to the left and are not shy about it.  Politics are discussed often and it's not uncommon to be asked questions like "who did you vote for?"  I've seen this result in favoritism based on whether or not you have the same beliefs.  Big no-no.
- Promotion of good do-ers into management positions.  There are way too many cases of people in management positions because they were good producers.  A good analyst rarely translates into a good manager.  
- Death by meeting - seriously - I would guess that at least 50% of meetings I was invited to were either completely unnecessary or very minimally applicable to me.
- Pains from rapid growth still exist.  Tons of separate systems.  External example: just look at the consumer product logins on the website.  It's been 5 years since the ING acquisition was completed and customers with a traditional Capital One checking or savings account still aren't integrated with the Capital One 360 products/services (formerly ING Direct)
- Major locations are generally in the suburbs so there aren't a lot of options if you want to walk to grab food, do a happy hour, etc.  Most things involve driving.  This is mitigated by them providing just about everything you need on campus but it sometimes you just want a change of scenery.
- Not many options for work locations unless you want to be in either Richmond, VA or McLean, VA.  Richmond is small and isolated and McLean has an insanely high cost of living and terrible traffic.
- Hard push for diversity recruitment sometimes results in great candidates being passed up to meet a quota 
- Performance management system is based much more on time at a certain level than actual performance.  For example, you pretty much have to move a mountain to get anything higher than a "strong" rating in the cycle following a promotion.  They do performance management on a bell curve, which means that for every person with a high rating there has to be a person with a low rating.  Isn't the goal to have every employee perform as highly as possible?

headline: Good people, poor management
pros: There are a ton of awesome and really smart people at Capital One. Generally there is good work life balance, if you like to coast and work 35-40 hours a week you'll be able to find a team to accommodate.
cons:
Management makes it really hard to get things done as a software engineer. There are seemingly endless hoops to jump through to meet compliance standards. Often times, the compliance standards aren't well thought out and are not flexible enough to meet the needs of the diverse set of applications being developed at the company. Every tech project essentially becomes waterfall as a result due to an insistence on project timelines, complicated compliance processes that become blockers and endless business justification for even small decisions.

Reorgs are frequent and political battles between senior management lead to major consequences for associates. Because of this, it can be hard to develop relationships with direct reports and managers.

My only other gripe is that performance management isn't an intelligent process. Essentially every team under a director is forced to rate their employees on a bell curve, the top x% get promotions and the bottom y% get bad reviews. This system incentives team members on good/productive teams to transfer to unproductive/poor teams if they want to get a promotion. You could have a team of rockstar engineers delivering awesome applications and only one will get a single promotion while another team that can't put a simple data pipeline together will get the same amount.

headline: Not the company they once were
pros: Good benefits, 401K, insurance, medical clinic and gym if you are at the West Creek location.  While the pay is pretty good - there are a lot of companies that actually pay better.
cons:
I have been here for 14 years and used to love it here but the culture has drastically changed in the last two years making it almost impossible to get anything accomplished because of out of control politics, egos and back stabbing.
1.  Although they talk about diversity, it is all lip service -  has rally become a "Boys Club" and biased against women, in particular on the tech side of the house.
2.  Performance management system is horrible and degrading.  The model is politically based and only rewards those working on the latest "shiny object" - fostering back stabbing and diminishing team work.
3.  Constant reorgs and restructuring is exhausting and disorienting, making it really difficult to really accomplish anything - I have averaged 3 reorgs a year since I have been here.
4.  Constant layoffs
5.  Unrealistic expectations with a "warm body" plug and play mentality - I am a Operations PM but due to re-org have been thrown onto a tech team and am now expected to instantly perform as a System / Data Analyst on a Software Engineering team with a system I have never worked with before - Although I am open to learning new skills, there is no training provided or even a direction for path forward from my almost non-existent manager - just a sink or swim kind of thing which just sets one up for failure.
5.  Although they talk about how collaborative they are - again it is all lip service.  Basically if you challenge or try to bring in a new perspective you are shut down - basically just do what you are told and act like you are thrilled about it.
6.  Also they like to say they offer "work life balance" and flexibility to work from home - honestly, although nobody would ever admit it, it is looked down upon - if you do you are punished for it in subtle ways - such as being first on the RIF list or come performance time - even if you do get all your work done and do a great job.
7.  People really are not all that nice or friendly - it is a survival of the fittest atmosphere, and with all the constant re-orgs and restructures it is hard to build lasting relationships.

headline: Great, but Diabolical
pros: Depending on what position/role you are in, the work/life balance is pretty good. There are people in pockets of the company that are truly trying to make positive changes in the company.
cons: Performance Evaluations are biased against women, introverts and anyone not working on whatever new shiny object they've decided is the next great thing. My position works closely with the tech division. Their management is insane. My development team had a new director assigned and suddenly everyone on the team was on a performance improvement plan. They were yelled at on a daily basis, told not to work from home or take sick days, forced to work ridiculous hours at a table about 2 feet from the director (so he could see that they were there). Micromanagement doesn't begin to describe the situation. No one here understands Agile, they just like to use the word. Then, there's the issue of 20 people that try and do the exact same job. It's frustrating.

headline: Highly Political and Agressive Culture
pros: The benefits were quite good (401k, vacation, low insurance premiums, etc).
cons:
I was with the company for several years, so I definitely had a good sense of the culture, processes, etc.  So many people there have aggressive, competitive attitudes, that teamwork really lacked.  Arguing and ego battles were fairly common, and everything always felt tense.

Because of the way the performance review process was structured, everyone was always running around trying to boss everyone else around.

If people had questions about the way you approached things, instead of talking to you, they just escalated to your management.  Likewise, you were criticized for the smallest things during performance reviews.

In order to  survive, you should be comfortable with negotiating difficult situations nearly all the time with high levels of energy.

headline: Director, Software Engineering
pros: The company has fully embraced a leading edge technology, open source, cloud, and software engineering culture.  The company makes bold, strategic decisions and initiatives powered by a technology first strategy.  Great facilities and better than average benefits.
cons: The performance management forced distribution system is archaic for a company that advertises being a high tech company.  It is the number one dis-satisfier year over year in the annual employee survey but the CIO and other tech executives keep burying their head in the sand and blaming managers for the survey results.  They have recently implemented a system where a pretty high percentage of technology staff have to be ranked in the bottom,  which is a death knell for anyone that lands in it.  They have also just raised their attrition targets significantly and are requiring their Managers to aggressively work people out to meet it.  The current tech employee morale is low and one of fear because of this and ongoing layoffs over the last few years in various parts of the business.  When added to the incredibly aggressive project goals leadership has declared, it is currently a very tough technology environment to be in.  Especially in technology management.  I know this flies in the face of the "Best Companies to Work For" awards Capital One gets but if you talk to most Tech managers you will hear what I have stated here.

headline: Hire and Fire, the Capital One Way
pros: Great benefits.  Great work-life balance once you have attained length of time.
cons:
This company offers great career roles but they do not scope them as permanent despite how they are advertised.
This company HIRES and FIRES (which they call redeployment for laying off numerous roles in bunches).
It is a part of Rich Fairbank's strategy: New and different business initiatives and practices each year.  When roles no longer fit in those new initiatives, they place you on 'redeployment'.  The company does not have a viable solution (Career Development Center) for retaining talent that may face redeployment.
Companies and roles change most certainly, but this is cut-throat.  In my 8 years at Capital One I have seen countless individuals placed on redeployment.  Great people, individuals with outstanding backgrounds, performances and skillsets.

The company does not make an initiative to retain this talent other than to say you are free to look for other roles within the company.

headline: Good opportunities to improve professionally - too much politics
pros:
Good learning opportunities - training and learning from the experience of Senior Developers and Framework teams
One all expense paid tech conference per year
cons:
Too much politics 
Senior Management, most of the time is not aware of what happens within the teams
Not always full credit is given to the work done by an associate - beware if you aren’t careful the other team mates could take credit of your work and the Team leads aren’t that keen to correct that 
Not that immigrant friendly environment - they do care about associates who would need sponsorship but beware you could be given a performance improvement plan and be fired from the organization without a valid reason even if your contributions to the team and the organization are tangible 
They care less about what the implications would be if they suddenly layoff a candidate on an immigrant visa, they don’t really understand the stress one has to go through in such a situation.

If you work in a team where you have a few TDP candidates(Technology Development Program, as they call in Capital One) beware that their feedback would count for or against you which would become the sole deciding factor to your performance analysis even if your contributions are great, their feedback would either boost or degrade your credibility all together in team(may be not maintaining an exceptional relationship with them - meaning never questioning the way they get their things done.)

They say that they are most flexible when coming to supporting their associates to work remotely if needed as per the situation they are facing - but that never truly happens - taking about 4 or less work from home days a month might cause you your job. Once in a while unexpected sick day to fall in the same bucket. These might turn out to be some lame reasons to get rid of you whenever they feel like it. Was accused of overusing the benefit for just the minimal use of it 


The senior management always mentions in their strategy sessions that they are in a mode to increase technology work force. But in reality they are forcing out the tech resources out in large numbers every two years and rehiring at the same pace which is totally making no sense whatsoever. I never understand why would they want to blame associates who contribute well enough to the team and organization, get rid of them and rehire a fresh batch of tech guys who basically would face a similar situation 2-3 years from now. I completely feel that not the best way for one to conduct his business


Very slow green card process
Senior management is never that employee friendly

They say they embrace open source a lot but what it takes to implement an open source solution is very time consuming tedious and approvals take very long and in return the blame comes on to the associates for not being able to accomplish something which is out of reach, the actual reason being lack of proper support model for the all the kind of applications which are being built in the organization.

The performance reviews and plans they dish out to the associates might not exactly pinpoint what they would need to do to improve as they usually would contain things that one might already be doing right except for a few time where he might have done a mistake

TDP associates dominate all the others 


Late night works, working on the weekend are all considered a waste by the team leads, never are that contributions counted properly atleast in my case for my performance review.

headline: Credit Card company in sheep's clothing

cons: They're clearly steering from human contact, they push credit cards relentlessly, they hire managers who are not only ill-equipped but also have lawsuits against them from other financial institutions. AR is a joke. They do not value their employees and flat out told me that if I didn't like the way my manager  treated me, I didnt have to work for Capital One. I worked for a branch that was closed and I was able to take my severance and move to a bank that values their employees.

headline: Retail banking - What’s in your wallet? - Nothing
pros: Great marketing. Customer come and walk in traffic is great. I love the mission and culture. A lot of focus on customer service. 30 min lunch is amazing and the continuous decrease in staffing is so wonderful.
cons:
Work life balance is horrible for retail. If you work in Mclean on your laptop it’s great, but when you are in the branch you have no idea. System outages like crazy. No career path for promotion. Teller can get promoted to uba. Uba to Bankers. And bankers will be bankers  for life. You go to a build your brand class and they say you are the cream of the crop. You apply for the next role and they say you don’t have enough experience. I am a banker for 5 years. I did mortgages until you took them away. I was successful in loans but now I have to call a 1800 for them to do my job. I am an expert in checking, Savings, and credit card....so is the capital one 360 website. 
Managers are all about coaching but cannot sell for the life of them. How can you coach me when you don’t do anything? Get managers who don’t sit in their office. Get a manager who is the best at selling and I will learn from them. I hate it when they just don’t tell me what to do like they know everything and don’t have any sales experience themselves. Pull a teller drawer once and a while. Digital solutions are so far behind but they claim to be Apple of Banking. Back office support needs to approve everything. We are not bankers...our role is to handoff our customer to another partner who drops the ball and the customer comes back to belittle us. Let bankers do Banker activities.

headline: Supplier Manager
pros:
Brilliant, ethical leadership; emphasis on doing the right thing; work/life balance commitment is strong; forward-looking innovation; uses fact-based decision-making; fail forward philosophy - okay to make mistakes, but must own resolutions.
Great benefits; they value continuous learning; open to internal job changes after you have a history of performance of course.
Great colleagues; positive atmosphere; generally no backstabbing
Flexibility on hours and locations (on-site workstation, flexible seating around campus, work from home if needed);
cons:
When business strategies changes there can be job realignments, redeployments, and/or separations.  Know it and be aware. Not particularly often but can be suddenly rolled out.  They are open with information about the strategy changes.
They still use a form of the old GE performance review process. It's part of the culture, but behind the times. Don't expect it to change easily.

headline: Good Company To Work For
pros: Company has great benefits and values.  Ability to work flexible hours for work/life balance.   Beautiful Plano campus with lots of amenities.
cons: As with any company, it depends upon your individual manager and how he/she upholds and lives the values of the company as to how your day-to-day job will be great or not.

headline: Toxic Creative Department
pros:
9-5
Good health benefits
4 mos maternity leave, tho they prorate and keep yearly bonus if you take the leave
cons:
-All white male leadership bro club atmosphere. Gave feedback to female creative directors like "perhaps if you smiled more and were more friendly to the (male) leadership team, you could be considered for promotion." 
-Had very abusive and toxic GCD in place, with over 50 complaints in HR - leadership did nothing about it. Protected him because it "made them look bad if they report someone to HR that they had put up for promotion".
-Had very toxic Director in place, lots of HR complaints, did nothing about it
-Women creatives of all levels are hired in lower than their level of expertise and have to fight for years to get menial promotions, and fend off feedback like "perhaps if you spoke less in meetings and took notes/smiled more/got a (male) mentor". Meanwhile, men were hired in at top roles, top pay, and promoted faster and more often.
-Performance mgmt was a popularity contest, not meant to set people up to succeed or learn
-Creatives who spoke up about the toxic culture and lack of diversity in the creative depts, were re-orged and managed out of jobs.
-Creative dept ultimately hired an outside consultant to come in and help with morale and issues - after report was issued and very serious charges logged, no changes made, all-male leadership still in place.

headline: Floor supervisor
pros: Best place to work !!!
cons: The company is great

headline: Unrealistic Expectations & Favoritism (Financial Services - Plano TX)
pros: Onsite gym, bikes to travel between buildings, good medical/dental/vision/401k benefits
cons: Compensation is low, associates do not have any autonomy or feel of inclusion, there are constant organizational changes, hard to get things done, constant layoffs (or "redeployments"), MAJOR favoritism of employees so if you are not on the "favorite list," you will not move ahead, no career growth opportunities especially now that they shut down the Mortgage business and moved their favorite associates into the Auto business, while firing some of the Auto associates to make room for their favorite Mortgage associates. Associate morale is low. They have unrealistic expectations for each level of the organization but yet do not provide appropriate coaching or development. Results don't necessarily matter but competencies do. Someone who has delivered a ton of work and earned multiple prestigious awards but has a few competency areas to work on can fall short during performance time. Everything is subjective.

headline: Review
pros: Good work place to work
cons: Too many lay offs and too many contractors

headline: Great entry level job
pros: Great benefits paid by employer. Great office environment. Great team of managers and amazing system always changing to keep up with industry
cons: No chance of advancement or extremely difficult to move up in company. You might Remain at same position for many years

headline: senior manager
pros: great benefits, great people, ever changing  work
cons: work life balance getting out of balance, losing sight of what made you a great places to work

headline: Mortgage Specialist 1
pros: Great work life balance .  Managers are wonderful . Love working with the company
cons: Just got laid off.  However I do have an interview .  Hopefully I get the job.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great benefits (7.5% 401k, cheap health care). Great work/life balance
cons: Shutting down businesses frequently, lots of layoffs

headline: Long hours low pay stress
pros: Health plan, 401k, set schedules, free lunches
cons: sales, extreme pressure, micro managing

headline: Not what it used to be
pros:
Nice working environment, although has declined 
On the face of it, relatively exciting business, but far too many poor decisions have been made of recent
Good work life balance, 9-5:30
cons:
Leadership team presence has declined and the engagement of associates has fallen
Morale fluctuates and leadership skim over the fact when it's poor
Talks about diversity but there is very little of it in the UK business
Strategy has slowed drastically and is very slow to get anything done
Extremely cliquey, some hard workers go years without promotion, others with a face that fits get promo quickly
There are managers in the business that do not deserve to be there

headline: Great place to learn and grow
pros: Flexible hours, competitive pay, great benefits
cons: People in management sometimes decide the fate of the technical aspects of the projects without knowing intricate details of the technology stack. Not very common but it still happens

headline: Exciting and fun if you like lots of change
pros: Exciting and fun environment.  Great coworkers and vision from the CEO.  Great severance packages.
cons: Be prepared to exchange that excitement and fun environment with lots of change for job security.  Lots of shifting as the company moves toward IT, data and API ownership in the banking realm brings lots of job cuts as departments are eliminated or moved in favor of more digital solutions.

headline: TEAM LEAD (SUBJECT MATTER EXPERT)
pros: I liked working at Capital One Bank , the location was perfect
cons: I was uncomfortable with the dress code

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Great community, location and benefits.  Design focused.  Large severance package when laid off.
cons: Some teams are amazing, others not so much.  My line of business was pretty disorganized and lacked product vision.

headline: Aspirational Tech Company, emphasis on aspirational
pros:
- work/life balance
- great benefits
- collaborative
- continuous learning encouraged including  role rotation 
- empowered to pursue new ideas at any level 
- trying to change the way things are done in banking
cons:
Gender-bias and a lack of diversity are pervasive issues (unless you are a white male), while this problem isn't specific to Capital One and a problem that plagues most of banking, don't expect to see diversity in roles higher than the Manager level.

There is no understanding of how to grow and develop Product Management talent. You're expected to make it up as you go, sounds great with lots of room to grow, until management decides what you've done isn't what they wanted and you'll find yourself seeking other opportunities. Depending who your manager and leadership chain are will determine if you were given any constructive feedback or an opportunity to take a different approach/adjust. 

Other quick thoughts:
- there are lots of great people at this company however your experience will vary greatly depending on your direct manager and leadership chain
- constant reorgs are exhausting and disorienting  
- consensus driven decision making makes it difficult to get thing done timely

headline: Growing Pains keep Capital One from being their best
pros: Great benefits, work-life balance and perks
cons: Lack of clear direction from leadership

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Large enough company that you can move around, find new roles and learn new things constantly
cons: Experience varies greatly depending on your direct manager and leadership chain

headline: 7 Years Together
pros: I truly enjoyed my time at Capital One. They hire great people and promote well internally. Resources is never an issue as long as you're in the right departments.
cons: Changes at Capital One happen ever other year and along with them layoffs. The culture/morale tends to become very cyclical with the highs coming on the off years.

headline: Great people
pros: Great culture and people, some of the smartest and most compassionate I've ever worked for.
cons: There is a focus on shiny objects and new and different, but the underlying structure is not stable enough to allow people to thrive. New talent, particularly at the Director and above level, often comes and goes quickly.

headline: Customer Service Coordinator
pros: The culture is great and diverse
cons: Capital one is always changings procedures and policies daily, you get new management every 6 months

headline: 401k is a scam. Cap One sucks
pros: None none none none none
cons: 401k is a scam read below

headline: call center
pros: pay, benefits, career opportunities, fun
cons: work-life balance is not the best. Scheduling is bad.

headline: Great for Ken and Barbie Types
pros: If you have a good manager and want to do well, you will flourish.  Lots of leading edge tech and a desire to cut through the red tape as banking is heavily regulated.  Good training opportunities and facilities are the best.  Work from home available depending on area.  Competitive pay, benefits.  Looks good on resume.
cons: Performance management walks everyone out the door sooner or later.  It's rare to find anyone who's a long term employee.  And they've hired a lot of Indian tech workers to do tech work who don't like to document or share, basically 2nd class workers (sounds familiar?).   Reorganizations that make no sense.

headline: Manager
pros: Great culture, amazing people - great place to work
cons: Long hours depending on job

headline: Banker
pros: Great benefits and amazing people to work with
cons: Work life balance  and constant change

headline: Uncertainty
pros: Capital One offers really decent benefits for their part-time workers. If you are lucky, you have a great team. Training is available. You are able to make change with your input. They are working to increase the pay.
cons: Many positions are going to be phased out, perhaps slowly but nonetheless still headed out. They removed many of the incentives and bonuses. Full Time positions are hard to come by They have also sold major departments  (Home Finance and the Brokerage) Technology is taking over, Many customers don't like being pushed to use new technology and harder to find actual people with all of the branch closures.

headline: Sweat Shop with Yearly Layoffs
pros: Atmosphere is great for kids straight out of college. Focus on healthy living (onsite gym,  ride bikes between buildings),  lots of restaurants on campuses, great health benefits, onsite pharmacy, visually pleasing campuses, relaxed dress, flex start time.  Genuinely great coworkers.  Capital One University Training courses available for workers to further themselves online.  Always learning bleeding edge new technologies and developing market first technologies.  Small consistent raises and yearly bonuses paid for employees that manage to avoid the layoffs that occur each year.  Flexible work locations.  After hours employee gatherings / parties (when you travel to an alternate location),  and semi annual team outings.
cons: Using agile project methodologies, you are constantly having to document what was completed yesterday, what you plan to complete today, and what you plan to complete tomorrow in daily standup .   Tell the employees what you want done, when you want it done by, and empower them to make the right decisions to get it done by the deadline you specified.   Quit focusing on delivering the next shiny new bell,  demoing a new application at the next south by southwest convention, and focus instead on delivering applications that change banking for good like credit cards for customers that have an lcd with a dynamiclly generated secure account number,  and the ability to dynamically do everything i can do in a physical bank on my mobile phone.     The performance management cycle is the absolute worst thing about this company, hands down.  They hire 10 to 15 new employees in each area monthly and then turn around at the end of year and eliminate 10 to 15% of their workforce in each department based on a performance based measurement system that puts everyone on a bell curve.  It creates an environment where folks are constantly playing dodge the whack a mole by moving between departments.    Employees are often working 11 hours a day every day (55 hours a week) to deliver on projects related to a race to be on the bleeding edge of tech (migrating all applications to the cloud, consolidating banking applications related to ing bank purchas and purchase of hsbc credit card company.    Because the high volume of work never ends, employees are beginning to feel like they work in a sweat shop and that they are in a lottery where its just a matter of time before they become part of the 10 to 15% workforce cuts that occur yearly.

headline: Sr Ops Production Coordinator
pros: great benefits, generous amount of PTO, awesome perks, very flexible
cons: frequent mas job eliminations, hard to move around, it was more of who you knew.

Benefits
Growth Opportunity
Culture
The Best Coworkers - they only hire the best

headline: Average Job

It is also a very gossipy/high school environment. The "work/life balance" has gone out the window.

The benefit package is Rolls Royce, upper management actually cares deeply about the employees.  I’m Republican and the company more Progressive/Democratic but is actually to the benefit of the employees.

headline: VM Team - Very Hostile work Environment

cons: There was one manager in Plano, TX that was TERRIBLE. He was a new manager who believed the rules did not apply to him and who divided the team by having his personal favorites. This created a divided team that backstabbed each other at every opportunity. It was a very hostile work environment to say the least and you did not know who you could actually trust.

Lots of disarray and many employees, especially at higher levels, are very overworked. The performance management cycle is the absolute worst thing about this company, hands down.

headline: Most screwed up place I've ever worked
pros: Good pay and benefits - 7.5% contribution to 401k to your 6%.  $1,000 company contribution to your flex spending account for dependent care or health care.  Reasonable rates for medical.  If it weren't for the strong pay and benefits, I wouldn't have stuck around even a year.
cons: Horrible business processes and systems.  Constant reorganization and restructuring.  No one is willing to step up and make a decision on anything - it's impossible to get things done.  Horrible bonus determination methods - lots of favoritism, and lots of times performance ratings are assigned by someone with almost no knowledge of whom they're rating.

headline: Outdated Performance Management System
pros: Great benefits. Decent starting pay. Onsite Be Well clinic is free to employees and their immediate family members. Love Dr On Demand - Free video visits with a physician.
cons: Low pay raises. Forced Distribution / Stacked Ranking Performance Management method is outdated and drives a “dog eat dog” culture. It’s every man for himself with focus on stepping on who you have to .... to prevent from being forced in a lower ranking that is not truly reflective of your actual contributions to the business.  Greater of the Greats culture with the lesser of the greats being forced in a low rating up to Inconsistent to meet distribution in Exceptional / Strong / Inconsistent. Simply demotivating and a slap in the face when your efforts are not recognized or adequately compensated at the end of the year.  This is worst at non-frontline and management level roles. The CEO truly can’t be aware just how bad this method is...

headline: Change is good, but...
pros: Work life balance.  Access to new/exciting technology.  Opportunities for growth.

headline: A place to collect your paycheck
pros:
Freedom to do whatever you want, including simply coasting. There’s generally very little accountability in tech across the company. This is good if you’re a self taught learner and want room to grow on your own.

Great place to give back to the community through outreach programs.

You can retire here
cons:
Visuals and Politics dictate your career here. 

Many “engineers” plagiarize others’ work, but because the chain of command has no way to judge people or their accomplishments, these people are quickly promoted and then leave before they’re discovered. A lot of headlining projects are just a front used to grab promotions and leave. Due to this problem, many projects are believed to have failed from lack of maintenance, when in reality there was nothing there in the first place.

A culture of “niceness” discourages honesty and leads to honest talented people being alienated. Many have recently left, yet HR and leadership are unaware of this brain drain because they use inflated internal evaluations to analyze retention. This culture and its intolerance to criticism also leads to simple projects taking 3 years to reach production rather than 2 months because people who actually know what they’re doing either don’t speak up or are simply ignored as just serial complainers.

headline: Work/Life Balance with Challenging Work!
pros:
- The work/life balance at Capital One is unbeatable. Excluding software engineers, I don't think you could make the same $/hour anywhere else early in your career.
- You drive how much responsibility you're given. If you want to take on extra projects and expand the scope of your role, you're generally given the freedom to do so - just ask! The time and effort dedicated to your professional development is incredible.
- You're surrounded by very smart and very friendly folks at Capital One. HR does a great job of hiring personable people who have the raw brain power to get up to speed fast.
- While it's a bank, Capital One really does focus on maintaining a high standard of ethical behavior. They do everything possible to help customers pay their bills on time and to make the customers' lives easier.
- Leadership takes the time to explain our strategic priorities regularly and thoroughly.
- While the promotion system requires a little bit of politicking at higher levels, it's overall well-done and fairly executed.
cons: - The biggest con applies to the entire industry: it's hard to get excited about financial services. Staying motivated can be hard when you're not passionate about what you do, and many people find it difficult to be passionate about banking.

headline: Capital One Investing
pros: Excellent benefits including  100% mass transit subsidy,  7 1/2% 401k match and gym membership.   Good upward mobility provided you take the initiative to make your career goals known  and you of course remain in good standing in your current role.   For a financial firm, they readily embraced new technologies so your skills stayed relevant and things stayed interesting.
cons:
I have witnessed an associate's attempt to move between departments thwarted due to the existing manager's negative comments.  I understand the importance of a manager's feedback but in this case I felt the negativity was more personal then professional.  
I worked in the Seattle office which was a small division and it was easy to feel a bit alienated from the much larger campuses where the major decisions were made.

headline: Customer service
pros: Great Company and I love it.
cons: I have no comments thank you.

headline: Tech + Finance
pros: With the current focus, if you have a love for both finance and tech, then this is the place for you.  The old school Wall Street personality doesn't fit in here.  You will be rewarded if you are able to develop change in the company.  If you are more of an entrepreneur and have foresight to see how to transform ideas into reality, and can visualize and communicate steps along the way, then you will be successful here. The majority of associates  here are very open to sharing their expertise to help you along the way.  If you're not open to teaching or learning from others, regardless of your years of experience, then this is not the place for you.
cons:
You really need to self promote here and be a 
Self starter.  If you want something done, you have to do the majority of the work yourself until you can gain momentum. It is a very risk averse company, so you will need to jump through a lot of hoops and beurcracy to make your ideas a reality.

headline: Manager
pros: Most of the employees are genuinely intelligent, engaged in the work,  and committed to doing what is right for the customer.
cons: The agile approach feels forced for the non-tech teams but at least they are flexible by allowing the agile process to be somewhat customized by department.

headline: Great Place to work Overall
pros: Pay well, provide training opportunities, opportunity for advancement.
cons: No company is perfect. There are some managers who are too political, have a top down style, and seem to be concerned with their next move rather than the good of all. My overall experience has been great but in every large organization there are some people you don't want to work for.

headline: Closed LOB
pros: Good culture, great facilities, competitive pay.
cons: Shortly after I was hired a hiring freeze was put in place which caused loan specialists to be overworked. Some process management issues preventing loan process from proceeding smoothly for both loan specialists and customers.

headline: Pretty Campus, Poor Exec Leadership, Performance Mgmt system a joke
pros: Benefits are nice, campus is pretty
cons: Can't call yourself a progressive company, and retain a rank and yank performance management system from 3 decades ago.

headline: Loved the job, but got laid off
pros: I really loved working at Capital One. The campus in Plano is great, and I liked getting plugged into a network of talented people from around the country. I was given a lot of authority and autonomy to shape content strategy for my line of business, and it helped me experiment and grow into new areas of that role.
cons:
There's a weird culture thing between full-time employees (FTEs) and contractors. Many people start as contractors and get moved to FTE after a while. While I was a contractor, though, I had many meetings where someone would say "this next part only applies to FTEs", and then we'd sit around as people talked around us.

For the most part, it isn't a big deal, but after a long time I started to feel like a second-class citizen. There's a two-year limit on contractors - if you don't get moved to FTE after two years, you have to leave for 90 days and re-apply for your job. After I'd been in my position for 18 months, I had to start job searching because no one would commit to bringing me on permanently.

I got laid off in November, and it was really a bummer. Eliminating 950 jobs and cutting an entire line of business after only two years in operation doesn't say good things about the company's long-term strategy and planning.

Also: applying directly to an FTE job or moving from one part of the company to another to become an FTE sometimes involves a weird, unnecessary standardized test full of personality, logic, and advanced math questions. I'm a writer, and I flunked the math portion pretty hard and got turned down by two FTE positions exactly similar to the job I'd already been doing for 18 months. Three months later, those positions are still listed as unfilled online. This unfortunate testing policy kept that role vacant and turned away a qualified applicant, and I heard the same thing from many of my co-workers.

headline: Great company to grow you career
pros: It is extremely difficult to get into Capital One but when you do there are few barriers to entry across different job families.  If you are smart, can problem solve and deliver results you can be successful across multiple job families.  They are not afraid to give you big opportunities and projects just be prepared that you need to then step up and deliver.  While not a ton of formal training you will be exposed to a variety of tools and techniques in everyday work that will be beneficial to you both at Capital One and at any company you work for in the future.
cons: Org changes and leadership changes are frequent and while lower levels are insulated from the changes the higher you are the more disruptive the changes.  The company is full of talented individuals who inherently think they have a better way which leads to big changes from leader to leader most of the time.  Perception of promotions is that they are slow unless you are on the big project with the highly influential leader and then things tend to move much quicker.  I do think the company does a good job of identifying top talent for promotions but that leaves those not in the top 5-10% frustrated with the process.  Leverage your top talents and find a senior advocate and you will do great.

headline: Great Company overall, tough year end review
pros: Working in IT -- all my colleagues & managers are very bright, nice, and a pleasure to work with. There are endless company sponsored trainings that management highly encourages us to take. We are provided with all the top end resources and technology for IT & software development.
cons: The number 1 complaint across the board by all employees is the year end employee review process. Most companies, you are graded based on your individual performance alone. Here, you are placed into a pool of people of your employee level (Associate, Senior Associate, Manager, etc.), and then senior management has meetings ranking all the people in the pool. People who do good work, sometimes end up low in a ranking which seems unfair and is why so many people complain. The higher your rank, the higher your bonus.

headline: Treat you well for now!! Beware the upcoming year!
pros:
Great benefits. Pay is ok. Great work/life balance. PTO is great. Coworkers are awesome. 


Good severance package. Certain managers are great!
cons:
The have slowly stripped away all ways to make commission or a bonus. They blame Wells Fargo but it’s just them cost cutting again to show profits so our Now Billionaire CEO. They have closed over 10 branches in my territory alone his past year. And mine is scheduled to close this year.  This after they have gotten rid of the entire home lending department so we no longer do Home lending. Never heard of a bank that only does accounts and credit cards. 

In my opinion they are getting ready to sell of the retail banking side and focus on just online banking. Sad because a lot of very good people are losing their jobs. All to save money for the bottom line (when ceo is paid in stock options this is what you get)

headline: Sounded like a good idea at the time.
pros: Work life balance. Flexibility to work from home. 401K match. Potential for significant salary increases at EOY based on Board of Directors.
cons: No transparency from changing leadership. Performance management is entirely contingent on your direct manager so if they are inexperienced or lack leadership skills, consider yourself screwed. Based on the rating system, associates are self interested and will withhold information from teammates in order to make themselves look good. The company claims they are diverse but they spend an insane amount of money sending leadership to classes and when they come back nothing has changed. Difficult to move departments because there are so many layoffs. No incentive to go above and beyond because there is no recognition unless you beg for it. Misogynistic attitude from the top down. The higher level associate, the greater chance of them acting like you don’t exist. If you are a head-down, get things done kind of a person, this is not the place for you.

These are the same people that are pushing down the change-makers and problem solvers in avoidance of losing their jobs. They lack strategic skills and vision in their respective areas of expertise and are not up-to-date with current trends.

headline: Loss Mitigation
pros: Great moral and fun work environment. Like a large family. Excellent PTO and benefits. If you work hard you can really propel your career here. Would definitively recommend as a great place to work.

headline: Delivery focussed, but still a little rough around the edges.
pros:
A very people oriented culture, actively work in a collaborative fashion.
Your experience particularly from the outside is valued.
A solid set of values set on improving customer experience, improving controls and being well managed. This is evident in some of the improvement activities which are being performed.
Some very interesting perks , a gym, a great canteen.
Commitment to improvement.
cons:
Can be a bit hit and miss dependant on the department you work for.  Those departments which can deliver revenue growth are seen as sexy, whereas as those areas tasked with loss mitigation can be a far tougher environment and have lower employee engagement.

In some areas it is still target driven, which is positive in terms of focus, but the mindset in some areas is not necessarily about doing right just getting an outcome and can be highly competitive. This does lead in some cases to games at associate level to try the teflon approach to divert blame which can be counter productive to good teamwork.  
The tactical approach is very evident and as a result can create additional unnecessary work. 
Whilst it is evident that there has been investment in systems to assist employees these are not necessarily optimised.

headline: Overall it was a great company to work for. I learned a lot in my 12 years there.
pros: Career growth, PTO, lots of engagement and fun. Huge on diversity and community outreach programs. I also utilized the tuition reimbursement.
cons:
They have an insane rating system that affects every aspect of your career. It’s the only company I know that no matter how well you do your job, if the external customer doesn’t audibly voice their pleasure, you get rated as a neutral or worse a detractor. No matter how wonderful you did, if the customer isn’t clear with their approval, it will count against you. Even in positions with no customer involvement, you’re rated as a neutral. It’s that way across the board. 
Also it’s extremely political. 90% of all internal interviews are just formalities. They know who they want ahead of time. 
Actively seek out feedback. Otherwise, you’ll never grow with the company.

headline: New Executive; The Pluses of A Large Bank With The Agility & Talent of A Growth/Tech Co.

cons: Too early to have witnessed any but the methodical interview process can certainly weed out those who are impatient and be taxing while one is in an existing role at a different company. Applicants need to really appreciate that the lengthy process with numerous rounds of interviews is deliberate to ensure proper fit and consistency of talent while also offering the candidate exposure to a number of the company’s employees in different departments.

cons: Re-org’s happen a lot. One minute you have a smart, nurturing supervisor that helps you build your career while praising you for your amazing work. And the next minute you have a back stabbing, ladder climbing, bully of a boss that manages by fear and intimidation and you’re wondering if you went to sleep and woke up in the midst of a bad dream because you’re certain that two days ago you were given an excellent review by a Sr Executive and today you’re being told that your work is horrible, you shouldn’t talk in front of superiors anymore, you require special treatment and you should think about your future here, all by a new boss that’s clearly intimidated by smart people and ready to re-org you out of the company because they can to save their own job.

headline: Good Benefits and Culture, but needs strong and consistent leadership
pros: The Company has a great overall culture. The top executives look to keep associates engaged. The work-life balance and laid back environment are different from most financial institutions. There is a reason it is a consistently a Top 100 place to work.  It earns the title.
cons: Certain groups within Capital One are steady (Card, Commercial, National Expansion), but the banking group is in constant flux. Leadership takes the roles to move on, never to build. There is constant shuffling as a result. It is best to take an exempt position or a role in National Expansion. Non-exempt roles are subject to too many vanishing goals. If you take a role in the contact center, fight for stability and change. There is a bevy of potential with just a little consistency and innovation.

headline: Dishonest Management and lots of lies and betrayals
pros:
A few great Co-Workers (others just stab you in the back)
Some great technologies you can learn for a short-term
cons:
1. Lots of Stress
2. No work/life balance
3. You should be your manager's pet!!!
4. Lots of talk about company's culture but nothing in fact, what you hear is not true and what management ask you to do you should NOT do (such as be vocal, do the right thing, speak up and etc...)
5. Lots of betrayals,  in fact, Capital One encourages this kind of behavior
6. Performance reviews are done based on your commit's amount! (lots of experienced people, are overusing this by creating a huge amount of fake commits and contributions)
7. Support for other OS's such as Linux or windows is a lie, only OSX is supported for development
8. Huge dependency on US team, most of the time you can't even contribute, change or deploy codes without US's approvals
9. Lots of delays in review processes from the US side
10. Management has their own favorite people in teams and they lesson only to them while they are talking about the flat team structure
11. There is a huge difference between Senior and Principal Rule and Capital One’s HR team can trick you with it - don't fall into this, renegotiate your salary if they change your title just before your start date, and expect that leads will expect a lot more from you when you are a "Principal" (And don’t expect that someone will explain this to you on the first day)
12. Lots of micromanagement - they count your breaks and they ask you to take fewer breaks - but at the same time, they expect you to be on call 24/7!
13. Canada's Software studio tend to follow the US almost everywhere, lots of in-house frameworks(built in the US) on top of famous frameworks which prevent you from gaining some fundamental knowledge

headline: Good foundation but need to weed out bad managers

headline: When I thought it couldn't get worse...
pros: Some of my co-workers are competent and I enjoy socializing with them. I don't dislike showing up to the office because of it.
cons:
Wow, where do I begin?

In the last few months, entire divisions of the company have been laid off. My office is going to be shut down tomorrow, and this was all planned while our VPs kept telling us with a straight face that they were committed to tech and our location.

These are some of the most two-faced people I have ever met and it's completely clear to me that Capital One doesn't really consider itself as a tech company. 

A very large majority of the programmers in this company are very bad. Job titles like "senior software engineer" and "master software engineer" are given to people who can't code, communicate, or collaborate in any way at all.

At the same time, I get push back from my leadership team saying that promotions need to be based on merit and accomplishments. I point directly to engineers both within my LOB and across the company who have been promoted and ask what I'm lacking that they have. I never receive an answer.

This company's stupid desire to have "product owners" who oversee one single feature in a project is baffling. My product owners are all on the east coast and we only interact with them on Slack and over the phone.

It really feels like a company that hired too many B-players years ago who continued to hire the bottom of the barrel with C- and D-level employees and have no desire to actually do any real, good work.

Don't come to Capital One if you're looking to learn or grow. If you want to circlejerk all day to acting corporate, you'll feel right at home.

headline: Data Analyst

In love with the company and benefits, not in love with my role. Unfortunately, I will push to move from being a Business analyst to a data analyst and if this push doesn't happen, then i'll be leaving the company.
cons: More power within the Business Analyst Community than the Data Analyst community. Business Analysts have more exposure to higher ups (i.e. VPs) and are higher in the unofficial hierarchy amongst job families, also it seems that currently as capital one is laying off people, they are pushing to retain business analysts much more than data analysts.

headline: Good Company but losing Strategic Vision
pros: The company is very laid back generally speaking and strives on trying to keep you happy.  Great PTO ( 5 weeks after 5 years non-exempt/ 4 weeks exempt)  Salary is good if you negotiate correctly coming in.
cons: The whole strategy with Mortgage Banking has been a complete failure due to not hiring the best and most experienced talent. Also not listening to experienced professionals and overspending from the reincarnation in 2009 caused this as well.  Capital One's claim is they are a digital company but this does not translate to many lines of business i.e.,  mortgage banking and even Small Business for that matter. Many processes are still very paper driven and disorganized even after spending millions of dollars on systems that didn't work. Unfortunately,  President of Financial Services Sanjiv Yajnik has a lot of blame for this mortgage division collapse. Leadership changes and remapping of strategic goals should have occurred years before.  A one fits all approach doesn't work in every business.  I do hope with a possible liquidation and  selloff of certain lines of business to a forward thinking company will help Capital One refocus on the markets it strives in.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Not too many...401(k) match is nice.  National Capital One Investing program is striving to make it a formal program with focus on holistic financial planning.
cons: Local management in New York City region.  Local managers treat program like a boiler room.  Name recognition is not a plus.  Prospects and bank customers accustomed to Capital One as a credit card company.  Very difficult to get clients to take you seriously enough to get all their assets.  Heavy favoritism on the part of local management whose cronies/favorites are inexperienced advisors.  Favorites who are grandfathered into company get and keep all clients except those with little to no opportunity (i.e. don’t live in area).  Constant churning and wrong recommendations from less-experienced advisors who only focus on assets they see at the bank (as opposed to considering/profiling for outside assets and full financial planning) and happen to be the favorites so they can pad their numbers.  Clients mysteriously move from your book to theirs.  Exact opposite of what National Investment program is saying/trying to do in a fiduciary capacity.  New advisors in program are treated like they are in a wirehouse program.  If so, why work at Capital One?  Work at a real wirehouse with some name recognition.

headline: Forced Distribution, Poor work/life balance
pros: I am a 15 year IT associate at Capital One in Richmond.  The Pros of working for this company include decent pay, good benefits and, recently, exposure to current technologies.  The best benefit of working at Capital One is the fairly generous vacation package; I receive 4 weeks of vacation with the option to buy an additional week for a small price.
cons:
My recent experiences (last 3 years) in Capital One IT have been very unpleasant.  Firstly, the culture at Capital One is competitive, nervous and fearful.  The primary reason for the horrible atmosphere is the Forced Distribution performance management practice.  Capita One shoe horns associates into performance ratings with 15-20% receiving bad rating.  As you might imagine in a corporate setting as this the decisions on who receives what rating is highly political.  While I have never received a bad rating in 15 years I rarely am acknowledged for the excellent work I produce and have only received above average ratings in years where I expressed displeasure in previous ratings.

So courtesy of the horrible performance management practices, what you end up with is a group of nervous, scared associates who are afraid of receiving bad ratings or perhaps even losing their jobs.  The response to that by many associates is to work over 60 hour work weeks and rarely take vacation out of fear.  Most associates fall into this category.  I'm always saddened to see fellow associates needlessly work long hours and send emails around midnight out of fear.  It's really sad and super commonplace.
 
The culture is horrible.  Plus, the fear of layoffs is never far away.

Management at Capital One is horrendous.  The typical Capital One middle manager is compromised, scared and a sellout.  These poor folks sit together in conference rooms two times a year "cross calibrating" their associates in an effort to determine who gets screwed with a bad rating.  It is awful.  Capital One has a ton of strong associates; only about 5% in IT are truly bad so these managers try to convince each other and their associates (keeping in mind the 15-20% bad rating forced distribution) that somehow Associate A who is a great worker and nice person should be told they suck for the year.

There is NO work life balance in Capital One IT.  It is not because there is so much work; it is because there is so much fear.  A truly horrendous place to work.

headline: Capital One

headline: NYC 114
pros:
It's a great company to be at. Overall, there's an amazing culture going on, especially in the DC/Richmond/Chicago offices. 

Ample snack, good selection of drinks, video games in the office, and most of what you can ask for at a tech company. 

Company is very well funded – if you work under their customer facing lines of businesses. 

Great pay to stay and collect a paycheck.
cons:
Too much bureaucracy for anything to get done.  

The culture is dying. The quality of new hires coming in are very low. Capital One  can't attract good talent and beginning to "settle" on the remaining applicants. You're not going to attract talent if you under pay your new hires. People are leaving / talking about leaving. Value your design and engineering talent. They're the ones who will bring Capital One to become the tech company it so desires to be. 

Work culture is very dependent on your team / manager. The NYC 114 culture is dead. Long hours plague many teams. It feels like a marketing agency.

If I come back into the office at 8pm because I forgot my keys, and there is an entire team of designers/engineers still in the office on a Friday night, there is a problem. 

If someone is in the office on a holiday, and I'm there to notice that person, there is a problem. 

Too much legacy code. Too many old guys trying to hold onto their jobs. 

It's a dead end for those just starting their careers.
