headline: Good work/life balance, aspiration culture, bogged down by politics and process
pros: Employee friendly workplace, work/life balance is excellent.
cons: Performance review based on networking rather than actual job performance, unclear prospects for promotion

headline: Capital One
pros:
Most of the job opportunities are in Virginia where the corporate office is located.

There is a commitment to volunteerism.
cons:
Capital One’s technology is years behind other Commercial Banks.

The branch network in the Northeast is made up of former Chase & Bank of America Associates creating a culture of nepotism.

It is a Credit Card Bank, the Retail Bank is an after thought.

Hundreds of branches have been closed with more on the way.

headline: Cap One review
pros: Capital One offers its associates several tools for career development
cons: Few job opportunities outside of main campuses

headline: Loved working here
pros: Great benefits, automatically gets 2 weeks vacation in the first yr.
cons: Quotas, was pushy about selling products, I believe they no longer have this though.

headline: Manager
pros: Capital one provided great training to employees at all levels including both technical and soft skills.
cons: The pay was not as competitive as other banks

headline: funding specialist
pros: good company good benefits good pay
cons: long drive -longer hours

headline: Great Place to Work in Info Tech.
pros: Capital One really cares about all of it's associates. There are a ton of incentives and associate intramural activities. You can expect several social events and also community volunteer events. They are flexible on hours which helps with the life work balance. I've never worked for a place with better management. This place is amazing!!
cons: My only Con of Capital One is that it's a far drive for me.... but that's my problem. Capital One is also always in a constant state of change. It's not a con from me, but some people don't sit well with constant change. If you like constant routine, this probably isn't the place for you.

headline: Analyst
pros: Great, nothing bad to say at all
cons: None that I can think off. Real positive company

headline: Highly recommended
pros:
Willingness to explore new and upcoming technologies
Caring and invested in employees
cons: None severe comes to mind

headline: Customer Service
pros: Great training and benefits package
cons: Company is great to work for but several instances of delay in pay check

headline: Possible Agism
pros: Great Salary, benefits, and generally the people.  I had great team members.
cons: Good luck with longevity.

headline: Needs managers capable of leading to founder's vision.
pros: Work force consists are bright, capable and motivated professionals. Comp/benes very competitive. Encourage good work/life balance.
cons: Lacks direction and well thought out plan for future direction. Periodically develop great new plan to go forward, shortly after change their minds.  Change is constant but never results in a "net gain."

headline: Information Security Specialist
pros: Relaxed atmosphere, but with clearly defined goals and objectives.
cons: Not enough sharing of relevant information about general activities in the company.

headline: Large Layoffs (likely to continue)
pros: Decent severance packages, good work cafeteria.
cons: Company is laying off ~400 employees a month (analysts, tech, etc). Probably spreading it out to avoid press.

headline: customer service cordinator
pros: good benefits, 401k, people are very friendly
cons: the systems could be updated, very outdated

headline: It's Alright
pros: Great benefits and work locations
cons: Not compensated well, work/life balance is hectic....

headline: Great Foward Thinking Company
pros: Committed to hire the best talent
cons: Capital One invests in its associates through great recruitment process and once hired, provides extensive training to associates.  However, due to competitive markets, these talents often will leave for better benefits and pay.

headline: A great company to work for
pros: Great people to work with.  A great company to work for.  Very good benefits
cons: The review process is rather competitive

headline: Great Benefits, Family Environment Feel, and Culture Driven
pros: I truly feels like we are a family here at Capital One. You walk the hallways and almost everyone knows everyone. The benefits are some of the best I've ever seen. Capital One truly cares about their employees and building them up.
cons: The contact center does work Holidays, however, the pay is very good if you do work!

headline: Must Work here!
pros:
Very encouraging 
Understanding 
Supporting 
Flexible
cons:
Nothing much 
Prior notice before projects ends, should be clear

headline: CapOne 360 (Former INGD) marketing dept
pros: Very intelligent people in the marketing department
cons: A culture that doesn't look out for the well-being of their customers. The office culture was not welcoming.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Great work environment, benefits, and salary.
cons: Not much to say here. It's a great company.

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
* A really experienced technical leadership team who have made some good tech choices
* High standards across Software Engineering
* Agile working practices and a good appreciation of tech across the organisation
* Innovation is encouraged
* Superb office environment - gym, great subsidized canteen
* Great benefits
cons: * Some communication issues between Nottingham and London sites, but this is getting much better

headline: poor work life balance
pros:
good company name for resume. 
lots of career enhancement opportunities through capital one university
cons: very poor work life balance. taking a lunch is frowned upon, and working late at night is expected.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Tuition Reimbursement and pto of 160 hrs
cons: I do not have any bad experience so far

headline: A great place to learn and grow
pros:
The cloud journey is new to a lot of people within Capital One which gives everyone a real opportunity to influence the direction of the company and the services being developed.  This also leads into an environment in which personal learning and growth are positively encouraged, meaning there is a constant expectation that not only should you be growing as a Capital One employee, but as a individual as well.

The offices are great, London especially is a brand new custom designed office, though the diagonal desk move in Nottingham take a bit of getting used to.  Nottingham also provides a free gym and subsidised cafeteria and the food isn't half bad!

There is a real diversity of people within the office, some of who are experts in cloud technologies, some are experts in platform specific development etc. which leads to a good collection of people working towards a common goal without a prescribed approach.
cons:
There does seems to be a clash between the Capital One culture in (old) Nottingham and the culture developing in (new) London.  This does seem to be seeping into Nottingham slightly, which is showing itself in how things like performance reviews and progression are being managed.

The vast majority of the Software Engineering senior management team (Director level) are in London where-as the majority of the Software Engineers are in Nottingham, again leading to a split in how some teams are managed and developed.

headline: Awesome place to work!
pros: A true fin-tech company with a cloud transformation well underway, great culture and investment in the future.
cons: Not much on site parking

headline: Senior Associate
pros: Flexibility if you are on the right teams
cons: Too many changes too fast, not everyone in company fully understands or has resources to implement

headline: Good company, great benefits!
pros: A company that will look after you and listens to all its people
cons: Process can feel very slow and frustrating however this is because of the highly regulated financial industry it is in.

headline: Working with great people
pros: Everyone at Capital One is so welcoming and friendly. You can approach anyone with a question and they will always try to help either themselves or point you in the right direction, I just love that everyone supports each other.
cons: The on-site gym and classes are brilliant to give you a pick me up during the day, the down side is the guilt you feel when you don’t go!

headline: Great benefits - poor progression process
pros: The benefits of working her are great. There's a great Work/Life balance. Salary is average but it's topped up with a great package such as Life Insurance, Health Insurance (plus family!), Travel to Work schemes, Subsidised restaurant (Notts only),  free Tea and Coffee and a good amount of holidays. The pension is also unbeatable!
cons:
You may find it hard to progress if you don't 'Play the game'. The people who discuss your progress could have absolutely no interest or scope of your work, so you can get stuck at a position for years despite working above and beyond your role.

The benefit package is so good that you'll struggle to find a suitable paying job elsewhere.

headline: Risk coordinator
pros: Benefits and stock purchase plans
cons: Not enough hourly pay

headline: It could be better
pros: Good PTO and campus amenities
cons: Too many company politics, behind on technology, no equal pay transparency and very low pay compared to the industry

headline: Fantastic company culture
pros:
Excellent commitment to training and development
Great opportunities and projects to get involved with
Amazing and varied benefits scheme
Good work life balance
cons:
High pressured working environment
Sometimes feels quite hierarchical

headline: Good company to work!
pros: Amazing work place. Great benefits.
cons: For quality engineering roles package is little less than software engineers.

headline: TELLER MANAGER
pros: Great vacation time after 3 months of employment.
cons: Too much pressure from management to meet sale  and customer satisfaction goals.

headline: Not for over 40
pros: They have an excellent 401 K plan .  Benefits are good
cons: Culture is aimed toward younger works.  The are over-emphasizing diversity , creating many business group networks, in order to imply inclusiveness- but by splintering the many groups, Asian, Black, (yes) Hispanic, disabled-"capabilities" , LGBTQ, Veterans, Women, Women in tech, blacks in tech, Hispanics in tech, they seem to have covered all the groups that one cannot discriminate against in terms of employment - except over 40 workers, Who are being edged out.

headline: Awesome!!
pros:
Pay
Tuition reimbursement 
Schedule- my manager worked with my availability 
Coworkers 
Customers are nice 
Volunteer opportunities 
I enjoyed working with my manager and my operations supervisor
cons:
Long lines
Customer satisfaction was nerve wrecking at times 
Typical customer service headaches 
Teller line drama at times 
Inconsistent Dunbar deliveries

headline: Leave while you can
pros:
Overall
    - Medical, 401k match and employee stock program
    - Learned how to work in a cut throat enviroment and keep my morals.

Plano, TX 
   - Great in office eats

SanFrancisco, CA 
    - Free Snacks
    - Nice office layout
cons:
CapitalOne is so political with people willing to stab anyone in the back to move up in the company. After my 6+ years of service I have seen almost everything.

- Forced distribution at year end performance reviews. 
- Every 3 - 6 months leadership changes.
- There is a massive layoff of people who are 40 years old and older. I heard that 3% attrition was "too low" for tech companies. So leadership wants 8% attrition. 
- People in San Francisco are very under paid.

headline: Data Engineer
pros: benefits are the best and salary too
cons: very bad work culture in chicago

headline: Marketing
pros: Great mission and worthy ambition to be on the side of consumers
cons:
The environment is institutionally dismissive to anyone who doesn't fit the mold of their chosen golden-child - the (typically male) "business analyst".  
WARNING TO MARKETERS:  Marketing dept moved into the operations group and under non-marketers.  They don't value marketing as a discipline or they would have real marketing leaders.

headline: Best job I have had so far
pros:
- Great bunch of people who are motivated to achieve and very friendly.

- Lots of paid for social occasions (food and drinks provided), at least one / month since I have worked here.

- Nice working environment (clean, tidy, good quality equipment, nicely decorated, plenty of natural light).

- Breakout areas to get away from desk Games room (pool table, table football, table tennis), Music room (drum kit, many guitars, piano, guitar hero on xBox), Gym.

- Free tea, coffee (instant and freshly ground 200 degrees coffee) and milk provided with taps dispensing boiling water so you don't have to wait for the kettle.

- Excellent facilities to run / cycle to work (huge bike shed, changing rooms with many showers, lockers and a drying room for towels / wet kit).

- Subsidised Canteen with restaurant quality food.

- Only have to ask management team once to remove blockers / perform tasks and there are absolutely no worries that it will happen.

- Half an hour / week meeting with manager to discuss absolutely anything that is happening at work. These have never been put off or cancelled to make way for anything, it's very important to the management to keep the communication lines open and stamp on any issues as soon as they arise.

- Excellent communication downwards from the top about what is happening in the business and what direction we are moving in strategically.

- Trusted to manage own workload and time. No micro-management.

- Possibility of company mobile phone if required.
cons:
- Workload not always as technically challenging as I would like it to be.

- Quite a lot of admin / process to follow (to be expected in a heavily regulated financial institution).

headline: Customer Service Solutions Team
pros:
Flexible Schedule
401K - 6% match
Benefits
cons:
Hard to get off days you need
Feel like a dog on a leash

headline: An amazing amount of talent in "the room"
pros:
Great work/life balance due to flexible working plus fantastic benefits.

Company is full of really talented individuals that aids collaboration and makes project work enjoyable. It also helps lead to a really inspirational working culture.

There's a lot of communication towards career progression and lots of opportunities for personal growth.

Continuous request for feedback and discussion helps lead to a feeling that you have a hand in defining the way we work.
cons: Can sometimes be hard to get into production work due to large amount of intermittent meetings.

headline: A company filled with smart people who strive to bring humanity to the financial world
pros:
Vision: Capital One’s mission to Change Banking for Good really resonates with me. A company where the bottom line is not the only consideration in business decisions and where there’s a genuine commitment to bringing humanity to banking.

Culture: A respectful, passionate and collaborative environment that works towards a unifying vision to Change Banking for Good. 

Design Team: An aspiring leader who has built a fully-rounded team of passionate experts who champion the user and good design across the business. 

Facilities: Beautiful and spacious new offices at the White Collar Factory in London with an abundance of quirky places to work and collaborate with others, either face-2-face or remotely via the Surface Hubs that are located throughout the office and meeting rooms.  I’m especially excited by our purpose built, in-house Research Lab which we use to gather insights about our customers and evaluate products in development.
cons: Dogs: I miss taking my dog to work :(

headline: Good Company to Work For
pros:
I'm relatively new to working at Capital One, but everything I have seen thus far has impressed me. The company has a focus on doing the right thing for the customer, and they have a focus on taking care of their employees. 

I'm excited to see how they invest in their people. I feel strongly that if I come to work every day and give my best, that they're willing to invest in my growth and success.
cons: The hardest part of the job so far for me is navigating the leadership matrix and understanding all the relationships between different teams.

headline: Long Term Employee
pros: Great benefits and culture, truly working to become a digital leader and not chase after futile goals as Bank
cons: At times I think major initiatives could started a bit more thoughtfully to ensure that we are better stewards of our investors and clients funds

headline: Great place to develop your career
pros:
Culture: hard working , fun, laid back, casual
Meaningful projects: do something that matters and improves customers' lives
Development: lots of responsibility early on as a graduate 
Working hours, benefits, gym
cons: Sometimes change takes a long time

headline: Engineers perspective
pros:
Tech
- Top of the range tech and working environment.  mechanically operated desks that rise to allow you to stand, huge widescreen monitors, latest laptops & machines.
- Always striving to work on the latest tech.
- Video conferencing is an everyday occurrence and the tech to allow that is extremely good and available in abundance. 

Working Environment
- Relaxed and designed ergonomically to be pleasing with great breakout spaces. 

Great benefits
- Private healthcare options, life insurance, gym, canteen/cafe serving amazing food. Games room (table tennis, pool, table football), Music room with drums, guitars etc. 
- Strong emphasis on ensuring fun remains in the workplace - its one of the company values.
- Flexible working where necessary 

Progression
- Amazing progression with performance management practices designed to ensure you succeed. 

Strong emphasis on company values and imperatives that guide the company and are used as a backbone to which a majority of decisions are made. There is a feeling that you're always working with the best in the industry and to be frank, you pretty much are.
cons:
- Lack of parking
- Financial industry ensures that simple tasks are wrapped in process - be prepared for that!

headline: Great start-  very friendly!
pros:
I'm fairly new to the business and everyone here has been very friendly and welcoming.  It's clear to see that everyone is quite ambitious and always searching for how things can be done better in the future.
Within my first few days I've either met or set up meet and greets with the senior management team for my department which promotes an open culture across teams
I'm very impressed by the how well processes are documented and reviewed - meaning that even a newbie like me can get started up quite easily!
Looking forward to using the onsite gym as well
cons: Haven't come across any major red flags so far.

headline: Teller
pros: They offer great benefits and PTO
cons: Pay, commission was not good.

headline: Amazing company
pros: great work environment for employees
cons: not much of a con

headline: Nice people, but learned nothing
pros: People are very nice and polite. Benefit is great. Work life balance is good.
cons: Very political. This is the only place that I worked at where every presentation starts with an org-chart. The most important thing is to remember your SVP and the other person's SVP and who reports to who. Pretend to be a tech company but still a big bank inside.

headline: Bikes and slides don't fix outdated EOY rating system and low pay
pros: It's easy to make friends and great if you considered to be a part of the "in-crowd". If you like happy hours multiple times a week and spending a ton of time with your coworkers outside of work just to get ahead and be recognized for your contributions, then you'll love it here.
cons: Fraternity/sorority-like culture. If you're not a young, good-looking, single, white socialite, then good luck making a successful long-term career. And forget up-ward progression. EOY calibrations are a joke.

headline: Constant Layoffs
pros: Great benefits, diversity driven, and AMAZING people to work with! A variety of development opportunities to attain certifications.
cons: There are constant reorganizations of departments within the company which don't give you enough stability with the constant layoff for tenured associates.

headline: Relationship Banker
pros: Great Benefits! They take care of their employees.
cons: Management needs to be better at the District Level and certain branches

headline: UK CapitalOne
pros: Super smart people,  if you push yourself there is loads of opportunity to develop your career, company Mission and transformation
cons: High change environment,  regulated industry creates a lot of rules to come up to speed.

headline: Principal Researcher
pros:
- Excellent company culture and values
- Great work benefits
- Fantastic work environment (modern)
- Flexible working
- People actually care about you!
cons: - Haven't seen any cons yet

headline: Continues to evolve and keeps getting better!
pros:
•Finance is a very interesting industry to work in as a designer.
•Great salary and benefits.
•Lovely London office in Shoreditch, with a usability lab and a running track on the roof!
•Large, diverse and talented design team, including our own in-house research team (and Adaptive Path in the USA!).
•As design is still quite a new function within the UK business, there is opportunity to be involved in defining how we work.
•Plenty of opportunity for personal career growth with funded internal and external courses.
•Extensive library of design books.
•Design team offsite every 3 months.
•Half a day once per month to spend on a personal creative activity to refresh and inspire yourself.
•Company is continually taking on feedback to make it easier to get things done and be a better place to work.
cons:
•Often feels chaotic, disorganised and difficult to get things done, meaning there is less time to spend on designing which can impact on quality of output. This is mostly due to design being quite a new function within the UK business and this is actively being addressed.
•Can feel competitive rather than us all working as a team towards one goal, although this too is being addressed.
•A very meeting heavy culture.

headline: Branded Card Servicing & Partnership
pros: A good place to work if you get your foot in
cons: Constantly changing. But so does the industry

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Great facilities on-site, development opportunities and great place to work for those who have ambition to get things done. There is a brilliant approach to work/life balance too!
cons: There is fast pace to change which sometimes is great but can be hard if you don't like that sort of thing

headline: Very supportive team with strong leadership
pros: Very beautiful campus and approachable managers
cons: Technology department is still in its developmental stages

headline: Some of my best work carried out here...
pros:
Really good focus on self development and a great culture of 'bringing yourself to work'.
I love the technology; laptops and iPhones with awesome stand up desks and the wide screens!
I think the new office in London is just out of this world too!
Running tracks and roof bar! 

Go Capital One!
cons: None comes to mind at the moment!

headline: Strong graduate programme
pros: The pay, benefits package and ability to work flexibly (within reason!) are great. Work/life balance is also encouraged by leaders. The work is interesting and you're encouraged to play an active role in decision making from day one. The company really does live it's culture and values and encourages all associates to do so as well. Lots of senior leaders joined through the graduate programme so career progression is visible and achievable.
cons: Be prepared for lots of change. You may not see an individual project through from start to finish as resources shift regularly to accommodate business need. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but something to be aware of.

headline: Capital One UK
pros: Flexible working patterns.  Great people.  Great facilities.  Fun days out of the office
cons: Nowhere is perfect, and everywhere has cons, but I can honestly say this is the best company I have worked for.

headline: Progressive Company
pros:
- Company cares about it's associates and customers
- Challenging work environment, constantly seeking to improve
- Associates encouraged to own their progression and development
- Nice perks - onsite gym, restaurant
cons: - Culture not for everyone

headline: Great place to work
pros: Somewhere that really values its people and is very aligned to a great mission
cons: No car parking, although transport links are good

headline: Great culture, trying to do the right thing
pros: Relaxed corporate culture, some sense of fun and fairly relaxed on spending for team success. Leadership is insightful and listens to their staff. Canteen, office and other perks are really top notch.
cons: Getting things done can be difficult at times; requires a positive attitude and lots of enthusiasm!

headline: Talent Acquisition Partner
pros: Casual and relaxed environment with an awesome office space, pool table and great view of the city
cons: none at this moment

headline: Love Mondays again
pros:
Full of bright, enthusiastic and positive people
Work life balance is not just a phrase thrown around - it means something and managers encourage associates to embrace it
Offices are bright and airy and the facilities are constantly evolving to make Capital One a great place to work (including the amazing restaurant in Nottingham!)
There is an emphasis on fun - from the annual Capital One music festival (held with a tent, bands and fairground rides) to the little things, like market stalls popping up each lunch
cons: There is currently a lot of change throughout the organisation and while that is exciting and  information channels are good, the be better communicated at times

headline: Friendly people with a collaborative culture
pros: Great benefits, collaborative culture where people are valued, flexible and good opportunities for progression
cons: Collaborative culture leads to slow decision making

headline: Amazing work with even better people!
pros: An amazing environment that shows a great balance between excellence and delivery. You learn so much especially as a Graduate and you get the best support possible to help you progress your career. You will work on life-changing projects and get the opportunity to really make your mark in the financial industry.
cons: Flexible working hours make me lazier. Too close to good pubs.

headline: Positive and motivating company culture while still being a sensible business
pros: The company has a great culture, where people collaborate and motivate each other,  where being a good person is celebrated and where learning is encouraged. There is also a drive to keep growing in the ever-changing technology environment. This is all while still being sensible as a business, with a strong focus on sound analytics and decision making, something that's really important at a lending institution.
cons: The UK business sometimes don't have as much resource as we probably need to achieve our lofty goals the way we would like to. Also, I don't think everyone's recruitment experience in the UK is a good reflection of what a great place this is to work.

headline: A great place to work with smart people and learn new skills
pros: You get to work with great, smart people. Every day is different with a high pace of change and a focus on innovation.
cons: Would be great to shout more about what we do

headline: Flexible Work Environment
pros: On returning from maternity, Capital One supported my request for a flexible working arrangement that allowed me to support both my family and my career.
cons: Need to evolve the meeting culture across the organisation

headline: Great place to work
pros: Casual, fun, engaging work, and great people!
cons: Competitive environment isn't for everyone

headline: Capital one review
pros: Great environment, work culture, peers
cons: Performance Management is little complicated

headline: Coordinator
pros: The training, benefits and paid time off.
cons: Some of the managers were not effective communicators.

headline: Senior Scrum Master
pros: Flexible hours, great work life balance.  The campus and benefits are amazing as well.  Pay is great too.  They looked at my military experience when I applied.
cons: Kind of a slow moving corporate entity.  You're another cog essentially.   It's challenging sometimes to separate yourself from the flock if you are working in a stagnated area.

headline: Great Company, but some departments/areas lack great leadership
pros: Great Talent, nice culture, good work life balance, great program of benefits
cons: Vision does not trickle down well from executive to senior leadership, talent calibration process is archaic and flawed, to achieve Sr. positions you only get there and keep position if you know someone and you get along well, not necessarily talent or fit based.

headline: Department Supervisor
pros: Work life balance and growth opportunities
cons: Limited locations throughout the country

headline: Awesome company
pros: Great benefits, great place to work at.
cons: Some people in leadership are micro managing

headline: A lot of opportunity
pros: Great benefits, positive work atmosphere
cons: mobility outside of the retail space is challenging

headline: Supplier Manager
pros: Capital One is a great company that offers comprehensive benefits for people that perform. The company is very flexible around schedules depending on your role and department. The environment is very Tech oriented, and is on the cutting edge of technology.
cons: Depending on the department and role, your experience may differ.

headline: Great Team
pros: Benefits, flexibility, merit based.  As long as you work hard, you play hard too.  Capital One may not pay as much as the others, but the benefits are outstanding.
cons: Limited opportunity for advancement here in Wilmington if you are not in the correct department.

headline: Very good Employer
pros:
Great inspirational team. 

Capital one are believers in flexible working. 

As part of the design team we also get 1/2 day a month to get out of the of the office  and do something non work related and  creative. 

Fantastic benefits and  career progression. 

Good company events and away days. lots of opportunity to travel
cons: It can take a while get stuff done. Lots of meetings

headline: Analyst
pros: Great company culture with a huge emphasis on associate developement
cons: Very data driven which can sometimes lead to slower execution

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Powerful Mission
Caring Managers
Bottom up technical decisions
cons: Lower salary in relation with pressure

headline: inbound sale and sr advocate
pros: striving to be the first digital bank
cons: employee turnover and more value to what your employees bring to the job

headline: Vmware team with micro management
pros: Rolling Meadows Office location is in a good area . Lot of parking. Senior team members are helpful
cons: I'm in the vmware team. Small team but two managers and Managers doesn't know what they are doing. Micro managing the team. No freedom.  No opportunity to learn the environment. Managers doesn't know how to identify and distribute the work among the team members. Managers doesn't have any management skills.

headline: Sr Manager, Software Engineering
pros: Provides good work life balance .
cons: Still very process encumbered though there are efforts towards change.

headline: ds in C1
pros: good people, good culture. a lot of fancy projects
cons: a lot of limitation, a lot of repeat works

headline: Senior credit bureau disputes specialists
pros: Customer satisfaction  when it counts
cons: Can’t get updates immediately

headline: Solid Company
pros:
-Great vacation benefits
-Good work/life balance
-Relaxed environment
cons: A bit too much red tape when trying to get things done or update processes. Can be a bit high school so don't share personal things.

headline: nanana
pros: training opportunity, new techniques, food
cons: DA job family is not well designed - require a lot of skills but very rough career path

headline: Teller
pros: Learned a lot about banking products and services. Coworkers are great and work well together.
cons: Stressful. Unrealistic expectations. Very low pay.

headline: Feel valued at a credit card company that doesn't behave like a credit card company
pros:
Great working environments, designed to encourage collaboration across multi-function teams
Commitment to employees is evident in everything the company does - from the interview process, to the welcome experience, to the support for personal and professional growth. 
Commitment to continuous improvement - processes and working practices at all levels are under constant review and suggestions for improvement are welcomed at all levels.
There's a genuine desire at all levels to build products for people, to help them gain the benefits of credit - not trying to get people into debt they cannot possibly manage.
Talented people from a variety of backgrounds.
Flexibility and work/life balance is excellent. Balancing work with childcare and family commitments is well supported and accommodated easily.
cons: As with many big companies, it can still take a little while to make things happen - but this is always improving.

headline: Personal Banker
pros: Great company to work for.  They really take care of their employees.  You get great benefits.
cons: make sure to put in vacation request when your hired.

headline: Data Scientist
pros: Fantastic learning opportunities, supportive leadership, friendly and talented coworkers. Really great place to work, especially as your first job. Keep it up!!
cons: Really depends on the team and manager you work with. Sometimes Reorg is a little too often. Don’t have much negative things to say.

headline: Open, Fast Moving Culture
pros:
Some of the senior leaders are outstanding although less consistent with recent outside additions
Culture with focus on Delivery and Competencies
cons:
Workload and Pace
increasing expectations year over year
Cooperation between various groups can be challenging

headline: Great company

headline: Outstanding
pros:
The number one reason to work in any company, I think, is your colleagues. It's one of those things that you don't have any influence over unless you're the one hiring, and actually contributes the most to how you feel about your work. I feel really lucky to have some of the smartest and warmest colleagues I've ever worked with. The culture, particularly in the Design team, is really nice; everyone is incredibly supportive of one another, and my colleagues are all experienced and enthusiastic about producing brilliant work every day. This makes me want to come to work more than anything else.

There is a lot of support from Senior Leadership in getting us the right training and learning opportunities. I feel like they invest in their team, and work to grow us to our maximum potential.

I also really love the culture, the flexibility with where and how I work. When I choose to come to the office, the spaces I can work in are varied depending on the type of work I'm doing. The expectation is that you're trusted to get the job done, so whether that's achieved in one of the cosier corners of the office or sitting/standing at your desk, it's fine.

The benefits are really nice; the pension is the best I've ever had, and health/dental care are all options you can take. I really appreciate the Mission Days and team days they organise for us, too.
cons: Some benefits are not equally distributed across locations, so the staff in the headquarters get very subsidised meals & an onsite gym, in London we have free cereal and fruit for breakfast and free fizzy drinks fridges, and a running track on the roof with a very small discount for gyms. The pay is less than it would be at other companies in this industry.

headline: For the first time I am able to say I love my job!
pros:
Capital One has invested greatly in the working environment with the new offices in the White Collar Factory right on Old Street roundabout. This provides a fantastic working environment both inside and outside the office.

The culture is great and not like other banks. Flexible working is available and well utilised by the team.

The organisation is investing in design and the mission to change banking for good is evident and clearly present.

The work is challenging and innovative which makes coming to work exciting and highly rewarding.
cons:
The disconnect between the Nottingham and London office can be a little frustrating. However the way technology is adopted in the business its made less painful. 

The interview process was a bit daunting but its clear that it works to create a great overall team.

Salary, whilst competitive is on the low side but to be fair the other benefits and opportunity for progression are up for grabs.

headline: Not what it is all cracked out to be.
pros: The benefits are nice and work well. And there is leave if you're expecting or have kids. That's really the only thing good about working for the company.
cons: Management is essentially stuck in the high school days. The benefits are nice but the consequences of being a human being are not worth it. If you have an emergency or are sick, you can call out but they are not understanding when it comes to life. You're punished for being a person.

headline: Flexible, Open Culture with Challenging Work Environment
pros:
- The people! Really smart people with humility and openness. 
- Challenging work. The credit card business area is infinitely complex with macro- and micro-economic factors, human behavior, and risk that all needs to be under consideration in decision-making
- Flexibility. Although with colocation and agile becoming an ever-present trend in how the teams work, there is flexibility in work hours and remote work depending on the role and team. Leadership is also very supportive of personal growth (within reason) so moving to new functions or business lines is commonplace and promoted.
- Parental leave. Capital One recently extended it's PTO for both maternity and paternity leave and is an industry leader in the US private company space
- Extra benefits. Team fun events, occasional dinner/lunches at the office, and onsite gyms with optional PT sessions in Richmond, Plano, and Mclean were nice extras to have.
cons:
- Office locations. While some more tech/digital roles are moving to city center locations (e.g. Clarendon - closer to DC, San Francisco, and New York), it is a long commute if you work in McLean HQ and want to live in DC proper.
- Varying hours, without varying pay. Teams, work style, and hours differ depending on where you sit in the business and how time critical or significant work is. However, there isn't pay differentiation between a senior analyst in one role working 40 hours per week or one working 60 hours per week. Performance/bonus/promotions are more dependent on competencies and results.

headline: Director
pros: This company is focused on the future. Very tech-savvy, and doing so much more than credit cards. Excellent work-life balance and a CEO that is a founder and has a ton of passion for the business.
cons: Employment is treated like a 24/7 competition. You're competing with every coworker every day to earn the right to keep your job, and maybe get promoted. Performance management takes up considerable time and causes considerable anxiety. You're considered an athlete competing to stay on the team. This idea is taken to extremes, causing a highly passive-aggressive environment. If you're "in", you're set. If you're not, it's an uphill battle to ever get the chance to break in. Too much time wasted on doing things "beyond your job", selling the idea that "being great at your job isn't enough". Nobody is in charge and everybody has a say. This is great in theory, but when it's time to make a decision, nobody is clearly empowered to make the call so compromise is key. As a result, moving forward means watering down projects to make lots of people feel ok about agreeing to move forward. Decision by committee takes the bite out of innovative efforts.

headline: Apply for part time teller position

Several branches nationwide allow me to relocate when I decide to.  Benefits for part-time positions as well as full-time.   Capital One was voted one of the best places to work.
cons: Hourly pay is not that great starting out, but the other benefits outweigh the cons.  A part-time position will be great while I finish school.

headline: Risk Coordinator
pros:
Let me begin by stating that Capital One is in fact one of the best companies to work for in this area. The emphasis on moral is great, and I'll always remember the good times they allowed us to have through employee appreciation events. The atmosphere allowed me to go into work everyday with a positive attitude, and I never dreaded going in unless I had my own personal issues. The job itself is not one you would necessarily dream of but it was not as bad as other collection jobs, according to coworkers. The customers generally understood we had a job to do, and there were only a handful of those who were difficult.  The incentives are good, but as I was leaving the management was making it a little more difficult to achieve eligibility.

Mobility within the company is also great. Although I wasn't given the opportunity to leave the department, many of my peers did (depending on the manager). The whole company was good at working internally. Great, great company in itself to work for.
cons:
Management... If you are looking into joining Capital One collections in Plano, TX...BEWARE. The department managers' methods are extremely questionable and possibly unethical. As far as they're concerned, you will be another pawn on the chessboard. If for whatever reason they found you unfavorable, it seemed to me as any formal policy went out the window and became arbitrary to them, and used to only their advantage to get what they wanted. The pressure became extremely unbearable, even for top performers. A specific example would be that one of the top performers of the past 6 months was unable to leave the department after a year due to the department managers preventing it for their benefit. This agent was able to leave the department after HR intervention.

Now, to say all of management was like this would be unfair, but definitely enough to make me leave voluntarily and go through the effort of writing this warning to you. You may assume that it was entirely my fault and perspective that I see things this way, however unfortunately I am one of many who also left due to the new management. I hope that one day the senior level is able to identify this issue and resolve it for future retention purposes. 

My best advice to those looking into joining the department would be to do as your told, and try your best to succeed while for lack of a better expression, kiss their a**. 

Other than that, the pay could be more competitive especially with the new pressures.

headline: Great corporate culture
pros: I never thought a big bank would feel like it cared about its employees, but Capital One does.  Great benefits, solid pay, flexible schedules, educational opportunities, great offices.  The leadership seems to have an eye on the future and doesn't get complacent for long, always looking on how to stay ahead.
cons: The year-end review process is a constant complaint at work.  Currently you're reviewing in "buckets" with people of a similar level, and on a curve, so some people are always going to be "exceptional" and some have to be "needs improvement."  They're working on fixing this, but for now it's the standard.  Also in some roles it's hard to find ways to move up the ladder, so you'll need to keep your ears open for opportunities if your department doesn't offer them.

headline: Restructuring and layoffs every month

cons: Quarterly restructuring and mass layoffs, people movement , heavy unengaged interviews & tiring hiring process , customer focus, too aggressive, often & quick strategy changes

headline: Fraud Detection Coordinator

cons: Downsizing Departments, Switching Managers, Lay-Off, PTOU, No Sick-Time

headline: Best company in banking.
pros: Everything! They offer medical insurance that kicks in after about 30-60 days. They also offer a nice life insurance policy. There 401k is the best, the company will automatically contribute 3% on day one whether you contribute or not, then they will match you dollar for dollar up to another 3% and lastly 50 cents on the dollar for another 3%. You are 100 % vested from the day you start. 3 full weeks of paid vacation after 90 days of employment, which increases up to 6 weeks the more years you are with the company. Raise increases are a decent percentage of your pay. The hours are standard 9-5 or 9-4 depending on your region. They are extremely diverse in the employees they hire and not just entry level but all through the company.
cons:
With all the great things they offer, current employees are staying in there positions, so there is no opening to move into in some states. 
The company is only in about 9 US states. 
It could take a year or more to move into full time. 
Part time associates don't get paid for holidays off, or bereavement.

headline: Perfect company to work for
pros: Excellent working conditions, great work life balance, and a place a person can call home
cons: Noe that I can think of

headline: A very good company to work

Couldn't be peaceful at home because of pressure at work

headline: Still a Bank. Lightyears away from a "tech company"
pros:
Work-life balance is the best I've had in the bay area.
Benefits are overall great.
I've worked with some truly amazing people.
Professional development opportunities are great, from paid conference trips and lots of free access to learning material, to 1:1 professional coaching sessions.
cons:
- Don't expect to get a promotion, regardless of how successful and impactful your projects are. People who are flight risks get promoted first, and then the rest of the allotted promotions are dolled out to the managers who are loudest (I wish I were joking).
- Expect being blocked by bureaucracy to at least double any project timeline estimation you have. This includes everything from internal approvals, documentation being wrong, a tool/API you're trying to use to not having an owner anymore, to your team all losing access to github randomly (again not joking).
- Organizations are very territorial. If someone thinks you're not the right person to talk to about something, they'll ignore you. They won't go out of their way to stop you, but they will certainly not be helpful.
- Expect anything you want to do is already being done by at least 3 other teams but you have no way to find out who they are.
- Everything needs a business justification so work on your business-speak.
- Ultimately the bottom line still comes first, not customer experience. 

Compared to other banks, Capital One is forward-thinking and ahead of the game. Compared to technology companies in the Bay Area they have a long way to go.

headline: Unsatisfactory Management
pros:
Some good things about working at a Capital One call center were:

- Somewhat flexible hours
- Decent pay
- Excellent benefits
cons:
The environment is very stressful and most managers were very keen on making you listen to your worst calls. They put the customer first in service which is a good practice and there was a lot of corporate mission statement buzzwords being thrown around and there was a lot of talk about how great it was to work for them; however, under the syrupy film of good nature that the management applied, they were not interested in the employees well being outside of throwing snack at them. 

I think a lot of the cons in working for them is that they are a company that is trying to change how they operate by building on top of old practices. These practices don't align with the new warm and fuzzy feels they are trying to portray.

headline: FRAUD

headline: Capital One

headline: Toxic work environment with racism and worst management culture in the IT industry
pros:
-Location and a sprawling campus
- Occasional events and parties
- Latest technology setup
- Training's
- Good 401 K
cons:
- There is a lot of diversity in the company but there are some really bad racist managers who pass comments, exploit and treat their employees horribly. It seems it is an acceptable behavior within the company as these people have been with company for 10-20 years in some cases. It leads to low morale, depression and can turn your life into hell.
- Hyper aggressive work environment and bullying by these managers that is never heard of anywhere in the IT or the banking industry.
- Brutal review process where managers have to fight each other and the one who beats up others in this fight gets a good review about their employee. Doesn't matter how hard you worked or what ever great thing you achieved, it all boils down to the teams you work with, how well your manager can fight them during the review process and the political equations.
- Politically charged environment where teams gang up against other teams or person.
- Age based discrimination.
- Medical insurance is not up-to the mark and you pay lot of money out of pocket during visits. Dental insurance is worse.

cons: some systems and procedures outdated but management seems to be diligently working on that. Office politics exist but aren't a complete morale kill. If you perform and do a good job, you Will get noticed. May not be the right company if you are looking for a stagnant career as employee promotions is very important and they want associates to improve themselves.

headline: Branch Manager
pros: I liked what the President had to say, his outlook, as stated at management conference after the Chevy Chase Bank Acquisition.
cons: They closed many Chevy Chase Bank branches.  Tons of people lost their jobs.  They set impossible goals for the branches. Only cared about money.

headline: Nice place to work, but watch your back .
pros: Very diverse , friendly atmosphere , & nice pay . The benefits are great & the pto offered is nice .
cons: They provide you with paid training , but once you get on the floor the information obtained during training isn't always valid . They tell you to do your own research . So, it doesn't matter what you learned or advice given by managers . If you receive the wrong information, and you Do what you're told, you're ultimately at fault . So that raises the question what's the purpose of the training and managers ? It's unfair to get fired , without previous warnings, for something you were taught . It's not a bad place to work, you just have to watch your own back bc clearly you can't depend on anyone else to guide you .

headline: Capital One Experience

headline: Cut-throat
pros: Work life balance, pay, benefits.  That's really it.  Narcissistic people are welcomed there.
cons: Associates are encouraged to boast and become self centered.  Narcissistic people excel and if everyone was as smart as they told you they were, C1 would not only rule the financial industry, but the tech industry as well.  Nice guys and gals finish last.

headline: Amazing company
pros: Great culture and values, great leadership, very helpful and room for growth, everyone is eager to help each other.
cons: There is no con for this job besides it being busy at times, but most contact centers are. And even with that it's not nearly as busy as others I've worked at.

headline: Capital One
pros: Great Company and culture and high bar
cons: Retaining Talent is tough and not easy

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Has a great work life balance philosophy and good benefits as well. Lots of room to grow professionally and opportunities within different teams.
cons: There is a very vertical hierarchy structure which can make it difficult to get promoted to up management quickly if that is a goal of yours.

headline: Recruiter
pros: Great work life balance, great benefits, growing company
cons: Lots of movement with upper management

headline: above all this is still a sales environment
pros: the corporate philosophy is to let one advance and achieve without hindrance.  Fast growing company.  Keep in mind this is still a sale organization.  sales are the key to success.
cons: help is not always available to solve problems,  the "figure it out" plan does not always work.  when someone falters they are then left on their own.  there are  5-6 different software programs that do not talk to each other and are not user friendly thus constant repeating same info.    learning curve on software is very quick  but it is the foundation of everything else.  Despite the "corporate line" of doing what's best for the customer, one is required to intensely question all customers to uncover new sales opportunities, even if they just want a simple transaction.  Customers hate this.  corporate environment is totally different than   sitting in a bank

headline: Probably Better than Most Corporations
pros:
- Great people to work with
- Most departments are very well organized
- Easy to advance and cross-train in other departments
- Decent pay and work-life balance
- Lots of training/learning opportunities
- Benefits are top-notch
- Many opportunities to bond with colleagues (social committees are well-run and organized)
- The company's LGBTQ+ outreach efforts are surprisingly good for a corporation, and I think other companies should take Capital One's lead in advocating for the LGBTQ+ community
cons: This is my opinion, and mine alone: the method used to review, promote, and award raises is outdated and not based on merit, but a "bell curve" approach. Basically, employees with the same title are compared to each other (whether or not the actual work they do is in any way similar), and there are only enough "slots" for a certain number of folks to get a particular rating level. It's an ineffective and absurd method of evaluating people.

headline: System Engineer
pros: Very nice working environment, startup setup, with on-site bars, free cookies, soft drinks and good coffee in New York offices. Decent benefits such as Medical insurance, 401k, PTO, etc. Integrate with new technologies fast, especially highly recognized in financial industry to adopt AWS thus consolidating on-prem data centers. CEO has very good vision and he is widely respected within or outside of company. Tech side, company is well-know and respected for innovations and quickly adopting new technologies
cons: Not all groups are equal among groups and teams, tech side Cards and Retail bank maybe very strong, while other groups such as Commercial bank and EDS might be in old schools who try to catch up. Expect drastic changes maybe no one really know the direction to advance technologies. With so-called innovation and transformation, they will keep bringing un-qualified new people to Dir/Sr. Mgr roles and drive 1+ years' veterans out. You will find yourself to be the only few guys as 2+ years tenure in Capital One meeting room maybe due to immigration status. Even if you like the company and try to be really innovative, you will be shut-off by your skip-level Gang of Powers  tech leaders since they don't want to veterans to work on anything innovative.  Worst of all, they will bash the guys who left the company, to survive HR surveys because they know no way you can fight with them if you choose to leave.

headline: Capital One is pretty cool

cons: Lack of change management and leadership training.

headline: "Sales/Operations"
pros:
1. Great benefits
2. Employee stock purchase  programs 
3. 3 weeks PTO
4. Diverse environment
5. Constant morale boosters
6. Various Capital One locations in the US
cons:
1. Favoritism
2. I've had a manager only inform one employee about overtime availability. Others were not informed.
3. My manager cheated the team out of their bonus potential. The manager ranked many of us as strong because he said that's the new "Very Strong". He also does not know how to use the systems we do. So how is he able to judge my work, when he can't complete the tasks himself.
4. Difficult transferring within the company. I have about 8 apps that have been declined.

Culture at the macro level is one I cherish, understandably this will change in good and bad ways depending on the department. High performance is well rewarded.

The project management program (now the mrp) was almost all female. I love working with other women but it made me question how the company viewed women.

headline: Great Culture/Excellent Benefits
pros: I have worked with Capital One for many years now, started out as a associate on the phones and worked my way up to management. They really do have a great culture, management tries to make it fun and the benefits are great. 12 weeks PAID maternity leave, there is paternity leave that can be split up as you want, insurance is good, 3 weeks vacation starting out and you earn more the longer you stay.
cons:
As with every job you have politics, it is all about who you know.  If you work for this company make sure you network and DO NOT burn bridges. The Home Loans side has org changes often and have had reduced headcount and increased headcount countless times. The Auto side is a much more stable side of the business. 

Pay for the tenured associates is on the low end, so for anyone coming in new they typically make more starting out than someone who has been in the role for example 2-3 years.

headline: Senior Fraud Detection Representative role
pros: I went through recruitment process which included; initial application, online assessments, online video assessment, phone interview, and appointment for personal interview. I decline the personal interview and withdrew from process. Overall, the process to this point was easy to follow, and took approx 2 wks from initial application online. To be fair, I'm not rating in the "stars" ratings below since I withdrew from the recruitment process.
cons: WHY? The pay started at 13.88/hr and is low, even for the FL market in my opinion. Raises do progress, but you must wait and qualify with performance.This was the number given to me by the H.R. department when scheduling a personal interview.

headline: Teller
pros: This place is a great place to work. Management was great and very helpful on giving feedback in places I could do better. They were also very flexible with the hours I was able to work. I was in college and in some after school clubs, so this was very helpful.
cons: Branches can be very slow sometimes

headline: Great place to work....
pros: There's a genuine sense of caring for one another.  It's very rare in FS that you get a company that has a desire to go above and beyond for it's customers, but Capital One definitely do that.  They look after their associates very well, great benefits, flexible working, supportive management, good salaries.
cons: More opportunity for people to progress, sometimes this is capped, not intentionally, but purely down to team structures.

headline: Director - Digital Product Management
pros: Great physical work environment; the top leadership and ethos of the company are very customer-focused and want to do the right thing for customers and associates; opportunity to move to different lines of business or different functions as a way to continue to grow your personal skills and gain better understanding to the overall business
cons: Highly data driven --- to a fault; promotion and upward mobility requires you to be part of the 'in crowd' and is not as meritocratic as they would have you believe.

headline: Great Company
pros: It's amazing the culture they have created there. Employees are highly professional, intelligent, and interpersonal, along with a passion for excellence and genuinely doing the right things. They have exceptional transparency and I loved their 360 review functionality.
cons: Their performance management process, while rightly highly valued/prioritized in the company, ironically functions largely counter to their culture in prioritizing strict percentages/bell curves over reality. They rightly have created a culture of excellence and truly exceptional employees, but then rank them on a bell curve as if they haven't achieved that objective. It's disappointing that they relocated many to a site with assurances, then all too soon closed that site. It's really so counter to their values.Hopefully just an anomaly.

headline: Great place to work!

cons: Can be difficult to navigate big organization.

headline: Awesome
pros: Lots of Perks, Balanced Workplace, they care for their employees
cons: Some are insecure people that loves to pull you down, favoritism

headline: Financial Advisor III
pros: Great Employee Benefits, excellent retirement, 401K match level is the best
cons:
The company claims to do what's in the best interest of customers and moving towards more of a planning environment. In reality it's very high pressured sales environment and very transactional. Only the final number matters, not the customer. For this, they always threaten to fire employees. No job security.

There is no effort to promote women in the Financial Advisement position, it's a boy's club. So to women looking to work as a financial adviser at Capital One, be prepared for unequal opportunity.  
Compensation Sucks - In the 2 years I spent with the company, Compensation structure changed 3 times, to structures that tightened the ability to earn a higher income.

co-workers are very friendly, very a great team environment, but not when it matters so beware - everyone protect themselves - no one stands up for the other when they should.

headline: VI & V Tester
pros:
Decent Pay
Fair Benefits
Good work/life balance
cons:
Climbing the ladder is difficult.
Mostly hire external

headline: custome care coordinator
pros: benefits and vacation days are good
cons: the job was boring at times

headline: Startup Environment with Scale to Impact
pros: We think differently about banking here. We have a startup environment, but have the scale to impact an enormous amount of customers. The work-life balance is also amazing. As a working parent, Capital One lets me focus on what matters most to me while still being a great employee that delivers impact for the company.
cons: There is so much opportunity within the organization that you might not ever want to leave. This keeps perspectives close in.

headline: Great Benefits
pros: Benefits- Health, Maternity, adoption,
cons: Hard glass ceiling in IT- women don't get promoted as quickly as the men. Women are told to be meeker, friendlier, always say Yes to leadership no matter what.

headline: Risk Coordinator
pros: Managers make or break whether or not you love your job and who you work for. I have been fortunate and blessed to work with the same people since I started working here 6 years ago. The company itself offers a wonderful maternity leave program of 18 weeks PAID, they offer reimbursement for Adoption costs, great life work balance, and vacation time.
cons: None-love my job and the people i work with

headline: What Values?
pros: Some benefits and some managers actually care and aren't pretending to.
cons:
They hire you making you believe in high moral standards and "values" when in reality they have Senior Leadership making decisions that is "best" for the company rather than the customer and employees.

 The employees are under paid and the promotions are highly strategic in regards to giving promotions to those who have already had salary increase within that year so they end up not qualifying for the 10-12 percent promotion increase. 
Even if you have all the knowledge and qualifications for a promotion the jobs can easily be given to someone who has no knowledge or any idea of what to do as a result of favoritism. Beware on the position you take because unless you follow "office politics guidelines" you could be stuck in that position and overworked for years. 

Finally, I am not the only Capital One employee that has had one of the worse and most stressful experiences. While there I met multiple employees who were driven to seek medical attention due to the stress levels and the total disregard for the well-being of their employees. Even as I meet individuals in my new career path who are former employees as well, they had the same experiences when they worked for the company.

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros: Great company to work. Moving aggressively into open source. Great company for software engineers. Can learn and work in cutting edge technologies.
cons: I don't find any cons as of now

headline: Chaotic and Hostile Technology Culture / Lacking in Direction / Individualistic Mentality
pros:
- If you're an intern or TDP employee, you're pampered with goodies
- Near the metro
cons:
- Too many to list.  Just stay away unless you're an intern or TDP employee.   Don't let the recruiters fool you.  
- The above is HIGHLY team dependent so choose wisely.

headline: Schedules, Benefits, Compensation flexibility

headline: nice culture

headline: It takes a lot perseverance to advance your career path from this level. It's all about net working!

headline: The Basics

headline: Best People and Best Culture
pros:
The Company truly lives their values. I have access to endless resources to better myself and my career. My leaders value my work, and spend extra time helping me develop my skills. As a result, I have been promoted every year.

I would argue that the re-orgs people are complaining about in other reviews create great opportunities if you are the proactive type. If you are comfortable coming in and piking it, the re-orgs will certainly upset your comfort level.

Top leadership is very forward thinking and has clear goals that get communicated to us by Rich himself, in person, once a year.
cons:
While the re-orgs can create opportunities, it does sometimes disrupt best practices in place, and as a large organization it can be difficult to correct in a timely manner.

Much like any large company, Some tasks can be overly cumbersome.

Leaves me constantly doubting the Leadership of my managers, and unable to trust them.

- Poor technological advancement and funding in the workplace. Multiple money counters that were so old that you had to reinsert cash like 5 times to properly use. Never had this problem at Chase as they always had updated, state of the art equipment.

headline: Couldn't ask for a better company to work for!

My leadership is incredibly passionate about making sure each of our associates are doing work that is truly fulfilling and inspiring. Never have I felt limited by hierarchy, role, team, etc. My opinion feels valued and I have many ways to voice it. I love that I can take an idea and run with it, without needing layers upon layers of approval.  The pay and benefits are fantastic.
cons: We've made improvements (and continue to make improvements), by leaps and bounds, but sometimes process slows down delivery of work.

headline: Good Mission ; Bad Implementors
pros: On your first few days of training, your class will be flooded by speakers , mainly bosses , from the GM, UM's TL's down to the maintenance workers and janitors. You will be awed. The speakers speak so casually making one feel at home. A sense of "family" creeps in. And especially when the facilities, benefits and perks are discussed you will thank God for putting you there. The company, it's vision, mission and principles , nothing but admirable..
cons: If only the americans Mr. Richard Fairbank assigns here know how the filipino employees whom they designate to head the teams really operate. How they practice favoritism. How they favor those who go on drinking sprees with them more over those who are serious and dedicated to their work and seldom has the time to hang out.  The BPO industry , supposedly doesn't have any sort of discrimination, and Capital One sort of adheres to that and one would think, if he / she is above 40 years old, that the company doesn't practice discrimination in age. Maybe the company, the leaders, managers, they clearly do. This is a good company put up and raised from the ground up by one good and exemplary man. Too bad the people they choose to lead are swell-headed, arrogant, power tripping filipinos who terminates their fellow filipinos if they find them too serious or too boring.

headline: Great place to learn and grow
pros: The structure of how work is done, coupled with a culture of moving associates through different teams and experiences contributes to a great learning environment. During my tenure, I have worked on expansion strategies, marketing, underwriting, new product development and associate-facing development programs. My managers have been supportive of learning new skills through trainings, projects, and conferences. I have learned a lot in five years!
cons: Banking is a highly regulated industry, which means that getting something to market can take quite a while. And, like many public companies I see leaders falling into the trap of focusing on short-term results over long-term strategy.

The managers ect do not know what they are doing but exepects the csr to know.. 
The managers go to all of these meetings for nothing..

headline: Out of touch

headline: It's ok if you want quick experience but get out fast
pros: If you are intelligent, ambitious and young prepare to be hated. There will likely be 0 advantages for you to work here. If you just want something that pays the bills and couldn't care less about being promoted to a decent post then this place might suit you.
cons: Very aggressive, unreasonable and downright dishonest managers. They tried to get me fired by spreading lies about me on multiple occasions but they ultimately failed because I was always on top of my game in regards to performance. It's impossible to obtain any constructive and honest feedback from these people. Also, you are required to get your managers SIGNATURE anytime you apply for a position/ promotion. I only received one promotion while working here and my manager tried to have it stopped despite the fact that I was one of the top performers. I tried to apply for other promotions I was eligible for some time down the line but would always be sabotaged by managers. I only had one normal boss while working there but I lost her because people either keep quitting, going on sick leave or moving to different departments.I'm far from beeing the only person that dealt with harassment from management. Many of my colleagues complained about unfair treatment. If some manager disliked you prepare to have lies about you spread around the company because they will try to make you look incompetent.I have left the company to complete a very in demand University degree and will soon start my Ph.D. studies. I'm happy I left and found more substantial goals to focus on but I feel its important to warn others about the nastiness that goes on.If you have to work with them find a manager that is nice or at least normal and find some way to be transferred to their department. Having the wrong boss will make your life hell.

headline: Bribes you well, but with some drawbacks

The cafeteria food is pretty awesome. 
They have a good amount of technology to play with.
The people are often pretty fun and awesome.
cons:
Reorgs are pretty constant, and can be highly disruptive, if only to team relations.
The performance management system does not come across as fair and seems heavily based upon whether the people like you.
The chaotic organization structure make navigating to get to things difficult, and encourages a highly political organization.

headline: Great culture
pros:
Culture/people are great.  Collaborative and supportive environment.  

Lots of ownership from day one.  Decision making isnt entirely top down.

Open and collaborative workspaces.

Able to grow and find new opportunities.

Not afraid to make bold strategic pivots, even if painful in short term.
cons:
Can have overly vertical org structure.

Good managers can be hit or miss.

headline: A Bank that Doesn't Feel Like A Bank
pros:
Capital One's forward-thinking, development-focused culture is the main selling point, in my opinion. The company is made up intelligent, driven associates who are supported by a management team that is committed to engaging them as humans, not just employees. The focus on growth is tangible, and it makes all the difference.

Another point that stands out is the willingness to take risks and learn from failure. The party line is that, if you never fail, you aren't trying hard enough, and this is taken into account when evaluating performance. 

All in all, when most people imagine what it's like to work at a bank, they imagine a scene out of "Office Space" or the beginning part of "Fight Club" before things get weird. Capital One is lightyears away from that stereotype. It feels more like a technology company than a bank, more akin to Google than Goldman.
cons: Because we're in such a heavily regulated industry, there are a ton of governance tasks and checks and balances. It can sometimes feel like you spend a large amount of your time cutting through red tape. This isn't such a big deal most days though.

headline: Great launching pad for your career
pros: Great benefits of a fortune 500 company and lots of opportunity to make an impact fresh out of university. Capital One is truly a leader in the financial industry making technology advancements no other bank is doing.
cons: Upward mobility becomes tough once you reach management level and salary raises between promotions aren't competitive to external hires

headline: Commercial real estate underwriter

headline: Great company to work for, but experience varies depends on manager
pros:
- Great compensation and benefits package
- Flexible work hours and environment
- Great people to work with
cons:
- Work-life balance can be great because of the flexibility, but often there is literally a lot more work to do compared with similar roles in other banks
- Managers have too much power over an associate: the same manager is your day to day direct boss, controls your performance/pay (no open discussion with other managers needed), and is also the official career advisor (which is usually a conflict of interest with their role as your direct boss)
- Some people managers are very inexperienced (fresh grad, worked at Capital One for 3 years, promoted to people manager)
- Management judge people by superficial impressions a lot more. Everybody that succeed at Capital One has the same personality traits and there is very little room for an introverted analyst to bloom who just wants to do work (as opposed to show off work). I get it that this is necessary for certain jobs/industries (e.g., consulting), but a bank should be able to make room for diverse personality.
- People experience very different career prospects within the company, due to the aforementioned difference in personality

Work-Life balance is manageable, and if you're looking for a start up career out of college, it's a good fit.
cons: Although the benefits package is decent, the compensation aspect is lacking.

Relocation, closing back offices and branches may save some money short term but adversely affect the loyal and passionate associates and trusted clients

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Fast paced and methodical approach to getting things done and done right.

headline: A great company with heart, but definitely room for improvement
pros:
Founder-led and market-back strategies: Fairbank still is at the helm and sets truly market-based strategic priorities 
Data-centric decision making: Analytics run this company.  Data trumps tenure.  
Amazing opportunities to grow and learn:  The organization generally values a breadth of experience and frequent rotation/movement is supported and encouraged.  Development programs available for high performing associates that come with HUGE benefits such as special training curriculums and full MBA sponsorship 
Fair compensation:  always better for newer associates, but, keeping an eye on the labor market is something Capital One takes seriously.
Benefits: To say the benefits are generous would be a incredible understatement.  Great standard benefits packages (e.g. retirement, health insurance, disability, tuition reimbursement) with ton of thoughtful extras (e.g. $35k in adoption or surrogacy assistance per child) plus some location-specific perks (e.g. fitness and health centers, walgreens locations, snacks, Tesla charging)
cons:
- Getting a raise and promotion: I think we most leaders do their best to administer the performance management process in a fair way, however, because people are involved, there are many imperfections.  There continues to be a relatively homogeneous group of associates (namely white business analysts who started as college hires) that are recognized and promoted more quickly than others.  
- Poor strategic execution: While the company excels at setting a high-level strategy, the one-level-down decisions are often poor.  The direct reports to the CEO seem willing to invest enormous sums of money, but $$ needs to be managed/directed much more closely. 
 Examples like the Capital One Labs, technology transformation, and obsession with "Design" and "Product" illustrate the idea that you can't just "buy it" --- you need to "grow it" to make a healthy organization.
- Org issues : The siloed accountable executive model doesn't deliver results as it is supposed to... still very much a matrixed organization (e.g. enterprise, technology) . The result is that the ability to navigate politics and effectively influence others is the only way to be truly effective
-

I mean come on it's 2017 and you can open up a bank account, apply for a loan, get a credit card, invest online. Took away bonuses for sales goals since it's now a liability and used them for marketing instead but still expects employees to sell. Bad compensation = low sales.

headline: Great company!
pros: The company has amazing values and had REALLY great benefits. I mean... like really great. They have full insurance benefits, offer great 401K matching, have a lot of resources to help you develop yourself personally and professionally, and have educational assistance.
