headline: Great benefits and good flexibility for work life balance if you can survive the culture.
pros: Benefits, flexibility with work hours (for non-front line jobs), good comp plans, amazing CEO and vision. Amazing community involvement.  Some of the most talented people work there.
cons: Leadership (VP + levels) - it's a good ole boys world and Richmond runs the show so if you are not in Richmond or follow suit and comply with old school methods and practices you will struggle in the environment. There is a culture of fear -(regardless of what is preached) and you are always needing to "show well" or "concede to egos" or you will be calibrated down in performance reviews (or out) and will not move up or around in your career there.  It's all about who you know and who likes you versus the impact you have on the organization. I have seen some of the worst leaders get promoted.

headline: Smart people, with heart
pros:
Capital One is an incredible place to work! Every day I am surrounded by incredibly bright, innovative people that genuinely care about one another, our customers and our community.  I believe that our values, mission and heart are the primary drivers for the company and they put people over profits. The company is an exciting and fast paced place to work, as we are on a journey to become a technology company that offers exceptional Financial Services to people. Money is so integral to our day to day lives-- from buying groceries to saving for college-- and it's important to be part of a company that wants to make managing money a positive and simple experience for people. 

In addition, Capital One has awesome work/life flexibility, paid leave, and career advancement. I have had unlimited opportunities for growth since I started with the company-- development through classes and trainings, new roles and promotions, and intentional mentorship. I genuinely believe that Capital One has set me up to do some of the most fun, most valuable work of my career.
cons: It is certainly a competitive environment, so you have to be thoughtful about making sure you manage your priorities well. Capital One supports work/life flexibility, but if you arent careful-- working from home and other options can cause you to work too much. Additionally, we are working on becoming more Agile as a company, but I still think it can be hard to get things done. As a federally regulated bank, there are a lot of hoops to jump through that you dont have to deal with at other companies.

headline: Don't take a Finance job at Capital One unless you're 22 years old
pros: Capital One is a huge company so I'm really only reviewing the Global Finance organization, where I had the misfortune of working for four years.  For the right person, it can be a great opportunity.  It's a big, well-run company and it doesn't expect you to work more than 40-50 hours per week (granted, strenuous hours in a Finance role).  If you work in Richmond, the West Creek facilities are fantastic.  I saw plenty of not terribly talented people in the their late 20's making (low) six figures without really knowing all that much or working that hard.  Especially in the undergrad program (FRP) the kids are treated really well with tons of training and networking opportunities.
cons: Capital One has a brutal performance management system and they really do fire people, even good people, and lots of them.  In the area I worked, pretty much anyone over the age of 40 was toast if they weren't a Senior Director or above.  The Senior Manager and Director levels ( for those age 40+) were constantly targeted in re-orgs and downsizings.  And it's not like you get great experience in Capital One Finance.  What you learn there is very internally focused and not valued outside of the company.  The people I saw getting caught up in re-orgs were not finding comparable jobs in other organizations.  For anyone over the age of 30, joining Capital One Global Finance is a horrible career move.

Overall culture is one that values work-life balance, there are team fun days, department fun days, balls so a lot is going on social-wise all year round

development opportunities can be limited once you hit a certain level, also easy to be passed over for promotion if you don't fit in certain stereotypes both professionally and maybe to a lesser extent socially.

org changes are not infrequent, and decisions from top management can take a long time.  Apart from your direct manager you don't get that many opportunities to interact with senior management in the office.

headline: Not as advertised

If you're thinking about joining because of how they want to "transform" the DA role and technologies - don't bother, they're not doing that, all you will do is write SQL.  Go somewhere else where you'll get a better title and better experience for your resume.  Your manager is very important to your career here.  Unfortunately, just because you have a great one doesn't mean you won't get reorged into a worse one.

headline: Toxic company.
pros: The benefits and work-life balance are good and if you're willing to sacrifice a few morals & navigate the political waters, you'll thrive here. If not, see you on the job market in 3 yrs or less.
cons:
There's an inherent culture of intently studying org charts, dropping names and vying for visibility and customer feedback at every turn to build your case for a promotion. Kissing up your business customer will take you a long way, as will attending happy hours and parties, incessantly promoting your work and being popular in your department. 

Diversity is a joke. For the most part, data scientists are asians, tech are indians and BAs are white.. and stick to their own groups (friend circles, lunches, .. you get the idea) You'll invariably see asian employees talking to their bosses in mandarin or their local language and feel left out if you don't speak the language and belong to the same team.

The company is toxic ; people either stick to their principles (& stay where they are for years), adapt or resign. The ones who adapt become aggressive Type A personalities who stop being team players, feed others' bad information and do everything in their power to use every minute in their own self-benefit. If you want to get ahead in this company, diss others' work, never admit when you're wrong, be supremely confident and take credit for others' work when needed. It can be attributed to miscommunication if identified later. If you're looking for a collaborative team environment and have chosen Capital One, it's hilarious :) Team work is eventually non existent so you'd much rather be put in a team with newbies who don't know any better. Don't believe for one minute that politics doesn't exist or 'Capital One has much less politics than other companies'. BS. Ever wonder why most the people at the director+ level *just happen* to be jerks?

headline: bad
pros: not any. it's so bad.
cons:
The issue with this business, is that associates are either managing too much, managing something they are not good at, or processes and setup at the business make it really hard to deliver results fast. AT THE SAME TIME, managers do not acknowledge this fact, continue to place harsh, unrealistic, and sometimes unsensible expectations on associates, and blame the associates for not working hard enough. These insufficiencies are well obvious in the day-to-day operation of the business. How can leaders blatantly neglect these fundamental challenges the business is going through? This is what pissed us off and why morale is low. What's so difficult about dividing the work a little more fairly? What's so difficult about putting the right person at the right role? What's so difficult about letting go some of your unreasonable expectations? And what's so difficult about reshuffling certain personnel (especially certain leaders) off their current role?

Leaders who are trying to make a change, I really hope you take a look at this. No one dares to say this cuz if they did, chances are they will get the blame for being not good enough and risk getting fired. We don't even trust the anonymous surveys to be anonymous.

headline: Full of type B leadership that can't handle any type A's around
pros: Pay and benefits are good, but not great. And not worth it when you consider the work environment.
cons:
Chesapeake, VA office: Constant stress and threat of termination. Absolutely no security. Don't be a different personality. Upper leadership talk all the time about ensuring diversity and that this doesn't mean just race. Yet if you are not the same personality as them and handle everything exactly as they do, you are in trouble and considered a troublemaker, even if your way of handling causes less trouble. As far as diversity with race? The Chesapeake site is about 95% African American while the local demographics show about 2/3 white to 1/3 black. Not diverse. Racist against whites. 

Hard work doesn't count. It's how many leadership individuals you can party with that counts. If you're not their party pal, you can plan on being terminated at some point. If you're type A personality and actually work hard and try to get the job done, you'll be termed even sooner as they get upset at "making them look bad" for not doing their jobs. Upper leadership actually lectures constantly on the fact that being friends with  everyone is more important than how hard or well you work. I actually had an upper leader tell me that I didn't get a promotion I applied for, even though they knew I could and would do the job better, because the hiring panel were friends with another applicant. A person who didn't know how to do the job and actually had to keep running to me to ask me how to do things after she got the job.

headline: Not customer or employee centric
pros:
-Wonderfully creative design team who fought for the customer when it came to design decisions
-Some product managers know what they are doing and are a joy to work with, others just want you to tell them what they want to hear
-I met and worked with super nice people
-401k had great options and was a good match
-Got bank holidays off
cons:
-Absent management who, when present, ignored major personnel issues. this resulted in my team loosing several individuals who just didn't want to be harassed any longer
-Narcissistic people were able to secure management positions, causing teams to suffer
-Product and Design do not understand what Agile is nor are they interested in following the practices, although they say they do
-Advancement is nonexistent unless someone leaves. You have to be a Sr. Manager (people manager) before they will train you for management. That's right, you have to be in the position before you can be trained for it. This leads to a lot of people who have no business leading anyone or anything in the positions of power and those who have the potential unable to use it officially (many many people do the job of their manager, because that manager can't do their own job, without recognition)
-Too many thought leaders who don't do anything
-If ideas don't come from sr. leadership, they rarely get implemented. If they do, they are quickly co-opted by sr. leadership so they can take the credit
-Yearly reviews are a joke. Your manager has to fight for your raise, bonus and promotion (if applicable) in a fight-club like situation where all managers present the merits of their employees and then they force rank everyone. So someone is always at the bottom. If you have a manager who is not good at this game, you have a very small chance of advancement.
-Beware of those who want to advance. They will step on you to take the credit for what you have done. In order to get promoted you have to promote yourself relentlessly, even if that means your co-workers have to do your job for you because you are too busy going to meetings where you are in front of sr. leadership. 
-Health insurance was expensive (more so than other companies I have worked for) but offered good options for coverage
-Only 15 days of vacation - non negotiable.

headline: Big isn't aways bad
pros: I think most people would be surprised how hard Capital One works to be more than a stodgy, mammoth, financial company. Sure it struggles with bureaucracy, but they actively work to fight that and instead be a mission driven business. On top of that they take excellent care of their employees. The benefits are great and even in outplacement they bend over backwards to make sure associates are set up for future success. I think that how a company treats it's employees says loads about the company.
cons: Your experience may vary dramatically depending on which portion of the business you work for. While the overarching corporate leadership and mission may be strong, if you are in a more fringe part of the company (such as investing) you may find your direct Leadership very challenging to work for and that there is an atmosphere of cronyism or tribalism. The single biggest con for Capital One though is that they still use a traditional stack ranking form of performance management that kills collaboration and innovation in favor of being popular or associated with high profile projects.

headline: Family Work Life Balance Obtained
pros: I love working here and have been working here for more than a year and a half now.
cons: Moving up is harder than what I thought.  Its who you know

headline: Best career move
pros: I have such a wonderful branch manager. He really wants his people to progress and be the best in their careers. Everyday he acknowledges how we did a great job. I came from retail with no banking experience and I've  learned so much in the past 7 months. I love working for Capital One. The best move I've made. Also the benefits and PTO are good.
cons: I haven't really had any downsides.

headline: fraud coordinator
pros: chances to move around w/in the company
cons: so much inconsistency with policy and procedure

headline: Sr Customer Service Rep from Home
pros: Great Benefits and in the comfort of my home
cons: I cant think of any

headline: Cheeky but good benefits
pros: Cap one has excellent benefits, PTO, monthly incentives, etc. Also tuition reimbursement and a nice corporate office; paid days to have fun for team building
cons: To advance in that company is such a struggle. They truly embody the idea of kissing butts to get ahead. Superiors are afraid of your greatness and like to keep you down if they believe you have a lot of potential to grow. A lot of overworking and underpaying. Be prepared to wear a lot of hats which can be beneficial however delegating work because you have too much work due to a chaotic business model is crazy! They are almost militant. They try blinding you with a culture like you matter when they truly have the same goal of any firm, to maximize profit. They will lead you on to believe you are doing great work but then pass you over for someone less qualified because they may be easy to manipulate. Worse thing than a boss who doesn't care is a boss who acts like they care just because they feel like it's their job. Most employees are dissatisfied and feel pressured in a lot of ways.

headline: Great Company
pros: A lot of flexibility and great management
cons: No cons at this time

headline: Changing Banking For Good
pros: Great Culture, Great Employees, Great Leadership
cons: Branch Technology does not keep up with overall bank technology

headline: Capital One
pros: Good people. Approachable management. Top of market maternity/paternity benefits
cons: Long hours and minimal work-life balance. Expected to be available at all times

headline: Great place to work
pros: Culture, ethics, mission, products, people, work/life, benefits
cons: Salary compression - If you stay with Capital One too long and are recognized for your success through promotion, eventually you will be work way more in the market than they are paying you.

headline: You either love it or hate it
pros: Capital One for the most part is  great place to work.  The West Creek Campus is beautiful and the majority of people are really kind and helpful.
cons: Performance Review time can turn the nicest people into the most competitive and sometimes cruel.

headline: Risk Specialist
pros: Fflexible work schedule. Great Benefits.
cons: Limited opportunity.   Promotion qualification for leadership roles

headline: Development Manager
pros: Very Good Company to work with
cons: I can't think of anything.

headline: Discrimination at its best
pros: You don't work on Sunday days and get paid holidays
cons: If you have a disability of any kind, please don't put your self through the Capital One treatment

headline: Supervisor
pros: good benefits and flexible schedule
cons: Favorites are played heavily and it spreads a selfish culture.

headline: Senior Communications Associate
pros: Capital One offers a good salary and benefits, but more importantly, they give their associates time during work hours to give back to the community.
cons: Many times I felt like a number, rather than a person. Emphasis was always on quantity of work.

headline: Regular Growth Opportunities
pros:
Capital One showed little hesitation to hire from a temp-worker pool, and frequently offered resources for advancement, including help to get licensed in the industry. Opportunities were often open to change departments for those who wanted to leave Customer Service.

The pay for an entry-level position was strong, and systems were in place to recognize associates with merit raises annually.

Company culture was fun and engaging; we had special events every 6-8 weeks and set aside one week a year for team-building and challenges within our department.

Capital One allowed me to add a partner to my health benefits package, despite the fact that we are not married.
cons:
Some business decisions have been puzzling. The company has decided to functionally close its office where I work and move cross-country. As a result, they are letting go many people who have more than 5 years of experience.

Certain issues my department raised got little attention or exposure. Some projects seemed to be in the pipeline for years before finally being released, despite their clear benefit. Top-down decisionmaking sometimes led to poor customer experiences.

headline: Fraud Representative
pros: Good insurance, Good amount of PTO
cons: Management, stress levels, training program not very good

headline: Best job in finance
pros: Amazing culture, puts the customer first, unlimited development opportunities
cons: After 10 years, I have no complaints

headline: Director, Information Security & Risk Management
pros: Amazing company and great benefits
cons: Uncertain leadership and lot of unplanned changes

headline: Mixed opinions after 15+ years here
pros: Lots of opportunities (outside of Richmond Va.), great investment in training, hands on technology
cons: As a female who has advanced in the company, I find the support limited the further upbi go. Yes, Capital zone has brought in female talent in the VP + lately but very few promotions from within. Not excited about a future with lots of support here past Senior manager as a female

headline: Truly a great company inside and out
pros:
Great company culture
Really care about their employees and customers
Great benefits
A lot of room for advancement, several career paths
Tuition Reimbursment
cons: Don't pick the right people managers all the time. Go off of performance instead of ability to actually manage others.

headline: Great company to work for, excellent benefits.
pros: They take care of you in all phases of life. Health benefits are the best.
cons: Not enough internal jobs in the area, wish they had more openings available.

headline: Great Company Culture and Benefits
pros: Capital One takes very good care of their employees. The incredible benefits (stock purchase plan gives you extra 15% free, 7.5% extra towards 401k if you put in 6%, focus on professional development, generous travel expensing, incredible amenities, etc.) alone make Capital One a great company to work for. Plus the business analyst role pays like a Big 3 analyst role, but hours are closer to 45 a week. The people are super nice but also brilliant, and a lot of special attention is put into the business analyst program. You also learn a lot through tons of hands on experience-- not a ton of just sitting around on the job.
cons: The company is constantly changing/developing, which can lead to a lot of reorganization and switching roles unexpectedly

headline: Sr Business Analyst
pros: Great people, interesting and challenging work
cons: Hours can get long depending on team/project

headline: Good Company to work for
pros:
You feel like home.
You grow quickly.
Many free events to celebrate the staff
Diversity in place
cons:
Old systems 
Old computers (to be changed in the near future)

headline: Capital One
pros: Strong business model with a focus on social responsibility.
cons: Career development, opportunities, and financial incentives are poorly structured.

headline: Lead teller

headline: Ample opportunities

headline: Was Really Great... For A While
pros: Training, their training, especially if you've never worked in the industry, is top-shelf! The work/life balance is reasonable, there's lots of emphasis on things like diversity and development, typically you get lots of face-to-face time with your manager. The benefits were really good.
cons: I worked in fraud for a while before everything changed--managers left, upper management changed, supplier sites which were severely under-trained were brought on. I was part of a focus group to discuss our concerns about the department and it was essentially a way for management to say, "Well, you don't understand xyz and here's why..." Lots of frustration stemmed from the fact that we felt like we were not being heard, especially given the fact that agents requested for the focus group were tenured. Additionally, the change left our direct managers stretched thin and during that time when I was also transitioning to a new department I had very little chance to discuss how that change would take place or who to report to, etc.

headline: It really depends on your manager/location...

forced distribution for performance management... more often than not your performance is based on how strong of an advocate your manager is for you 

Capital One is a different work environment based on what location you work at and where your department is primarily located 

Associates move around often internally... mostly because it is the only way to advance or not be managed out 

Capital One is a great place to work for a certain type of person.

headline: Strong culture with good perks.
pros: Many resources at your disposal to continually grow as an employee and individual (training, tuition reimbursement, health/wellness, etc.) Unified direction for most business areas; this vision enables quick alignment of priorities.
cons: Size of company generates many checks and balances, so change is sometimes annoyingly slow. Hard to fail fast, unless you're part of an agile team that oversees specific products or projects.

headline: Fun Company. Managers play favorites, standards are inconsistent.
pros: Very fun company to work in. The have lots of free lunches but those have started to become less frequent. The environment is very casual.
cons: Management likes to questionable individuals. The quality standards they rate you on are frequently unfair and change without notice. Can be very hard to keep a high employee score which affects your pay raise and bonus.

headline: n/a

headline: Not what I expected
pros:
Clear mission based business. Customer focussed.  Senior leaders give regular updates on how the business is doing.
Nice office with restaurant, free tea, coffee and hot chocolate, pool table, gym, music room, etc.
cons:
Employee performance reviews are done by ranking all employees of the same pay grade. As a result, colleagues are very unhelpful towards each other as they consider them as competition.

High staff turnover.

Whilst from the outside it looks like a very flat organisation, with VP’s and Directors sitting in an open plan office with everyone else, people are very status oriented and regularly say “X is a Principle Associate” or “Y is only a Coordinator. He shouldn’t be talking to someone of our level like that”.

headline: ok but extremely cliquey
pros: Nice working environment and some good technical guys there. some interesting projects.
cons: there is most certainly a core clique of people who create a campaign of propaganda and most certainly do not like honest opinions. If you speak your mind regards project deliverables, strategy or staff members who are clearly playing a game then prepare to have your card marked and be rounded on by the stasi "This is the cap One way" police. Long time serving staff at Cap One have been slowly brainwashed by the Capital one ethics. The one upmanship approach is encouraged, staff are passive aggressively managed out of the business if the face or opinion does not fit. Many very talented people joining from external organisations rarely stick around as they see and experience the wrath of this unhealthy culture. On the outside it looks like fun and enjoyable but underneath there is a very protective and somewhat nieve group of people who only care about how good you can make them look. Very divisive and intrinsic.

headline: They are employee focused, offer great benefits, and create a good working atmosphere.

cons: Internal technology applications are terrible, creating a lot of administrative overhead. It's a regulated entity, so there are a lot of additional processes to get deals done.

headline: Still a bank, not a technology company
pros: Management is taking some steps in the right direction to become more technology forward. Capital One also has the funds to move in that direction, and has an overall good company vision. Overall work environment was also inviting, and balanced.
cons: Unfortunately, implementation of the technology bank vision is poor. The company is wasting money hiring way too many engineers at a low bar. These engineers are then managed by non-technical managers for projects that are then randomly killed with poor leadership synchronization.

They use so much unnecessary paperhey need to go green.

- Exciting and compelling business strategy

- Resources are prioritized for digital innovations, few good roles in business operations and fewer career growth opportunities
- Performance management system disproportionately rewards heroic efforts
- Richmond VA (where the main campus is located) has few other major employers - poor job mobility

headline: Great company - what's up with Chicagoland location?
pros: Great company, great mission, great benefits (including loads of training). Lots of overarching good on the surface. Emphasis on work life balance.
cons: Can't put pulse on it but something is just not right with the Suburban Chicago (rolling meadows / atrium) vibe. Not same company it used to be ....

headline: Title Handouts
pros: Capital One encourages growth through educational programs, mentorships, and activities outside of work.
cons: Capital One as a company is great, but some managers tend to ruin the values. Examples: obvious favoritism, quid-quo-pro, and handing out irrelevant titles to people that have no experience in said titles (even technical ones).

headline: career growth and amazing benefits

Amazing benefits for full time employees, good pay for beginners. 
I loved working for this company overall. I had an amazing team. If you work hard there is room for career growth if you are willing to relocate
cons: short training time, sales goals are a tad too high, need more branches

headline: Part time teller

cons: Too many goals to meet with management being very out of touch with lower level employees. Working beyond the 20 hour a week every week does not affect your paid time off.

headline: Great benefits; as long as you're under 55.
pros: Diversity, inclusion for most minority categories, generous 401k match
cons: The  stacked ranking for performance reviews pits employees against each other and forces good employees into poor ratings when someone has to fill the lower ranks.  Also, very few people last there after age 55 - they are forced to retire, or jobs are eliminated.

headline: Unprofessional Waste of Time
pros: Benefits, The Company Overall, Incentives, Work Life/ Balance
cons: Untrained and Unprofessional Managers, Call Center Positions

headline: Data Scientist
pros: work life balance is quite good
cons: bonus is low in general

headline: Revolving Door
pros: Large company with good benefits, remote work depending on department and manager, encourages employee training, nice facilities.
cons: Constant re-orgs result in constant layoffs then hiring in different departments or locations, hence a reputation as a revolving door. Very difficult to get promoted. Cross calibrations are phony because it all depends on how your manager presents you in the meetings so you could be screwed if your manager doesn't like you or if they don't know enough about what you actually do. There is overt ageism as evidenced in the majority of the people who get laid off. Depending on department or management, you could work yourself to death with very little work/life balance.

headline: Business Manager
pros: Good work life balance, good people
cons: Limited upward mobility, lot of people are coasting!

headline: Fun place to work
pros: Loads of perks - onsite medical office, fitness club, putting green, bikes, various dining options.  Many opportunities to volunteer and join special interest groups.  Recycling program throughout the campus. Training options are endless. Some LOBs offer flexible working options and casual attire.
cons: Some buildings have wide open cubicle seating with an unhealthy noise level making it difficult to concentrate on detailed work.  Calibration style performance management is cumbersome and a motivation killer.

headline: not a very realistic company
pros: nice office environment. good equipment.
cons: this company has an unrealistic culture. they have an issue facing the truth and is either overly optimistic or overly stringent. they assess works and people not objectively but subjectively. a lot of favoritism going on and not accepting of diverse personalities. lots of bullying (offensive behaviors) going on as well without being addressed at all.

headline: Manager
pros: The All Hands Calls/Meetings are motivational to all employees
cons: Salaries are low. Management does not work as a team.

headline: Great Experience
pros: nice work environment and good pay
cons:
unorganized at times 
employees gossip

headline: New hire call center
pros: 401k match, stock options, full medical and dental, great culture, supportive enviornment. First time working at a call center and one month in Im loving it. I have never had a job where I felt like I've worked their for years in such a short amount of time. Lots of areas around the center to relax and keep our minds relaxed while dealing with the high stess enviornment. People are always ready to help when you dont know something and team building abounds! Opportunities for advancement not only in the center you work but in other states. I enjoy coming to work and so far so good!
cons: High call volume, many layers of management, short breaks, stressful enviornment not for someone who breaks easily with rude customers and non-stop calls. Must be able to mutli-task and bring enegry to every call!

headline: Teller
pros: Great work place, a lot of room for growth, great benefits even for part time employees
cons: Frequent turn over computer systems seem outdated compared to competitors, unstable management

headline: Sr. Fraud Account Supervisor
pros: Great benefits, wonderful people and perfect flexibility.
cons: For such a large company, doesn't pay enough. Salary is very cheap compared to other companies. A Lot of favoritism.

headline: Former Vault Teller
pros: Hours, meeting new people, holidays off, direct customer interaction, for me, it was my first banking experience. I learned a lot.
cons: Management plays favorites, promotions not based on most qualified, get sick used unsceduled time off you risk getting terminated. Even when you have PTO to use! This is a policy they don't tell you!  Watch your back, other employees are very dishonest. First banking experience, and I will never work in banking again. I have numerous years of customer service and management experience and was excited to transition into banking, after 2 years (2 long), I am left feeling like I just left an abusive relationship!

headline: Amazing First Job
pros:
In terms of balancing future career aspirations and enjoyment of your job, its hard to get better than the Business Analyst role at Capital One. There are a lot of growth opportunities, but at the same time I enjoy going to work everyday which is hard to say of my friend who have high growth potential jobs.

Additionally, the people are fantastic. Everyone is kind and intelligent which is the combination of people you want to work with. Also, just about all my co-workers really like their jobs, which is rare, and this helps foster a happy culture.

Also, it actually feels good to work for Capital One because the bank is really trying to help people, which is unusual for banks.
cons: Its a big company so things can take too long to accomplish. Additionally, there are lot of different types of Business Analyst roles, and there is the potential that you will end up in one that doesn't fit your skills or interests. That being said, Capital One is good about helping people rotate around the company

headline: A Job not a career!
pros: Great benefits, company activities, relief from boredom.
cons: Constant scrutiny, weekly report cards that can jeopardize your employment. You will be held accountable for things that are out of your control. If a customer is having s bad day and doesn't do backflips from the service you provide, it's your fault and you will be written up! If a customer is upset with the previous rep they talked to and they do a survey about being upset after they talked to you, you get the bad review on your record and can be written up! Three right ups for something stupid and you're fired! Be prepared to deal with pettiness and butt kissing! High turnover. On the flip side, if you work your butt off and customers refuse to complete surveys, you will go unnoticed. If you care enough not to rush a customer off of the phone, be prepared to get ding'd for long phone calls! You can't win!! If you can deal with constantly being judged and told how to do your job, this is the place for you!

headline: Great Company with some weaknesses
pros: The greatest benefits I have ever had, and other than moving to better shifts, the company treats employees great.
cons: Recruiting lies to you when offering you a job, and management continues to lie to you. You figure this out after about 6 months to a year.This is mostly in regard to the hours you will work. For example, my team was hired to work until 2:00 PM - 11:00 PM Tuesday - Saturday. We were told that all new hires must work evenings and one weekend day per week. After working there for a while you will find out that new hires get whatever shifts are open at the time. For example, many are hired 8:00 AM - 5:00 PM Monday - Friday, or 4 ten hour shifts, weekdays only. If you start on evenings, it is very hard to ever get a day shift, and even after 4 years, cannot get an early morning shift, or a weekend off. They also say metrics is what is used to get better shifts. That is not the case. Even if you are in the top 10 for metrics, better hours are almost impossible to get.

headline: Branch Manager

headline: Engineering team is led by non-engineers
pros:
Latest technologies
Good benefits
Work culture varies by team but overall good culture
cons:
Recruiters try to hire you at a level where once you join you'll realize that people with lesser skills than you are at higher levels just by virtue of being in the same place for a long time.
Inspite of their shift from being hands-off to vendors to being hands-on engineers, sr. managers and directors are all non-technical folks. This is a challenge in terms of growing as an engineer.
Pay hikes each year are measly. Promotions are not evaluated by an independent group, the people managers get together and decide and a lot of value is given to handling "visible" work and "coordination" rather than "complex" work.

headline: A year and a half in and the honeymoon continues!
pros: My colleagues have been a pleasure to work with. I feel the company rewards good performers well. Exciting work that makes me eager and motivated to be in the office with my colleagues every day. Executive leadership in my department is approachable and challenges all levels to bring ideas to the table. Truly feels like a tech culture in financial services. Work life balance is great.
cons: The meetings. Oh lord, the meetings. You will be pulled into so many meetings you will barely have time for productive work hours on some days. It's one thing if you're a value add at the table, but sometimes you're called upon to just be present for no other reason than to be present. I feel like the company needs to do a better job of addressing "the meeting problem," because it's a consistent complaint across Glass Door.

I think the branch I was in was an old branch that was still in the process of redefinition. Everyone there was old with no sense of unity, which is not the energy I witnessed as I work alongside other branches.

It's a standard 'big machine' environment, very bureaucratic and slow to get things done.  Strategically, leadership always says the words others want to hear, but very rarely back it up with actions.

headline: Don't bother being a teller.
pros: My manager and some co-workers were great, hours aren't bad. PTO is pretty good, and benefits were pretty inexpensive.
cons:
There are no longer full-time tellers being hired, so if you get hired part-time don't think you'll get a chance to go full-time. Also, the teller position is being phased out as the select service center model is being adapted to most, if not all, regions. In my branch, my schedule changed constantly. There was no way to make plans for my days off because they could change, and even as a part-time worker I had to schedule my life around this job. Lead Tellers have attitude problems and are passive aggressive. 

Guests in my area are privileged and refuse to show ID to a new person. Get used to that.

headline: Disability Benefits
pros: our benefits have always been the best!! I never had any complaints. In 2014 I was put out on disability and although my doctor wanted to take me out for a longer period I was eager to go back due to the support, willingness to help and guidance Aetna and Capital One benefit reps gave me. (Short term disability)
cons: Change in short term disability 3rd party--Fast forward 2016 I got sick again and the new company "Sedgwick" who deals with disability claims has been a nightmare causing additional strain by denying my claim and not paying. Currently I am out of work going on two months and without a paycheck to sustain my family. Needless to say this has caused additional stress and my doctor will not release me.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
- Co-workers and managers are all knowledgeable and friendly.
- Campus facilities are great
- Benefits are top-notch (BCBS Health, BCBS Vision, Delta Dental, 401(k), stock purchase program, training, bonuses, unlimited sick time in addition to PTO, + more)
- On-site health clinic available to employees and their immediate family
- Active community volunteering participation
- Campus is environmentally conscious with recycling bins throughout
- Fun campus amenities include ping pong tables, Foosball tables, video game console lounges, coffee shops, tree house, comfortable outdoor seating in relaxing environment, putt putt golf course, softball field, sand volleyball courts 
- Great food selections in on-campus cafeterias daily including subsidized healthy choices to encourage good health through food choices
cons:
- Computing environment is constantly changing due to acquisitions, consolidation, upgrades, and decommissions of systems, networks, and applications.
- Turnover in smaller, acquired banking locations can occasionally be sudden as management decides which locations to keep and which to shut down.
- Hiring process is long, drawn-out, and rigorous (but this helps to ensure a good team, so it's not really a con from the perspective of the inside)

headline: Customer Service Coordinator

This company lives for having humanity and "changing banking for good" Well there's not much humanity when you terminate someone without warning for an honest mistake, especially with Holiday's around the corner. I thought management was great until I realized that everyone is a snake, just living for a paycheck and will terminate you quick, no advocacy for their employee's but we go above and beyond to advocate for their customers. I was fired and the manager asked me "so how long have you worked here"? with a bright smile, as if he didn't fire me. People are so heartless, I would never do that to a person. You reek what you sew...remember that!

I.E. -  Do more with less....there seems to always be pressure to streamline, this does create some stress.

headline: Good company, great benefits, strange job advancement
pros:
Benefits. Capital One provides great benefits.
401k - 3% auto, 100% match of first 3% of pay, 50% of next 3%
Health equity plan - pretax deduction w/ 50% match
Stock purchase plan - match of 17.65 cents for every dollar contributed up to 15% of your salary
Free 3rd party career advising
cons:
Career advancement requires persistence, networking and timing (luck).
Where you start in the company determines how quickly you can advance. If you start as a lower level employee, growth will be slow and it is rare to skip job levels.

cons: Was forced to pretend I cared about customers and ask them about their lives. Felt forced. If you didn't get a particular number of referrals per week  you would get cited. Always on your feet.

headline: Frustrated by deeply ingrained financial institution culture; despite a lot of rhetoric to the contrary.
pros:
Plenty of capital resources. Lateral mobility. Upscale office designs. Flexible office schedules. Solid benefits.  Offices in several locations. 

You shouldn't have to worry if your paycheck will keep coming.
cons:
Very difficult to get ahead. Antiquated year end review process is designed to contain costs, not reward and retain performance and talent. Good people forced into lower bracket performance bands so target distributions are met. 

Way too much focus on perceptions.  Not enough focus on real business value. 

Very competitive environment results in people willing to submarine others for their own ambitions. Self imposed schedule pressure creates stress and diminishes quality. 

Organizational infighting. 

Way too much energy spent on recruiting instead of retention and training. 

Poor IT support often gets in the way of productivity. 

Too often, "more people" is the answer. When really, fewer, but better people would lead to superior results.  

Numerous facilities and space management issues.  You will likely move your desk at least once a year.

headline: relationship manager
pros: Excellent benefits and compensation, decent team leadership, bonus incentives and training

headline: Review 1

cons: Capital One hires very smart people.  Promotion can be tough to achieve because there is a talented workforce and the bar is very high.

headline: Capital One is a Technology Company

headline: Decent place to start

headline: Senior Associate
pros:
Most departments support a flexible work schedule, enabling you to work-from-home if necessary, and leave for appointments or family scheduling conflicts.  Most departments support and encourage a health family/life balance, recognizing the importance of family commitments and interests.

The benefits are impressive - company matching 401K contribution percentage, enables you to buy a week's worth of vacation time, most departments encourage team outings and volunteer events.  

Most people are of good intention and have good attitudes on a daily basis, making it a friendly environment.
cons:
Their performance management process is severely flawed.  Much of management abhors the twice-a-year process, admitting it is extremely stressful and upsetting.  Forced performance rating distribution mandates that your department has 'poor performers'.  Meaning, even if everyone is doing a great job, exactly what they are asked to do and they do it almost flawlessly, they still need to decide who isn't performing as good as the rest, so they can be in the lower performance bucket.  Managers either get in arguments in which one person ultimately loses because a manager isn't as an effective communicator or advocate as the others, or because a manager steamrolls the discussion and is so stubborn the opposing manager just gives up out of frustration, hence making their associate become the poor performer.  Associates rated as poor performers often have an extremely difficult time invalidating this label and perception, and are often used as the automatic scapegoat for future calibrations' low performers.  Additionally, once given this low performance rating, you are unable to move to a different role, even in cases where the manager agrees there is a job fit issue and the associate finds a more suitable role to go to.  Based on this, associates who stay in this category for too long inevitably are pushed out of the department and by default, the company (aka are fired).  This is frustrating, disappointing, stressful, usually unnecessary, and in many cases heartbreakingly unfair to the "poor performer" who is only labeled as such because someone has to be.

*note* For those wondering, no, I am not a disgruntled employee writing a review, I have been rated as Strong, Very Strong, and even Exceptional during my career in the company.  I have witness and be involved in these discussions first-hand.

headline: Great work environment!
pros:

Someone who is doing great but moved teams or is trying something new might be forced into the bottom if others in the same group have been in the team for a long time. Therefore, forced distribution is anti-diversity and anti-learning and trying something new.

cons: Got re-deployed (laid off) and was told they would do anything to help you get re-hired. Applied for at least 15 jobs and only got one interview. All of the rest, I never even got a phone call. I had to check the website to see it said candidate declined. Numerous calls to HR to find out status of applications went unanswered. Horrible HR communication. Or lack there of. Upper management is not much better. They say they'll help but then never do.

headline: SHAME ON YOU CAPITAL ONE!
pros: you can ask for ridiculous amount of salary, recommendation is negotiate for 10-20% higher than the offer. because people are quitting left right and center due some bad apples, the company is desperate for new hires. Don’t forget to ask for that signing bonus!
cons:
too much bullying... 
some people are egoistic and power hungry, where they purposely sabotage newer staffs by not including them in meetings, giving them the silent treatment, treating them like they don’t exist, not providing them with project updates, and giving them misleading information. And there isn’t only one or two of them, it is a gang of them like that. 

people are leaving or fired…
the company does a good job at hiring good people but then don’t equip them to be successful. new people get discouraged quite quickly because a lot of people go out of their way to make them life miserable. feb is bonus payout time and is when a chunk of the company leaves. when managers don’t like their direct reports they would have HR investigate them and get them fired. it is hard not to be underperforming when the odds is against you so people get fired all the time. another way is reorg-ing them out. 

weak leadership
the slt continues to try to build morale but usually ends up a bunch of people quiet in a room. you can fool the newbies but can fool everyone. turning a blind eye on the bullying issues cause of pressure to drive results. unsustainable approach.

The process that are set up are disorganized and the representatives in other departments have no clue of processes and messes up the customers account where we have to fix it and take blame for other representatives mistakes. After constant calls after calls of competencies it can be quite frustrating

headline: LOVE WHAT THE COMPANY OFFERS BUT HATE THE LIFERS!
pros: Capital One Canada is an interesting company; being a foreign branch of a top american bank, it has access to great associate development programs and training resources. They also compensate their associates above well industry standard to compete for talent in the financial services space and technology space. This company is a great stepping stone for new graduates.
cons:
There are quite a bit of lifers in middle management at Capital One Canada. These lifers are pretty much stuck and content or even happy. They get paid at less 100k base salary for delivering the quality of work of a junior consultant. Sweet Deal, Right? The chance of transitioning to a big 5 bank probably means a pay cut or running the risk of being the underperformer of a big bank. As these are lifers could only perform in a junior consultant level, the top tech firms like apple, google, amazon, etc, probably won't take them and tech startups mean getting a pay cut and doing REAL work, so NO… Staying put is probably in their best interest. They make it incredibly difficult for new hires to settle in. The turnover is pretty high, on average associates stay for least than 2 years.

P.S. A lot of the 4-5 stars are fake posts from HR. If you filter the rating from highest to lowest, you would notice that there are not a lot people find the posts "helpful" but you filter the rating from lowest to highest, you would notice a lot more people find the post "helpful".

headline: Quality Assurance

cons: Its far from where I leave, I would like to work from home and this is not available for me

headline: Competitive Pay, Growth Potential, High Pressure
pros: Competitive pay, solid benefits, great 401K.  Very supportive of development.
cons: Conflicting executive priorities, crumbling infrastructure, IT leadership is atrocious.

headline: Wonderful Benefits and Associate Focused
pros: Capital One has great overall benefits--Flex Spending, PTO, 401 k match, etc. The company is performance based, so metrics are very important and key to you being able to earn more money through salary increases, monthly/annual bonuses,  and promotions. You work hard and smart -it pays. Capital One cares a great deal about it's associates. A lot of emphasis is focused on associate engagement. I could go on and on about how wonderful it was working for this company.
cons: In my case, the biggest con would be the Year End Appraisal process. Depending on the business group you work in, you are stack ranked based on your job level with people with different job functions that may not have anything to do with what you do, For example people manager vs process manager vs operations analyst. There is a rigorous calibration process across different sites/locations to determine what your Year End Appraisal will be. Which is unfair as many of the decision makers may not know you or know what you do as they are a in a different business unit. It's left up to your manager to convince them how great you are.

headline: Intern

cons: Downsizing on employees. Normal to only have 5-6 staff in busy branches where no other branches are close. Focus is getting customers away from the branch via mobile or online transactions. Multiple job duties, no extra pay, reduction in incentives every year.

headline: Great!
pros: Flexible, great pay, great benefits. Challenging work with good focus on development. The company really makes associates feel valued.
cons: Currently going through some growing pains with acquisitions, expansions, new offices, etc that create some extra red tape and inefficiencies that are annoying.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Very fast paced and fun environment. The location where I worked had several buildings and great places to eat. I enjoyed the agile work environment. Loved having a laptop and having a choice of where I could work. I'd often have back to back meetings in different buildings. I will always remember my experience at Capital One. I enjoyed it a lot.
cons: Very fast paced environment. You have to catch on quickly! Processes were constantly changing. Just as things started to make sense and you became very good at a process, the next day you come in and everything had changed. Sometimes that included a change in management, restructuring of departments, or layoffs.

headline: Bland Culture with Mixed Values
pros: Salary is good.  Flextime and working from home a big plus.  Lots of opportunities to move up.
cons: Passive aggressive culture with a great deal of "big bank" initiatives that go no where.  Game plan changes every six months.  Churn and Burn culture.

headline: Senior Account
pros: Great Company to work for. Treats employees well.
cons: there isnt a con that i can think of.

headline: Business Analyst
pros:
- Comfortable pay
- EXCELLENT 401k and healthcare benefits
- People are nice
cons:
- ...BUT the culture is boring and robotic to say the least
- Lowest company diversity of any I've ever seen. Heavy skew of white male employees from generally privileged backgrounds operating a company for low credit customers??
- Strives to be a tech company like a cat wanting to be a dog, but is constrained by heavy regulations and underwriting investment as per financial institutions
- Unmerited inflated egos just like in other large companies
- Bureaucracy and company politics dictate the environment just like in other large companies
- Work life balance is completely up to your team, so it's all up to chance. You face both extremes at Capital One

headline: Senior Business Analyst
pros: Great company culture and employees have the opportunity to take on a large amount of responsibility at a relatively junior level. The work/life balance is better than at a lot of similar positions
cons: Your role can vary widely from one team to the next, and there are some positions that are 'better' than others, in terms of promotion opportunities, visibility, etc.

headline: Best People + Most Fun Place to Work
pros:
I joined Capital One out of university, and I haven't second guessed that decision since. It's been such an awesome place to start off my career, and when I look at my friends who graduated around the same time, most have since left their first employer or aren't nearly as satisfied with them as I am with Capital One.

A few things contribute to this satisfaction:
1) High performing culture. They hire incredibly talented and hard working people, and they foster a collaborative environment where people are incented to coach and develop others. I've always been fortunate enough to have managers who are passionate about people leadership, which is really exciting as someone new out of school.
2) Job variety. Whether you're interested in building quantitative models, designing marketing strategies, working on the Mobile App or new tech products, etc., there's an area of the business that's at the forefront of the field. I've had the opportunity to move around a handful of times, each time learning a new space and working with new people.
3) Fun. Nothing beats loving coming to work every day. The people I'm surrounded with make me laugh multiple times per day, and the formal committees within the company do an awesome job planning activities like Blue Jays games, Paint Nights, Holiday Parties, etc. Because the culture is close knit, there's also a lot of informal fun, like after work drinks, etc.

All in all, this place is pretty awesome.
cons: My biggest dissatisfier about working at Capital One is the North York office location. While it's on the subway and super convenient to get to on a daily basis, it's not as exciting as being downtown. Luckily, the office is moving downtown in 2018... and I can't wait!

When push comes to shove they are selfish and management chooses themselves and screws you over. They let go ALOT of hardworking people and employees were dropping like flies in the course of 2-3 months. They "cleaned house" as corporate would say. You have ZERO job security and when you think management has your back and can vouche for you, think again. They will be the ones to save their own butts and throw you under the bus. 
Capital One is glitz and glam and then they take it all away from you because they need "someone to fire" 
If you decide to work here, just know not to put all your eggs in their basket...

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Fairly dynamic, very smart people, often very likeable, they tend to be 'good people' with solid ethics and values. If you like the culture it's great (though it can be a little cliquey with the folks who've been around since the '90's being a tight knit group who seem to take care of each other). Very high quality work facilities, great benefits, competitive compensation packages. Emphasis on strong people management can be a good thing - the Card division is especially good at people management, they grow good people leaders there from the bottom up. Not so good at growing people managers/leaders in the functions like HR, finance, legal, etc (not sure about the Bank division).
cons:
Relentless focus on performance management and constant assessment of everyone at all times, and never ending giving of feedback can have a dark side (though it can definitely help everyone grow too). Specifically it can and does sometimes lead to a culture of nastiness, judgement, and a rigid heirarchy (because semi-annual performance appraisals are heavily influenced by committee discussions where every people manager at the next level up has the opportunity to give input both positive and negative - so there's a lot of striving to impress and never offend/disappoint anyone a step up in heirarchy). Also, people can spend their time indulging in judging others as an intellectual pastime (past the point of usefulness), rather than actually doing something meaningful - it can be an excuse for people who don't know how to get results in their own work (or who want to avoid confronting their own issues).

In fairness around the time I left that the company was starting to discuss finding ways to overcome some of these problems, and may have succeeded in the meantime. However, if you are gentle soul, who has any trouble at all taking criticism, or doesn't like being in a pretty fiercely internally competitive (although the competitiion is below the surface) environment then you may want to think carefully before moving here.

One other negative - historically Capital One has been very unplanned in having massive hiring sprees in good times, with insufficient internal controls. Then at some point they realize they've added too much overhead (either if there's an external shock in the market, or they just wake up and smell the coffee one day) and then go through heavy rounds of layoffs. As a result, especially in Richmond, Capital One has a reputation for these major reductions in force - and unfortunately this reputation has been earned. So this isn't as secure a place to work as some others.

headline: A growing and profitable company with room to improve

If you work in IT which Capital One calls Shared Technology this is a very good thin as the company invests generously in the latest technology. Also, the level of engineering talent is very good, much better than some other companies I have worked for. The pay and benefits are also above average. The Plano campus where I work is beautiful and has a number of really nice amenities ( covered parking, bikes, gym, sports fields ).  The food served at the cafe's is really good.
cons: The annual review process is overly complex and burdensome.  I have worked at other companies where managers were given much more autonomy in the review process. Work/Life balance is non-existent in my group. My manager agrees but there is not much he can do as more work keeps coming. Recently, there was a realignment and people where laid off based on location.

But regional managers and branch managers push and stress you out. They force you to turn away clients by promoting digital banking and in the evening you are asked to sit late at branch and call customers inviting them to branch to discuss product. I didn't know I signed up for an after hr call center job. Company boast about being digitally forward, may be from the client side, not internally - employees have to use more than  3 different applications which are reluctant to load ,to get customer info while customer is in front of you rushing. Break room walls are full of target and sales charts - so dont expect break in break room. You call compliance assistant or help desk  every time you are in doubt, even in front of customer which makes you look incompetent. Customer surveys are a joke. Even a tech savvy person can mistake in those stupid surveys and can put you in trouble.

headline: Capital One Intern Review
pros: There is an incredible culture at Capital One. There is a sense of really banking for good. I was blown away by how much a large company would do for their customer. Additionally, there is great work-life balance. People come in at around 9 and leave at 5. Sometimes people will work from home a little later at night, but there is no expectation to stay in the office late into the evening. Finally, the people there are great. People are very open and willing to talk to you and there is a pretty flat structure.
cons: There isn't always overlap with lines of business. It can be easy to be relatively siloed into your own line of business, but there are definitely opportunities to get to know people if you are active about it. There isn't always great integration between BAs and non BAs.

I was on maternity leave when it happened to me,  I never missed a day until my baby was born and was consistently a top performer but management accused me of fraud for an award program that they created with a $25 gift card. Now not able of being rehired as the company does not reverse, even though the manager that made the claims was terminated and another manager has confirmed that the claims against me were not valid. Breaks my heart as I saw myself making Capital One my work home for the long haul.

headline: Engineers, Dont work for this company
pros: The campus and atmosphere is very nice, but management is non existent
cons:
I was hired on through contract for 3 months contract to hire, after being on the job for a couple weeks the manager above my manager was let go. (Although I didn't meet him, I gather that he was a manager with drive that wanted to accomplish something) After that point three new full time employees were hired on the team, and the four existing contractors were let go.

Capital One's management has no plan. They hire engineers, give them no products or requirements and assume they will innovate like a startup. Upon asking for requirements from management (whom aren't located in Plano) we were directed to a manager who didn't communicate with the team. (And were told not to waste his time by scheduling meetings with him)

There were 5 people at the company that had been there longer than a year. Everyone was new and had little to no idea how things worked. Being a bank they rely heavily on "friend of friend" hiring, other than the penetration testing contractors that worked near us, no one really did any real work from what I could see

headline: Cool environment
pros: You get tons of benefits day one, solid salary, bonuses, cafeteria, on site gym, and great mobility. The management team behaves like family and truly care for their employees.
cons: There's a lot of technology around. You need your keycard to get into everything. There is no standard clock in as you use your mobile divide to clock in. Also they have one smoke pit located all the way in the back of the building.

headline: Good Benefits Bad Management
pros: Benefits are really great.  Capital One as a company encourages work/life balance and is rated high for working moms and working parents.  Working from home is popular and they have many great volunteer activities and events to make it a great place to work.
cons: Do your research and ask what the maximum salary is for the level below the one you are applying for or you may be underpaid.  Some managers are really bad and don't want to be there as they have been with the company for 15-20 years or since the company started.  If you get a bad manager it will be hard to transfer into new roles or get the support and development you need.  Although, the company as a whole supports work/life balance, there are some individual managers who do not which sucks.  There is also a lot of turnover.

headline: Highly political, not a career, says one thing and does another
pros:
- Says the right things, right values
- Concerned about costs
- Lots of new,  young people are always around, and therefore it continues to feel entrepenurial and energetic. 
- No "old" folks.
cons:
- Everything they say and value does not matter.  The only thing that matters is your manager's rating of you which is only their perception of your results and you better hope that you know where you sit at all times and that your expectations are aligned at all times!  He/she can spin "performance management" and 360 feedback anyway they want.

- Don't stay here a day over the age of 40 unless you're a VP and you're staying put in your role that you've been in for at least 10 years.

- My manager was entirely unprofessional, made comments about my weight, my religion, and regularly threatened and bullied me.

- Antiquated performance management that is no longer practiced by Microsoft or GE.  They've both matured and moved on a few years ago, yet, sadly, Capital One holds onto this terrible practice.    It gives way to politics, backstabbing, insincerity, and to ultimately 'just a job'  instead of a career.  I can promise that sooner or later  this game of "spin the bottle"  will  land on you!

There is a lot of show off, precedence but really lacks computer science part. Those people who makeup things and bluff the achievements can progress much faster. headline: Enterprise grade
pros: The resources of an Enterprise.  Why do people rob banks, right?  So the cash compensation—including signing bonus—is great.  Strongly run relative to other large entities that make money from usury (banks, credit cards)... just look at how C1 recovered from 2008 financial crisis vs Wells Fargo or Bank of America.  Stable and I think recession-proof job.
cons: For a software engineer, things are bogged down.  Use of AWS Cloud especially.  And just so much process, anonymous systems sending emails demanding compliance, etc.  They self insure, so can't get Kaiser in the Bay Area.

headline: Risk Audit
pros: Great coworker employees to work with and lots of learning opportunities.
cons:
Per several managers, 80% of Capital One employees are contractors.  When there is a layoff, full time employees (FTE) are laid off first followed by contractors.

Many new managers do not have mortgage or auto financing work experience or understanding and are hired just to increase productivity.  As we all know, each account may have conditions or issues that may take longer to resolve than others and sometimes each person will always have different numbers for the day.  If Quantity is the priority, Quality is diminished and maintaining a balance of each will always be difficult.

headline: Capital One Retention and Customer Service  Departments
pros: It was a paycheck with good benefits while it lasted
cons:
Full disclosure - I last worked at Capital One in Tampa, FL in 2004. 2012 is the last year in the drop down box. I am biased, not because of Tampa location closing, but more because of how they went about it.
My cons of working at Capital One, while I was there was there was no communication between management and employee. We also had mandatory overtime every week (still not sure if that was legal). I don't mind working overtime and usually did even before it was mandatory, but many people pushed back against it. People fell in line when jobs were threatened and a few were let go (officially for other things, not for refusing to work overtime). We never had time to breath between phone calls, usually 300 or more calls in queue. We were "encouraged" to work through our breaks and lunches. The last 12 to 14 months before the location closed became very oppressive.

headline: Relation ship Banker / Branch Designee
pros: The best part about working at Capital One Bank were the people I work with. I've have become very close and gotten to know a lot my coworkers, of whom I still keep in touch with. They made coming into work everyday a pleasure and only made me love my job more. Also loved both the atmosphere at the the bank which was always very positive and friendly, everyone would help each other regardless of our positions whenever help was needed. I also got to know a lot of my customers on a personal level and looked forward to seeing them come in. All the managers I've been lucky to have work with have all been great role models for me and I've not only learned a lot from each one of them but I've grown and it has only made me better at my job in the long run.
cons: Although there is not much I did not like about working at Capital One Bank, if I had one thing to say it would be the Sales aspect of the Bank. Although I can understand it is our job to inform  I do not like to push people to get it and at times I felt like that is what is was like. Another aspect that I would say I did not like was the goals we had to meet. However, I usually did meet my goals most of the time but then there were times I was not able to meet them, but a lot my customers were regulars so it was hard to open new accounts.

headline: Customer Service Coordinator
pros: Amazing benefits, some departments actually care about their employees, 401k match is outstanding, solid company that really tries to help their employees, gives room for out of the box solutions and most teams want to hear what their employees value, dress code is very relaxed. There are genuinely some smart and talented individuals that work there.
cons: Unfortunately Capital One has a high turnover rate for a reason -- some departments are strict in micromanaging their employees on an absurd level. You're given PTO and flex time and some managers are more lenient than others. There's definitely a lack of communication between different departments and even managers in the same department. There's too many higher ups to have one focused idea and some hardly know what to relay to their employees because it's all "he said, she said" in the office. You have to be careful who you speak about because the company is tightly knit and word travels fast. One particular manager in the High Value Servicing department only cares about herself and not her employees and unfortunately you'll find other managers like that in different departments. This manager, though, wants you to believe she cares about you but when you have a real and pressing issue, her so-called empathy disappears. Particularly, the High Value department hires upper management typically from other departments. These individuals have had little to no idea what happens in High Value and will base most decisions by the book when the department boasts transparency and reaching "outside the box." I think Capital One needs to look at how they structure their management teams and find ones that truly care about their employees. It's such a high turnover rate in that department because employees are being fed misleading information about policy and procedure regarding their work ethic and a customer's account.

headline: Great place to work

headline: Middle management needs a lot of work!
pros:
- Competitive compensation (e.g. Benefits, base, signon bonus, RRSP matching, vacation days and personal days).
- Flexible work from home options and depending on the team, good work life balance.
- Office space is brightly lit and lot's of natural lighting. Plenty of meeting rooms and collaboration spaces. Now there are standing desks and Macbooks available.
- A selection of foosball tables, ping pong table and TVs for watching games with coworkers.
- Free goodies (e.g. Tea, coffee, occasionally food).
- Plenty of committees to join (e.g. Fun Committee, Philanthropy Committee, Asian Committee).
- Casual dress code.
- Various Fun Days or company social events throughout the year.
- Coworkers are generally intelligent and hardworking. Have met some really nice people and even made some friends. People are usually open to helping and connecting with you.
- Senior leaders are friendly and relatively approachable (e.g all hands, office hours, walking around the office).
cons:
- Lot's of bullying in the office by middle management that are not addressed through HR policy or by senior management (e.g. coercion, pranks, humiliation, tolerance of inappropriate behaviour). 
- Rampant favoritism that is counter to its claims of meritocracy. Very obvious in-group and out-group dynamic. 
- 360 degree reviews are now gone so performance review is more of "he said she said" and whether you are on the good side of certain key players. 
- Managers don't know how to coach or develop. Just provides passive aggressive "advice" to keep you in check of your "development plan". 
- Everyone seems nice but will go behind your back to complain to your manager/others. No one really cares about your development like the company claims unless it helps he/she get promoted. 
- Overemphasis on the charming and extroverted personality as a factor to success. 
- Lack of focus and forward momentum in the strategic direction of the company. 
- Things are poorly documented and very poor training in general so good luck with your own onboarding!
- Pressure to spend a lot of time, whether you like it or not, to "socialize" with your peers above and beyond what is reasonable for a professional relationship. 
- Better to keep your mouth shut about issues in the workplace because it will probably get back to you and you will be the one who gets penalized (this includes the many many "employee" surveys that you are asked to fill out).

headline: Extremely good company
pros: Great medical benefits, PTO every year and paid holidays. Coworkers are for the most part really nice, capital one chooses employees that have people skills. Employees can definitely grow within the company.
cons: Hours 7:30 am to 6pm. Managers give overtime without asking if it's ok. Micro manage.

headline: Great Culture, Poorly Managed
pros:
-Capital One is a great company, they stay out of the news and are very customer focused. 
-They care about employee development and give opportunities to better one's self often. 
-One day a quarter was given for each team to have a "Fun Day" (at least while I was there they did).
cons:
-The amenities and employee engagement activities deplete the budget for raises-- my first year end raise was 0.9%, average is typically 3.0%. 
-Department Managers do not like to hire from within their teams-- they opt for former colleagues from outside. 
-Preach innovation but any idea presented to help the company is thwarted by red tape.
-Upper Management has an old-school mindset that is unwilling to mesh with today's business needs.

headline: Sr. Risk Associate

headline: Software Engineer - Good opportunities to learn technology
pros:
Technology
- Opportunities to work with new technologies, there's definitely a heavy emphasis on using  open source tools, openly encouraged to build with new instead of old. In terms of my personal experience, this includes backend, frontend, and DevOps. 
- No issues  obtaining tools you need to do your job (software, hardware). This may be team dependent. 
- People are willing to share their knowledge within the company. There are many ways to do this and it is encouraged. 

Environment
- Lots of smart people in the company with varying levels of experience. You can learn a lot from them. 
- For the most part, pretty relaxed environment. People can dress fairly casually. 
- The building itself is pretty nice, and a new one is being built as well. 
- Snacks! This might also be team dependent. 

Benefits
- Excellent 401k matching. 
- Other benefits are industry standard for the most part, but are solid.
cons:
Performance Management
- You are expected to essentially compete against other people of your level. Even if you perform pretty well for your project and your team approves of your work, it may not be enough. 

Technology
- Since there has been such a shift to use new technologies, there is a lot of change within the technology stack. If you use an application which integrates with other new applications/systems, there is definitely some growing pains and a learning curve. 
- Still in the process of updating legacy software and integrating with legacy systems. Still need some time to fully go modern in terms of the stack. 
- Agile is pushed but there still needs to be refinement in terms of how it's implemented. Not sure how different organizations handle this, but there needs to be a FULL buy in from all parties (business and tech) otherwise it leads to many inefficiencies and Agile in name.  

Environment
- Probably a case of preference, but it's mostly an open floor plan. Some people can be loud across the room and you can hear them. 
- I wish work from home was more acceptable on a regular basis. It is definitely possible to do this occasionally but it is not encouraged. This is also probably team dependent.

The result is a highly political environment where it's more about how you market yourself vs. how you actually perform.

headline: Senior Software engineer
pros: Lots of interesting projects and exposure to executives. Relies heavily on AWS for infrastructure. Company's goal is to only use open-source software.

headline: What's in your wallet?

For the purposes of clarification of my experience, I was a mid-level leader with Household Bank, then with HSBC when they purchased Household, and finally, with Capital One after they purchased HSBC's North American Cards division.  My review of Capital One is based on my experiences from the time of the Capital One purchase.

Very cliquey

cons: Advancement opportunities, promotions and recognition are majority based on favoritism/popularity.  Leadership is moved around when they are not performing but lower levels are replaced.  People are told to get their name and face out there to be promoted, recognized and advanced but not given opportunities to do so.
