headline: Great people and wonderful culture
pros: I have worked in Capital One for over two years (mostly on the bank side) and I must admit that the company has wonderful culture and great people. I have had 3 managers and all of them were great, extremely supportive and took genuine interest in employees. The talent pool is tremendous and the company strives to have a top tier consulting firm's approach in solving problems. CEO's vision to change banking for good is genuinely pursued by the management and the associates. The company also offers tremendous flexibility to its employees. Love , love, love Capital One!
cons: Very frequent reorgs can lead to a lot of inefficiency

headline: Long hours; only got 30 min lunch break, and the lead teller was a bully
pros: Free bank account that's about it I can't say anything else otherwise I would be lying maybe it was just the branch I worked for but capital one has given me a bad taste in my mouth.
cons: As a teller you can't sit down; the customers were some of the rudest people I have ever met. Especially the drivers at the drive up window they would throw their check at you and expect you to know what kind of transaction they wanted like if your'e some kind of psychic. We would always run of out 100$ bills and we had to keep our cash drawers no more than 3K. So if a customer wanted a big withdrawal we would have to wait a while until the slow lead teller decided she wanted to get you more money. The cash advance machine was ALWAYS broken,As well as the ATM machine that was on the outside of the building. But some how getting a new coffee machine was not a problem. The manager was almost never there. So the lead teller would take it upon herself to "try to run the bank" she had a nasty attitude and talked down to everyone.

headline: Beware Capital One will Lay you off!!
pros: Good benefits, good interaction with people and customers, friendly.
cons: Management constantly changes, had 4 managers in less than 8 months.  Constantly lays people off, no job security there.  pay is terrible. over 3500 employees were laid off in the last year!

cons: In your face evaluation system  a bit cut-throat at times.   Drives a bit of a wedge between teammates.

headline: AVP / Branch Manager
pros: renewed commitment to improve technology
cons: Sharp staff reductions but greatly increased goals.

headline: Company Review
pros: Excellent management team. Professional and friendly working environment. Employees are recognized when they perform a good job.
cons: Some supervisors go by the book, at times, some do not communicate well with certain employees.

headline: Director of Customer Valuations
pros: Large scope and significant influence on the business
cons: Low resources and increasing governance requirements

headline: Customer service coordinator
pros:
Work from home 
Great benefits package from start of job 
4 weeks vacation time after 3 months 
Friendly management and teams 
Great pay rate
cons: No room for advancement for work from home opportunities beyond call center customer service rep.  Last minute changes.

headline: Good company
pros: Good vision and management support
cons: Competitive and long hours for most

headline: relationship banker
pros: the benefits are great at this company, there are different departments you can move to if you desire. I worked there for over 10 years
cons: I would like for the company to reduce the amount of paper they use in the branches. I would be nice to have more things done on the computer to reduce the paper in the branch.

headline: Operations Production Coordinator
pros: Great benefits, pay, work environment and culture.
cons: The only con is that they do not have an office in the city where I relocated.

headline: Principal Anayst
pros: Flexible work environment, good benefits
cons: too many analyst profiles, low pay

headline: Decent Company
pros: Pay was ok, flexible work schedule, benefits, PTO days accumulate so you could earn a lot of vacation time
cons: Closing branches, removing tellers, not a great place for advancement. its about who you know and not how hard you work if you're looking for a promotion.

headline: Good starter banking job
pros:
Good salary
Nice management 
Good benefits
cons:
Need better training 
More Mobility opportunities 
Better technology

headline: Review
pros: Great facilities.   Opportunities to learn new skills through excellent training options.  Capital One hires smart and capable people who are driven to succeed.   Implementing Agile methodologies.
cons: Performance Management process is inconsistent

headline: Associate Creative Director
pros: some very smart people. decent salary and benefits
cons: Heavy politics and lack of respect for experience

headline: Customer service coordinator
pros: Capital itself has great values and great benefits. I worked from home for 5 years and loved it.
cons: No room to move up within get the company I was in the same position with the same schedule for five years they tell you there is operator ty for growth wishing but there isn't.

headline: Loved working with the people there
pros: People, games, days off, out of office activities, luncheons, monthly bonuses
cons: Not many cons. Extremely strict on time management. Many different management styles wanting same results.

headline: Great Company
pros: Great benefits, diversity, opportunity to grow.
cons: depending on the manager, may not have as much opportunity for growth

headline: Merchant Help Desk Analyst
pros: I worked here for more than three years, It is the best company to work for.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Senior Recruiter
pros: Benefits, life at capital one
cons: I don't have any, I love it here

headline: Good start
pros: benefits, tuition reimbursement, friendly customers, friendly coworkers
cons: Work-Life balance is poor, long hours, coworkers complain

headline: enjoyed the experience but it could've been better
pros: It was a good learning experience I enjoyed getting to work for a fortune 500 company, it was a job that led me to different opportunities
cons: management can be a little wonky, where they will not tell you if you are making errors just fire you on the spot which is unfair to contractors.

headline: great Agile experience
pros: Very good Agile process in place.
cons: No work from home option

headline: Compliance
pros: Good benefits and work/life balance.  An industry leader in investing in staff development, training and certifications.
cons: Too many layers of management.  Seemingly disingenuous attempts by top management to understand and connect with lower levels.  Driven to geographically centralize compliance jobs to headquarter office, which is career limiting for those wanting to live and work outside of the DC area.

headline: Sr. Director
pros: Outstanding, fast paced culture.  On the cutting edge of technology.
cons: Reorganization are not often well managed.

headline: Business Analyst
pros: The pay is reasonable and people are nice to work with. The work culture is very good and congenial.
cons: The company does not seem to have a strategic direction as to where it is heading. It seems to be trying too many things, which in my opinion is leaves the people who work on these things high and dry

headline: Overall, Pretty good
pros: pay, ability to learn beyond your role, mission-centric regarding innovation
cons: hr practices - 6mo blackout rule for posting to other positions if you apply, interview, but do not get a job, almost constant transitions (people going to new roles and people being "redeployed"/laid off), diversity

headline: Senior Operations Representative
pros: Great company benefits, amenities and culture. Management is very easy to approach regards to workplace policies and procedures and most esp fairly advocates to employees welfare and concerns
cons: Salary increase is somehow slow esp if already nears the cap or threshold for a specific employee level or role.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Great culture and people. Parking in Wilmington is paid for by Capital One.
cons: If you want to move your career forward you will need to work out of either the VA or TX locations

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great Work life balance and you work w brilliant people.  Easy to change roles.  High performance is typically rewarded.  Beautiful campus
cons: Layoffs are routine.  Can have a country club feel.  Most departments have their own culture so it is important you are a good fit for the given culture

headline: Inside Sales 360
pros: Met some great friends through training. Everything else was a nightmare.
cons:
Company did not pay out commission during one month because of an "error" in their system. 
Mid Level Managers barely have high school diplomas and are some of the worst and dumbest human beings I've ever met.
70-80 calls back to back per day because of simple inefficient procedures.
Be prepared to walk senior citizens through finding the internet for 8 hours a day

headline: Master Software Engineer
pros:
- Excellent work culture, Awesome environment and nice people overall
- Good pay and benefits
- Lots of give aways
cons:
- The management doesn't have clear strategy
- No transparency

headline: Customer Service Rep
pros: Fun staff, great benefits, flexible hours, pay is good, vacation time.
cons: Customers are priority allowing them to be right when not right is a rule with Capital One, Lacks backing up employee

headline: Do not work here - especially not in tech
pros: The negatives out-weigh the positives in every way. They waste time while talking about "not wasting time". They applaud time at the company with complete disregard for ability to manage and Capital One dips itself consistently into technology that they have no idea what to do with. They do have a great work from home policy on occasion depending on who your manager is but they re-org so often that it's hard to have consistency.
cons:
Pay is not good, normally they try to sell you on a yearly bonus that is a range that they make impossible to attain the top dollar of.Capital One is a true example of management styles that are stuck in the past. They have weak people in management positions taught by the bureaucratic environment that sticking up for their employees is not worth it. They have lost numerous people (who are great employees) simply due to policy and weak management not willing to stand up to precedence for team members. 

Capital One presents itself as a technology savvy bank. However I can only attribute this presentation to the marketing department because within the technology departments I worked in the people in charge had no understanding of their products or the technology necessary to produce quality. They would fully staff teams before they even procured new software that these teams were planned to work on. The amount of waste is really overwhelming. I would advise going to another company if you want to be challenged. If you prefer to coast then this place is perfect.

headline: Work Culture
pros: Cool with Fast pace - I like working with capital one financial services
cons: changes are being made fast and random sometime it is difficult for teams to adopt

headline: The Best so Far
pros: professional people, the culture is the best i had experienced, the company is trying its best to make us happy by keeping the work environment at its best. they do listen and everyone is encouraged to share their ideas. flexible work time they even offer an option to take leaves without impacting your work performance. great work benefits.
cons: the pay is low. other companies offer considerably higher rates. i hate the how slow our system is. i dont know why but it feels like im using a computer

headline: Great Culture, but People are Always Running Late to Meetings
pros: great culture, they foster an attitude of gratitude, they make effort to promote work life balance/flexibility.  You get to wear jeans to work as long as they don't have holes in them.
cons: wannabe tech company that's still considered a financial services/banking company, way too many meetings, associates and leadership cannot handle negative feedback.

headline: Company Review
pros: Great company to work for. Great pay. Great culture. Great incentives. Tuition Reimbursement was provided. Benefits are provided starting on the first days.
cons: I am in the call center and they almost make it impossible for you to move up and excel. There are alot of politics and its all about who you know.

headline: great place to work
pros: smart employee, open culture, facility is new and beautiful, great training program, cafe is nice, I like the bikes on campus
cons: pay is not very good

headline: Credit
pros: Fun work environment and company-wide meetings with CEO
cons: Management is reactive as opposed to reactive

headline: Risk Coordinator
pros: Good place to work if you have no collection  experience.  Get your experience and go work for another company
cons: Over worked and under paid  very little pay raises

headline: good environnment, nice people
pros: good benefits, profit sharing, rrsps
cons: shift bid, difficult to use personal days, and vacation

headline: Eh
pros: You make connections fast, lots of fun, themed days, VTO, PTO, opportunities to transfer
cons: Pay and raises were not based on experience. They were tired and based on entry, while there were plenty of opportunities to transfer, it was as if you had to kiss your manger's behind and rub their feet to move up. Lots of reorganization and lay offs

headline: The company is on the right track to becoming a digital leader
pros:
Capital One is dedicated to becoming a digital leader within financial services. 

Pay and benefits are fair.
cons: The company's different lines of business are not well coordinated, creating disconnected organization. The leaders of the lines of business are hit and miss.

headline: Great Place to Grow
pros: Lots of opportunity for growth, good work/life balance, decent pay, high company morale, great sense of ethics
cons: Somewhat slow to change

headline: Fraud Detection Coordinator
pros: Great company to work for
cons: They close the site in Oregon

headline: Principal Learning & Development Specialist
pros: Great Benefits, stable/growing, diversity, digital - building foundation and developing associates' knowledge and skill, professional growth, fun campus, culture of learning
cons: The pace of change can be a challenge to keep up with,  Somewhat challenging to get through all levels of approval to get things done.

headline: Good pay/benefits but less and less enjoyable workplace
pros: Good pay. Good Bens. Ample PTO. On site gym and cafeteria. Nice front line managers and supervisors.
cons: Too much back and forth on policies and practices. To many "experimental" and "trial" changes. Upper Management always talks about how we need to embrace change and expect it but seems to make changes without regard for how it impacts agents and front line management.

headline: Great company
pros: Great co-workers and benefits. Lots of training and classes available.
cons: Takes a long time to promote within

headline: Good Company
pros:
Great benefits and pay
It's like a big family
Very relaxed and not very stressful
Several opportunities to move up
cons:
Schedules aren't good at all
Barely ever has shift bids
No part-time positions

headline: Look past the Sugar Coating
pros:
Onsite gym 
Healthcare- moderately priced coverage
Culture
Bank Holidays
Paid Time Off 
Café Onsite 
Paid Military leave for training/ Differential Pay
Education Reimbursement
cons:
Basic Call center issues make this position difficult: like only being allotted a certain amount of time to use the restroom. That is just the nature of a call center. Capital one does at least try to make the cubical experience engaging. They have games and contest consistently going on. Capital One advertises itself as :A work place that is extemely focused on its employees work/life 
balance
 Tis  is NOT true.To explain this I will have to share my personal experience here. When I was hired but Capital One I was told that schedule changes are common and that I would likely have the opportunity to change my schedule within the next 3-6months.
I was not worried about the schedule at the time, but it was comforting to know I worked somewhere so flexable. 
soon after I was hired my husband recieved an offer to move to a better position at his job- but it would put him in a conflicting schedule. 
We were not hesitant for him to switch at the time: because I would soon be have the oportunity to switch my schedule right?- WRONG. I have been employed for a year now. 
I request a schedule change nearly
 everyday from my coach. I have been doing so for over 6 months now.
I see my husband maybe 6hrs during the week. During our weekends my
husband and myself have committed ourselfs to serving in the Military. I have communicated that this is very difficult, as I cant even seem to find time to squeeze in conversation about bills, or building a family.
Every time I mention a schedule change I feel it falls on deaf ears. I have seen others schedules change, and everyone that was in my hiring class has had the ability to change thier schedule long ago. There is no system for schedule changes- it doesnt matter if you preform, or are a more senior employee. I have seen non preforming, and  recently hired employees be offered options to change thier schedules. I know that there is no system in place, because I have asked: so that I myself could meet those requirements. I had a coach suggest I fake a school schedule that would allow them to change my work schedule. 
It seem ridiculous that the schedule is "not avalible" but if Im willing to lie about it then it is. 
The other issue, is moving up.
In the call center in order to move positions you have to hit specific sales percentage for a certain amount of time. It makes it very easy to move up: if you apply yourself to sales. However, it also means the guy that sits next to you and comes in late half the time may get promoted before you: if he sells more. So its not based off of the employees preformance as a whole, but rather who is better in sales. It is a sales position, not a customer service position. If you understand that then you will be fine. 
Capital One over all has good benifits and the overall culture is pretty upbeat. Howerver I find that the position and the company was misrepresented to me during the hiring process. I suggest doing careful research of whatever position you are consisdering with CapitalOne. I would not recommend a friend to work in this position.Basic Call center issues make this position difficult: like only being allotted a certain amount of time to use the restroom. That is just the nature of a call center. Capital one does at least try to make the cubical experience engaging. They have games and contest consistently going on. Capital One advertises itself as :A work place that is extemely focused on its employees work/life 
balance
 Tis  is NOT true.To explain this I will have to share my personal experience here. When I was hired but Capital One I was told that schedule changes are common and that I would likely have the opportunity to change my schedule within the next 3-6months.
I was not worried about the schedule at the time, but it was comforting to know I worked somewhere so flexable. 
soon after I was hired my husband recieved an offer to move to a better position at his job- but it would put him in a conflicting schedule. 
We were not hesitant for him to switch at the time: because I would soon be have the oportunity to switch my schedule right?- WRONG. I have been employed for a year now. 
I request a schedule change nearly
 everyday from my coach. I have been doing so for over 6 months now.
I see my husband maybe 6hrs during the week. During our weekends my
husband and myself have committed ourselfs to serving in the Military. I have communicated that this is very difficult, as I cant even seem to find time to squeeze in conversation about bills, or building a family.
Every time I mention a schedule change I feel it falls on deaf ears. I have seen others schedules change, and everyone that was in my hiring class has had the ability to change thier schedule long ago. There is no system for schedule changes- it doesnt matter if you preform, or are a more senior employee. I have seen non preforming, and  recently hired employees be offered options to change thier schedules. I know that there is no system in place, because I have asked: so that I myself could meet those requirements. I had a coach suggest I fake a school schedule that would allow them to change my work schedule. 
It seem ridiculous that the schedule is "not avalible" but if Im willing to lie about it then it is. 
The other issue, is moving up.
In the call center in order to move positions you have to hit specific sales percentage for a certain amount of time. It makes it very easy to move up: if you apply yourself to sales. However, it also means the guy that sits next to you and comes in late half the time may get promoted before you: if he sells more. So its not based off of the employees preformance as a whole, but rather who is better in sales. It is a sales position, not a customer service position. If you understand that then you will be fine. 
Capital One over all has good benefits and the overall culture is pretty upbeat. However I find that the position and the company was misrepresented to me during the hiring process. I suggest doing careful research of whatever position you are considering with CapitalOne. I would not recommend a friend to work in this position.
I expect the sugar coat that is lavishly put on the job you will be preforming is a big reason why there is such a high turnover rate in this position.

headline: Work at home swap my card agent
pros:
work from home
variation of shifts available
pay
cons:
no room for growth
supervisor that are no as attentive as they should be

headline: Senior Business Analyst
pros: The work is great, you are given lots of responsibility and the opportunities for growth and learning are spectacular.  The company has a good vision and strategy.
cons: The company is not great at executing.  Processes are archaic intertwined and getting anything done requires lots of effort.  It is like moving a barge upstream with a single under-powered tug boat.

headline: Good Place to work
pros: Led by founder CEO, it has a mission to change banking. The company is very flexible in terms of work hours. The benefits are designed to provide maximum return and use for employees. 'Fintech' and startup mindset prevails in many areas!
cons: There are no cons as such.

headline: Segment Lead, Marketing Operations
pros: Capital One was a great working experience. The people are collaborative, the West Creek campus is beautiful (tree house and all), they truly "get" the mobile work environment and promote it, and processes are mostly clearly defined (at least more so than you would expect from such a giant organization), communication is open and honest, and they take the time to train mangers how to lead mindfully.
cons: As with many large corporations, there is a LOT of process to learn to get even the smallest item into market, and this takes a whole lot of time and meetings to accomplish. So it can be a bit frustrating moving at a snails pace. The organization was trying to become more Agile in it's digital development, but still had a bit of a hike to get there (and they might be there by now). Also, because of some development programs and the large number of contractors, your team changes constantly, sometimes mid project - so this can slow progress some as well.

headline: looking
pros: great people to work with
cons: was downsized every year end

headline: Great place to work
pros: It is a meritocracy - you get what you put in. Smart people to work with. Empowered. Good benefits and culture is great too!
cons: Many reorgs. Very matrixed organization. There is a Capital One "way" of doing things that you need to figure out and get used to!

headline: Great Benefits!
pros: Great benefits: medical, vision, dental, 401k, PTO, Paid Holidays
cons: More into NEW technology (e.g. mobile deposit,bill pay, ATM transactions)

headline: Commercial Credit Analyst, Multifamily Finance
pros: Office Culture/ Environment, always something new to learn, fast and fun environment. Great exposure to the multifamily/ agency finance platform, along with the fixed income in its entirety
cons: Some of the admin tasks should fall on the processors. A lot of the culture is wrapped around 'drinking the punch', but all in all, its a very positive environment and I think it supports growth overall, so all good.

headline: Boring job, great company
pros: Great company, caring managers that really seem to care about you and your personal and professional development
cons: Very routine, can be stressful. The hours can be long.

headline: Great company to build a career with great benefits
pros: Yearly bonus and pay raise available based on performance review. Great benefits with many options, a gym available on the same floor. Work from home 1-4 days a week depending on your level of progress and expertise. The senior directors are very open and honest about where the company is going and constantly touch base, provide uplifting and motivational books they've reviewed and speeches, motivate employees to speak up, dare employees to find ways to make the company better, more efficient, and effective. The company is always improving. Career advancement opportunities. Feels like a family. Did I mention work from home!?
cons: Salary is low. The new hire process is difficult (learning curve is very high and training takes 10+ weeks because everyone is so over tasked they have to give that much time to ensure the new employee can handle the work load when released into "the wild.")

headline: I love you all
pros: Capital one Is an awesome employer. They love and care for their employees like family
cons: Not very flexible with scheduling

headline: Initial
pros: Great pay, work life balance and very dynamic culture.
cons: Regulatory environment, still banking, and slow to change certain practices

headline: All In
pros: Provides great benefits and flexible schedules
cons: Not a lot of diversity in upper management

headline: C1 Review
pros: Great vision.  Great community and work life balance.
cons: Salary low for tenured associates.  Diminishing career advancement opportunites

headline: Ok for a resume building
pros: Good benefits. Can promote from within if you have the drive. Good training. Mainly encouraging managers.
cons: Bloated corporate policies that do not take into fact individual situations which can lead to easy firings. You are only a number in the end.

headline: Best company
pros: Great training development programs, customer-centric mission, and smart people all around
cons: despite a lot of investment in technology the core platforms for many of of the banking functions still leave a lot to be desired

headline: Risk Coordinator
pros: Good place to work. Good benefits. Lots of different departments to work in. Variety of schedules to work. Pay can be good to great depending on your willingness to work. Have some great managers who care about their employees.
cons: Claim to have open door polices but it depends on your manager. Trend has been cutting back on the number of employees and departments for the last 3 years since they purchased the company from HSBC.

headline: Great benefits. Poor organization.
pros: Excellent benefits and 21 days of PTO. Ability to be promoted quickly...if you play the game correctly. They love your feedback...as long as it's in agreement with their opinion.
cons: They aren't a fan of people who ask to many questions. They treat retail banking as an after thought. They purposely create situations that allow them to justify not giving someone a raise or minimizing that raise.

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Many opportunities for lateral movement. Excellent facilities in Richmond. Beautiful campus. A variety of interesting problems and challenges. Data & logic oriented culture.
cons: Managed distribution on appraisals creates a divisive work environment. Company is caught between being a bank and fin tech.

headline: SR QA Analyst
pros: Good place to work with
cons: Less compensations and more stress now a days

headline: QA Manager
pros: One of the Best Companies to work for with one of the Best Job Cultures in the industry.
cons: Very Fast Pace for a few people

headline: low Salary
pros: good company culture, nice working spaces
cons: low salary for associates who work their way up, frequent layoffs

headline: Teller 1
pros:
Incentives for referrals. 
Great benefits
Paid holidays
cons: The need of the business surpasses any family priorities you may have

headline: Formerly great company, going through some transformation challenges
pros:
There is incredible talent in the organization (although a lot has been run off in the past couple of years) that if we could better align it we could truly achieve great things.
With that said, even despite management mis-steps we continue to be successful.
Work Life balance and overall flexibility is awesome.  
Cultural values are great (when they are adhered to.)
cons:
Pursuit of being  a 'technology company' has been costly without the return expected; we now are paying huge amounts to 'buy' talent who have not delivered nearly to the level we are investing in them
Like many companies, as Capital One has grown it has become highly political;  Company is still run by ex Card Marketing people who have very little digital or technology acumen but they are the ones supposedly turning us into a 'technology' company.  And they continue to drive more layoffs yet interestingly none of them have been impacted.

headline: Retail Bank
pros:
great colleagues
interesting clients
great neighborhood
pretty branch
cons:
long hours
worked overtime every week

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Very open and collaborative, Fast-paced, innovative
cons: Cut-throat and very hierarchical. Hard to move internally.

headline: Teller
pros:
- Friendly environment
- Career Opportunities
cons: - Stigma with banks is apparent with many customers who are shy away from bank products

headline: Great company
pros: The culture is amazing the people are amazing
cons: No cons for the company

headline: Great work life balance and great company!
pros: Truly a great company that is trying their best to innovate and provide customers with a positive experience. A lot of companies preach that they are focusing on customers needs and wants but never really do, its just marketing. Capital One has really invested heavily in user research and development of new technologies to change the way they do business.
cons: It is a very large company with lots of legacy systems. It takes time, energy, and patience to be successful. There are no quick solutions, you have to plan, convince, and really drive your agenda each day.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Very driven atmosphere. I launched my career with Capitol One and it was a great stepping ston to propel me into my next job.
cons: Very demanding. Meeting your numbers is crucial and can be very stressful at times.

headline: Good company
pros: Challenging and ever changing work. Very fast paced with a good team environment for the most part. Great money for the position and lots of hours.
cons: The management was always around to help deal with the social issues that arose frequently. Need to make sure they treat the interns with the right level of respect.

headline: Teller
pros: The pay is good but everything else sux.
cons: bad management- this place really sux

headline: Very Aggressive and Agile
pros:
Get to learn new tools and technology.
Despite being a bank its working style is that of a Tech company like Google or any other for that matter.
They religiously follow the Agile best practices and latest industry standards/processes emphasizing more on free ware tools & softwares
cons: You never know when you'll get fired.

headline: Manager
pros:
*There is an assertive effort to stay ahead of the industry, which means things change quickly and stay fresh.
*Messages are consistent from "the top" to your immediate manager.
*The company not only preaches "doing good", it actively seeks to change actions and perceptions of the banking/credit card industry to one that helps its customers.
*Pay and benefits are fantastic.
cons: *Things can change quickly, which means you have to work to stay on top.

headline: Great company to work in IT.
pros: Great place to work. Great health benefits, stock purchase, bonus, work environment. Flexibility in work and great growth apportun itineraries.
cons: Fat layer of middle management . Slow to make changes. Lot of employees turnover year to year and frequent layoffs.

headline: Enjoyed working there
pros: I worked their as result of Capital One acquiring my employer.  The company I worked for paid below market wages and provided large bonuses.  Capital One came in and level set our salaries to the Capital One salaries, providing most workers with significant raises.  Great benefits
cons: No real cons however the company I worked for had a different culture that made it a point of differentiating itself as not a typical financial institution.  This perception changed with the public after our acquisition.

headline: Excellent Work Life Ballance
pros: The people, the environment, the autonomy and the excitement of getting to work on interesting projects
cons: constant reorgs, consolidations, etc. especially after buying several banks and credit card portfolios.

headline: Sr.Unit Manager
pros: Great benefits, the 401 K is non like no other. The vacation days that are earned over time are the best. Great opportunity to advance within the various lines of businesses.
cons: Too many changes at the top of the leadership board. There is a disconnect when it comes to the information that is shared with the lower level managers and associates.

headline: Fraud Intake
pros: Good Pay, Great Management.
cons: Hours of operation.

headline: Great Company, But Management......
pros:
- Benefits
-Co-workers
-401k Plan
-Health benefits
-Employee assistance Program
-Discounts with Perks
cons:
- Employee who get hired after me, as a teller, get more pay then the Older Employees in the   Branch.
- Manager Micromanaged us, for Customer Service Score and Sales.
- The amount of hard work we do, it hard to move up.

headline: Kind hearted and good banking organization
pros:
- Management's vision is so great, especially CEO
- Nice company to work
- work life balance
- good onsite facilities
- WFH options in some projects
- Technically strong people
- Opportunity to learn new buzzing technologies
cons:
- low pay
- professional growth chances are less
- politics
- weak HR 
- Manager centric

headline: Great Pay, Great Benefits!
pros: They have a fantastic culture where feedback is highly valued. The agents receive feedback weekly (at minimum), and agents are welcome to give opinions at any time to their immediate manager or senior managers. This was the most "fair" company I have ever worked for. They always erred on the side of the employee.
cons: The only downside was that Capital One moved the majority of their call center business offshore, and they closed our entire site (almost 1,000 jobs were eliminated). However, I have no hard feelings. The company really took care of us till the very end.

headline: Data Analyst
pros: It is a great place to start your career and learn new skills. Company provides freedom to explore and grow in your career. Capital one is growing more on the Big Data Analytics,which will bring more insight and access to data.
cons: Salary rate does not very much with location and no room to negotiate

headline: Senior Manager Software Engineering
pros:
The Technology organization remade itself over the past few years and is now competing with elite tech companies for talent.

Competitive pay.

Smart people.

Diverse technology and lots of opportunities for lateral moves.

Great place for people with 0-10 years experience.

Innovation is encouraged by most managers.
cons:
Advancement opportunities are very constrained for the senior ranks.  (Probably because few senior people leave the company voluntarily)

Performance appraisal process creates bitterness and unhealthy competition between peers.  The company stresses the value of 'team' but the performance process is directly opposed to it.

People who are good at appearing to contribute rather than actually contributing are richly rewarded.  If you want to excel here, make sure you pat yourself on the back in front of the directors.

headline: Wasted years at Capitalone
pros: Work life balance was good. Gym was really wonderful and healthy food options were available. There were some interesting, intelligent people working in the company.
cons: Capitalone does not care for career growth. Does not matter how much money I made for Capitalone, I did not get promoted. Sometime I felt racial bias. You would see highly qualified people with MBA, consulting experience doing poorly in the year end calibration process whereas no nothing white undergrad is treated as the master of the universe. Then your manager gets changed every 3-6 months. Capitalone is good as a starting place but one should not stay there more than two years. I made the mistake of staying there close to 4 years and I could not get back those years..

headline: Serious koolaide drinking required
pros: Benefits are great. Campus amenities are superior. Overall organization's mission towards the customer being the #1 priority is honorable and inspiring, and the perspective lives throughout the company. Bonuses are very generous. Compensation is average.
cons: Advancement is extremely difficult, as it requires a heavy amount of politics and a to have a particular personality type. If you make it to the next level, you are placed into a stretch role, which means you aren't promoted technically for a year. There are 3 levels for every one compared with most companies in the industry, so these are baby steps. You must have a very high energy level and communicate a certain way to be successful. Lots of buzz words.  Highly competitive. Lots of hype, not as much is actually accomplished compared with the intensity. There is an overly zealous focus on several different forms of documentation. Several groups work on the same solutions at once and may the first to deliver a mediocre presentation win. Culture caters to 20 somethings, and not many are older than 40. If you are over 40, and like to get things accomplished and be recognized in anyway for your work, the environment will be tough coming in from other organizations.

headline: The Truth..
pros: Hands down, it's the people. Capital One does a great job with diversity and inclusion. You work with all kinds of different people from all over the world and it's very rewarding.
cons: Overworked and underpaid is an Understatement. Call center managers are piled on and piled on and expected to balance entirely too much. The "free thinking" culture that is promoted is only a dream in the call centers. We are walking on egg shells each day as to not make a mistake and be "marked" by upper management. If your opinion doesn't match upper management, you get "redeployed". You are scheduled for mandatory meetings, some of which are all day long and then they send a survey out asking if you are visible to your team. It's an extremely stressful situation to work in.

headline: A Mission to Believe In
pros:
1. Rich Fairbank is someone that has a vision for his company, a plan you can get behind, and a set of values that are actually present throughout the company. This attitude and passion flows (not trickles) down throughout management. I am the bottom of the totem pole, and everyone above me has "spit flying" passion about the company and their job. "Change banking for GOOD" is a real thing.

2. I have had my career nourished since day one. The   People here genuinely want you to be successful. The performance evaluations are not only fair, but insightful.

3. The resources -personal and professional- are vast and GROWING! 

4. The culture is genuine, inclusive, and is ever present throughout the company.

5. The pay and benefits are goooooood. And the company actually believes in work-life balance.

There are more but I felt like a top 5 would be enough.
cons: There are some growing pains as new technologies are being conceived and adapted. Some of the legacy systems are unintuitive, and take some time to learn. Once you do they are adequate, though sometimes feel inefficient.

headline: Capital One - A great place to work (generally)
pros: Overall Capital One is a great place to work.  At least in the Richmond tri-cities area, they are near the top of the list in compensation and benefits (including a very generous bonus each year based on performance, training/certifications, and health options - free health consultants and discounted gym memberships).  Furthermore, because there is constant change  (which I've also listed as a con), if you don't like what you're doing, you don't have to worry about doing it very long!  Finally, Capital One allows, and even encourages, lateral movement across the organization.  Many people move from technology roles to business/operations roles and vice versa in order to gain a holistic view of the company and to find their niche.
cons:
Like many fast paced companies, there are constant reorgs at Capital One,  and you should expect to be shifted around a couple of times a year.  While this allows for growth to those who embrace it, it can be a bit unsettling at times and keeps many on edge around the security of their job.   If you can accept that change is inevitable and that job security is a myth in the 21st century, then you will be fine.

Because of the competitive salary and benefits, Capital One has a stringent and somewhat difficult performance management process that consumes about a month of the year each year (at least for people managers).  This involves calibrating associates (often in different role types) - often an apples and oranges comparison that can seem somewhat unfair.  As such, there is little room for "individual performers" who do not display strong leadership qualities.   Again, once you understand and accept the process, this is not an issue.

headline: Relationship Banker
pros: Capital one is big on career development and making sure the employees achieve their career goals
cons: potential digital banking changes that are coming

headline: Depends on your Reporting Manager
pros: Good Benefits, on site cafe, great training opportunities, lots of fun activities on and off campus,
cons: Lot of H1B, Tendency to Hire H1B and fire citizens or GC holders. Last year, COF laid off a lot of people but I don't believe a single H1B employee was affected at least not in Plano. Loan Servicing technology middle management is made up of ex-WIPRO employees with no prior experience to working for a US based company resulting in Managers who don't know the ABC's of management. I have seen Managers talk down to people,shout at people in meetings (especially at contractors who cannot fight back), be condescending and just downright rude. Lot of politics. You need to suck up if you have to get ahead or even get a good rating. Employees are constantly compared to their peers which hampers team spirit. There are other divisions in the company where things are much better than what it is in Loan Servicing IT. There were multiple management changes and each VP brings with him/her an idea of  what technology we need to use. This results in Engineers having to become jack of all trades and master of none. If someone cannot keep up with learning new tech every 6 months, then your mgr will get the chance to give you a negative rating, either forcing you to quit the company or fire you so they can hire a H1B.

headline: Proceed With Caution
pros:
No commute 
Decent Pay
Benefits
They provide equipment
cons: Everyday things change with no warning and you are left to deal with angry customers on your own. The company has no idea what NPS really is when bigger companies such as Apple doesn't use that to coach agents they use CSAT (customer satisfaction).  The customers will give agents 100 across the board but not promote company because they outsource jobs or change made to rewards program but yet it's the agents job to fix them. A joke! Your family does not matter in order to get your schedule changed they give a set of criteria then change it during selection process to meet the needs of the favorites. No morale boosters oh and don't live two hours away if your internet goes down you are expected to come on site to work and won't be reimbursed for travel. The things you learn in training won't be used when you start production. Hours are not great for parents especially with small kids. Monday's Tuesday's Friday's and Saturday mornings are the busiest. Most time there is only a few seconds between each call.

headline: Customer Service Representative: Onboarding

"Demonstrating leadership skills," was vital for advancement, but said demonstration required more work with no compensation other than oblique, non-committal promise for the chance to be promoted. There was no clear path for advancement , only a clear path for potential recognition.

headline: Good place to work overall

headline: Great culture, great opportunities

cons: There are a lot of reorgs that make it feel hectic, some times. I believe there were five or six, in various parts of the company, in the two years I've been here.

headline: Great place for tech.
pros: Always stays on bleeding edge of tech. Flexible work and nice people to work with. They seem to care about the community
cons: Review system is flawed. Very hard to get promoted. They make you set a target then just move it. Makes you feel like you can never achieve a goal.

headline: Senior Director
pros: Cool vibe/culture. Very un-financial services...in a good way.
cons: Some pockets of questionable talent in brand area.

headline: Top 100 Best Company to Work for 10 Times!
pros:
Capital One is in a class of it's own. They are a Fortune 200 Company that has been awarded the prestigious Fortune Top 100 Best Companies to Work for 10 times. In addition, Capital One is a top 25 best companies to work for in the Dallas/Ft. Worth market. Amazing things are happening here from driving cutting edge technology to providing a superior service to our customers. This is no longer a bank- It's a tech company and thought leader.  

The internal culture is phenomenal. Work life balance is a core company value for it's associates and we have it. This is the first job I have had in my career that really offers a work life balance. They don't just say it, they live it. I came from the technology industry and think what is going on at Capital One is like a hidden secret that is getting ready to explode. Capital One takes great care of their associates through carer progression and benefits offered to employees and their families. The 401k match is awesome. The system where you go to look up all your benefits is super easy to navigate and user friendly. Internal mobility and job security is remarkable. 

Diversity is another big focus for Capital One. The company is committed to hiring, promoting and retaining their talent, which includes a diverse workforce. Capital One is a mecca for all races, ages, ethnicity and sexual orientation. They value hiring top talent  and only want to hire the best. There is uber smart people everywhere. We have a diverse customer population so, Capital One wants to mirror the same diversity inside the company and it shows when waking down the halls.
cons: Continue to focus on enterprise wide initiatives vs working in line of business silos.

headline: associate
pros: big company = big benefits
cons: it's a big company so you feel like a number

headline: UBA
pros: The number one thing I love about working there was because they had great insurance! Also, they had a lot of options if you want to go to a different department.
cons: Not many cons in my opinion, but if I had to put something I would say the Work life balance wasn't as good as I thought it would have been.

They don't care about your career advancement, and there is no training.  You will never get an annual raises. Management has LOTS of excuses why things are not working, but no answers on what they are doing to solve them. The people that run this division have no direction, and no real focus on getting the right tools in place to make this even a good position.

The first 2 1/2 months I didn't have system access which is needed to learn any job, however I applied myself with due diligence so well that I gained recognition only for this injustice to occur.

headline: Not enough pay for work

headline: People with Disabilities former or current beware!
pros: They win on work life balance.  401k is nice, but it's cliff vesting so don't rely on it until after 2 years.   The food and coffee is amazing.  The company is highly collaborative.
cons:
So here's what happens.  You get unhealthy and you fight the docs, you will also end up fighting the companies' internal HR policies.  Good luck if you have disabilities documented or not.  IT WILL BE AN UPHILL BATTLE IF YOU DO NOT HAVE SOMETHING STRAIGHTFORWARD.  I'm a disabled veteran and I'm still having difficulties and my disability is completely documented with the VA.  

FYI they will give you options if you cannot get the correct documentation.  The HR processes can be arduous.

1.     Return to work   *****MOST LIKELY could result in failure***
2.     Resign from Capital One (you will be eligible for rehire based on voluntary resignation term reason)  **You're without a job**
3.     Be terminated from Capital One based on attendance policy  **You're without a job**

The point i'm making here is that you are up a creek without a paddle and despite all of your efforts, they are running a business and would like to happily run it without you.  Beware.  

Overall, I'm a very positive person, but the reward system and the disability management is very poor in this company.  We're not asking for a free ride or anything, we just need a SAFE place to operate, that's all.   The funny thing is the company has disability recruiters who are full aware of options, but somehow I made it through without the proper support which I'm fully aware of now.  

Managers are technical managers and will not be invested in you until you are at a higher level.  

There is a reorganization going on - take it for what its worth.

They are not always as willing to learn new tech.  Or use web-based technologies to make their lives better.

headline: Mortgage Operations
pros:
Capital One offers a great benefit package.




C
cons: Getting raises and promotions is a bit of a lengthy process

headline: Worth the trouble

cons: Middle management can be a pain. Power hungry and biased. Advancement is near impossible unless you're a great salesperson, which can be difficult depending on what branch you work in. Reviews/raises certainly leave something to be desired. Sales goals/incentives (for lack of a better word) suck.

headline: Open source technologies but, way too much cruft

Lots of Klan members in leadership positions

Lots of wasted money in the cloud
Lots of broken applications on demo days
Lots of applications that do not function as intended

headline: Meritocracy, awesome benefits and work-life balance
pros: Although the company has its flaws, this company is the most meritocratic company that I have ever worked in. Also, the benefits are generous and the work-life balance is nice too!

headline: Financial Rotation Associate
pros: Unreal work life balance. The benefits are the best I know of, for just starting out of college. I have a corporate stock plan at 22 years old. I have never heard of that.
cons: I don't think there really is anything major. I would say the company is very layered when it comes to getting things done. Data and projects have to go through a lot of reviews. But I think that is part of the culture because the bank is more conservative and worries a lot more about operational risk than other banks.

headline: Entry Level Associate Review
pros:
Flexible work environment, decent pay (I make $69k, started at $50k six years ago), opportunities for advancement. 
Inspiring, technology driven strategy that makes Capital One a forward thinking bank and unique among competitors.
cons:
Health benefits are not great for employees with large families (multiple dependents) or ongoing health issues.  Capital one is self insured, which means higher premiums (think 800+ per month for a family of 4), high co-pays, deductibles AND co-insurance.  Other benefits are on par with industry standards (bonus, time off, retirement, etc).
Lots of change (re-organization, layoffs, site closures, etc), but this is perpetual here.  
Overly complex change management procedures that could use simplification.

headline: Great place to work at

headline: Capital one home loans #FAILURE!!!
pros: Benefits are good. 401k has a good match. Medical is good. But, a lot of back stabbing and management has much to be desired.
cons: Very poor upper management starting at the top home loans. Very poor upper management starting at the top of home loans. Distributed Chanel is a revolving door for LO"s looking for a guarantee. Top producers are shunned if they speak up. A lot of attrition in direr t also. DE site had 2 LO's leave within 3 weeks of hire date. Questionable manager settling false expectations in DE. Not a merit driven department. Only those that play the political game can advance. Employee turnover and engagement is comical. It seems in this department upper management is fixated on self preservation opposed to growing the business. Employees are an after thought. For gods sake gmail now views our promotional emails as spam.

You can survive here if you are not too ambitious about your career. Otherwise this place might hurt your software career in long run.

headline: Love. Love. Love.
pros: Career Development Center. I feel that a lot of my fellow associates do not take advantage of on-site Career Development Centers. These CDCs provide amazing services and materials that provide you with vital tools and feedback necessary to further develop your personal brand and career; whether it be within Cap One or outside of Capital One. Resume writing. Mock interviews. Classes. Online university that you can access at home. Capital One is the most diverse company I've ever worked for. Within their very own little professional social network, you can join groups that include LGBT chapters for your specific location; There are many groups promoting ethnic diversity; groups for women, the armed forces, etc. There is such a diverse mix of associates. Managers are awesome; but, there are some better than others of course. Not everyone can have the same leadership style. Benefits are amazing and Capital One is very accommodating if you need a medical accommodation. Capital One is always striving to develop new tools for associates to help solve customer's problems effectively and efficiently.
cons: Aetna still handles FMLA and disability benefits. I CAN'T STAND CVS CAREMARK, which is the proscription provider. They are awful IMO. Other than that, I love Capital One.

headline: Capital one
pros: No sundays worked, you get out at 5:30
cons: Goals are unreasonable as the banking industry is now slow. Managers will delegate alot of their duties to people underneath them.

headline: Open and fast paced company
pros: Very flexible, fast moving, competitive, good pay and benefits, the West Creek campus in VA is a great location with everything you need
cons: Constant fear of layoff if you are not a newer project team, performance management process is terrible and destroys morale for everyone

headline: Benefits
pros: Great Benefits and believes in great customer service
cons: Tax bonuses, have pointless roles

headline: Software Engineering
pros: Awesome place for technology hands-on people! Tons of opportunities with in the company to explore, learn and advance. This is a technology company with banking license. Very smart people working on technology, you will be amazed to see the talent. Capital One is going to change the banking and for good. This company values the eco-system and cares for employees and customers.
cons: If you are not a geek, you don't want to look in here for technology jobs! Of course there are tons of opportunities in other areas like compliance, risk etc...

headline: Political but lots of learning opportunities
pros: There is big community of statisticians/data scientists, and lots of training opportunities including courses offered by internal guru or from outside like SAS.
cons: Very political. An individual manager was very mean to his direct reports while being very nice to people at higher ranks or his peers. The turnover rate is very high. In order to push ranking of the employees in his/her own team, managers or directors kept attacking employees in different group, even bringing it up to performance if an employee sent out an email earlier than set up, which did not cause any issue except sending it out earlier. Quote from a previous reviewers " It is a place of dog eating dog." Was not able to take any vacation in one year.

headline: Great benefits but work schedule is not a great fit if you have family
pros: Bonus, vacation time. If you hit your referral goal you get a payout in every check. If the store makes it you also get pay. Great christmas party
cons: Long shift, working on the weekends. Very little time for personal time. Very fast paced environment. Management can be hard at time

headline: Director
pros: Capital One offers a diverse and accepting culture.
cons: Opportunities for advancement are limited.

headline: Actors needed
pros: Easy to get hired I worked with people who had previous experience as stockers at grocery stores.
cons: Everything else about the job.  I was in the loyalty department wich asked us to be enthusiastic and energetic on every call. You would get reprimanded for not building rapport with customers.  After you established rapport it would be subjective to the manager if you  established ENOUGH rapport.  You could help the customer but then fail a call score due to not enough rapport with the customer.  Pay was very low.

headline: Great Potential, Great Benefits - High Stress, Ultra Competitive
pros: Solid Company. Genuinely care about their employees.  Provide great benefits, and tons of training opportunities.  Doing cool things to get ahead in technology and banking and staying competitive.  Moving around is more than ok, its welcomed.  You can define your own career path and network across the company to get there.  Awesome to work with Smart People, and overall genuinely good people.
cons: Performance management is ultra-competitive, and corrupts even the most decent individuals - creates a lot of overhead in politics, a super competitive culture and inches stress levels to unmanageable heights impacting overall health of many individuals.

headline: Good Work life Balance
pros: Senior leadership is best in class.
cons: Middle management is the weakness of the company

headline: Great first role
pros: The benefits, training and work life balance are excellent.  Company culture and values are stressed in a special way.  Coworkers are genuine friends who associate outside of work.
cons: Career growth seems heavily influenced by who your manager is, and when in the review cycle your name comes up.  Don't try too hard right after a performance review, as no one will remember it by the next one.

headline: Teller
pros: It's a good experience as far as allowing you to deal with different types of people and familiarizing you with working under pressure.
cons: They have unrealistic goals with terrible products which makes it impossible to sell to customers sometimes which in turn looks bad on the branch and its employees.

headline: Anonymous
pros: Great company, good job stability and good culture
cons: Too many politics not much career once stuck to a position. Benefits lack industry standards

headline: Great Job for Corporate Minds
pros: Great benefits, volunteer opportunities within the surrounding community, and the company understands work-life balance. There are a lot of options if you are looking to advance with the company.
cons: Our teams changed regularly, and therefore direct management would change frequently. This would sometimes change the work environment from great, to terrible rather quickly. Position can get repetitive and tedious. Far too focused on the corporate aspect of things. Hard to get the best hours unless you continuously ask.

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Great benefits, smart people, interesting projects
cons: Lots of re-orgs and restructuring / downsizing

headline: Senior Coordinator
pros: Laid-back, fun days, holidays, work/life balance
cons: stressful, ghetto people, and not a lot of advancement opportunities, the pay is horrible

headline: Overall pros outweigh the cons
pros: Positive atmosphere, great benefits, some flexibility offered, good pay
cons: Your experience will depend greatly on which team or group you are in as well as who is your manager.

headline: Loss Mitigation Specialist
pros: Capital One definitely cares about employees being happy as far as work life. Flexible schedules, fun environment. They also promote healthy lifestyles
cons: Unorganized on the mortgage end of the business. Often had layoffs in short periods of times. I've had 4 managers within one year.

headline: Customer service Rep
pros: The company looks great, provides decent work environment.
cons: Manager don't care how you perform and they don't care about employees, if you want to grow within the company you need to learn how to suck up to the managers, they hire family and only promote family. I had a co-worker who showed up late didn't care about doing his job right got promoted just because his brother was the good friend of the hiring manager.

headline: Great people and work/life balance
pros: Very competitive pay without the extreme hours.  Flexibility to work from home/ take vacation time as desired.  Great people with emphasis on diversity.  Opportunity to move around and rotate between roles to keep things interesting.
cons: Sometimes the work can be dry or repetitive.  Not as much room for growth/rotation in the Chicago office as in Mclean or Richmond.  Executives are mostly based in Mclean/Richmond so face time in the Chicago office is limited.  Noticeable lack of female executives.

headline: Home Loan Processor
pros:
Great  working environment amongst co-workers.
Good Pay
Good Hours
cons:
Management that are out of touch with Employees' needs.
Managers that are in another state.
A lot of workarounds

headline: Senior Associate
pros: Focused on doing what's right for their customers and associates.  Great benefits!
cons:
Not really focused on doing the right thing and protecting management level.
A lot of blind eyes to areas that will impact employees and business as a whole.

headline: Relationship Banker
pros: Capital One is committed to offering the best possible services to its customers and strives every day to achieve that.   However, their commitment to excellence is also reflected in the treatment of their employees.  They have incredible benefits packages, and their implementation of it shows how much Capital One truly cares about its employees' well-being.
cons: They do not promote well from within, unless you live in the Richmond or Plano area.  They also impose goals on their retail staff that are bordering on unreasonable, especially in today's technologically digital age.  Several times, they require tasks from their employees without adequate training.

headline: Great Company to work for
pros: Competitive pay, more than adequate pto available, full benefits , great bonuses available, fun work environment
cons: Advancement limited in some centers, not all management equipped with skills to deal with agents needs nor to help agents achieve their full potential

headline: Old Management
pros:
Great Benefits
Great community/volunteer events
Great staff in some departments
cons:
Lack of Career Opportunities outside of VA
Old management doesn't like change
Pay below industry average

headline: Great culture, innovation, digital
pros: Great culture, innovation, digital focus and customer focus
cons: Ongoing reorgs can extort a lot of focus

headline: Retail Bank call center
pros: benefits,vacation time allotted, life insurance, retirement & stock purchase
cons:
no management support - feel like disconnect from higher associates
heard credit card not like this

headline: bank teller
pros: paid vacation, good work/life balance, holidays off, work half day on saturday and off sunday.
cons: nothing i can think of as of right now.

headline: Capital One review
pros:
Welfare package good. Some groups are really good. Some are bad.
If you get to the core credit card business it's great.
cons: Corporate politics can be serious. Each team can be a fiefdom. My team doesn't grant green card sponsorship for people despite company-wide rule saying after 1 year sponsors.

headline: 6 months in and still doesn't feel like I work for a bank
pros:
Capital One's Technology department is young, diverse and very tech-forward. Feels as current with the tech scene as any startup I've worked in—from the open office culture to the product development methodologies to the actual tech stacks we use.

I also very much appreciate their hiring process, which focuses as much on your character and chemistry with your potential teammates as your technical chops. I enjoy the people I work with now even more than close friends whose companies I've worked for in the past.
cons:
Capital One's non-tech departments have a little ideological catching up to do. Not a lot, but some.

There's definitely a gap in understanding between the agile/lean methodology of the tech department and the more numerical timeline-/goal-oriented mentality of the company at large.

Luckily, it's not a conflict or a war—just difference in backgrounds. One that I believe can (and will) be overcome with more communication between the two.

headline: Work Place
pros: Great Benefits People Friendly Great Pay
cons: Management  no diversity no advancement within the company

headline: Great Place
pros: Great people to work with. The managers are very personable and do not micro manage. This helps create a great work environment at Capital One
cons: There is no cons in working here

headline: Lots of great things about Capital One, and some things to work on
pros:
-Great company vision with an inspiring CEO; well managed strategically
-Offices are generally nice; lots of good food options and amenities
-Work life balance below Director is generally good
-Benefits are much better than average
-Big enough company that I got to tackle some pretty cool problems and build my skillset
cons:
-Approach to promotions and employee recognition needs some work; slow promotions; small pay raises; our team didn't do a good job of rewarding folks until they had one foot out the door
-Work life balance takes a big hit at Director and above; with a little bit better staff continuity I think this problem could be greatly reduced
-Lots of turnover (primarily due to the first bullet on the list)

headline: Customer Complaint Rep
pros: The environment is laid back and easy going.
cons: Listening to Customer complaints can be taxing on your sanity.

headline: Advanced Service Coordinator (Spanish- bilingual)
pros: Incentives, work atmosphere, easy job, work- life balance.
cons: In an industry that is always changing, they are behind technologically in some aspects and need to catch up to make the job easier and the experience better for our customers.

headline: Ok
pros: Decent place. Decent perks. Decent pay. Overall a decent job lol nothing special no bells and whistles. Pay incentives help too.
cons: Very very very boring. Sitting in one spot all day and asking the same people all day everyday if they would like to open another account gets real old real quick

headline: Not worth it - YOU CAN DO BETTER!
pros: great benefits and nothing else that I can actually think of right now
cons:
-ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE culture: backstabbing culture encouraged through feedback surveys; you get the feeling that it's like a bad cliche high school movie 
-their culture forces people to start acting like they are on survivor 
-existing long term employees are absolutely incompetent both in Canada and USA
-HR has no idea what they are doing: do not believe anything they say to you, it is almost always a lie
-so much red tape you cannot accomplish anything
-very poor compensation package compared to other companies of the same size
-old systems that do not function properly
-not open to new ideas from new experienced employees
-if you are an experienced manager, do not bother coming to this company
-be careful when signing your contract, they will try to screw you
-they have a great pitch to get you and when you arrive they will sell you on their values, but nobody is actually following through on what they claim
-absolutely no work/life balance
-if you absolutely need a job, come here but be careful in every aspect and continue looking for a better offer, under no circumstance come here if you are already employed
-the only reason why they are rated well in external surveys is because they force their employees to vote this way

headline: Cut pay for employees as profits skyrocket
pros: Very easy job. Have sales goals but they are generally easy to reach. 4 weeks vacation and great benefits.
cons: What's the point of having so much vacation if you can't afford to go anywhere? Incentives have been cut every year in half or more each time. The 2016 incentive cut makes it working here not a viable option for work for anyone that needs 35- 40k or higher. Upper management pretends to care and sends shoutouts for the highest achievers via email, but little else. The future of capital one is to go digital which means employment cuts. Automated teller machines and one to two employee branches are what you have to look forward to. Encouraged to train customers to be self sufficient so we are no longer needed. Bank profits were 4.4billion last year while capital one cut incentives for bankers by 10k a year.

headline: Banker

headline: Good work life balance
pros: time off  and work life balance

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Capital One has a great employee benefits package and has multiple ways of keeping employees happy to work hard and to increase morale. If you have an idea that will increase productivity, unlike many employers Capital One will listen, and if the idea is feasible will quickly put it into place.  Quarterly fun days are paid days where your team leaves the work site for lunch and a fun event or team building exercises.  Lunches are often provided, holidays are paid time off or extra pay if worked and morale boosting events and rallys happen monthly. Medical, dental, optical and retirement benefits are offered as well as discounts to local events.
cons: There are many opportunities for promotion within Capital One, but there is also a lot of competition from coworkers to fill these positions.

headline: Senior Operations Coordinator
pros: Good benefits, great ability to climb the ladder, great ability to move throughout company, very focused on family/work balance, compensation is fair, diverse work environment, ability to voice opinions and have them heard
cons: constant promise to go digital but very few changes made, comp is fair but not the best, not a lot of ability to work for company in major role outside of Richmond,VA and McClean, VA

headline: Capital One
pros: Good work life balance and opportunity to work with senior leadership
cons: Repetitive work, BAU work, Corporate life

headline: Principal Project Manager

headline: Agile product owner

headline: You didn't hear it from me, but expect more layoffs this year
pros:
Beautiful campus (in Richmond, anyway), complete with an affordable gym and variety of eating places on campus.

I have met some very intelligent and talented people here.
cons:
Capital One has a 'follow-the-leader' mentality. They are now convinced that they are an app company, since that is in vogue. They were a bank during the recession and banks were receiving bailouts.  Once the tech bubble bursts, they will follow the newest sexiest trend, who know idea or commitment to what that really entails. 

A very unstable, hostile work environment. The review process forces you to hold back when supporting your peers and always make sure that you have something over them. Not only do you have to be a politician, you better make sure that your direct supervisor is a politician too.  

I have seen many great workers ruined because the higher ups didn't like their supervisor.  If you fall into an unpopular team by chance, you are screwed. 

Incompetent middle managers are there due to nepotism and/or favoritism. They will move form ruining one team after another every year or two. They will be gone just before the complete garbage of their contribution is fully realized to the tone-deaf upper management.  If you're lucky, a competent manager will take over and start to turn the team around. But even in this case, they too will be gone before too long. 

More layoffs are coming later this year, while the CEO will continue to be in the top most overpaid CEOS in America list (according to Forbes).

The campus is beautiful, but way over crowded. Come early or don't come at all, unless you like calling a small corner of a table your desk.

headline: Process Manager

In spite of your great contribution and multiple customer commendation some unhappy or insecure managers don't value your achievement. It's not the company but some of those people who ruin the company's good reputation that do such thing.

It is tough to get very far if you are in shared technology services unless you have been there a long time or are Indian.  Not enough time to learn technologies properly....more interested in being first to launch.

headline: It's Not Just A Company, It's a Home!
pros: The culture and people at Capital One are second to none, as is the work-life balance. You are surrounded by smart, driven people and it pushes you to be your personal best. The company's slogan, "Do the right thing," aren't just words that are spoken, but the guiding principle behind everything we do, whether it be for our customers or associates.

headline: Consumer Bank Marketing Department

cons: Tons of reorgs and manager switches which makes it hard to stand out when being considered for promotions.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Capital One really seems to value development and ownership. They also provide great benefits (ESPP, 401K match, bank holidays off). Lastly, it feels very exciting to see the company changing to be a more technology-focused organization.
cons: There is a growing divide between the perks offered to digital and technology associates and the rest of the company.

headline: Amamzing Company
pros: Excellent Culture and Dynamic Leadership
cons: No cons to speak of

headline: Manager, Supplier management

headline: Capital one customer service coordinator

headline: Relationship Banker
pros: Great benefits, Nice environment  good working hours no take home work Good training !
cons: Unrealistic Goals and expectations upper management NOT in touch with branch operations. The last time they worked in a branch (if they ever worked in a branch) there were limited number of banks and the customers were very loyal to the bank. Now the customer always in the "what can you do for me " mode which upper management don't understand! Customers are not stupid they know when you are selling them !

headline: Great place to work but no place is perfect
pros: Capital One prides itself on having a great work life balance and I can confirm that they offer flexible work schedules, good leave packages, and have very understanding leadership in this space.  The people are generally smart, talented, and committed to doing the right thing.
cons: There is a middle management culture of consensus based decisioning that drives down certain teams and individuals potential.  This stifles innovation, reduces speed, and leads to a feeling of distrust and lack of autonomy within teams.  For a company that sells itself as "being agile" this is something that many people find difficult.

headline: Administrative Assistant
pros: Great company benefits and perks. If you get in a good department and have a good manager you will have lots of opportunities available to grow.
cons: Technology lacking in some departments. Lots of job cuts in certain locations.

headline: not brain surgery, good if you don't want to move up
pros: Close to home. Not difficult to do well. Training provided. Nice co-workers. Customers are easy to speak with, helping to make the job that much easier.
cons: Irregular hours. Working on the weekend, lucky to get 1 Saturday/month off. Difficult to move within the company.

headline: Capital One work environment
pros: Great in-house training on all subject matter. Intelligent and diverse employees. Solid performance review process. Excellent compensation and benefits package along with corporate perks.  The primary corporate sites are very high end with a plethora of amenities.
cons: Leadership shifts direction quite frequently. When there is a change in direction, the (lengthy) leadership approval process typically causes work efforts to be placed on hold until approved.  My teams tended to be rigid and too serious during team interactions.  A more relaxed working environment would have increased morale. Many colleagues were constantly concerned about their job security.

headline: A Company with a Heart
pros: Fantastic work/life balance, the ability to work remotely for some roles, fun work environment, great company culture and values, corporate citizenship and volunteerism, open communication, visibility to and from leadership, onsite campus amenities (cafes, gym, health center), great benefits, awesome people and opportunities for training and growth.
cons: Career pathing and growth opportunities for some roles, lower salary, flawed promotional process and at times slow execution on initiatives and deliverables.

headline: Senior Business Systems Analyst
pros: Awesome West Creek campus environment.  Clothing requirements flexible. WFH based on manager choice.
