headline: Fraud Identity Coordinator
pros: Under Brent Owen, an exceptional work environment, individual goal and team oriented. Promoted and lived customer service, while we tried to "WOW the Fraudsters".  Internal "Agent Feedback Loop (AFL), which maintained an open line of communication between the Agents and upper management.  A number of major, positive policy changes came about through the AFL.,  Well though out, and generous severance package.
cons: Call center environment, mind numbing, repetitive work.  The call center in Tigard, OR, and Sioux Falls, SD shut down in 2015. over 1,000 job gone, replaced by contract employees in South Florida.  a quote from the meeting that shut us down- "We need a more flexible work force for the digital age."

headline: Administrative Assistant
pros: Great company.  They try to make the NYC office like the McLean Campus.  They do care a lot about their employees.  A nice company to work for.
cons: There is a work from home flexilbe work schedule.  But, it really depends on the department you are in and who you work for.  Reviews can be frustrating because you can work so hard and make contributions and still not get pass a "strong" rating.

headline: Great people/team members; not so much management
pros: People are some of the brightest, smartest and most motivated and creative that you'll ever encounter. True team and partnership mentality. Associates encouraged to build skills, knowledge (if they're associates) if they can find the time (and that's always the issue). Teams across company are dedicated and hard working. Teams trying hard to really find best ways to be more digital. Customer service and the customer are truly at heart across the organization - not just lip service; associates and leaders really mean it. Great benefits, buildings/facilities are awesome.  Some flexibility in work schedule - most people work from home on Fridays or school holidays, etc.
cons:
So many layoffs and reorgs in US Card that leaders down through associates are leaving rapidly. They're sick of all the changes. With the mass migration, all associates are overworked. Although US Card is focused on being more of a digital leader, they don't get it and aren't hiring or training people to get the right skills. I learned more in 1 year way from COF in a digital role than I learned in 4 years there. They're still too slow to change.  

Mid level management (Sr Mgr - Sr Director) is overworked; need more training and time to be effective mentors and managers. Pressure is so high that leaders are micromanaging and expecting perfection when associates are working 50 hrs a week. The whole work-life balance that COF touted for years is a joke. It doesn't exist anymore. 

Work and roles are too siloed and sub categorized. Too many people doing just one role when they could combine (for example, brand, corporate communications, PR - you don't need one role who just publishes articles intranet or creates templates, presentations, sends emails. Combine that into each PR/Brand/Comms role and give person opportunity to  more than just be an email/article publishing jockey). 

Too  many clunky and limiting processes, although that's slowly improving with Agile and process management methodologies being implemented across the company. 

Hard to get promoted unless you're a superstar because of the performance management program. If you accept a job there, expect to be in it at least 4-5 years. You can always move to another team in a lateral move. If you're a contractor, expect that you won't be treated that well. You'll need to just do whatever junk work is left over at the end of the day that the lowest level associates don't want to do.

headline: Great Company -- Be wary of the expand and contract cycles
pros: The company takes excellent care of their full-time employees: good benefits, freedom to fail fast and experiment, open to new ideas, changes very fast (can also be a con depending on how you deal with change), proactive in training, opportunities to attend in-house conferences with industry leaders, great facilities and offices.
cons: Life at the company is very fast paced, almost hectic sometimes (granted, depending on role), and change happens so quickly that it can require some fancy footwork to keep up. The company also tends to function in cycles where they will hire many new employees and 6-12 months later let a large group go. It's a good place to be if you can keep on top of change and avoid the layoff cycles.

headline: Overworked, under recognized but great benefits
pros: Great benefits, like none I have ever experienced. Besides medical, dental, vision insurance, 401K contribution, and paid time off, they offer and onsite acute care. Makes it easy when you are sick but not quite sick enough to miss work. They also have a onsite fitness facility and offer amateur sports throughout the year. The culture is built on constructive feedback which will help you grow as an employee.
cons: Office politics are strong. Most recognitions are about who you know and not the work you have done. Capital One doesn't seem to find value in hiring people into management that have experience in the industry. Although there is value in a different perspective, some basic industry experience can help avoid some common pitfalls.

headline: It's a good company to work for
pros: Compared to other company, Capital One definitely provides better working balance. People are generally nice to each other.
cons: Not quite sure if this is a bad thing, but all the things are moving a bit slow here. I will say people need to do some homework for their advanced career movement.

headline: Abandon hope all ye who enter here
pros: Full time employees get the normal benefits (health, dental, vision, time off, etc.), though the benefits are nowhere near as good as they used to be before Capital One bought this company (we used to be ShareBuilder, owned by ING Direct).
cons:
Where do I begin?

1. Leadership is always saying they want people to bring new ideas and question how things are done, but if you ever begin questioning things you are quickly shot down.

2. The CEO of the company, Rich Fairbank, touts a work/life balance that seems to apply only to him. Salaried employees are expected to constantly travel and put in hours upon hours of work but when he goes on his annual "Strategy Roadshow" he can't even be bothered to come to Seattle. He spins this as a sweet little story about not wanting to spend time away from his family, but it's just disrespectful. The rest of us spend plenty of time away from our families. FUN FACT: When Capital One says you have the option to work from home, it usually doesn't mean you get to stay home and work. More often than not, you come home from a long day's work at the office and just keep working remotely.

3. As others have pointed out, the annual review process is a joke. Associates are stack ranked against each other and their managers are thrown into the pit to decide who gets what bonus. If you had an incredible year of work but your manager doesn't speak up (or another manager argues better for one of their people, regardless of what they accomplished in reality) you're going to get the shaft. Period. It's a political mess and neither your dedication to the company's values nor the quality of your work have any bearing on your bonus.

4. Possibly because of the review process, there is a culture of withholding information and taking credit for work done by others that permeates through a majority of the organization.

I could go on, but this should be enough to make reasonable people second guess accepting an interview.

headline: A Good Vision Poorly Executed
pros:
I like the people I work with and people are willing and help and support each other.  The vision of  moving to new/open source technologies, Cloud and MicroServices makes sense.

The work life balance if great and I think it's one of the reasons much of the tech staff has been patient but that's waining
cons:
The re-org that took place in order to move teams onto new technology platforms was needed but with the change getting drug out over 6 months it was the most poorly executed change I've seen.  

The company is using the stack ranking approach that Microsoft abandoned after much churn last year.  The end result is you could be doing stellar work but 

* if your manager isn't politically connected your chance of getting a good bonus is slim
* If your manager is shy or lays back you won't get the bonus you should
* Your manager can only hold up a limited number of names so if they have too many they won't be holding you up for a good bonus


And my favorite (encountered this year)
* If you changed managers once or twice during the year the manager at the end doesn't need to incorporate feedback or scoring from previous managers so you don't get the bonus you should.

I went to talk with someone who has been here a long time.  Her response was that yes, this isn't uncommon and you just have to find a different manager.

Have seen blacks and Indians targeted over the last few yrs in such a way that I'm surprised there is no law suits. Rich fair banks idea of changing banking for good is telling his employees how great is life is while making up these so called certifications to shrink the work force and not pay employees. Screwing over financial advisors and stealing from the everyday working stiff. Saw a DM get taken to HR for racial behavior by 2 different employees who didn't know each other and capt 1 swept it under the carpet. What's your worth with this corp. Don't wanna sound to disgusted but I am.

headline: Great company and challenging atmosphere
pros: Beautiful campus.  Great benefits.  Amenities are second to none.  Bright people.  Rewarded well if high performer.  Plenty of opportunities for engineers.  Pay better than most, if not all.  Enable associates to volunteer during work hours.  Work from home (within reason).  Great focus on professional development through Capital One University.
cons:
Work/life balance.  48-60 hrs/week seems to be the norm.  Stay away from Capital One if you are not or find it difficult to adapt to  change instantly.  Continuous reorganizations and head count cuts.  This company is not for you if job stability influences how you feel.  

Performance management system in combination with the above reality causes some people to be solely competitive rather than collaborative.  People who are promoted deserve it.  Some hard working dedicated associates could end up on the wrong side of the system.  It is unfortunate as they add value.  I feel it is an unintended consequence.

headline: Great company for motivated individuals

headline: Stay away, there is no future with this company.
pros: Good vacation time. Average benefits. Nothing special, just the same as most large companies. Good 401k match, but you will leave before you are vested.
cons: Okay, where do I begin? Massive layoffs of all aassistant managers in the entire company. Massive pay cuts in incentives, bonuses and generally all areas. The company claims to want the best and brightest, yet every year associates make less money. The morale at branch offices is at an all time low. So the winning formula is less employees, more work for those who remain, while also paying them much less. How is that for a future? Do yourself a favor and avoid applying. Despite the corporate propaganda, this company does not value their employees.

headline: Capital One Pros and Cons
pros: Capital One is reasonably supportive of their Associates as long as they are interested in retaining them. While there are opportunities to make innovative contributions, things do not always seem to be under control. They are not afraid to risk significant time and expense experimenting with ideas which ultimately may never be used.
cons: Rapid changes due to experimenting with new ideas, technologies, process management, business priorities, etc. can lead to frequent re-organizations, shifts in managers, teams, responsibilities, job titles, job duties, etc. which can make their complex performance management process subjective and unpredictable.

headline: Great Job, Awesome Benefits
pros: Benefits are awesome here with Capital One. It's a great company to work for, with a ton of different options for lateral and upward movement. Work/life balance is real solid and the work environment is pretty cool.
cons: Management is horrendous. Coming from a previous sales job, we had 1 manager for my teem but still managed to push out weekly meetings at set times for months and months straight. Here, you're lucky to get a 1 on 1 maybe once a month. It's pretty sad. We have 3 managers for 20 people and even still I am lucky if one of them is around the entire day. Nobody on the sales floor knows where they go.

headline: Doing the same old thing
pros: Medical and Dental are great.
cons:
Our Sr. Leader had told us there is no forced distribution. Well there is. The S curve is there and this what Rich wants. 

Here is the basic break down:

Needs Improvement - Inconsistent: 5-15%
Strong: 20-70%
Very Strong: 1-10%
Exceptional: 0-5%

It does not matter what you do as long as you put something into production. If you're not a developer then there is not a lot of upward movement for you.

If you happen to want to work here ask for all the $ you can. The avg raise is 2% - 3% if you're lucky.

headline: growing to hate this company
pros: Oh sure it's great at first... Don't be fooled by the recreational activities they furnish, trust me, there's a catch
cons: I am having my job threatened because I went home today very, VERY sick... With the flu. I brought my thermometer in and took my temp (which has been in the 101_102 range all day ) right in front of them. I feel that i need to be hospitalized... I've been very ill for last 3 days. I was told before leaving work that this will result in a written warning, and my attendence better be perfect for the next 2 months... And i am an employee (contractor) who  comes in an hour early almost everyday and has shown a lot of initiative. One of the occurences i received was for leaving work (when my trainer told me to) for 2 hours to go to an urgent care for a kidney infection, which i came back to work and worked through and i had a dr. Note. . I am so sick i should be hospitalized right now, and instead of taking care of myself, I'm laying here seriously ill worried about losing my job if i don't go to work tomorrow, and my temp is still 101.3 and i feel aweful. It's abusive and inhumane.

headline: Insight from a former Senior Recruiter in Human Resources
pros:
I supported the Human Resources department hiring throughout the entire organization, but primarily the HR dept.  I visited Richmond for a week long training but sat in the Plano office. 

Great Company Brand
Culture is similar to a consulting company
Remote employees are celebrated
Remote working is celebrated
Process-oriented work culture
Intelligent Hires- Rigorous Interview selection process to include case studies
cons:
As someone who directly recruited for the organization, I interacted with hiring managers at the Manager to Director level. 
Bureaucratic Process Oriented work culture- Lots of Red Tape to do simple tasks
Dogmatic Leadership style- Yelling Screaming Berating employees
Unfair hiring practices with regard to discrimination of candidates based on race, nationality/origin widely practiced. 
I would not advise anyone of color to work in the HR department.

headline: Open culture, high volume of change
pros: Very flexible, open to different approaches of doing things.  Great work life balance.  Collaborative.  Lateral movement supported.  Leadership is constantly asking for feedback.  Great benefits.  (on-site medical center, free PT, on-site fitness center, on-site pharmacy, 15 days of backup childcare, FSA contribution matching, tons of discounts for healthy eating and living)
cons:
High level of change,  Not much continuity.  I have averaged around three manager changes each year.
Over focus on socialization and consensus building.  Very few things have clear, singular decision makers.  Default is to shop idea around and convince everyone.  While in some cases this would make sense, for more BAU work, this becomes very inefficient.

They're hiring directors and VPs who aren't leaders they're taskmasters. Very hard to get work done given very frequent org changes. Even Rich Fairbanks who I loved has changed his soul and tries to be hip and it isn't working. I loved this company, but it is going downhill culturally. If you're into the hipster scene and you like buzzwords and kissing butt, you'll do fine.

headline: Manager
pros: I am working for this company from last 8 years , close to 5 years as employee . You will love this company working as a consultant rather than employee . Flexible work hours , Good cafeteria's and nice perks . You will definitely excel in this company if you are a project manager or into project management . There are not much pros about this company .
cons:
Though the vision of the company is to become another FB , Google , Yahoo , Intuit they do not have the resources , caliber or the balls to become one in current market . This company is probably few years behind compared to any true tech company . The commitment ( verbal ) is to build the skill set or to hire people who can or are proficient with coding aspects of emerging technologies but they necessary doesn't show while implementing it. All it cares about is being politically right and definitely people can get promoted who are good Project managers or who can suck up to their management . 
Not a good company who are technical  savy.

headline: senior statistician

headline: Inconsistent
pros:
-Teams all seem pretty happy in spite of the weak salaries
-The culture is decent, compared to what I've heard about similar places
-
-Good benefits 
-Diversity networks are great
cons:
-Not all departments are created equal - half the place walks around with macbooks and works from home as they please, other teams are paper and pencil only and don't have the option to work remotely at all, even in the event of a storm or on work trips. 
-The performance management system is completely out of whack.  All departments have completely different stances on promotions and raises, so equality is basically non-existent, but you are still rated against your "peers" (aka those with the same job title as you) at year-end, regardless of what your individual jobs entail.  The system also basically tries to eliminate any attempts at negotiation of salary by delivering the final decision to you in a tidy little package with seemingly no other options.
-The pay is much lower than the industry standard.  
-Depending on where you are, there is ZERO opportunity.

headline: It's clear why they win "best place to work"
pros: Excellent Nottingham office. They really think of everything, from hair straighteners in the gym changing rooms to a dry cleaning service. Working in complaints there were always lots of bonuses to be had, awards to be won and socials to get involved with. Flexible working hours arrangements to fit around your life/travel. Great holiday allowance. Managers followed a process and so they couldn't go too wrong and the senior team were visible.
cons:
Rewards and bonuses within complaints team were there to create as much output as possible and I was never entirely sure that the customer was always getting the best service as the staff (myself included) were solely driven by money and reward. 
Temps and fixed term staff offered no security and generally fobbed off for as long as possible with regards to what may happen with role, particularly when nearing end of fixed term. I and all people on same contract as me were given minimum notice and I know full well that it was done intentionally to prevent productivity dropping off. (As that was the be all and end all)
Promotion generally happened to management's favourite people. It was never about what you knew...always who you knew.

headline: Director
pros: Challenging work, exciting projects, company is trying to reinvent itself with tech
cons: no work life balance, old poison culture from east coast is not compatible with Silicon Valley. Bell Curve based performance management model in 2016!

headline: Customer Service Coordinator
pros: Capital One has a lot of great benefits, the pay is good and you get up to 120 hours of paid time off starting out with the company. There are some perks such as the company buying lunch every now and then, and having annual outings with the company. It is a laid back work environment.
cons: There is lack of communication and management can be very unorganized at times. There are constant major changes in processes, that can be hard to deal with if you don't adapt to change quickly.

headline: Great Place to Work - They really appreciate employees
pros: I liked this place from the day I started.  The onboarding process was straight forward.  The environment is conducive to getting work done and everyone is bright and cheery.  I am glad I left my deadbeat old job and moved here.
cons: Parking can be a tad difficult but other than that I havc to say this company does it right.  It would be nicer if I could park closer to the building.

headline: Bad for females
pros: Flexibility since you will be given Laptops. Compensation is good
cons: Since Male-Female ratio is not good. Being a female employee you might have to face lots of challenges if you are not willing to compromise on several factors. If you do not want to get involved with co-workers, then be ready for unfair treatment, ratings and work related challenges. The lobby culture is quite popular here and if your are not part of any lobby, you will be sidelined badly. Policies are good but when you want to avail it, you will be denied.

headline: Good work, life balance
pros: Great company for single mothers or fathers. Lots of growth opportunities.
cons: It's hard to move around unless you know someone.

headline: Good place to work
pros: great people, great culture. You are empowered to do what you think is right and pursue some of your own initiatives. They want you to be happy.
cons: Sometimes too much analysis is required to make decisions, leading to wasted time preparing additional information for easy decisions. Traffic around Tysons is very bad, but that is to be expected

headline: Great place for certain types of people
pros: There is a lot of opportunity if you are a self starter.
cons: There are sometimes almost constant reorgs. This can make it tough to build deep relationships with your management chain, but can give you a broader exposure.

headline: Constant org changes, good work-life balance
pros: Good overall work-life balance, good benefits. Job became nebulous and difficult to perform in the wake of so many organizational and mission changes.
cons:
Extremely difficult to get a promotion. The process expects that you work at the next level (in a "stretch role") for at least six months, sometimes a year, without any increase in pay. Additionally, the process states that there must be a need for someone at the next level in order for a position to be open. But since you're already doing the job while you're at the lower level, there's never a need to promote you or pay you more. Massively unfair catch-22. 

Nearly constant org changes. Very little value put on consistency of management presence -- it wasn't unusual for people to have 5 or more managers in a single year. The Virginia sites seem unable or unwilling to work with other sites across the nation. The culture on the Capital One campus in VA is strong, but they did not know how to make that culture work outside of VA.

headline: Capital One
pros: Benefits, PTO, Culture, Tenured Employees
cons: Large Company, Difficulty rolling out ideas due to large Customer base and impact

headline: Work-Life balance
pros: Work-life balance, advancement, people management, training, and compensation
cons: recruitment process- recruiters don't do a good job following up with internal candidates.

headline: Reflections on Capital One
pros: Definitely good benefits, training opportunities, and technology tools.  Campus is great and the ability to work mobile/remote is valued. Some managers care about their employees and can be great mentors/leaders.  Opportunity exists to move around and try different jobs as wanted.
cons: Performance management is brutal.  You are expected to achieve at a high level all the time and continue to take on more and more.  There is no work-life balance (trust me, I was there for over 15 years and I know what that looked like in the past).  If you don't work at least 50+ hours then you will be lucky to get a strong (meets expectations) rating.  Constant reorgs/shuffle of leadership.  More and more the focus is to bring in new college level resources and to hire outside management.  Most of old school Capital One leadership has been shipped out.  Also, promotion process is more about who you know (political) than your actual value/abilities.  It is a meat grinder at time...culture is now about what have you done for me today.  I definitively feel bad about how things are there now (have many friends there, all anxious about what will come next and if their job will be move to another location or cut or even managed out if they don't want to continue to work long hours with high stress).

headline: Rates and overall workplace
pros: Less than the average market around this place with the same skill sets or number of years of experience.
cons: Relative stability, No hassles of client letters for immigration purposes, flexible and adaptable work environment, aggressive on new technologies.

headline: Unit Mgr
pros: Employee friendly, COO and President would speak to everyone not just mgmt.  They took the time to have lunch with associates and talk about their past not just work issues
cons: Upper mgmt needed to treat employees better until  you get to the COO and President were exceptional

headline: Excellent Company
pros: Wants to work with employees to bring out full potential
cons: Salary is not based on a competitive market

headline: Great Company
pros: Capital One has repeatedly been selected as a top 100 company by Workplace Magazine (among many others) and deservedly so. The pay and benefits are great and the people who work there are amazingly supportive and wonderful. I can not say enough of how well they treat employees and the amazing work life balance.
cons: The only con was that being such a collaborative culture does sometimes slow down movement on projects. Also if not on a main campus you don't get as many perks (such as on site cafeteria or gym).

headline: Analyst review
pros:
Flexibility
Opportunity to work on cutting edge technology
cons: Static in terms of career progression

headline: Friendly environment
pros:
The environment is really friendly and encouraging.
People are helpful
No time restrictions
cons: Less number of people in India's office

headline: Worst Financial company for technologists
pros: Decent pay and flexible work from home options for some teams.
cons: The company tries to be a technology company. They really do not care about technologists. Very political. Even providing creative solutions that save the company lot of money will not get you rewarded. Layoffs every 3 to 6 months. Constant team changes every 6 months. I would not recommend this place for technologists if you want to rise up in career.

headline: Still the best big bank to work for...
pros: Overall, great place to work. Smart people, good benefits. Mr. Fairbank, the founder and CEO, is a rare gem; great vision and inspiring.
cons: The culture that the company was built is regressing towards the culture of the other big banks in the US.

headline: color barrier
pros: Great customers. If you dont have color, you will get the best positions, with the best pay
cons: Company pays women different from men. and if you have any color, expect the minimum. No matter how much work you put in. They will 3% bonus you forever! If you are exceeding in your position, again and have women parts or color, you will stay there. HR decides you are qualified for a promotion, set up an interview date, and local managers will not give you the interview. You will stay put!!! Period. Being proactive in your career will NOT get you promotion if you fit the description above.

headline: TECH Company
pros:
Great culture
Great ideas
Work life balance
cons:
Resource constraints
More starting than finishing

headline: Treats employees well - though trying to do more with less
pros: Great benefits - company was generous to its employees in terms of employee stock purchase plan, perks, etc.  Good bonus program and flexible time-off policies.  Felt employees were treated well, as a whole.
cons: Transition to Agile was a panful and challenging process - removed many well-regarded senior positions that had a wealth of knowledge.  Made the changes much riskier.

headline: Very Slow growth
pros: Very flexible, you can work on the campus from home, etc.
cons:
Salary wise under the average, performance evaluation process old and unfair, focus on friendship more than real metrics about your job performance..
The creer growth is very slow, not many opportunities to go up in the chain.

headline: Bank Teller
pros: The salary is decent for a part-time teller. You meet a lot of great people through the training process and even at your own branch. Of course, it will vary but I've been to several branches for training and everybody was nice. They aren't as pushy when it comes to sales goals like CHASE or Citi, but you are still expected to prospect each customer you take and offer them a product or to sit down with a banker. Retail banking is sales so its no surprise.
cons: Branch Managers that micro-manage their employees.

headline: Data Scientist at Capital One
pros:
(1) Interesting work: Capital One satisfies all three rules of the "advice to data scientist on where to work", as provided by Stitchfix. We leverages data Science for its strategic differentiation; we already have great data to work with (as opposed to aspiration to great data); and we are applying big data technologies to many green field opportunities for the first time. 

(2) Great team and great learning opportunities: since data scientist is still a relatively new profession, one of the most important criteria in my mind is whether you can still learn new things on the job. Capital One as a company is strategically embracing open-source technologies such as Hadoop, python/R, Spark, AWS... etc, and there are many open-minded and experienced data scientists on the team, so that we can still continue to improve our capabilities.

(3) Competitive compensation and great work-life balance. The work life balance is definitely encouraged here. Some people have long commute, but if their job nature allows them to work from home, there is no cultural stigma associated with that. In fact, several members in our extended team work from home on a regular basis (a few days a week).

(4) Company culture: we really are changing banking for good, and the actions we take as company reflect this core value.
cons: Financial industry is heavily regulated as a whole, so if you are used to software-industry speeds, you may feel that things don't move as quickly (especially on things that concerns financial regulations)

headline: great company with great benefits
pros:
I love my work family. I am in Retail Branch Banking, so I know the environment is different from back office positions. 
4 weeks PTO
Health Insurance
Dental
401k
etc
cons: always making changes in staffing. also always changing goals, and focusing too much on customer service scored. Customer service scores are rated 1-5, and anything less than a 5 is failing. Even if the customer comments say the service was excellent.

headline: Sr. Fraud Account Supervisor
pros: Wow! I am approaching my one year anniversary with Capital One! There are so many awesome things about this company,,,, I could go on and on. Fantastic medical benefits starting on day one of employment, generous vacation time, matching 401k, four day workweek, recognition for performance, family atmosphere, raises based on empirical data not how much you kiss butt, team focused, fantastic training which is ongoing, excellent support from management, real time feedback on your performance, wonderful work atmosphere, and overall a very well managed company! And free coffee, not French Vanilla, but free!
cons: I can only say great things about this great company!

headline: Capital One information
pros: Capital One has good overall benefits with a nice 401(k) plan and stock purchase plan.  It's a well known company who maintains a fun culture throughout all divisions.
cons: The pay is overall not too strong and some divisions through the company can seem to have less opportunities then say, the credit card division.

headline: CapOne
pros: Good benefits, most employees seem dedicated to making their teams excel
cons: Frequent management shakeups, tendency to jump on the bandwagon for the latest fad in project management and IT direction.

headline: Pretty Great
pros: - great team and collaborative environment
cons: - some of the management got stagnant and lazy in their job

headline: Fair workplace
pros: Very professional. Good controls of employes. Incentives.
cons: Turnover rate was high. Not enough staff at all branches.

headline: Manager, Commercial Bank
pros: Fantastic culture, great company & very flexible depending on which division/ manager you work for.
cons: Management - too many politics and decisions that don't make business sense, quite disorganized with too many location changes.  Promotions that don't make sense either.. Need to do a better job of rewarding middle layer managers.

headline: Customer Service Call Center
pros: Good benefits,  PTO, and bonuses
cons: Call centers in general are boring, but that's all companies.

headline: Good things for good places
pros:
1. The Team - The people there genuinely want you to succeed.  they understand this may be a foot in the door job and not your first love.  But they willing to help you find it.
2. communication - I was never in the dark about "how I was doing".  The feedback was relevant and brief. With expansions as needed.
cons:
My job ended. They pulled the trigger a year early because of finances and closed the site. I feel this was a bad move as they had goals of increasing their Net Promoter Score, but now they have all new staff. 
Parking wasn't great but it wasn't the worst either

headline: Capital One does Change Banking for Good!
pros: Capital One is a bank with a high-performance culture that recognizes and rewards talent while also staying true to its core values and mission: "Change Banking for Good". Great organization!
cons: As a large regional bank, Capital One does not have a national footprint and most of the best jobs / growth opportunities are in VA.

headline: decent job
pros: company focuses on employee moral
cons: maybe too focused on fun days and rallys

headline: Small business
pros: Good benefits, medical, dental, 401k, stock options.  Company has the interest of the customer first, which is a pro and a con.  It was a company that I would work again for if i had the opportunity.
cons: The company is trying to go digital.  With small business accounts and some folks just don't like to do banking online.  I think this may be the wrong direction...I guess they will see.

headline: Assistant Branch Manager
pros: Good company to work!!!Good benefits.
cons: Outdated technology!!!Too many changes.Jobs tittle elimination.

headline: Overall great place to work
pros: There is a very energetic environment. I really feel like I'm making a contribution, and given the company culture, I imagine most people feel the same way.
cons: Annual percentage raises are pretty small compared to where I worked previously.

headline: Cool place
pros: Great with people in company
cons: sometimes the pay isn't enough

headline: Administrative Assistant/Principal Coordinator
pros: Capital screens its employees carefully. The position is multi-faceted and possibility to advance is available. Training is always available to the employee and it is expected that employee earn a certain number credits each year.
cons: For me the biggest downside was frequently being moved to a different location. A lot of reorganization was taking place and the executives and directors I supported changed frequently.

headline: Sr. Risk Coordinator
pros: you get paid every 2 week and incentives if you are good at it
cons: Career development hard to move in company

headline: N/A
pros: Work/Life balance, competitive pay, best in class people
cons: None to note at this time

headline: Awesome
pros: Benefits, room for development, many career options, flexible work schedule, family friendly
cons: Lots of change, massive organization, competitive environment (could be a pro for some)

headline: Treasury management
pros: Treasury at Capital One is filled with amazing potential.  The excitement is so thick you can feel it from everyone.   The innovative approach pioneered by the card group flows throughout the organization.  Almost everyone is supportive and encourages using the consultative approach and adapting new practices for the improvement of the bank.
cons: Management is too 'old school' bank focused.  There is a glacial pace around innovation that is extremely contrasted with the card side of the bank.  Management is quick to use buzzwords and speak the language of design thinking, agile methods, but when a decision point is reached the team reverts back to traditional, waterfall style management.  This lack of real innovation is coupled with a horrible political management style that is promotes through who you know more than what you produce.  It is a shame because there is so much potential waiting to explode out of the commercial bank the tension is exhausting.  The better team is small business.

headline: Great Company to Work For
pros:
Great Company. They really care about their employees. I never had an issue with HR or the Company as a whole.
(#91 on Forbes top 100 Best Companies to work for) I absolutely would work for Capital One Again .
cons: Unfortunately, They can't directly control the lower department management which can make your work experience H.E.L.L., Which was my case.

headline: Great to Work There
pros: Company has solid mission and values. Great benefits, and an excellent environment.
cons: While the mission is great, some individual interpretations of the values or mission are not the same as the overall company.

headline: Like it
pros: Great  company to work for!
cons: not bad at all. great atmoshpere

headline: I love Capital One culture
pros: it is the best group of people I have ever worked with. big drive to turn the industry on it's head.
cons: I can't think of anything negative. Banking is a tough industry and changes are incremental. One must have the stamina for that.

headline: experience at capital one
pros: great work culture and smart employees
cons: starting to become too corporate with politics. Difficult to get promoted

headline: IT Director
pros: Good culture, pay, flexible work hours, benefits.
cons: Company direction in IT changes too much. Latest change is a wild and reckless move that cannot succeed.

headline: IT
pros: Good place to get entry level experience and good benefits such as health, vacation and retirement.
cons: Current associates are often overlooked for advancement since they place a higher value on contractors. Also, in IT, more attention is given to younger workers with little to no experience as compare to older ones who bring knowledge and experience.

headline: Senior Ops. Assciate
pros: Great benefits, good corporate perks. Good work life balance
cons: Unorganized management, very difficult to move up in ranks. Often very difficult to take of for personal matters or anything.

headline: Banking Industry
pros: You learn a lot with IT and Banking.
cons: Keep up with training associates

headline: Capital One Review
pros:
-The pay is nice
-The benefits are also good
-The atmosphere was enjoyable
-The employers and managers were accommodating and friendly 
-Flexible dress code
cons: -The work environment was very fast paced.

headline: Mortgage Loan Originator
pros: Comp Plan, Benefits, Stock purchase plan, generous with marketing and the best part is operations.
cons: Not enough programs to be successful.

headline: Sr.Systems Coordinator, ops
pros: Great benefits, diverse environment, many monetary awards and phone agents receive hourly wages plus commission.
cons: it's hard to move up. salaries are always at the minimum part of the table

headline: Overall, good company to work for.
pros: Great brand to be associated with.  Good growth opportunities if you get a manager who will stand behind you and coach you in the right direction.  Lots of smart people to work with.  Fast-paced with lots of change, keeps the job from getting boring.
cons: Very competitive culture forces employees to push for themselves more than for the team.  Slow to add new technology.  Hard to push new ideas as too many believe they do it the best way possible already so why change.  Employees acquired struggle to be accepted as equal in value.

headline: Great First Job
pros: Top-tier people. Strongest analytics team in the F500. Best business job that gets you close with customers.
cons: Huge difference in quality of work depending on which team you are on. If you're in an area that is heavily regulated, you'll do a lot of one-off small-scale work that is tedious and ignored during promotion decisions.

headline: Mortgage
pros: Excellent Benefits and a fun work environment
cons: Consolidating to Plano, TX from DE

headline: Fraud Decisioning-Coordinator
pros: Great Benefits, Company promotes good teamwork and  rewards employees substantially for accomplishments. Also working for Capital Once contributes to a great sense of pride in being able to contribute to protecting customer accounts when they have been victimized.
cons: Site-Closure-Relocation is not an option.

headline: Great Place to start
pros: Great benefits, and an excellent training program. exceptional place to work
cons: Don't look at all the aspects of your numbers. The branch I was at ended up closing, but for the year leading up to it closing, we as bankers were blamed for not reaching our goals when we really just didn't have the traffic and were exhausting our resources.

headline: IT Help Desk
pros: Good company benefits. Some opportunities for advancement.
cons: It is a relatively new company so they have some IT organizational issues that can be resolved with implementing ITIL.

headline: CapOne
pros: Great place to work with fantastic benefits, flexible scheduling and extremely knowledgeable people.  They are also well known for their company's charitable contributions both monetarily and through employee volunteering.
cons: They are currently working toward becoming more of a technology based company rather than staying within their current functionality (banking) and these changes are negatively impacting their employees within IT (short term) and I believe they will also have a negative impact on customers (long term).

headline: Senior Mortgage Loan Officer
pros: Company culture; benefits; campus; compensation
cons: Pay was excellent however compensation was drastically decreased in order to be inline with other major bank compensation however business was not at same level of other major banks.

headline: Ehhh its an ok place to work
pros:
Training is paid and mileage as well.
Great atmosphere in training.
Get to work with a diversity of people.
Always something to do.
Payouts if you hit goals.
Great customers.
Modern
cons:
Small group to work with everyday.
Very numbers oriented.
Get ready to get yelled at a lot by managment.
Must have thick skin.
No way to balance work and life with little flexibility (depending on your manager)
Get ready to work 6 days a week with no days off.

headline: Capital One Bank Student Branch Intern
pros: Family feel, hands on experience, great pay, ever lasting experience, provided gift cards for business attire, great networking, great professional preperation
cons: customers would often downplay me because of my age

headline: It was ok
pros: Good benefits, no stress and managers rarely bothered you
cons: Little ways to be promoted, felt meaningless, tellers and bankers didn't take it seriously

headline: IT senior manager
pros:
Cutting edge technology
Good benefits
Big with many locations
cons:
changes too often
not well managed
IT strategy does not account for how to get there

headline: Good Working Environment
pros: There are multiple pros associated with work here: There are good outside development opportunities, job opportunities, analytical work and technical projects.
cons: There are a few cons associated with work here at Capital One. The largest is the size of the company and some of the repetitive work

headline: teller
pros:
great benefits 
great 401(k)
employees work hard
cons:
long hours
too many changes happening too fast

headline: Director
pros: Compensation, High Caliber Employees, Strong strategic plan
cons: Large group decisions, absolutely adverse to taking risks, lack of expense control, doesn't provide employee empowerment

headline: Relationship Banker
pros: Great for someone who is good at, and likes, sales. The company provides countless resources to help make you a better salesperson and have more success with the company. A competitive yet supportive atmosphere among the bankers, for the most part. In the branches, everyone is incentivised based on team goals.
cons:
Graded in many different areas, but the only ones that hold significant weight for promotions are the sales goals. Only a worthwhile position to take if you are extremely sales-oriented. 

The changing environment in the banking industry makes it so that people are afraid of layoffs as positions are phased out to make room for newer, often lower-paid, positions. The recent removal of all Assistant Branch Managers has made many people in lower positions afraid for their jobs.

headline: Overall a decent place to work!
pros:
A great starting salary
Warm, friendly environment
Benefits are awesome
Employee ideas and suggestion taking into consideration
Promote from within
cons: Quite a few changes within the company that seemed unnecessary or made matters worse.

headline: Good Company
pros: Well managed company with great resources and plenty of advancement potential.
cons: Sometimes suffers from analysis paralysis but generally it's for the best.

headline: Good Benefits, Unorganized
pros:
They have good benefits and lots of money to take care of people. Really trying hard to be a technology company.
All the people there are the nicest bunch of people you'll meet
cons:
Backend systems are a mess. Down lots.
They also believe in throwing lots of people on a project, hoping that more people will make things go faster.

headline: Principle Coordinator
pros: Great benefits, location lots of business lunches, some work from home, career planning,
cons: Ranked quarterly and forced distribution. 15% get needs improvement and may be fired

headline: business director
pros: The people are great, the culture is great, and it is a meritocracy where you can advance quickly if you are talented
cons: There have been some growing pains causing some people to struggle as Capital One tries to become more tech oriented and has transitioned to a mission oriented company

headline: Analyst
pros: Great work place to be .
cons: Nothing to be more precise

headline: Thumbs Up
pros: They offer great training opportunities
cons: still growing in the bank business compared to local competition. will improve in time

headline: Banking on decline
pros: work life balance, ability to set your own agenda
cons: technology and systems don't always work well, lots of redundant processes, communication between various departments

headline: Excellent
pros: Benefits, flexibility, great environment,  great branch buildings and strong training. I been with the company for almost six months and it's been a great experience so far.
cons: Reduced amount of programs, no bilingual processing and loan specialist support. Most of the times I have to get involve in the loan process on clients that as not English speakers.

headline: Junior Underwriter
pros: My manager was very nice and there was no micro management
cons: When it came to promotions it was solely based on who liked you so a lot of people are promoted but cannot underwrite loans. There's a lot of favoritism and the salary was about 20% less than their competitors which is why I left.

headline: Capital One 360
pros: Great people and company to work for.
cons: The job itself is draining and competitive.

headline: Good Company
pros: Flexible work schedule, excellent benefits
cons: Lots of organization restructures, which could result in layoff

headline: IT Manager
pros: Great work life balance. Alot of work location flexibility.. ie. WFH, not remote however. Decent pay and  bonus structure.
cons:
Way too much upper mgmt attrition. No leadership in Plano for IT Tech Ops. President has this vision of moving the entire IT footprint to the cloud in 4 years. 
Performance Management process is outdated and flawed. Needs serious overhaul.

headline: Is what it is...
pros: Good hours for mothers.  You can go to school or another part time job if you have to.
cons: System needs upgrading always shutting down and offline.  System shuts down in the middle of transactions. Back office never able to help.

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: Flexibly with students and family
cons: No advancement it's hard to move up

headline: Too good to be true
pros: Many "Best Place to Work" Awards and seemingly strong support of Associates. One of the most positive things is how well they treat you when you've been laid off (not me, but has happen to many teams/friends)
cons: Pay for awards and only faux support of Associates - when it comes down to it, you'll work long hours and be stuck in middle management (at the best).

headline: Great company to work for. Very dynamic and has growth opportunity.
pros: Very focused on associate development and brand awareness.
cons: Your job satisfaction is tied to your line of business. Some business units excel in building morale and teamwork, where others are silo'd and have very low job satisfaction. Move around!

headline: Home Loans Team Manager
pros: Pay was better than average
cons: We were led to believe that there was a commitment to our team only to lay the entire department off a year later

headline: Unit Manager
pros: Great Mission, Great benefits, Great people
cons: Not enough pay for the amount of work.

headline: Legal Coordinator
pros: The pros of working for Capital One are the vast opportunities available in multiple fields, the incentive programs provided, the extensive learning opportunities and the great benefits provided to employees.
cons: The downsides of working with Capital One are the lack of equal incentive programs between the banking and credit card sectors of the company. Also a con is the lack of stability in employment.

headline: Job at capital one
pros: Great campus,vacation policies,nice benefits,cafeteria,tech support,latest devices.
cons: Too much pressure,expected work 24/7,unfair evaluations,too many politics,no family work life balance,unfair salary range,work like a robot.

headline: Sr. Fraud Coordinator
pros: okay work environment. Mgrs in my department very understanding. Company tries to show belief  in family values. upon notice of separation from the Oregon area company did provide generous severance.
cons: Favored toward Richmond. Big company taking hits from poor business decisions causes loss of employment and to make up for it moves overseas.

headline: Compliance
pros: Great culture, above average salary and growth.
cons: Too many meetings at times

headline: Dealer Funding
pros: Great company culture, great people.
cons: Specifically with me, the only con is how difficult it is to obtain an education reimbursement. Long story short, it seems the system was designed to make it as difficult as possible to obtain educational assistance. I remember when I worked at Racetrac some year back I literally just submitted an application and the company would send a check to the school. I wish it were that simple here. Case in point, I paid out of pocket last semester and was never able to get through all the red tape and obtain a reimbursement.

headline: Best People
pros: They hire the best people and have a true interest in developing their employees.
cons: Ultra competitive, and job security is always in limbo.

headline: Great Opportunities
pros: Capital One is a great culture.  You always work with very smart people.  Their is plenty of room to grow and develop.  The environment fosters and rewards an entrepreneurship mindset.  Leadership and direction of the company is great (just review the growth trajectory!).
cons: It can be a bit of a meat-grinder.  The down-side to the constantly upward movement of "the bar" encourages a continual stretch year-over-year.  Good for young people, hard on the older ones.

headline: Work life balance and people are great
pros: Work life balance is emphasized. People are all open to questions as it is a very collaborative environment. Some bureaucracy in promotions, but people that perform higher than their peers generally get the recognition and promotions they deserve. Location is great, in the suburbs.
cons: No big ones here. Nothing that would drive me away. Sometimes decision making is slow if you don't talk to the right people.

headline: They left state
pros: best job ever, good hours, fair pay. wonderful support and thoughtful caring management
cons: They left state. best job ever

headline: Really Happy to Join the company
pros: I only joinedCapital One in about a week.  But I am very pleased to be its employee.  They treat employee well.  Capital One offer a very good benefits package and generous 401K match (up to 7.5% of your salary in total).  Nice facilities. Free variety of gourmet coffee, nutrition drinks and snacks, including subsidized lunch.
cons: Can't say anything for now

headline: Loan Specialist
pros: Company benefits were great especially the 401K match program.  Pretty decent support from senior leadership but my direct manager was horrible.
cons: Direct manager was horrible.  They have too many meetings and the daily huddles were a great idea, but the manager was horrible at it so it just dragged on and on.

headline: Sr. Support Specialist
pros: Great place to work, many avenues for growth opportunities, a forward thinking work environment down to the ergonomics.
cons: There are too many managers that could just function as team leads instead.

headline: Under paid,  over worked, and managers lead individuals by creating fear not by positive examples or encouragement.
pros: Health benefits and paid time of were nice as well as the paid bank holidays.
cons: Low wages,  high call volume,  no support, weekends are mandatory, and managers are all slave drivers.

headline: Flexible, supportive, interesting
pros: new exciting projects, lots of mobility, tons of support from management, flexibility on hours and vacation
cons: not the highest salary and benefits, lots of restrictions and regulations on technology due to financial institution regulations, some issues migrating from out-sourced to in-house engineers

headline: Business Manager
pros: Great people, great culture, fact and data based strategy
cons: Not much on the bad side

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Great place to work. Team environment. Each day was different. I loved the people I worked with. I  learned new things every day.
cons: Too many company reorganizations. It is very hard to get promoted. You must work on highly visible projects in some departments in order to get promoted.

headline: Operations Manager
pros: Leadership cared about their employees and customers.  They hired good people and did the best they could to retain them.  Benefits and health plan were great.
cons: Career pathing in retail bank was not clear.  Many good employees left the company for another job as they were in their same position for years.

cons: not really work life balance, high turnover rate

headline: Customer Service Representatives
pros: The team was great, the supervisor was fantastic, the benefits were great and the job responsibilities with the people were super.
cons: Working at home made it feel isolated and alone. I would have rather been at brick and mortar to communicate with my team better and to see face to face all those with whom I worked.

headline: Unit Manager

cons: Long hours and can be somewhat layered.  interaction and communication from site to site can be cumbersome and iffy.  Technology support is off-shore most of the time and can be frustrating

headline: Vice President

headline: Master Systems Intigrator
pros: Company as a whole is very employee focused and takes care of there employee. They provide training when required and when it is in the best interest of the associate. Most managers take of their team ensure they have everything they need to be successful.
cons: Some managers within Capital One are the same as other companies. All projects need to get done ahead of schedule regardless of the complexity or lack of valid requirements. The thought is to just put something out there so it can be said it is done and hope it doesn't cause a SEV 1 incident and causing major rework to repair applications that do not work well.  These managers have a detrimental affect on employee work / life balance.

headline: Bank teller

cons: The constantly changing weekly schedule made it difficult to determine when i'll be able to take care of other errands. Sometimes customers tend to become rude due to the fact that their wait in line was a bit longer than usual.

headline: Plano
pros: Overall, solid company with well defined culture, good benefits and the company is doing well.  CEO works very hard to provide a clear strategic vision.
cons:
Your employment experience will be highly dependent on your manager.  As with any company, some of the leaders and people managers lack key people skills.  Its difficult to compete with your manager's drinking buddy.... unless of course, you are the drinking buddy.
  
Leadership decisions from the CEO down result in continuous change.  Just when you think things have settled and you are on a clear path, org and direction changes force you to reset the foundation.

headline: Coordinator
pros: Excellent health and dentist benefits. Other benefits include matching 401k after 5 years you become fully vested. They provide 3 weeks paid vacation after your first year of employment and you can buy an extra week. After 5 years of employment they offer 4 weeks of vacation and you are able to buy an extra week of vacation.
cons: I have made less money every year at Capital One since I started!!! $29,000 a year to start. I made $30,000 salary and made $5000 in incentive bonus in 2015. Capital One has consistently dropped the top pay out incentive every year for the past 5 years.  Don't plan on getting a year end raise!! This is a joke! If you get an Exceptional rating you might get a raise between 4% and 5%. A Very Strong rating is between 3% and 4% yearly pay raise . A strong is around a 3% raise. The whole idea at Capital One is to get promoted. This is a joke!!! If you get promoted to a higher position, the most that they will offer is a 10% raise!!!

headline: Be aware of what you're getting into
pros: Excellent pay for my field
cons:
Good old boy network is in full force at Cap 1. I am in a technical role and expected for the stellar pay that everyone hired would have commensurate technical abilities. 80% of my team had NO TECHNICAL EXPERIENCE at all and were hired to run a data center. Out of those 80%, ALL of them were "buddy" hires. Cap 1 works on antiquated tech policies that are barriers to getting anything resolved quickly. It's as if all Cap 1 full time employees came from the government sector. The brilliant idea to hire offshore technical support is just asinine. In my 2 years here I have only met one offshore counterpart that knew anything that could be remotely construed as actual technical knowledge. The money they lose in downtime of systems alone is mind-boggling.  

Now for the bad news. Ready? If you're a contractor you have a 2 year life span. That wouldn't be so bad if you went into the gig knowing that, but most likely your recruiter fails to mention that. In fact no one on my team knew that until almost their 2 yr mark. Several people only had a 2 week notice their contract was ending. This was 4 days after Management came in to address that we would be there for several more years despite technical changes to their model. Apparently no one, including Cap 1 Mgmt or the Recruiters "knew" it was a 2 yr contract, as if it was a surprise to them. Ironically, my entire team reported to and was directly managed by Cap 1 mgmt. And with that announcement came the real face of Cap 1.  After stringing us on with becoming full time employees for two years, we suddenly became anathema--- just disposable contractors. I couldn't even get management to return my emails on anything, including their plan to supposedly bring us back on after a 90 day hiatus. Neither could my co workers. They did bring two people over as full time associates prior to the announcement. And ironically, they were two members of the good ol' boy network. 

That aside, management is clueless. They are all "yes men" marching in lockstep to edicts from above that are devoid of reality in the trenches. The pay was great, there was little politics I had to deal with at my level, but the reality is you;re a second class citizen and no amount of hard work, loyalty, or dedication is going to change that. If you go into it knowing it's at MOST a 2 yr contract and can plan accordingly with that, you should be fine. Don't buy into the hype though, mostly they are looking for warm bodies to fill positions as a numbers game because their inefficiency and productivity isn't one of their concerns apparently.

headline: Collections
pros:
Great vacation benefits.
Good 401k 
Decent office setting
Lots of holiday meals provided
Decent bonuses
Lots of paid bank holidays
cons:
Training is completely subpar. My trainer was gone in meetings 90% of the time and had an employee from the floor babysit the class, but we were hardly trained at any point in time. 

The dialer is a disaster and crashes half the time. 

My manager was atrociously bad. If questioned, she would put her own team members off onto another manager because she didn't know the answers to problems. She yelled at staff and encouraged them to quit if they fell below 100% because they would make her look bad. She had the "best" Mini Miranda team in the location because she would bully and humiliate employees until they quit. 


The system and phones were slow and often crashed or hung up on customers. It was not uncommon for the computer to freeze and crash once a day or more. The entire system would crash for the entire site and we would have irate customers screaming at us while we couldn't use the system to take payments.


The QA team is extremely meticulous, which is fine, except agents are not trained on what counts against them. There is varying answers among teams. You will almost never get a legitimate answer because every single manager believes QA does something differently. These passings/failings mean you don't get bonuses depending on how bad you did.

headline: AML Compliance
pros: There are flexible schedules, especially around the holidays. You can also purchase more vacation days. They offer work from home twice a week in the department. The benefits are great as well as the break room!

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Fast growing in SF. Great office spaces, resources, and culture (in the SF offices). Benefits are amazing. It's not a typical stuffy bank environment and the company is focused on disrupting the bank industry.
cons: HQ based in DC so it can be hard to push things forward quickly if working with colleagues from corporate HQ. The SF culture is vastly different from the corporate culture in DC. DC associates don't seem to understand the growth in SF and what digital teams are trying to accomplish.

headline: Nice place to work, limited advancement
pros: Capital one has good benefits, competitive pay, flexible hours and nice campuses. Employees are generally given the required authority and resources to to their jobs and I would say senior management is fairly decent overall. It's a nice place to work..but...
cons: Advancement opportunities are extremely limited in most business units and promotions can take a very very long time to go through. Most of the guys I worked with ended up having to leave for other employers to advanced even after years in the same job and getting stellar annual reviews.

headline: Great option for banking career
pros: decent pay and benefit, nice people, great working environment
cons: Not so much so far

headline: Fraud Detection Coordinator
pros: Not an inbound call center position, excellent training, great benefits. Discovering fraud is often fun and having the opportunity to help people is very rewarding.
cons: Case work can often be repetitive and job is often boring. Overall, moving up  in your position means that you would have to manage people. So if you're not aiming to be a people manager, you can't go too far.

headline: Lots of politics
author_position: Capital One Front Line Manager Call Center
pros:
-Great Benefits (medical, dental, stock purchase, 401k, vision)
-Good Training (both instructor led and online
cons: Capital One Bank is a good place to work until it is not. Leadership has no problem spending money, celebrating, and going out of their way to entice their non-exempt staff to work excessive overtime. Capital One Bank has a new org chart every 4-6 months, so you will spend a lot of time feeling like you are spinning your wheels. As I mentioned before they don't mind spending money, they will spend it to keep you and spend it to get rid of you. Lots of lay-offs. Mid level management gets things done by turning entry level managers against each other. Very cut throat.

headline: Great company with equally good benefits
pros: This place has a tech-company vibe. I appreciate the energy and the enthusiasm my coworkers bring to the table. Above all else, teamwork is paramount at Capital One. The lone rangers and credit-takers don't last here. As far as the benefits, they are very competitive within the banking industry - probably the best of all the big retail banks.
cons: While I feel fairly compensated, others (especially) in more junior roles, may not feel the same. Work hard and move up or negotiate on the way in to manage your compensation appropriately. That should go without saying, but you will find many employees sharing the same disheartening sentiment.

headline: Inconsistent Organizational Strategy

headline: Micro-management to the extreme

cons: Extreme micromanagement. You have to put "appointments" on your outlook calendar and share them with your district manager so they can call you out on the weekly banker call. Most bankers end up putting their walk in customer as their 'appointments' so it's all just an effort to appease higher ups.

headline: Company changes rapidly
pros:
Great benefits for part-timers:
-plenty of vacation time
-401k with company matching
-decent starting pay
cons: The company tries to change with technology and keep up with the competition. In doing so they consolidate a lot of positions, but instead of allowing lower level employees to gain promotions they instead shuffle around older employees and even allow upper level associates to take demotions when they are not meeting their goals or performance standards.....which is good for them but terrible for younger/newer employees looking to advance within the company.

headline: Finance
pros: Great opportunities for career growth

headline: Great pay, good benefits, no security and competitive culture
pros: Capital One facilities are great places to work with many ammenities.  The pay is high for the Richmond area and the benefits are better/as good as any other company around.
cons: The culture is now of a BIG bank and they now have lost the culture that originally drove folks to apply.  The performance management system is rigid, political and competitive to a fault (I am a high-performing associate, but don't like how it works - good people get screwed over).  There are continual cuts every year, and it seemingly is targeting long-time/older folks in the workforce.  A ton of experience has been redeployed from the company over the years.  There is a move to Mclean, DL, and Chicago for jobs, so Richmond has the most limited hiring, which limits your options for growth.  You WILL work REALLY hard for that salary and more and more folks are logging in to work more hours late at night and on the weekends to keep up.

headline: Innovative, congenial culture - definitely not your traditional bank!
pros: I've been there 5 years, working mostly in Card Technology, and the company feels more like a vibrant academic laboratory than a stuffy corporate office. It's a real dynamic, open, collaborative and modern environment. There's a huge corporate focus on innovation, and my colleagues are extremely intelligent and hardworking. Company is a great place if you are personally open to change and dynamic (and I mean constant change every 6 months in terms of organizational structure and strategic priorities); on the other hand, it's not a great place if you are a old time 'good ole boys' kind of banker. Another positive is the organization is structured around cross-functional teams and so usually decisions are driven by consensus and not by a single authority - so the decision making process on almost any task requires continuous collaboration among associates at all levels and roles. GREAT company if you are right out of college and looking for meaningful work. College hires are given meaningful work and given a wide latitude of ownership. Also the benefits packages are great: 7.5% 401(k) matching, medical / dental / vision plans, and (while definitely on the lower end) there's modest educational assistance although some star middle-manger performers are given full-funded MBA tuition. WORK/LIFE balance is awesome! You get 3 weeks vacation plus 10 paid holidays and unlimited sick time (within reason). Overall, associates are super friendly, congenial and excited to come to work. It's really this entrepreneurial, hardworking and amiable culture that's kept me here.
cons: Given the company's 'start up' feel there's no real career pathing. This can either excite you or distress you - and it's not uncommon in some areas for an associate to have sometimes 4-5 people managers in 1 year. Capital One really requires you to 'own your career,' meaning it's up to you to manage your manager, write your objectives, and move your career at the company in the direction you want it to go. I find this exciting but others get burned out by what they feel is lack of support and direction. But on the plus side I've never had a manager who didn't encourage me to explore new opportunities. Another downside is performance management can overly focus on softer items like communication, etc. which can seem at times nit picky and trivial, ignoring meatier results and hard skills.

headline: Not The Company It Used to Be
pros: I have the pleasure of working with some extremely talented, intelligent people. My manager is engaged, responsive and helpful. The PTO and insurance benefits package are excellent.
cons: Morale is low following recent layoffs and constant changes in leadership and direction. No one I know feels secure in their position and many associates were randomly placed into jobs with no regard for their skillsets or interests or had additional work added to their role that they are not equipped to handle. Change can be good, but forcing people in roles with no consideration of their competencies or career goals makes for an stressful environment and sets people up for failure. People can embrace change if it is well presented and implemented as a smooth transition as opposed to the shot gun approach used currently. Many of the current senior leaders are relatively new to the company (less than 5 years)and have made drastic changes to the culture of the company with less and less focus on people over processes and tools. Associates are not respected and receive important communications via pre-recorded messages or email with no ability to ask questions. The recent exodus of key leaders is concerning and politics is king as the remaining leaders try to keep their jobs and newer leaders attempt to make their mark.

headline: Enjoy at work
pros: Good environment to work and nothing. Really only the environment is good.
cons: Except the environment there is nothing else which is worth it. Everything else is bad.

headline: Enjoyed It
pros: Great people and great high level vision.
cons: Performance management too political and not rewarded for delivery.

headline: Universal Branch Associate
pros: Good training, and you learn a lot on the job. Great ladder to get to a banker position.
cons:
Tough for promotion within company.
Scary job stability with so many jobs being cut.

headline: Growth makes culture difficult to navigate
pros: Strong benefits, good salary structure, health services and gyms in house in many locations
cons: Navigating the culture from a remote or new location can be very difficult.

headline: Review
pros: Salary is competitive and the benefits are good
cons: Capital One does not have any Cons

headline: Manager, IT Operations
pros: Great corporate culture established. Aggressive in adopting technology solutions.
cons: Recently reduced IT workforce in 2015.

headline: Used to be better - now mostly awful
pros: Decent benefits, good pay for Richmond, subsidized food on campus
cons: Capital one used to be a great place to work - most old timers can agree on that. In more recent years they seem to have lost their way. Coherent, integrated strategy is lacking. Performance management focuses only on results and bright shiny objects. Managers have a cursory knowledge of how to effectively manage people, and leadership is lacking all around. Some departments are hiring only externally and ignoring internal candidates in favor of fresh blood. Ironically, this hasn't done much to improve the quality or speed of products coming out, nor has it helped overall morale. Most people I know here are smart, capable and deeply unhappy - they see it as a means to an end. A lot are trapped as this is one of the top employers in Richmond. This will change over the years as new companies start to move to town, but evolution here is slow. The people who are the most successful here are the ones most willing to play the game and play at the expense of others in many cases. A lot of senior management has been here since the beginning of time, and this is all they know.

headline: great company
pros: great benefits. high recommended company to work for.
cons: none tcome to mind. just work hard every day!

headline: Great company to work for! Cares about Employees and Customers

-Lots of re-orgs and a bloated middle management tier that is tough to break through

headline: Funding Analyst

Management doesn't have experience in field. Most managers were promoted from different departments and contribute little help to their team. Very much a whip-cracker type management style. The managers can't do their team's work. 
The job is very monotonous. 
If you're used to origination or market type jobs this is definitely not the right job. This is closer to a call center atmosphere.

headline: Honest review

cons: QAs based on perception, hard to transfer to another department, eliminated departments to "streamline" heavy emphasis to build rapport with customers even if the customer didn't want to, despite them telling you in orientation that there are no favorites believe me there are. If a manager likes you they will cover for you. They wanted us to go above and beyond for customers to the point they were giving away the bank

headline: Great company with opportunities for advancement and great salary.

The atmosphere is amazing and the people at work make you actually enjoy our job.  The management is amazing and make you feel like you are actually valued in the company.
The pay is wonderful and monthly incentives are phenomenal.

Hours are horrible and the amount of shift swaps is few and far between.
Not a great job for people with families because they are normally 10 hours shifts.
Company is corporate so the higher ups focus on business needs versus the employees.
