headline: Senior Associate
pros: Great work/life balance. The benefits are really amazing. They seem to value their employees as a whole, though certain departments are consistently overlooked. There are some really great people with a wealth of industry knowledge.
cons: Poor senior management. Certain departments are undervalued and used as a dumping ground for displaced employees. Since the acquisition of HSBC, there seemed to be a sense of entitlement from the legacy Capital One employees with a reluctance to accept and work with the acquired employees. Now that two more of the large sites acquired are being closed and work is being moved to the main corporate location, it's a bit of a moot point.

headline: review of capital one
pros: It is an okay company to work for.  At the most senior levels they company has a vision and communicates that yearly to all associates.
cons: Leadership is not on the same page.  Very slow to get things done - too much socialization.  Not enough trust in the associates.

headline: Trainer
pros: Great high energy environment. Great Benefits.
cons: Sometimes hard to get changes made in the company.

headline: Good opportunity
pros: One of the very few large banks that you actually believe is trying to keep a morally justifiable course.  All of the horrible headlines about big banks during the financial meltdown largely did not apply to Capital One.  They are constantly trying new things and expanding into new areas.  Their campuses in Richmond and Plano are top notch, and at least when I was there compensation was above average.
cons: Constant churn internally.  Director and up are constantly moved around, often times just to provide change for change's sake.  A department that is running well is almost guaranteed to be largely disbanded within a year.  Some people enjoy a new job every year, others not so much.  Constant heavy pressure to perform with overly ambitious goals set by senior leadership.

headline: Experience as a TDP intern
pros: Tech at Capital One definitely breaks the stigma of being a large financial company. Offices look similar to what you find at large tech companies. Intern events provided were a lot of fun.
cons: The work given to some interns, including me, wasn't the greatest. I learned a lot more from a voluntary project for interns than my actual job function.

headline: People Manager
pros:
Great work life balance
Solid Benefits
Plenty of opportunity for front line associates
They care about what their associates think to a fault
cons: they feel they can pay less because they have family fall festivals or spring flings, when I say less we're talking 20% of what the market pays. I'd rather pay my bills or drive a newer car than go to some dumb outing. The DFW area is saturated with auto finance companies and COAF constantly loses talent to competition.

headline: Sr Manager, Process Management
pros: Great and really smart people, associate focused culture, very good benefits, strategy that helps the company survive through hard times.
cons: Current state of financial services industry is making cost savings the primary focus; too much pressure to reduce costs, long time to grow in the company, cut throat competition.

headline: Worst bank in 21 years

cons:
Not enough space and gigibityes --- 

No one is client focused.   NO ONE!!!  took me 6 weeks to book a commercial loan and amidst lost a $50mm trust opportunity.   Lost a $10mm credit relationship because it takes 90 days to underwrite commercial credit.

headline: Could be better....

cons: It seems the company is so focused on growth that they are neglecting their employees  pay increases. Sometimes very political

cons: Limited opportunity for growth, promotions.  Sometimes lateral move or promotion is just lesser of two evils. Pay is average, bonus structure based on varying policies that are not company wide.  Limited schedule options for those with family.  Too many software systems being used at once, inefficient and confusing, not updated properly.

headline: Credit card company owns bank

cons: Turnover, bad back office/hr depts, still developing sales/service culture - might turn off seasoned bankers. Rigid control over fees and going above and beyond

headline: Excellent..!
pros: work life balance and flexibility of work hours.
cons: quality of work, slow project approvals

headline: Great place to work!

cons: Montreal office: limited vertical opportunities coming from a typically flat call center reporting structure, though much efforts are deployed to improved that aspect.

headline: Designer
pros: Flexible work schedules. Nice cafeteria.
cons: Limited opportunities for creativity. Thinking inside the box is the rule.

headline: Disenchanted
pros:
- aggressively pursuing cutting edge technology
- dynamic environment
- lots of smart people
cons:
Over my past four years,
- corporate culture has lost focus on work/life balance
- increased need to travel due to conflict of geographic distribution and co-location expectations

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: The culture at Capital One is amazing - collaborative with leaders willing to listen to outside the box thinking.
cons: With any company as large as Capital One, communication can be a challenge across all levels of associates. Capital One has challenges in this space, however it has been making adjustments to make improvements to it's communication.

headline: Avoid if you can!
pros: Health Benefits - Mediocre, Gym - Always crowded, Stock Plan - be ready for loss(check last quarter stock price trend), Remote work - only if you're your manager's favorite, Unlimited Paid Sick Leave - a tough one to take, work life balance - jk. Just the heads up,  don't get surprised if these strike you if in a different way than the rose garden which you imagined before you came on board.
cons: High politics environment, low morale, no growth, mediocre pay compared to market, chronic high stress(I am serious, don't overlook this one - emotional and physical illnesses due to high anxiety, stress and depression), unrealistic expectations, obsolete performance review process, scapegoating, poor communication(your manager can act like God sometimes)

headline: Bank teller
pros: They give Tuition Reimbursement, and offer many benefits. They offer insurance, 401k and pay a good staring salary. there is room to move up in the company and become an assistant and manager
cons: There is pressure to provide many referrals, but over all the job has many benefits. working hard and knowing and memorizing rates and rules for auditing purposes.

headline: Better than average
pros: The people that work there are great.  The overall strategy is great.
cons: Process hurdles and red tape add unnecessary delays and complexity.  The culture is chaotic and beyond "fast-paced".

headline: Business Manager
pros: Great company - fun, challenging atmosphere and great work-life balance.
cons: Too much bureaucracy, too much travel

headline: Sales
pros: Amazing work environment and great pay
cons: No real cons to this job

headline: relationship manager
pros: Great options for 401k matches  and employee stock purchase.  Great vacation time and family leave time.  Insurance is OK, nothing to really talk about.
cons: No cost of living raises.  Almost impossible to get a raise off of performance.  Gross miss alignment of salaries between employees doing the same work.

headline: Fun, but can be very stressful
pros: Getting to know your customers and your co-workers like a second family.  Love having Sundays off. Small office environment. Sale rallies are fun. Commission and prizes for referrals made it worth it.
cons: Depending on your branch manager, they can make your day or break it.  Very repetitive tasks and scripts.  Capital One is VERY big on sales and referrals. standing on your feet all day in one place is not ideal. Some customers can be unpleasant.

headline: Senior Data Analyst
pros: It is a good company to start your career.  Great Work and Life Balance for working mom, Great Training Opportunities for graduates.
cons: Salary is less competitive.  Promotion is very slow for technical positions.  Sometimes have to travel between different office locations

headline: Sr Risk Coordinator
pros: Benefits are very good, coworkers, cafeteria on site, some career opportunities but only if you kiss major a##!
cons: Micromanagement to the max! Management is lacking leadership skills, too much change constantly, monthly incentive (bonus) seems to be getting smaller and smaller and harder to reach because all the new stupid policies the company comes up with.

headline: Agile Project manager
pros: "Capital One has a vision, mission, and purpose, and we all know how we can ... Fortune's 100 Best Companies to Work for® 2015 (ranked 91) ... recognize some of the various cultures represented at Capital One
cons: There is no work/life balance in some areas

headline: No Growth
pros: Great Values, ok pay,great extra curricular activities
cons: No growth, upper management, Managers really don't care about you only themselves

headline: good company
pros: Best customer service in banking
cons: Not many opportunities, a lot of employees

headline: Awesome place to launch a career!
pros: I came to Capital One for the Fortune 500 experience, but I've stayed because of the amazing culture, growth opportunities and challenging work.
cons: Sometimes a bit bureaucratic. It's hard to get things done quickly, processes get in the way of great work sometimes, etc. But it's nothing unexpected for such a large organization.

headline: One of the best places to work
pros: Capital One really makes you feel like they care about you on some level. The better you do your job the more money you make.
cons: Some of their processes were a little backwards. They spent a lot of time and money to improve their system, and we were left with a marginally better system that was great is some regards and then a step back in others.

headline: Great Company - Poor District Level Leadership
pros: Great benefits for all company divisions, plenty of opportunities to grow with company, dedicated to associate development, the card division and corporate setting is where the company earns all its high marks for associate satisfaction
cons: retail banking in the northeast lacks positive, consistent and effective leadership, low pay for mid level bank associates - example bankers paid approximately $5000-$10,000 less than the competitors. retail banking does not have the staff to effectively give the net promoter service expected by management.

headline: Company Review
pros: Benefits and opportunities abound. Associates are treated with respect. Our favorite motto is Assume Positive Intent.
cons: Change is constant. You will be lucky to have the same manager for 2 or more consecutive years.

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: Great source of many opportunities to build a career and grow within the company! They take care very well of their employees, hands down the best benefits offered! Also, Capital One is always trying to innovate and stay ahead of the game!
cons: Their pay can be a little more competative, but it balances out with the benfits.

headline: I love my job
pros: great pay and benefits and room for growth
cons: some departments deserve higher pay than others.

headline: It's ok
pros: Very easy job to do with the tools and lee-way they provide you with for the customer.  Alot of time off (pto) and awesome benefits.
cons: Management is all over the place.  Not many people are on the same page and things get a bit hectic.  Moving up is very hard too.

headline: Very good company
pros: Great founder / CEO with outstanding vision and leadership
cons:
Too many org changes
Performance management process needs to be updated

headline: Assistant Branch Manager
pros: Great benefits, generous time off
cons: Pay raises are too low

headline: Great Benefits
pros: Great benefits and room for advancement.  I worked in credit card and auto finance division.  I much prefer credit over auto.
cons: none at the current time

headline: Financial Services Manager
pros: Nice facilities in Plano.  Nice cafeteria and good benefits.  Mission is amazing.  Good IT help desk.  High community service culture.
cons:
Even though Capital One was honored again as a top 100 company by Working Mothers, the flexible work arrangements are non-existent in the Financial Services Division in Plano.   There is no telecommuting allowed, working parents are expected to attend after hours daily meetings, leadership meetings, recognition events, etc. after 5 pm.

Agile is the new way of life here.  Flexible work arrangements and other family friendly flexible work arrangements are frowned upon or are not allowed.

headline: Front line manager
pros: One of the best places to work because of culture and professionalism. Employees are encouraged to develop their own career path. Ideas and suggestions are considered from all employees.
cons: None none none none none

headline: Nice but too many layoffs
pros: love the Benefits and good pay. A few great people.
cons: there's no stability anymore too many layoffs

headline: Former Employee
pros:
1. Benefits
2. Work/Life Balance
3. Quarterly Team Outings
cons: You could go home but the work went with you, as there's never time to get things done with your employees present.

headline: Top Talent
pros: The fast paced career and promotion path is a norm allowing the top talent to move through ranks.
cons: Depending on the field you are in long hours due to fire drills and new projects make it difficult to plan any normal day

headline: There is hope
pros:
Responsive support system, generous in investing employee development, some of the brightest talents, flexible schedule, great employee engagement opportunities, 
above industry average benefits and pay for most positions
cons: Inconsistent in talent acquisition -- a certain plague of cronyism and nepotism, seniority in internal promotion, certain leaders' empire-buildings, lack of locational flexibility, difficulty in interfunctional job transfer

headline: Sr Data Engineer
pros: Great company if you wind up on a team that understands how they should treat there highly skilled employees. I was a member of 3 great teams with 3 great managers before things went south.
cons:
If you wind up on a team with ineffective management, do your best to get a transfer.
Im sure its an anomaly, but do what you can to avoid a position on the FRAUD team.

headline: Vp
pros: Great tech company to work for!
cons: Locations are not that great

headline: Hated It
pros: The training was great, and helpful to my career.
cons: My manager did not support us, and the company went on a mass firing spree, letting go of many bankers and tellers that had been there for years. Also, the products offered were not up to par with the biggest competition.

headline: Changing Banking for Good
pros: Working with a lot of smart and skilled people (Capital One is known for hiring absolutely best people). A very fact-based decision making culture. Promotes competencies and values like collaboration, regarding others with positive intent, results-driven mindset, being intellectually bold and empowering employees to pursue their ideas.
cons: Very selective in hiring process.  A dynamic company culture permeates constant change.

headline: Nice company for your firsy jon

headline: Great Place!
pros: Flexible work environment and great people to work with. Good compensation too.
cons: Slow growth and learning opportunities can be less sometimes. Organizational changes are frequent.

headline: Principal Learning Consultant

headline: Customer Service representative

cons: Constant Change and updates. They want to be innovative so they are always developing new ideas but they start them without perfecting the old ones

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: I left this awesome company & less than a year later, I came back. The culture is unbeatable and it really is great place for career and corporate development in the banking industry.
cons: The salary could certainly be better.

headline: Great Company
pros: Great work environment and great people
cons: Not great collaboration between different teams

headline: Current Employee
pros: They pay well and ect...
cons: Schedule, Management and other normal things

headline: Risk Associate
pros: Great people, great benefits, opportunity --
cons: A lot of layoffs --Unstable company.

headline: Customer Service Coordinator
pros: Capital One offers an excellent compensation package
cons: My job here in Tigard, Or is being eliminated

headline: Data Scientist
pros: It is about finance. This company has a fast development. There are many smart managers. You could learn largely more than before.
cons: The workload is relatively large. The competition makes people stressed a bit. But it still worth to stay there. Enjoy.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Hands down one of the best places to work as a working mother. I've been there for the past 4+ years, and have really enjoyed the work, the telecommuting flexibility, the culture and the quality of the people. I would recommend Capital One to anyone who is passionate about making a difference in the financial services industry.
cons: I really don't have anything bad to say. Occasionally, there are people that you don't jive with, but they tend not to last long.

headline: Strong culture, slow moving
pros: Strong  data driven culture and good benefits
cons: Slow moving and limited interesting business growth limits the project types

headline: Review After Two Tours of Duty
pros: Capital One hires bright and motivated people. It's a dynamic environment in which you are always challenged to do great work. Pay is above scale in Richmond, VA and total compensation - salary, benefits and bonus - are generally good to very good. If you are a young engineer or developer you are currently primed for a good run at Capital One.
cons: Like any large corporation, decisions at the top of the house don't always play out well for the rank and file. After two tours of duty resulting in two layoffs Capital One became an increasingly tough place to work and move up. If you are a people manager or technology generalist, the deck is currently stacked against you. Be aware that Capital One regularly lays off and they are doing so now.

headline: Oracle Functional Consultant
pros: One of the most reputed banks
cons: There's nothing to mention, I felt working good over there

headline: Customer service
pros: The job was good paid good! Very great benefits, the company was great with your time off
cons: Very high call volume, sometime 30 calls waiting, didn't really get a chance to breath and chill

headline: Pretending to be too techy
pros: Good benefits, flexible work options, great severance package.
cons: Highly political environment and managers are like clan leaders. A very hierarchical environment. COF wants to portray as a cutting edge technology company, while the core business is financial services. Everyone is after the "coolness factor" and just hop on buzzwords like cloud, big data, devops etc. and there is too much talk and no much output.  Changes are too frequent, and layoffs at unexpected time, when you think the company is doing great. Recently, management thinks software programming is the only great job and wants all IT folks to do coding work.

headline: Too Many Changes
pros: Great people. Work/life balance is top notch, and depending on one's position, there is a lot of flexibility for working remotely or at different sites.
cons: Too many changes and too many layoffs, especially if tenured, well performing employees. If cuts need to be made, they should really be performance based and not so arbitrary. The job posting process, both for current employees and for those looking to get on, is a complete joke and takes entirely too long.

headline: Relaxed environment but very old school
pros: Very relaxed environment with the ability to find the perfect balance between work and personal life. Good training opportunities.
cons: Very slow and old school. I think this is something you will find across the entire industry. I don't think Capital One is a good place for someone who wants challenging tasks and see their work impacting people's life.

headline: Salary
pros: Competitive salary in the beginning. Moving costs are given and sign in bonus as well.
cons: No negotiation was allowed at the sr analyst position. Growth rate is slow, so salary doesn't match market value after a while

headline: Great experience!
pros: The company really cares about its associates. They take really good care of you. Great benefits. Great work-life balance.
cons: You have to not only work hard but go WAY above and beyond in order to get recognized for your hard work. End of the year reviews are really stressful and outdated.

headline: Business Analyst Senior Associate
pros: Flexible Schedule and very collaborative work environment.
cons: There is so much work that it is easy to get overwhelmed.

headline: It's a Great Company but...
pros: Work life balance is pretty much great, the company offers great health/401K/tuition reimbursement, etc.  Managers are generally good, the customers are generally good.
cons: The company is changing its direction very rapidly.  It's closing branches every quarter so you don't know if you're going to be out of a job.  The company just restructured again so we lost all of our assistant managers and district operations consultants.  The company seems to be changing so quickly it's leaving the people who worked so hard for them in the dust.  In order to join capital one you should have a degree in computers/info tech, etc.  That's where the bank is going.

headline: Digital Aspirations Dysfunctional Management
pros:
- Embrace digital and innovation journey with user design and innovation labs
- Flexible with work location (many, many work from home)
- Some exciting projects and aspirations
- The CEO Rich Fairbanks is inspirational and seems to be an amazing leader
cons:
- Commercial bank is spread out across the country with no leadership or management to make it operate as a whole
- There is a lack of team work and a competitive environment that had caused a bit of a toxic environment with the vacuum in leadership
- Work/life balance is terrible in that while you can work from home and handle personal issues when they surface, 80 hour weeks and lots of weekend time are the norm
- Promotions are scarce and more on who you know than what you contribute

headline: Current Employee
pros: Fari compensation, really smart people
cons: Culture is becoming increasingly toxic

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Good culture and good incentives. Also very IT company like
cons: Roles and title could be better . lot of similar titles and varying pay scale it's misleading compared to the market

headline: Best job ever
pros:
Easy work
Work/life balance
Promotions
Employee's are treated great
cons:
Customers on the phone are not the nicest
Upper Managent is always watching your every move

headline: sr manager
pros: work life balance and benefits
cons: competition  and the review process

headline: Fantastic, large company - just be flexible
pros: In short, I perceived Capital One to be a bit of an odd duck amongst big financial institutions. It's very progressive, both in business and in its social stances and efforts. It's large, but its structure feels relative flat, and they value independent input and questions. They don't squash down constructive dissent, they welcome it. They don't brace against change, they embrace it.
cons: They embrace change, and so you can expect a lot of it. That makes day-to-day work challenging at times (but also exciting), and it may mean that you get changed right out of the picture, which is what is happening to me as part of a site closure. That said, they've been more supportive about that change and transition than you can imagine, so even that isn't very much of a con.

headline: Ok
pros: Not so good, not that bad
cons: Not too much of a learning opportunity

headline: MTID
pros: Automatically give 3% towards 401K even if you don't participate
cons: Can not use Flex Spending Account for your important medical needs

headline: Overall good experience.
pros: Definitely a good company.  Definitely need a Type A-go-getter-Activator (make things happen) kind of person-which I think one needs overall to be in the banking industry and you'll fit well with the corporate culture.  Fortunate to be part of retail branch teams that really had a good team mentality kind of culture which I think comes from the corporate culture in general.
cons: I would not exactly call it a con but something to be aware of before applying and when hired and working for and with the company.  They have not been in banking as long as other banks so up your adaptability skills even more so.  They have definitely grown and evolved over the years.  I left awhile ago (not b/c of this) so ask someone who is currently working there if you can to get an even more accurate picture in the retail banking segment of this corporation.

headline: A
pros: They believe in promoting from within
cons: Office was very strict, not very friendly

headline: Great place to work
pros: great benefits, great work environment
cons: too many layers of management, internal politics

headline: Digital first
pros: Very digitally driven company.  Cutting edge vision. iPads in branches, simple product set, best credit cards. Good 401k and stock plan.
cons: Shrinking branch network.  Shrinking incentive plan. Shrinking traffic in branches.  Backward and cumbersome home equity lending process.  Too many silos

headline: Too much change
pros: Great company culture. In my 3 years working here I have yet to meet someone I disliked or couldn't work with. Everyone is very professional, smart and dedicated. The pay is ok (could be better) and the company is willing to try new things
cons:
Too much change. While there is a vision of where we want to be and an understanding of where we are, there isn't a clear direction of how to get from A to Z. It feels like every year the company is changing direction and what you've been working on for the past year is no longer worth anything. 

Plus there is a pressure in the IT department for everyone to be able to do everything - which will only lead to everyone to being the jack of all trades but the master of none. 

Also, for a company that want to be the google of banking, they need to do more to remove barriers to innovation.

headline: Overall a great place to work
pros: Great culture, interesting work, competitive compensation
cons: Sometimes seems like people are brought in from externally for roles that could be filled internally

headline: Started out as a good experience...
pros: Benefits, good pay, incentives 90 days after you start
cons: there is a high turnover in the company

headline: Capital One Review
pros: great benefits and work life balance
cons: difficult to move around for a big company, some managers not ready to lead a team

headline: Change Banking For Good
pros: ok pay, good benefits, vacation time and sick days/
cons: hard to move up if you don't get referrals even if you are good in every other aspect of the job. you can't even go full time without getting referrals.

headline: Brand Marketing Intern
pros: Amazing People, Great Salary, Full-Time Opportunity, Work- Life Balance, strongly encourages interns to network with as many people as possible.
cons:
Not an adequate way of being able to measure performance since the internship program is in an agile format. 
Not able to operate within the different departments as you may want

headline: Great company in general
pros: Great Benefit, good work life balance, smart people
cons: Reorg very often, didn't put the right person in the right position

headline: IT Portfolio manager
pros: Flexible, self driven, good people to work with, good opportunities for advancement
cons: For a large organization, decision making is slow.  IT direction changes frequently.

headline: IT Operations
pros: work life balance.  I'm allowed to work from home or office
cons: Lack of IT leadership at the CIO and executive level.   One year they are tackling a data center insourcing from IBM then building a new data center and the next they are outsourcing to AWS.   No vision beyond unicorns and rainbows on how to service our IT customers.   It appears a few solutions have been "sold" to the executives and no one has stood up and pointed out that the emperor is wearing no clothes.

headline: Sr Admin Assistant
pros: great benefits, flexibility, team work, diversity, community volunteer work opportunities
cons: Very hard to move out of Admin position into anything else

headline: Come for the work, stay for the people!
pros: Capital One's culture of "excellence" and "do the right thing" creates such open, autonomous and empowering environments.  It's so refreshing to be surrounded by smart, capable and diverse people who look for better ways to deliver great products for our customers.  The flexibility in schedule and work environment is key to balance.
cons: There is constant organizational change that disrupts both business value, associate morale and customer experience. The communication and change management associated with these types of changes is mediocre and must be improved. Tons of opportunity for improvement here.

headline: Customer Service Rep
pros: They make you feel welcome.They have a very helpful carrer center that will help you better yourself even outside of the company.
cons: They do not pay enough for the work asked to perform.The job is very boring with little growth.

headline: Doing the Right Thing
pros:
Excellent Career Development Tools
Great culture of inclusiveness and collaboration
Doing what is right for its customers
cons: It can be difficult to move up the ladder

headline: Ok job
pros: Great pay, benefits great co-workers
cons: Long hours, work weekends no time for family

headline: Good people
pros: Nice people to work with
cons: Needs clearer direction with management

headline: Administrative Assistant III
pros:
Flexible schedule
Onsite Gym
Great Cafeteria 
Laptop 
Smart Colleagues
cons: Negative, back-stabbing environment.  Calibration review process based off what teams says and  you can not defend yourself.  Can be fired over not being liked not job performance.  Great benefits bt not worth the immature environment.  The McLean office is full of arrogant kids.  Diversity means India and China and not Black or Hispanic.

headline: Good pay but culture is not for everyone
pros:
The pay is good and the people are nice if they don't know your level.
The culture is flexible to accommodate a healthy work life balance.
cons:
Horrible prejudicial culture when it comes to employee levels and heavy hierarchical structure. 

People will refuse to talk to you once they know you are a lower level coworker which hinders on work productivity. I once worked on something that had been terminated but was not informed due to my lower status, this wasted my time and effort. I would not recommend Capital One if you prefer a classless culture that promotes team work.

headline: Personal banker 1
pros: Fun events. Excellent training when first hired and any new product or systems training.
cons: Lack of communication with management. Salary and hours not good for all the work a pb does. Not willing to work with employees. Very low commission and payout.

headline: Subjective Performance Review Process
pros: Great Pay; Great Opportunity (if you are one of the 'chosen'); Great Training
cons:
Meetings; people are afraid to make decisions, so they schedule more meetings to bring more people into the discussion.  Performance Management criteria are defined after the year ends, not before it starts.  Brown-nosing and Sucking-up are standard methods to get promoted.

I think the CEO gets it; but his message does not get down to senior management.

Lots of places within the company  it is run as a very command-and-control.

headline: Funding
pros: The  Culture and values are great
cons: Micro manage...the managers don't know how to manage

headline: Great company to work for
pros: great company to work for
cons: a lot of work is assigned, sometimes resulting in long hours

headline: good intentions, but bad timing...
pros: Great atmosphere, leadership at the top has great vision and ideas. Tons of very bright peple looking and willing to do the right thing
cons: Failure by senior most leaders to measure the affects of their changes on the people that do the work. There are also a few there who harbor ill will towards any who disagree and take great pains to run them out (even though we are suppossed to Disrupt and challenge). The company also fails to properly budget and forecast which leads to massive layoffs (or what is currently being labeled as a change in focus).

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Great culture! They really value everyone's input and make changes. The mission is very clear and achievable. Great company to work for.
cons: New vision of going digital is reducing internal employees and resulting in more 3rd party vendors. In recent years Capital One stopped working with vendors and brought all work in house. Once senior leadership changed, they decided to move back to vendor sites.

Manager wasn't open to creating your schedule - it's set in stone

headline: Great job
pros: Great people, pay, benefits and management.
cons: Some of the management is less qualified than others creating an inconsistency at times. If you're a strong employee and not afraid to reach out when something seems wrong this won't impact you really.

headline: Great employer
pros: Great culture, smart people, flexible work environment, strongly capitalized and profitable bank
cons: Profitability reducing- so pressure on growth and compensation prospects. Significant change in direction

headline: Software Engineer, Master
pros: Capital One is a great place to work.   Good pay and benefits.  They go the extra mile to care for the overall well being of their employees.
cons: Sometimes manager expectations can be unrealistic.

headline: Great Company With A Lacking Culture
pros: Working at Capital One was honestly a breath of fresh air compared to a number of other financial call centers and how they interacted with their customer base. There was more of a focus on customer satisfaction and resolution rather than sales or time spent on a phone. Supervisor roles were given great autonomy to take care of phone agents with customer concerns as well as develop needed work skills to attain new or promoted positions within the company. The people were always amazing to see and you really felt like the people you worked with were a second family.
cons: The major downside I had with Capital One is that they have an almost forced culture of doing the right thing and being encouraged to promote new ideas/concerns to company leadership. This all sounded good to the front line/customer facing associates, but rarely anything was ever done with agent feedback or ideas and simply stowed away for tracking purposes. Reasons that action was rarely taken was a lack of resources within certain departments or more often than not self serving interests of senior leadership did not feel the proposed feedback was important or necessary at that time.

headline: Capital One review
pros: Great benefits, including on-site gyms with personal trainers(free), decent pay
cons: Too many layers of management and policy's of meetings for the sake of having meetings....  needing to "check the box"

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: Great company to work for.  They really take good care of their employees and offer numerous opportunities for career development within the different departments - retail banking, auto financing, credit cards and mortgage.
cons: Most new hires start off working every Saturday and are not given much room to negotiate the schedule.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Work life balance is great.  Flexibility to spend time with family.
cons: Advancement is tough if you are not 100% on the same page as your manager.  Priorities change frequently making it difficult to have one solid stream of work.

headline: Great work environment
pros: Do not need college degree and can make 15 +
cons: Have to be on phone all day 8-10 hrs doing sales and servicing

headline: Director IT
pros: Great long term strategy, great people, and great opportunities.
cons: Great company to work for, enjoyed my long career at Capital One

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Endless opportunity for individual educational growth. Leader in agile transformation. Great environment to work with flexibility. Work from home if needed.
cons: Extremely Competitive environment. Annual layoff despite being promoted the year before. Never know where one stands. Difficult to move up the ladder unless someone is layed off leaves the company. Difficult entrance exams.

headline: Coordinator
pros: Good benefits and overall company very good
cons: Management is not  approachable.

headline: Good place to build career
pros: They give you leeway to run with ideas right away. And if your idea didn't net the results you hoped, there is no negative repercussions as long as there were learnings to be shared with the team.
cons: Very analyst focused. Other job families have harder time proving their value.

headline: Fast paced, high change, high energy
pros:
High standard of performance.  Culture thrives on competition (internal and external) and ability to lead or adapt to change.
Competitive salary and benefits and great workplace environment.
Great rewards for high performers.
cons:
Competition and pace is not for everyone.
Performance management is on a curve -- there is a winnowing of low performers.
What it takes to succeed at senior levels not always crystal clear -- be willing to chart your own development.

headline: Talented Associates, Low commitment to executive diversity
pros: Competitive pay and benefits. Very talented employees.  Good work life balance.  Excellent place to learn business strategy, analytics, and customer driven design.
cons: Not a very diverse place in SVP+ positions.  You are expected to communicate and contribute within a very narrow range to be considered for the best roles.  Diversity of thought is ok in mid/low level roles but it is not encouraged in the most senior roles.  Working within such a tight range is significantly draining and leads many talented executives to seek opportunities elsewhere.

headline: Ops production coordinator
pros: Paid time off that's about it.
cons: Too many mass layoffs and terminations without warning.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Amenities are awesome, people are collaborative, driven, and very smart.
cons: Difficult to move up, frequent layoffs in certain areas

headline: HR Manager
pros: Work/life balance.  Collaborative environment.  Good people.
cons: Cut throat...fosters competition in an unhealthy way.

headline: Ops Production Coordinator
pros: Nothing good to say at this time

headline: Customer Service Rep
pros: Friends co workers location of job site on site cafe
cons: i dont have any cons it was ok to work here

headline: Customer Support Merchant Service
pros: Excellent pay, train very well, give you everything you need to succeed. Advancement is there. Family feel. Team building trips, and monthly meeting so all departments felt connected.  Great health benefits. Monday through Friday and holidays off.
cons: Capitol One sold this part of the business. Did give great severance package.

headline: Poor Prescription Coverage
pros: Work/Life balance. There is a huge focus on ensuring that you are able to spend time outside of work doing things you love.
cons: Prescription healthcare coverage is severely limited. Many of the prescriptions my young family uses are not covered by the health insurance, even though they were covered three months ago by another employer.

headline: Great Place to work!
pros: Great Culture, Benefits, People and compensation
cons: Sometimes feels overly complex to get work done

headline: Fraud Account Supervisor
pros: All Great good PEOPLE. Good environment
cons: I have nothing to say about the cons

headline: Relationship banker
pros: Capital one pays you what you work.
cons: Once you reach platform level,promotions are very difficult.

headline: Great Engineering Culture Evolving
pros: The is a highly skilled, highly motivated workforce in Technology where new methods, tools, and problem-solving techniques are embraced.  Open source technology is available and the teams are encouraged to use them.  The company is even producing open source products now.
cons: Working in a large technology organization can be a challenge when so many teams are empowered to explore and use tools with a specific purpose.  It's very possible that others are looking at similar or competing tools.  You need to build a network among peers so that you can be informed of what others are doing.

headline: Good place to work, but going thru lot of changes now in overall direction
pros:
Business Leadership led by CEO is far sighted and strong.  That shows in the company being the only monolith Card company surviving over the past 20 years and growing into a top 10 bank in US!  

Overall work culture is good, though things keep changing a lot and the employee morale can go up or down depending on the nature and timing of those changes.   For instance, Company is going thru changes and upheaval currently in effort to position from a Financial services company to a Technology Company.  

Good Benefits;  Fast paced work culture.
cons:
There is constant change of direction, managers etc in the Technology groups  and for someone who is looking for steady role, this can be difficult to adjust.   Like in many other corporate companies, layoffs occurs in cycles and can be sudden (though there is time and benefits given to support transition outside of the role).

Work-life balance of job can vary depending on the group/manager.

headline: Great Company
author_position: Vice President, Senior Human Resources Consultant and Business Partner
pros: Founder led organization with strong focus on culture and talent
cons: Not many....tons of change but that is what makes Capital One special.

headline: I do not have a title :(

headline: Teller

headline: The rewards are great if you're great.
pros: They reward those that add great value.  They pay higher than average, offer performance based annual bonus, and have good benefits.
cons: Very fast paced and chaotic environment.  Everything is urgent and the highest prioriry.

headline: Advanced Service Coordinator
pros: You get bonuses. Your take your time off when you need it, no need to ask. Tons of schedule choices.
cons: This is from a call center. You run out of the time very quickly and Capital One does not understand work/life balance. If you have family problems or anything, you have to take unscheduled leave and if that gets up to 32 hrs in a year you can get written up or fired. That includes snow days.

headline: Funder
pros: Decent Pay, great benefits, good cafe.
cons: Overly competitive environment.  Managers encouraged or overlooked employee that worked through lunches and breaks to get ahead, making metrics look better than they were.

headline: manager

headline: Review

cons: Strict, the department I worked for micromanaged too much. Management wasn't always honest. You are expected to do your job and act happy.

headline: Internship at Capital One
pros: Excellent culture and brilliant people

headline: Not bad
pros: Benefits are great, Vacation is awesome, my experience has been great! I don't have anything really bad to say because they've helped me a lot

headline: Relationship Banker
pros: Learned lots of valuable information for both personal and business use.

headline: IT Field Services Engineer

headline: (left in 2007) Challenging Job, Smart People, Crazy Culture
pros: Enormous resources, focus on constant improvement, lots of opportunities, very high bar for performance, top slice of the workforce, some cultural values are in place like diversity and collaboration
cons: Predatory culture and force-ranked performance management system creates unhealthy competition among peers. Significantly overvalues presentation of ideas, so people with big egos and high self-interest often take the prize

headline: Fun inviting environment
pros: Working with great people and feeling at home
cons: Closing doors in Sioux falls to venture elsewhere

headline: Bad Management
pros: Great Benefits, flexibility, great relationships
cons: Racist Managers with intentional motives to stifle non white american with career advancement

headline: Processor
pros: pretty good at the time
cons: none at the moment now

headline: An Excellent place to work with great people
pros: A growing organization which gives oppurtunities to good performers. The culture is pretty transparent and numbers driven.
cons: Still do not have some of the big services which the big players in the market have so becomes tough to beat the main players in banking while selling

headline: Ageism, No Management, and work here only if in Virginia!
pros: OK Bank to hang out at and make good money IF you work for them IN Virginia. The non-Virginia locations are so miss-managed that you can hide for years doing nothing and still make good money. I left because I am a high performer and couldn't stand all the dead weight and people, including Sr "Management", that don't know what they are doing...I think it is by design!
cons: If you like to do the right thing, this is probably not the place for you to work. If you want to be rewarded for bringing issues to light and fixing things that are broken,... go elsewhere! They hire a lot of younger folk, which is good....IF there was good management (but I feel sorry for the younger ones who get hired here). They get rid of a lot of the older (over 50) folk, so watch out if you are nearing that age! There is rampant favoritism, large cliques of people who do not carry their weight, and all the usual lip service about work/life "balance". If you are not drinking the kool aid, caution advised. The wrong word or instant message or email and you will be OUT! Many, many disgruntled people in this place! Don't take me wrong...I was not fired. I left because I have better things to do with my career than spend any more of it here!

headline: Strictly business, don't take it personally.
pros:
Good people, good management at the middle and associate level. Good place to work, as long as you are in a big center, especially Richmond. 
Management makes everyone feel valued, until it is time to reduce staff or close a site. As long as you remember that no one is irreplaceable and it's nothing personal, you'll be fine.
cons:
Capital One legacy and Richmond-based employees are favored, though many good people have come with acquisitions over the years. 
Cross-training is emphasized and people are shifted around in some departments, regardless of expertise, resulting in damaged trust in support departments.
Communication from top down could be better.

headline: i came i saw i went
pros: my manager before he moved on
cons: the company itself doesn't practice what they preach

headline: Manager
pros: Great benefits and nice place to work. I have enjoyed my time working here and am on a great team.
cons: Depends what team you're on as to the cons, which can differ greatly based on your manager.

headline: Operations Manager
pros: A great place to work for analytical thinkers.
cons: The company can be extremely bureaucratic.

headline: Alright to work for if you fit in the culture

headline: IT Senior Manager - Good Company - but no loyalty
pros: Good benefits and decent yearly bonuses, lots of time off.  Good work/life balance.  Decent Training Opportunities.  Lost of smart people who seem to want to do the right thing.  great work facilities.  Lots of focus on families and personal interests.
cons: Stacked ranking stinks!  Basically everyone falls into 4 buckets, Exceptional, Very Strong, Strong and Inconsistent/Need Action.  The problem is that their are required percentages in all 4 buckets including the inconsistent so even you have a high performing team, someone is going to be forced into the bottom bucket!  Also, there is no loyalty!  Been there for more than 10 years and was laid off with at least 100 others in IT without good reason!

headline: Principal Coordinator
pros: Great benefits - ample paid time off, medical/dental, 401K. Work-life balance was better than other companies. The company values are admirable.
cons: The company culture is inconsistent and depends on which business unit you work in. I've had a positive experience working in some departments compared to others. The performance management process needs a complete overhaul and do not match the company's values. 360 feedback reviews are a political tick the box exercise and are a complete waste of time. Cross calibrations in some business units unfairly penalize certain positions if they do not fit into a standardized job description. Middle management is poorly trained in people skills and does not encourage career development, despite the encouragement from senior management (VP+). As a result, advancement is nearly impossible, based on favoritism, and is definitely not merit-based. Process change management requires multiple levels of red tape, is poorly executed, is extremely slow to implement. Pay was competitive up until about two years ago. It's now easier to advance and earn greater pay if you leave the company, which may explain why longtime employees are now leaving in droves.

headline: Capital One work at home representative

headline: Love going to work again
pros:
New software studio in Toronto with, and I'll admit to be amazed by this, real agile development models where the teams are actually empowered to figure out how to they want to organize themselves and tackle problems whether mobbing, paired, or solo. Choices on gear such as iPhone 6 vs Galaxy S6 (and 64 GB models too) and Mac vs PC. Even better, techies get administrative permissions on their computers and access to the latest software tools, patches, etc. That was seriously shocking.

Very good location, near Mel Lastman Square, so close to subways, shops, and lots of good restaurants (especially if you like Asian cuisine). Facilities have really nice spots for more casual relaxation or comfy work with a cafe, foosball, pingpong, x-box, and more. 

Work-life balance is more than expression, it actually exists and encouraged. There are fun days, opportunities to engage in charitable efforts, and more. It's refreshing to work in company that actually encourages you to get out and involved on company time.

The company sees itself as being a digital technology leader that happens to be in the financial world. From the CEO on down, the plan is lean, agile, tech savvy, and future focussed with a willingness to spend to make it happen. You can't ask for much better as a techie, but even for non-techies this is good. Bringing in agile coaches and scrum masters to help their business teams become agile is well-nigh unheard of and is great news because, in my experience, many attempts at agile software development die on the vine because the business doesn't go along with them.
cons:
It's not all sunshine and roses, obviously, but the cons are not that bad and many are starting to get knocked down.

Capital One is in a very regulated industry, banking, and so there are some rather onerous processes and gates to get through much of the time. The company does want to fix this, but that's a slow moving change and much of that is related to risk mitigation.

The company is still very meeting oriented and many of them don't actually resolve anything. It is improving, but I've never had 6 concurrent bookings in my life until Capital One! Mind you, nobody seems terribly offended if you skip their meeting.

headline: Bait and Switch
pros: Benefits, Pay, a handful of amazing people, great customers who value what you do for them
cons:
Here is what it was like:

The job is nothing as described.  You are sold on the idea that Capital One wishes to hire people to take care of their customers, and the customer is king/queen and all that matters is your amazing skills with the customer.  In fact it is an "inbound call center"  looking for butts in chairs.  Once you are past the sales pitch  of HR  you realize you didn't read the fine print someplace along the way.  In your role as work at home customer service front line agent, be prepared to play C.Y.A. to the extreme.   You will be blamed for any problem that exists within the company.  From technical issues to legitimate customer complaints you attempt to escalate for resolution, it's all entirely YOUR fault.  No one else is doing anything wrong at this company EXCEPT the front line employee. You can be fired in a heartbeat for anything at all.  I quit in disgust, but after talking to persons who were fired, there is never any hard fact to back up what managers say.   They can apparently say anything at all and HR just goes along and signs off. 

 If you look back at reviews you will see a very negative one from 2010.  I feel the same way today and it is 2015.  You will also see an "answer" from management stating "we have an open door policy reach out to us"  That was around 2 years ago.  I have no idea who is above my up-line manager, the name of my site HR representatives, nor even who manages this site.     The only person i can reach out to is my manager who is going to write me up any chance they get, and never educates me as to what I can do to improve my performance.   In fact my manager does not follow company procedures when it comes to customers. It is clearly stated that it is part of our job to call customers back at time of their choosing if we cannot resolve their issue within the call.  A representative is supposed to be given time to make these calls.  However you are not.  You must make these call backs when you have "slow time".  It is currently back to back calls without even a second of breathing room in between.  Well if you don't make your outbound calls then you are going to get  people on your back for that.  This is just one example of how entirely impossible this company is.   If you are a person who can figure out how to cheat the system and likes sucking up to your boss and is totally self absorbed and likes to lie to customers then this job is right up your alley.   If you are used to facing problems straight on, coming up with solutions to them, and having this heard and implemented, then not the company for you.  If you are used to teamwork and consulting your manager and other departments in the interest of putting your heads together to work out issues for the customer, this is not the place for you.   If you believe that everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect from the janitor on up to the top, this is not the place for you.  You will see plenty of good reviews for this company.  Most likely they were sent an e-mail, and given time off the phone and told to complete a "survey" all within the watchful eye of a manager.  Because I don't know a person I have talked to that feels in any way this company is  doing what is right.

headline: Great place to work, but check group turnover before accepting a position
pros: Challenging, team - oriented environment.  Great place to learn and develop critical skills, including effective communication and consensus - driven decision making.  Senior management team is exceptional and the reason I joined the company.
cons: Quality of life differs significantly from team to team.  Before accepting a position with Capital One, try to learn promotion timing and turnover data for your prospective team.  It was striking to me how in one department, associates on two teams had entirely different experiences.

headline: Questionable Values
pros: benefits, starting salaries are pretty good, mostly a good culture
cons: if you are not a female, moving up can be really difficult in certain divisions.  Capital One's focus on being a top employer for working mothers overpowers promoting people for their respective contributions.  Even their benefits are very slanted toward providing more protection to females.  If you are a male with a disability, you can forget being treated equally. I would certainly never go as far to say that women in the workplace have had it easy, but does it make it right to punish males for this??  It's a new day and age, time to move forward and recognize people for their contributions equally.

headline: Awesome Company
pros: EXCELLENT culture; fantastic learning opportunities; great benefits. The company is comprised of many very intelligent and talented individuals. The work-life balance is also great.
cons: Because there is so much talent within the company, it can be more competitive getting a promotion. With that said, the company provides several opportunities to further develop yourself and your skills.

headline: Horrible Company

headline: Good company

headline: Nothing but smokes and mirrors
pros: The benefits are fabulous at Capital One and the free coffee was great. The office I have worked at was also conveniently placed, close to public transportations.
cons:
For my couple of years with Capital One, we were promised a better salary as it was much lower than the competitor. This promise was only keep for the least paid employees, many of the employees slightly higher were completely ignored. Promotions were also very iffy. Very often promised to be open internally first but many of the new promotions are often announced late or hidden from internal employees. Many of the new promotions are also "reserved" to preselected candidates and employees are often discouraged or prevented from applying to new position. Job security is also a big issue there, employees were laid-off even if they had decades of tenure with the company and as someone who had access to their performance numbers, I can attest that the reason was not their performance.

I also did get laid off so it may seem that my opinion may be biased but consider this. I worked very long hours off the clock (overtime was discouraged), including Christmas eve and Christmas day. My position involved very specific work and against impossible odds, I did manage to keep myself on time with everything. I was laid off under the pretext that I did not perform well in certain areas that was not the main focus of my position. Evaluations from peers also went against my superiors' opinion on those performance points. 

My goal here is show you that I never felt that it was a great place to work. Surveys were forced to us and the worry of a prying eye often forced people to give a positive score no matter what.

headline: Traveled a long way to find out it was just like everywhere else
pros: At first, Capital One seemed to be an ideal place where customer service and associate engagement were not contradictions in terms.  Certainly the site management, with a few legacy HSBC exceptions, did their part to ensure the culture was maintained.  The front line incentive has been generous and based only on QA scores, no sales.  The company seemed to be dedicated to bringing customer service work back in-house and on-shore in spite of the expense, and made multiple investments in the site and associates to underscore it.
cons: The punch line is that Capital One hired a new Sr VP of Card Channels, and her vision was to outsource more service work under the guise that it was needed to be "scalable" in a more digital world.  Also blamed was the city for not making it easy to recruit or retain employees.  All of that seems like a ruse.  The truth is that the folks in Richmond and McLean want to control everything and don't want in-house leaders making them look bad.  If you are seriously looking at a Capital One job outside of HQ, recommend you pass because they are likely to up and move at any time.

headline: IT Senior Manager
pros: Good pay, benefits, time off, etc.  Pockets of great leadership.  Campuses are excellent - great work spaces and amenities.  Coworkers are super bright, most committed to the success of projects, their teams, and their peers.
cons: Confused on their identity.  Want to be a "tech" company, but are a large financial institution.  This conflicts with federal regulations/controls/and risk reduction practices needed to support a financial institution.  Also has a tendency to do a full pendulum swing verses really thinking through broadscale shifts in direction.  In this new agile world, senior leadership should pilot, implement, learn in smaller pockets vs. taking an all or nothing approach to everything they do.  It's ok though because with the tendency to overcorrect, wait a year or so and it will balance back to what would have made sense in the first place...

headline: It can be great or awful - depending on the group

cons: The stack ranking performance system seems to be out of favor with a lot of companies, but Capital One loves it. There is no focus on developing good people managers. The managers I've had have been more focused on their careers than mine. For most groups, the focus is more on being visible than on actually delivering high quality work. Generally, all things considered, good work on one high $ projects is preferable to exceptional work on several lower $ projects.

headline: Great Place to Work, Awesome Benefits
pros: The campus and buildings are beautiful in Richmond. The salary and benefits are among the best in the Richmond market. Most everyone I have worked with is high performing employee, that wants to do what is best/right. Everyone is dedicated to doing excellent work and focusing on constantly improving things. The company provides it's employees with the tools to do any job right.
cons: A very competitive environment. Employees are rated and forced into distribution (a bell curve). The problem is that some areas have such few employees at a particular level that they're forcing a distribution on less than 10 people. Like most large companies there are some politics and it can be hard to get things done. Meetings have overrun this place.

headline: Great benefits, minimal opportunities for advancement
pros: Competitive salary, nice bonuses, big 401K match, great benefits overall. Smart people.
cons:
Incredibly hard to get promoted. Certain job families are valued (mainly product owners and business analysts) and others are not. If you find yourself in a category that is not valued, you will likely never be promoted. Don't let them convince you otherwise.

If you are being hired in as a professional - not college - hire, make sure you are at the correct level. HR/hiring managers are notorious for interviewing at one level and then offering the role at the level down, saying they want to "set you up for success" and you can get promoted in 6 months. It is not true and you will never catch up to the right level.

"Reorgs" happen at least every 6 months. Usually these involve layoffs and massive organizational challenges. I had managers in the double digits by 3 years in. Very disruptive both for getting work done and also for career trajectories.

Super hierarchical; no one owns anything, so it's hard to get decisions made, and when they're made, they can be undone by one person questioning the decision or thinking something else; highly regulated environment; lots of bureaucracy, so it's hard to get anything done.

headline: Great Company Mostly

headline: Horrible company to work for!!!!

cons: Very mismanaged company. Specially with their work at home core dept. Advancement is oportunities are minimal. They will change your schedule without your consent with a weeks notice. Started in a class of 20 and 6 months later 7 were remaining. Every employee is micro managed. Could be there for a couple of years and all of the sudden you can recieve a phone call telling you that you are no longer employed there without an explanation! Managers heve their favorite employees who they favor more than others. Oh and if you leave involuntary or voluntary you will recieve a letter by mail months later asking you to pay your vacation back.Thats not all. If you leave involuntary they will lie about the reason why you were terminated so you dont get unemployment. Hahaha What a joke of a company.

headline: Fraud Intake Coordinator / Fraud Account Supervisor
pros: PTO, available after 3 months, health benefits, and 401K matching are great. You probably won't find any place better for a call center job. Some managers are really nice and do legitimately care about you. I loved my manager and that's what led me to stick it out as long as I did before quitting for a job with less stress.
cons: Don't let the title fool you, you're customer service, just in the fraud department. There was a time that the job wasn't so bad, before the Home Depot compromise. After that, the department got slammed. Back to back to back calls, no time in between, from angry customers because Capital One's oversly sensitive fraud detection software rejected their purchase and having people fax documents (fax...it's 2015, come on) to clear up ID concerns. It's interesting for a while, but then you just wear down and begin hating the phone. You cannot really take a breather in between the back to back calls because you're graded on time in between calls, it's one of the stats that goes into your ranking which impacts your bonus and chance of moving to a better shift. QA scores are completely random. You could do the right thing, say the right script 99.9% of the time but if the manager so happens to pick that on call where a customer threw you off and you missed saying something, there goes 12 points and your chance of bonus that month. The stress of QA scores ultimately drove me away..and that was even with me getting a top bonus over 50% of the time in my year+ there. There are no advancement opportunities in this position. You can move to a different department, but about 1 out of every 200 hired employees might have a chance to get promoted to the CAAT team and from there about 1 out of 10 may make manager...eventually. But it will take a while. Pay was poor. I started at $13.01 an hour and got like a .05 or 1% raise after the first year.

headline: Takes a Specific Kind of Person
pros:
Working at Capital One was great, at the start.  My team was friendly, the people were good to work with; but the on-boarding was horrible.

The pay, benefits and ancillary perks were amazing there, as was the cafeterias that were available to eat at.
cons:
There is a complete disconnect between upper management and everyone else regarding job expectations and performance; leading to a ton of confusion as to just how you're supposed to perform so that you get a good rating and bonus at the end of the year.  It seems entirely subjective, from the outside looking in.

They treat their full time people like temporary hires, including moving you from one location in the country to another, and then eliminating your job.  The morale seems to go down further every 6-10 months, as they announce more layoffs, excuse me, "redeployments", and as they reorganize constantly.

headline: Amazing company

Constantly evolving and changing...could be a con, could be a pro. Sometimes it can be difficult to keep up with the integration of new acquisitions and constant changes as they drive forward at lightning speed to be the innovator of finance, credit, and technology.
The pay structure seems to be evolving into one that is more complacent and less competitive.

headline: Not at all what its hype up to be, Can be a stressful Job
author_position: Work At Home Customer Service Representative
pros: The pay was fairly descent, you do get benefits and some vacation in which I will explain in cons. The teams are all cool and the fact you get to work from home can be a plus. Their Bonus incentives ranging $300-$900 based on performance half is taken for taxes. You will get major holidays off. There are plenty of overtime or shift swaps available. Good experience to learn about differ banking products. Customer service only, No college education needed.
cons: Its not a fun job and you have atleast 24-30 task to do and you will make outbound calls. Capital One is outsourcing like crazy so very little to no room for advancement. Nobody every fully knows what they are doing including management. Their communication sucks. You may be stuck with the same pay for a long time without a raise. No split shift you work 8-9 straight with lunch and breaks in between. You have to bid on vacation and most of the days are always taken up. Referral program is a joke. No incentives for having one of the products. The training sucks, you will learn more on your own if you are tech/computer saavy. team bonus is a joke. Don't go in this expecting to make a nice salary like 50k plus yearly, not gonna happen.

Career growth is not well encouraged and calibration system is not transparent. Sometimes there is limited to non cross team collaboration.

headline: Sleepy job.
pros:
- great work-life balance
- competitive salary
- nice people
- if you are in management you will love it to bits (not being sarcastic, you work with great people who pretty much manage themselves)
- everything depends on which group/location you're at, I hear some are good though I haven't personally experienced this
cons:
if you are looking for a company where you will never do anything interesting but get paid well for it, this is a great place for you. There is so much red-tape and bureaucracy that you will literally spend 3 months  on something that would take 1 hour in a regular technology company. (You only think I'm exaggerating because you haven't worked here. Yes, I was surprised too but it's possible, trust me.) 

Basically, they hire really smart people who are then told to "wait" before they can do something. Most of the employees think the whole charade is ridiculous but pretend it's okay because the work-balance and salary are good. So you are surrounded by nice folk who share in your misery of having nothing whatsoever to do.

You are essentially getting paid to shut up and do things you know are wrong.

So ask yourself something, are you prepared to surf the Internet all day long while you wait for someone in another location to become available for a meeting (two weeks from today) which is necessary to be allowed to get started on doing your work? Then you're set. Do you enjoy endless meetings where you are mentally checked out? Then this is a great place for you! Do you enjoy a changing landscape where yesterday's words are rendered meaningless by the new directives of today, which will be equally meaningless tomorrow because none of it matters? Do I have a company for you.

If however you'd like to grow your job skills and are worried about becoming obsolete in your profession in a couple of years, avoid at all cost. If you are one of those sad people who like their work to have meaning, avoid at all costs. If you want to come home after a day of work and say, hey, I did something interesting today, avoid at all costs.

You have been warned. Choose wisely, grasshopper.

headline: Process Coordinator
pros: Benefits and a sense of community are great.
cons: Salary is below average with little hope of becoming even with the market.

headline: Capital One
pros: Great place to work. Associates are given a lot of ownership and I am surrounded by extremely successful and creative people. Pay is competitive, time off and benefits are top notch, and the company encourages a casual work environment.
cons: The company goes through "reorgs" a lot which can make it difficult for job retention. New hires are usually safe, but older executives don't last long because the company changes its profiles for various positions so quickly.

headline: Data Analyst
pros: very good, flexible, time management, bonus, team
cons: nothing as such. over all good

headline: Standard For Big Company
pros: Good pay, good bonus, 7% 401k match, Paid Vacation, if you are a director or above you get long term incentives (LTI)
cons:
All the exact things you can expect with big companies. Empire building by staffing up, over hype of products for promotion, and politics. 

While cons, not really much outside of what you would expect from any big company

headline: A great place to work

They are very inclusive and always willing to support you both at work and outside of work.  The company is also very active in the LGBT community and very supportive!

There is a lot of emphasis on doing what is right for customers.  The management is always available and everyone feels comfortable going to them for help.
cons: It can be a challenge to move up from an entry level position.  Unless you truly demonstrate that you deserve it.  Even when you do, sometimes you get hung up on corporate politics.

headline: Great Company

headline: Standard financial services corporation.

headline: Pays well, but not worth the backstabbing
pros:
Capital One pays very well in many of its departments. Especially if you're looking to work in one of their digital departments, expect to get a pretty competitive salary.

The company's got a pretty strong strategy and seems positioned to do really well in the industry.
cons:
Maybe it's because the headquarters is so close to D.C., but I never thought a corporate job could be so similar to an episode of House of Cards. Expect each and every one of your coworkers to play the political game extremely well. Capital One structures its performance reviews around a process that pits you directly against others in your job family to determine who gets the few coveted high ratings. So it behooves everyone to spend 99% of their time making themselves look good and making their coworkers look bad. 

Unfortunately, because of this, little to no actual work gets done, as everyone is more concerned with making a friend or two that will help them advance and backstabbing everyone else in the process. With such frequent reorgs, there is ample opportunity for ambitious people to try to wrest control of teams or entire departments from anyone who tries to focus on getting work done rather than playing the game.

If it weren't for the paycheck, there's no doubt that I'd call Capital One the worst decision I ever made.

headline: Amazing people to work with

We are responsible for ensuring that loan packages are in compliance with State and Federal regulations. Since our jobs are of such great importance, I feel that Capital One should offer a bit more starting pay.

For a company that touts Lean, Six Sigma and other efficiency measurements, Capital One implements it badly. Very poor communication amongst leaders and teams.

headline: Capital One

cons: The food is terrible.  A lot of bad people managers.  You'll hear everyone say how smart everyone is, but that isn't true at all.  Very corporate/political in the office.  There is a lot of backstabbing.

headline: Innovative , profitable and changing banking for good
