Great benefits and pay/bonus 
Good training and learning options
Stable and flexible job environment
cons:
Many layers resulting in bureaucracy 
Slow growth for existing employees . New people can come at a higher level even though competency wise they are okay or at par with existing employees

headline: You
pros: The best place to make money for non exempt associates. is in collections and recoveries. The bonus money alone could move you up a few tax brackets. The medical benefits are great which many people probably don't realize until you get benefits from another company. You'll also have plenty of time off between holidays and vacation days.
cons: Capital One is all about the numbers and the money. The only reason they have any ethics at all is based on congressional legislation, excessive regulatory complaints, lawsuits and government oversight.

headline: Principal Coordinator
pros: Great career development, excellent work life balance,
cons: Not enough opportunity for growth in certain areas

headline: Customer Service
pros: A good company who needs to think of workers as humans at times.Decent
cons: Need to balance the Over pressure

headline: Intent vs. Reality
pros: Capital One seems to be very interested in doing things differently for their end customers. Some creative thinking going on in the company.
cons: In the trenches it's very much like any other large financial institution. Aggressive timelines that are near impossible, but management seems to believe this is necessary to create a sense of urgency. Kind of a dated method in the current world.

headline: Great first job after business school
pros: Strategy, analytical depth and uncompromising integrity
cons: May be losing its original creativity

headline: Great Company
pros: I have worked as a Branch Manager and  a Small Business Banker with Capital One.  The leadership team at this bank is great.  They support you and genuinely care about your career goals and growth.  You have banking hours so work life balance is also hard to beat.  Compensation is fair and great employees.
cons: Their computer systems are convoluted and way outdated.  Be ready to re-key info.....a lot. Depending on your career path opportunities may be limited if you do not live int the VA or NY areas.

headline: Good for those without a degree
pros:
Decent hourly wage
Good benefits
Work environment
cons:
Nature of the position
Little room for advancement

headline: Great Place To Work!
pros: They are very focused on doing the right thing for the customer and employee engagement. They go above and beyond for their employees!
cons: The only con I can think of is that the vacation time is a little lower than other large banks I have worked for but not by much; maybe a day or two lower.

headline: Business Analyst
pros:
Capital One has invested a lot in your consultation and analytical skills; you will find many lower to middle managers with great analytical minds. Capital One also offers a wide array of training classes from SAS to scripting languages. You will learn a lot.

Capital One has also created a new venture called Capital One Labs. It models after start-ups with lots of freedom to pursue interesting products. In short, Capital One is a decent place to be if you are a young analyst looking to crack into the world of data analysis and finance.
cons: High turnover and lots of re-orgs, just like any other big companies

headline: make the shareholders more than happy!
pros: Large cap and stable company with strong benefits. Not afraid to mix it up with the big banks. Offers self-directed investing platform
cons: One flavor of the month was for us to be "locally devistating". If that doesn't pump you up then try working for 7 branch managers in less than the same number of years. Now that is devastating. Growth only through playing the political game. If you are looking to work here make sure that you polish and hone your political skills to maybe get a shot at a promotion.

headline: Great analyst community
pros:
I worked for Capital One as an analyst for several years, coming in straight from college.  The Analyst Development Program was a great way to make a transition to the "real world," get a lot of training and support, and meet many people throughout the company.  I felt like my managers cared about my development and provided great opportunities to succeed.
On a broader level, Capital One has a very collaborative culture.  Work/life balance was prized and easily obtained.  Pay and benefits were very good, especially for the Richmond area.  It is easy to switch teams if your current position is a bad fit, and that flexibility is supported by management.
cons:
Bureaucracy is a necessary evil, but that doesn't make it any less annoying.
People are smart, but this can also result in overly complex systems and processes.
There always seemed to be constant re-orgs that seemed disruptive and may or may not have actually achieved business objectives.

headline: Great work/life balance, limited career growth
pros: Great people, flexible schedules, autonomy, work from home opportunities.
cons: Heavy workload, limited opportunity for career growth, standard raises lower than the rate of inflation, a forced ranking system is used for performance management which has the potential to lower staff morale.

headline: Director of Analytics
pros: Smart people who care about results.
cons: Work life balance can sometimes be hard to find

headline: Company with great values
pros: The mission and values are great. The CEO is an excellent human being. Its an honor working for him. I believe in his values. Its all about the customer. The benefits are beyond great! There is flexibility and work life balance.
cons: Some managers do not live the Values set by Mr. Fairbank, they bring their personal bias and can make the place unpleasant.  There is not opportunities for minorities, which is contrary to the values of the company.

headline: Good company
pros: Good commissions, great advancement opportunity
cons: Too much for too little pay

headline: Great Company - lots of change
pros: Really rewards exceptional associates, extremely smart and driven associates, and work/life balance among the best
cons: lots of change, laying off 10-15% of associates in lines of business every 2-3 years. This works well because they do great severance but you must be able to handle change. Commitment to diversity in general has not led to diverse executives

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Great benefits, forward thinking, great people!
cons: Can get hectic at times. Disconnect between Data Analysts and Business Analysts, but this is likely not just an issue at Capital One. Slowed down by big company sludge. It's often hard to get something done, and it won't be quickly. Made worse since we are in the banking industry.

headline: Work at home specialist

cons: Minimal interaction with co-workers and management

headline: Micromanaging Company

cons: Micromanaging.  No opportunities for advancement (which is why I left after 2 years), lack of positive reinforcement (its always what you are doing wrong).

headline: Not what I expected
pros: None that I can think of, except that I got learn something because of my initiativeness.
cons: Standard recruitment process applied irrespective of what the position is. Frequent re-orgs, changes; leadership teams not in sync, no clear direction/vision on which way ahead.

headline: IT
pros: Great work culture and good work life balance. People respect your thoughts
cons: IT is not given importance. Salary for IT is low for testers compared to any other sector. Growth opportunity for testers is not so great. Performance review every 6 months sucks

headline: Product Manager/Owner
pros:
-Focused on new technologies
-Rapid turnaround cycle to add customer value
-Embraces Agile and Design thinking
cons: -Too many gate keepers still which slows down delivery

headline: Marketing Consultant
pros: Good flexibility, opportunity to move around within the org, moving towards a start up mentality
cons: Can be very "corporate," but working on being more dynamic.

headline: Good Company

cons: frequent reorg, change 3 mgr in 2 years

headline: Bank Teller
pros: Bank was close to home.  Hours are good.
cons: Too much stress on referrals.

headline: Mixed
pros: Great benefits and work life balance. Many opportunities to learn and grow professionally. Access to best in class resources in many instances.
cons: High turnover by design. Competitive culture  to the degree it degrades collaboration and results.  Outdated and counterproductive performance management process (GE / Jack Welch) . Career opportunities are narrow and deep in scope. Promotion opportunities are limited

headline: Executive Resolutions Las Vegas
pros: As a Principal Coordinator we work to enhance and build the integrity and trust of Capital One Customer Experience.  Not a hard job but a challenging one.   The perks and benefits of the company and department are like no other.   We are a team/family. Not to mention job security, as we have not been impacted with recent layoffs.   We have a supportive management team who are approachable and get in and work alongside of us.  Proving we are one.  At times would think it be an uplift to see management be acknowledged more and not always appear to be the bad guys. Understanding they have a jibe that they signed up to do too.  Plan to be a part of this group for a long time.
cons: Slow computer systems and too many hands in the pot at times.   Would like to see some consistency in the letter review process, we are not perfect and neither are those who review our letters.  The associates would like to see professional English reviewers.  Letters are a huge part of what we do and no matter how hard we try we never get it right no fault of our own.  Would like letter writing class opportunities but know those reviewing are qualified and not judged by my peers.

headline: A bank trying to decide if it's a bank or a tech company
pros:
- Awesome place for new grads looking to start their careers with plenty of training in soft skills.
- Team members are usually super friendly and very bright, talented people.
- Great place to be cultured in data-driven decision making and dealing with a lot of data (but not to be confused with Big Data).
- Great work/life balance, but only if you choose to.
cons:
- Hit and miss for experienced hires due to a lack of career advancement opportunities.
- Performance review is a popularity contest as politics reign supreme.
- Most people managers lack leadership skills; some just bypass associate development altogether.
- Starting offer is competitive with market but low growth trajectory quickly erodes that position.

headline: Small Business Customer Service Coordinator
pros: Great atmosphere, Hard work is recognized and compensated, Continual training
cons: Call center is open long hours, which make for long shifts if you choose a 4 day 10 hour schedule.

headline: The only thing that's constant is change
pros: Capital One hires amazing people, Good benefits, generous PTO (160 hours/ year after 90 day probationary period). Great community involvement. Paid volunteer opportunities.
cons: Constant changing environment. During a 12 month period I was transferred teams 7 times. The micromanaging has become a bit much, honestly we are all adults.

headline: Associate
pros: I work with a group of people who are very intelligent and empathetic.  The company treats its associates well and offers great benefits (401K, stock purchase plan, vacation, etc.).
cons: Like most big banks, it can sometimes be hard to get things done.

headline: Business Risk Analyst
pros: big company with good benefits/ working hours. The infancy of the commercial bank, allows for good development opportunities.
cons:
The commercial bank is in it's infancy, and is not as streamlined in it's internal processes as more mature banks. 
Expect to encounter strange clashes of corporate cultures, from lots of new management coming from other financial institutions.

headline: Former Employee
pros: Great Vacation/Health Insurance Benefits. Family type of environment.
cons: Hourly pay wasn't so great. Sales goals are unrealistic.

headline: Great Opportunity
pros: Great people, and lots of training opportunities
cons: Not many opportunities in larger cities

headline: Analyst
pros: great work environment, very friendly co workers and managers.
cons: Cant think of it, its a great place to work.

headline: Terribly disorganized, no clear roles/responsibilities
pros: Amazing benefits. Incredible 401(k) match, awesome bonus program and good salary. They even match your FSA and offer multiple health related programs during the year where you can get extra bonuses in the form of gift cards. Decent number of in-office perks like free breakfasts/lunches, lenient business travel policy.
cons: You just can't throw money at people and expect it to make them happy when the organization is a complete and utter mess. There is tremendous overlap across teams and departments, so you're constantly facing redundancies and duplicative work. No one has a clear role so everyone is fighting to "own" something and it creates lots of tension. I work in Brand Strategy, only there is NO strategy. We just react to everything and change our minds every 5 minutes, so it's impossible to accomplish anything. Processes are rigid and get in the way of doing work, rather than helping it along. People are fairly nice, but many are in the wrong role and don't know what they're doing, which further slows things down. Performance management is talked about every 5 seconds, but is highly political and even one weakness can hold someone back from progressing...unless they're connected to the right people and have become a favorite. Stay away!

headline: Great place to start a career
pros:
- Good work-life balance. Depends on your team, but I have 35-45 hour weeks and work at home whenever I feel like it.
- Decent pay. Perhaps not the highest around, but you're well compensated for the amount of effort you put in. Richmond-based people can live like kings. Excellent 401k match.
- Smart and friendly people. The culture is pretty open - but see cons.
- Good cafeteria in McLean. Richmond's is worse.
- Very focused on development. Tech/finance skills are weighted equally with presentation/influence skills and you are strongly encouraged to work on these through practice and classes.
cons:
- Capital One is trying hard to become a tech company but not much is changing. Buzzwords abound but few understand what they mean (and they keep leaving). Some people work on innovative side projects, but the core work stays the same.
- Too many highly qualified people are stuck doing monotonous work.
- People can be too nice. Reluctance to openly criticize or flat-out reject a doomed project results in wasted time.
- Promotion/rating process is very secretive and results are sometimes surprising.

headline: Amazing Company!
pros:
Work life balance
Diversity
Great people
Capital One exceeds expectations in the areas of customer service and customer satisfaction. Continually seeking to improve the process and develop innovative technology.
cons:
Alot of change and reorganization occurs
Difficult to obtain promotions

headline: Not bad at all.
pros: Awesome benefits. The starting PTO is amazing.  My manager is great.  There's a reason why the CEO has over 90% approval rating.  The company really cares about it's associates.  Ignore the other reviews which claim that you get fired for anything.  Those reviews were made by employees who simply didn't try hard enough.  If you're not performing up to standard, then your manager WILL be there to help you develop your skills.  However, if you're still not meeting minimum standards, then you're let go.  That's how it is in EVERY company. Capital one literally gives you more than 3 months to improve.  If you can't show the slightest bit of improvement in more than 3 months, the job just isn't for you.  Favoritism is there, but there's always favoritism in every company.  Make yourself known, be outgoing, talk to everyone you meet in the lobby during your breaks.  The managers are all nice and friendly and are more than happy to stop what they're doing to answer any question you may have.  When it's not busy, there will be between  8 to 10 minutes between calls.  Another positive is that you get to learn a lot about fraud in general and how it affects card holders.   You primarily get calls from people with high credit limits (meaning they're pretty rich), so it's always nice striking up a conversation with them about their job or business.  You may even get to speak to a famous person too..  I recently got an incoming call from the co-producer of "Resident Evil: Extinction"  in regard to his declined transaction.  Pretty cool.
cons: The job itself can get a bit mundane; especially if you keep getting the same types of calls throughout the day.   The pay is not great.  The potential bonuses are good, but even if you make top bonus every month, the overall yearly pay still isn't great.   Like the other reviews say, the room for advancement is very slim.  If you're not networking and not keeping your stats up every month, don't expect to be promoted.  A big negative is having to fix the errors that the over-seas agents make on a constant basis.  Nothing is worse than  getting a call from someone who didn't receive their card after they requested it 3 weeks ago, only to find out the over-seas agent forgot to request it.

headline: Great up to a point...
pros: Awesome to place to begin your career - Dynamic company that genuinely wants to do the right thing - Challenging and fast paced - Always, always striving to do things better

Change is a lays afoot, so you will likely have multiple managers each year

While I believe Capital One wants to cares about their associates, ultimately it's all about results

When Capital One decides to move in a direction, it goes all in - without fully thinking through consequences

The Marketing & Analytics team (M&A) team runs Capital One.  If you are not from M&A, your future is limited once you reach middle management.

headline: Excellent place to develop skills early in your career
pros:
Joined Capital One as a member of the Analyst Development Program. The program is world-class in terms of developing employees analytical, quantitative, and technical skills, and gives new hires fresh out of college the chance to own high-impact ($MMs) projects right out of the gate, with lots of exposure to senior management. Analysts operate under an 'internal consulting' model, with internal clients or customers for whom they are responsible for providing analytical support for various projects. Culture is very similar to that of a consulting firm, as many of the firm's senior leadership initially came from consulting.

Skill development in the program is phenomenal, and analysts leave the program with a very robust skillset that is applicable not just in financial services, but a wide variety of industries which value analytical talent. Expect to receive numerous inquires on LinkedIn etc, if you have Capital One on your resume. 

Company also promotes a strong work-life balance and a collaborative work environment, where learning and development is highly encouraged.
cons:
Simply put, managers at Capital One are, for the most part, a total clown show. Traditionally promotes employees to management roles following strong work as an analyst, but unfortunately, the company puts in very little effort at developing actual human people management skills. As a result, managers tend to be very strong analytically and at problem solving, but horrendously poor at communication and influencing, motivating, and developing their own employees. This is compounded by the fact that the company has very vague and subjective criteria for evaluating employee performance, and puts too much weight on things that are not important in the grand scheme of things when it comes to performance. As a result, the performance review and promotion process tends to be a nightmare. 

Company is also very inefficient with regards to their decision-making process, due in part to being overly reliant on PowerPoint presentations, and in part due to the many levels of hierarchy that must be cleared before any decisions are implemented. Even policy decisions with the smallest level of customer impact require a 10-page PowerPoint presentation to at least 3 levels of management + a third-party office responsible for evaluating credit policy decisions. As a result, the pace of change and progress tends to be rather slow.

Compensation and benefits are good enough, but pay levels could be better - especially with respect to other Financial Services firms.

headline: Senior Data Analyst
pros:
- Great 401(k) match. One of the best I've seen outside of oil and gas companies. Stock purchase plan is also very attractive. Onsite gym is pretty great. Onsite medical clinic in Richmond is also amazing. Really cheap lunch and breakfast options. Overall very good benefits.
- Smart employees and lots of opportunities.
- So many courses that you can take through Capital One university. Honestly the best training programs I've ever heard of and they're all free. Taking a half day to take a course is totally cool.
- Strong moat, good company overall. We didn't lose our hat in the financial crisis by any means so we'll be around for the future.
- Awesome analyst development program. Capital One wants to bring in and train people for the future.
- Great work/life balance. Flexible work arrangements. Work from home if you want or need to, but people tend to lean towards coming in every day
cons:
- Finance company parading around as a "tech" company. Big push to hire tons of software engineers and go "digital," but I have my doubts that this will ever affect the bottom line.
- I have a great team, but it's such a large company that everyone's experience is different. For a company that claims to be a "tech" company at heart, we're really slow to adapt new technologies. It took awhile just to get one Tableau license. 
- Rich Fairbank might be ADD. He demo'd Tableau one day (This was before my time so it's a second-hand story) and it was all the rage, now I hear they're pushing SAP Lumira as the BI tool of choice.
- Base pay is definitely below market for Data Analysts and Data Scientists despite a lot of these people having very valuable skills. (some combination of Python, SAS, Shell, SQL, HBase/Hadoop and R)  Richmond, VA or Plano, TX pay is alright when adjusted for Cost of Living, though.

headline: COU
pros: Work-life balance; Facilities far above average, (with the exception of Wilmington) benefits are above average; retail bank presence is strong.  Exec management communicates frequently.
cons:
The constant  change is somewhat ridiculous. Hire, layoff, recruit for new positions, hire, layoff, recruit for new positions and change senior management - seems like this is done quarterly. Previous ING folks seem to take precedence. The merger happened over 2 years ago and they still talk "ING" language.  Newsflash - ING in the US is Capital One - get used to it.  So many duplicate positions.  Card Services remain the "golden child" and typically run separate from the rest of the organization.  Training and Talent development is awful - the worst I have ever seen.  They lack consistency and fail to build solid relationships within the organization.  

Sr (Exec Mgt) does communicate frequently - town halls, etc.  Done particularly in Richmond and McLean. Most communications will never disclose anything but positive or good news about the enterprise - very filtered so as to believe it is a perfect company.  Very "Virginia" based. Other locales are felt like outcasts. 
Technology far behind banks of their size.  Salary scale somewhat lower than banks their size as well.

headline: Teller I
pros: Training program for new hires is one of the best I've seen. The company as a whole has a great culture and great benefits. They offer tuition reimbursement, even if you are using a degree that may not be relevant to work in a banking environment. The traditional benefits (insurance, 401k, etc.) are also some of the best I've seen, at least in the area I live. The company encourages advancement and prefers to promote within.
cons: The local management is has too many cliques and doesn't like to work with those who choose not to be part of their cliques. If you don't fit in with their group, they will make work very difficult and will criticize even things you do correctly. The district manager that was hired during my time with Capital One also had unrealistic goals for branches in our area. He had never worked in the lower levels of the banking industry (teller, relationship banker, branch manager) and had only been upper level management since moving to banking, therefore he set unrealistic expectations.

headline: Where Did They Find These Managers
pros: Let me think about this and get back to you
cons:
My manager soon to be X-manager they must have picked him from the bottom of the barrel. Yes, this is true and I am not kidding. I took my issues with this person to HR rep. And it went on deaf ears. This person tore apart the structure of the team and hired all new people and fired nearly everyone else just to save $. I guess the old employees were too much $.  I never saw this manager EVER work even 8 hours a day - totally unplugged could care less about anyone on the team except número uno. Even after I went to HR multiple times, they did nada. And now the loser manager is leaving cap one. And in the process has literally destroyed the team. All I have to say is I am SO glad I don't do ANY business with this company. YES I mean it!
The net result of POOR management is the customer suffers. And that frankly is why I don't do any business with this company. I really wanted this to be the company that everyone one wants to work for but frankly was so naïve. This company must have bought its way to the list of Forbes 100 best companies. Because, if it was a good place to work there would be procedures in place to protect an employee from an unethical manager.

headline: Overall great company but some integration challenges

cons: They are currently working through some culture challenges resulting from integrating Bank acquisition and a focus on hiring external talent for Digital positions. The culture can range from conservative "that is how we always have done it" bankers to "hey let's do this cool think" digital managers

While their are opportunities for advancement and promotion - many managers would rather place their "buddies" in new roles, even if they have no experience. Opportunities are also given to the same 4-5 people in a department, but everyone is held to their expectations to produce results when they are not given an opportunity to do so.

headline: Very enjoyable work environment
pros: Great benefits, excellent career advancement opportunities with on the job education and training.  Competitive pay with bonus potential.  Management really seems to care.
cons: If you have seen the movie Office Space, it can kind of get mundane, but Capital One does it's best to keep morale as high as possible.

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Good work-life balance, nice people and the Richmond campus is great.
cons:
- Looks like you can only move sideways if you're in certain parts of the organization, which doesn't make sense.  Regardless of what department one is in, everyone should have the opportunity to progress upwards. 
- Additionally, if you're based in DC - you have to go back and forth to the Richmond office frequently.  Sometimes meetings will be scheduled in Richmond without even consulting one's availability to make the 2-hour one way trip.  Going for a day is 4 hours round trip.... If I wanted to travel that often, I'd rather work in Consulting for higher pay.

headline: Area sales manager

headline: Program Manager

headline: IT developer
pros:
1. The agile methodology is a breath of fresh air compared to the waterfall they used to operate under.  

2. Their software is using some pretty old technology, but they have meetings to practice and discuss newer technology and they occasionally bring them into operation if management likes it.  

3. They seem generally interested in hearing employees concerns and addressing them.

4. Annual bonus is nice if you get a good review.
cons:
Working late is expected if your team needs to meet a sprint commitment.  

The 70/20/10 rule is used for performance reviews.  I usually land in the 70%, and once or twice in the 20% high ranks, but each time the reviews come around, there is a lot of anxiety and self doubt.  

The way it works is your manager has to advocate on your behalf in a big meeting and convince everyone else of your value.  You are compared against all other employees with the same rank as you.  If your manager isn't very persuasive, even if you are one of the best employees, you could end up in the bottom 10%.  Also, a manager who is a great salesman could sell a bad employee into the 70% pretty easily.  So rather than measuring employees to get rid of the worst 10%, they are really just punishing employees who work under a bad manager.  This model seems to really highlight the old saying, "A team is only as good as their manager".  

Also, the system also seems to encourage leaving coworkers out to fail publicly so that you can get a leg up on them in the next review session.  I've never done it, but I can see the strategy working for some.  Because its agile, you have an incentive to keep your team mates on track, but there is no incentive to help Joe from the other team.

headline: I love this company!
author_position: Work At Home Customer Service Coordinator
pros: The starting pay is incredible and full time agents can bonus up to $1000.00 per month on top of that. Some positions allow you to work from home which really helps with the work/life balance. They offer a lot of optional overtime. The benefits are the best I've ever had and they give you a lot of vacation/sick time. You are not required to work holidays but you can if you want and they pay triple time if you do. I could go on and on! If you get the chance to work for this company, take it!!!
cons: Sometimes the customers can be over the top rude but that says nothing about the company itself.

headline: Great for working moms

pros: Capital One invests a lot into new college graduates. During the first year, there are lots of networking and fun events where they fly you to richmond to meet other people in the company. At the networking events, they will also train you for job specific roles. Also, most of the new hires are from ivy league schools. This creates a very intellectually stimulating environment.
cons: They don't treat contractors too well. So there is constant hiring, firing and training within the it contractor section of the company.

headline: Contractor life at Capital one
pros: Great company to work for. I was working for product that was about to be launched in market, so environment was like a start up that had been fully funded.
cons: As a contractor you have certain limitation on what benefits are available to you or if your concern will be actioned

headline: Falling behind in terms of pay and benefits but work is good

cons:
People are ambitious which can cause problems. Senior UK management are pretty lack lustre and don't follow through on any promises they make. Investment was promised and has not been forthcoming.
Pay is falling behind the market.

headline: Model building, statistics consulting

headline: Great Place to Start In Banking.

cons: Additional bonuses and incentives  have been steadily decreasing since I've been with the company.

headline: Good job, although not as fast changing as they claim.
pros:
Overall Capital One provides a good, stable work environment. Many of the projects are interesting and at times, challenging. Your colleagues are typically very talented and of the same mindset. It may take time, but problematic employees will be managed out.

Benefits, PTO and Work/Life balance are strong pluses for a corporate or professional role. I cannot comment for our call centers and front line roles.
cons:
Legacy Capital One is very  much stuck in the old days and it creates this weird divide between the new arrivals and old guard. This divide helps slow down the company as some groups resist change. Although, this seems to be continually improving.

Invest some more money in Downtown DC, local growth is Fairfax-centric and we are missing a large chunk of our local talent pool.

headline: Employees are bright and talented but the review process makes for a competitive and adversarial environment.
pros: Inspired by bright individuals with different perspectives
cons: Competitive; little room for creativity

headline: Generally great culture, rapid management changes
pros:
- Generally great culture, very open, fun events, free swag and food
- Investment in education
- Great pay when comparing to similar positions on the market
- Work from home option
- Employee stock plan has no vesting period
- Employer matched RRSP contributions are really good
- Generally really good hiring process that weeds out individuals without the appropriate technical skills
- They actually fire people who are not performing to keep up a high performance level
cons:
- Hiring process is long and slow with many steps
- Lots of change in upper management results in a very dynamic and not so enjoyable work environment
- Some departments not as good to work for as others.  Data analyst team is great; finance team is not so great
- Not a lot of room to move up within Canada, although there are lots of opportunities in the US and particularly Richmond, Virginia

headline: Great culture and atmosphere. Awesome company to work for.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good family environment – many growth opportunities within the call center -- good money
cons: They do not have a good system for growth outside of your department.  It is very hard to move outside of the call center.  Very easy to get stuck.

headline: Good benefits but all people are expendable
pros: They pay and benefits are very good.
cons:
Any employee can and will be replaced at any time. Change is a constant and never makes much sense. Every manger is ruled by Corporate Buzz Words and the overall driver of everything which is statistical measuring. The Six Sigma management has gotten to the point where processes are created , and managers hired and fired to manage those processes. Capital One has been trying to slowly turn into a bank, but they DO NOT have a clue as to how a bank operates. 
Capital One also has a corporate arrogance and discriminates against older employees.

headline: Amazing Company
pros: Capital One embraces their employees for who they are.  the culture is very laid back and casual, the opportunities to get involved are endless, and they really help you out as much as possible to advance in your career, whether its with them or not.
cons: It is a metric driven company, to be able to get to where you want to be, you have to delegate your time appropriately to maintain your goals.  Also, making the top bonus is very difficult, but not impossible.  Along with any call center, the gossip and drama is never ending and very high school.

headline: Capital One
pros: 401k, free health clinic, salary
cons: Company structure, promotion requirements of

headline: Management in Home Mortgage/Equity are incompetent and machiavellian
pros: Great benefits, excellent on campus gym, top notch cafeterias.
cons: The Home Equity/Mortgage department is a complete joke.  They did a system conversion in October of 2014 that was a disaster and left many customers frustrated.  They do not seem to plan ahead and things fall apart as a result of this.  They make too many changes too fast with out listening to employees to get viable feedback. Managers are on a serious power trip and micromanage employees to death (i.e cant be at you desks until at least 5 minutes before shift start, daily meetings that accomplish nothing.)  Micromanagement in itself is bad, but when you compound it with incompetent leadership.

headline: CapitalOne is an awesome company to work for. They care so much about their customers.
pros: They are customer service oriented, they care a lot about their employees and they treat us well. Their training is the best because the first two days you get to travel to the corporate office and train there and meet upper management. Lunch was on them for those days, they treated us well and gave us very good information on the history of the company. Then we train at a training center for 9 days and we learn the whole system and policies and procedures. We practice a lot so we can get it by the time we get to our branch. After this week then we will shadow at another branch to see how they do it. The life balance is great 9-5 job and on Saturdays 9-1 and no Sundays, so it is great. The time off is awesome, we get 4 weeks per year for the first four years and we also get 10 paid holidays off in the year. So much opportunities to grow within the company, just be great at your job and they will provide you with everything you need to transfer to another department or promotion.
cons: There is absolutely nothing that is bad about this company, they are just awesome in every way they continue deliver on their promises to their employees.

headline: Great place to start your career and learn all there is to know about the surprisingly innovative credit card industry

headline: Great company and great people with poor management skills.
pros: Benefits are good as compared with similar ones. 401K contribution, vocation package and other benefits overall. Compensation is acceptable, but it's not in the top in region area. A lot trainings with lunch free, Xmas party, team party. Nice campus in West Creek and Buildings with nice office. Company have good profits so far.
cons:
Waste your time to work if you want career opportunities. Company is still using 'tech' as old as 10 years ago and try to keep it forever. A Bank company's goal to be 'Technology' ones, but it's not realistic. Senior managers are anxious of their 'performance' to get higher annual bonus, They do not care what is the new and DO CARE WHAT PEOPLE LIE AT STANDING UP MEETING. A lot meetings create 'good' communications with trashes. For example,
10-10, How to listen your boss's lies and flatter them.
Agile, How to lie your daily work.
Agile grooming, How to generate a lot trash tasks and nobody really cares later.
PS: Over 100 people fly from different regions to discuss one or two week tasks for less than 10 people. 
Richmond JAVA Community, Another trash meeting to benefit special purpose (individually).

headline: Primitive Commercial Bank is a Great Place to retire
pros: Great work/life balance. Excellent facilities in McLean HQ. Friendly, non-bank-like environment, even in the commercial bank. Good and cheap cafeteria in HQ. Free parking!
cons: Treasury management rife with senior management turnover - very little confidence in senior leaders to execute on long term strategy. Siloed departments do not collaborate, making it hard to build solid relationships with customers. Favoritism runs amok. Extremely unclear performance review process. Easier to get promoted if you are well liked or a 'yes man' vs. actually being good at your job. Bonus structure not competitive vs. industry. Tendency to hire externally vs. promote internally.

headline: Great Benefits

headline: Master Software Engineer (Manager)
pros: decent salary, 7.5% 401k match, perks not that bad when compared with other traditional organizations like capital one.
cons:
capital one preaches one and practices one. you will be able to see this across all layers of management. every year when i speak to my directors they speak about promotion opportunities and expect you to make a difference in the organization etc., etc., and finally award promotion to non technical talents because there is no growth path for technical people who wants to stay technical. as you see upwards of the management hierarchy, all of them are from non technical background and hence they don't really like technical talents except for getting work done through them.

only 1/10 will be technical talent and there will be a huge crowd of people who you will deal with everyday and get frustrated. you might start feeling very dumb over a period of time because the environment is not fostering enough.

headline: Waste of 10 years
pros: Pizza parties, stupid and dumb senior managers, team night out- and the Xmas party

When I resigned and did my exit interview I was shocked to be told this boss marked me ineligible for rehire... without any reason.  HR said all managers had the right to do this and there was nothing I could do about it.  I confronted him and I asked him to go back and correct it. Requesting a raise takes weeks to be submitted and months to get declined. People being hired from the outside into sales-focuses positions get paid tons more than those who have been promoted internally (ex i make 36k after 5 years, new hires for the same position are hired at 40k) They recently changed their sales incentinves/goals and are making it much harder for bankers and tellers to get their monthly minimums and to make decent commission

headline: "Work/Life Balance"
pros: Their benefits are competitive. If you're fortunate, you will have a manager who acts as an advocate for you and provides additional resources when needed.
cons:
It is very difficult to get things done due to the structure of the company. Every line of business is partitioned off from the other and it's like pulling teeth to get complete answers to your questions and resolve problems.

Even though overtime isn't required, they make sure you do it by assigning more work than can be done in 40. You can work 10+ OT a week on average, and you will still be reprimanded by taking unexpected time off if you're sick. There are no "sick days", only "unscheduled time off", and you are only allowed 32 hours of that a year.  If you are struck with the flu, experience car problems, kids have a snow day, etc., that can add up fast.

headline: Top Bank strives to be a Technology company, but still a long way to go
pros:
Mission is a real thing, not just a slogan.  This company genuinely cares about its customers to make sound financial decision. 

Great value and competencies

cons:
Arrogant in a wrong way.   1)  Always chasing after a shining object, whether technologies or practices, company has not fully exploit the benefits before moving on to something new.  2)  demanding year-after-year efficiency but not investing in people and tools to make things better.

Still very Richmond-centric.  Still operating in old-school out-of-sight out-of-mind mentality.

For a financial company, it does not have a good finance practices. 1) unbalanced budget hinders business competitive edge.  2) 1 billion+ budget is being run by less than qualified people who in turn creating havoc year after year    

Some critical applications are still running on antiquated infrastructure with no incentive or enforcement for owners to refresh or innovate.

Performance management process is extremely heavy that it actually takes away cycle for real work and innovation

Slow decision making process is in the way of agility and innovation

headline: Don't let the back-office employees with the plush jobs fool you about what working Capital One is really like...
author_position: Relationship Banker I, Then Mortgage Loan Officer
pros:
Benefits are solid. I was a little disappointed when I left and lost my contributions, due to a vesting schedule that was NOT well communicated. Auto enroll me into the 401(k) without my consent, but not let me know how long until it's vested? Pretty lame

I took advantage of the tuition reimbursement and wasn't disappointed. 

Pay and bonus potential were good, but depending on your branch location, traffic, demographic, you'd either be doubling your salary with incentives or making your base salary ONLY, no matter how hard you worked.
cons:
Incentive program changed rapidly - sometimes 2-3 times a year, based on the direction of the company and how they felt if too many bankers did "too well." It's their game - they make and change the rules whenever they want.

Being a branch employee is like prison - while there may be work-life balance, there's no leaving outside of branch hours for life/family/adult responsibilities. 

I moved onto a Loan Officer role after they began to remove the Assistant Branch Manager and Sales and Service Coach positions that I was promised and working so hard towards. 

As I moved to mortgage origination, Capital One destroyed the majority of my book of business. 
1) deceptive advertising - how much money did they spend on a No Closing Fee loan that almost NO ONE met the underwriting criteria, leaving inquirers upset and disappointed?
2) ridiculous lack of communication and flow through the mortgage department. There's a reason they abandoned mortgages all-together for quite some time. People often left the process and moved onto other institutions. 
3) forcing people into products they didn't want. No one wants your high interest rate, low closing cost fee "first lien" home equity loan.

And many other issues. 

I finally went back to school and left banking for much more lucrative pursuits. You should all consider the same.

headline: Analyst
pros:
Great mission "changing banking for good" - company is truly putting action to this and it has greatly excited our workforce.  The customer focus is truly awesome and is really inspiring.
CEO continues to be the charismatic driving force behind the mission and the declared corporate strategy and spends significant time getting in front of associates annually to present on it
Awesome benefits
Company is doing very well overall
cons:
Company continues to be heavily skewed with most senior leaders having come in as Business Analysts in Marketing and Analysis (M&A in Capital One).
Lately Digital Product Managers and Data Scientists are the hot jobs - coming in as anything else is definitely less appreciated and long term outlook for some roles is questionable at best (Project Manager, Data Analysts, etc).  Of course it is still good to be a BA also (although some are starting to question that, and attrition is going up).
Performance management, while a 360 process, continues to be questionable at best.  Promotions don't always make sense and clearly are not always results based (no different than many other companies, but good to go in with eyes open that it is far from perfect here despite our 360 process)
Continued hiring swings.  Record # of hires in some areas while redeployments (layoffs) in others.  Senior leadership does not manage this well.

headline: Mixed bag so far, but things are on the way up

Especially in the past year or so, customer experience is an increasingly larger focus of most projects.
cons: We are a huge organization with high amounts of specialization, so I've noticed a recurring problem of different teams not communication with each other. I am in a support organization and have seen many of my completed projects de-prioritized before they are implemented. It has gotten pretty discouraging. Also, our recruiting and compensation teams within HR are awful. I can't count how much blatantly irrational behavior I've seen from these teams.

When the contract expires it is extended (2 years max), rather than going perm, implying performance was not the true factor (i.e., poor performers should not be offered extensions).  There is also a bullying culture that rewards aggression under the guise of promoting "Type A" personalities.
