headline: Like working at a (technology) startup that has good funding, great benefits, and decent work-life balance
pros:
This is an update of a review I previously posted

Benefits are great. 401K up to 7.5% company contribution, short/long term disability paid by company, discounted company stock purchase option, vacation days (able to buy more during open enrollment), unlimited sick days, 3 family care days, free financial planning consultations via Fidelity, free use of athletic trainer in company fitness centers twice a week (there is a fee to use the fitness centers, but no additional charge to use the trainers). I find the medical insurance (bronze/silver/gold options through Aetna) to be expensive compared to the HMO I can get through my spouse's employer, but I don't think the Aetna costs at Capital One are out of line with what I have observed at other companies; I'm not a fan of the high deductible though. Capital One does try to brunt the pain of the high deductible by offering free health clinics on site at major locations (no copay - family members can also visit) and no copay to visit CVS minute clinics. Very progressive company - just announced expansion of maternity leave to 12 weeks PAID, 2 weeks paid paternity leave, 6 weeks paid adoption leave/surrogate leave (if your child born via surrogate), $10K contribution toward adoption expenses, fabulous medical benefits for families with autistic children. Company will contribute up to $1000 toward your flexible spending accounts (medical/dependent care). 

My manager (and senior leadership team in general) have been absolutely fabulous - when my dad died, I was told "take the time you need" - very humane.

I had severe culture shock after joining Capital One for a very long time... I have encountered very few "slackers" and am continually impressed at how responsive most associates are to any requests/questions I may have - it's highly unusual for it to take more than 4 hours to get a response. Capital One takes pains to hire very intelligent, data-driven associates. I am very satisfied with my work/life balance, but that balance can be a bit unpredictable at times (mainly because I am in an operational role - stuff happens... and you have to deal with it right then).

Capital One has taken great pains to recruit/retain associates hired as interns/new college grads - this program is very well-designed/run. They would be well-advised to pay a reasonably equivalent level of attention to experienced hires (obviously, more seasoned hires don't need as quite as much hand holding).  While there is clearly room for improvement in this area, I've observed some progress on this front over the past few months - a *lot* of energy spent on trying to improve the onboarding process for experienced hires within my line of business so that they have everything  they need to do their jobs once they finish the 1.5 day long HR onboarding process (which incidentally is *very* well done).  Similarly, I've observed some efforts aimed at reducing the red tape that makes it difficult to do your job efficiently and reduce the "environmental" learning curve associated with being a new hire. While you might be a subject matter expert in your area, you can't be effective without also understanding the company environment.

I am thoroughly impressed by the company's commitment to doing the right thing by their customers. While I won't go into any detail here, suffice it to say Capital One gives up a LOT of $ by not following the same practices used by many of the other large financial companies. The latitude given to call center associates to satisfy a customer's needs is unprecedented.  

Capital One University is a fabulous resource for associates ... many different types of training courses (online, instructor lead) are available - many at no cost to the associate's department. Subjects covered are typically either line of business centric or role centric (e.g. project management college, software engineering college, information security college, etc.). 

The corporate culture is heavily oriented toward recognizing associate contributions. The size of your pay raise and bonus are heavily predicated by your performance review rating  (which is in turn based upon your contributions); the higher your performance review rating, the larger your pay raise/bonus.  Bonuses can comprise a very significant portion of associate compensation - the higher your paygrade, the more significant the bonus is.  

Any associate can recognize another associate or team of associates for their contributions. The recognization can range from a simple thank you note to points that can be redeemed by the associate for gift cards from a wide variety of vendors to cash awards. 

Promotions are a *HUGE* deal at Capital One.. they are generally recognized twice a year. All promotions are publicly announced (typically first within the individual line of business, then company wide). If you are on the receiving end of a promotion, you can count on being flooded with congratulatory IMs, emails, and phone calls from fellow associates once the announcement is public. It can be a bit overwhelming if you aren't expecting it.  Promotion recipients are also invited to a luncheon with their managers and members of the senior leadership team.  I personally have felt very empowered to "grow my flame" here.

Mobility within the organization is excellent - there are many, many  roles available within information technology. If you get tired of your current role, there's an excellent chance there will be an opening in a different area of IT that you can apply for.
cons:
The "startup" culture at Capital One can be a double edge sword - if something isn't working, just wait six months (or less) and it will change. 

If you are a person with a "glass half empty" attitude or someone who greatly values organizational structures/processes etc. remaining static over a long period of time, this is NOT the company for you. 

There have been big changes in the senior leadership team (most external hires) in my line of business during the time I have been at Capital One, a significant number (1100+) of associates hired (many as part of the drive to insource key functions). While I think the CEO and very senior management have good plans for the company (e.g., identifying key objectives each year, and making solid plans to reach them), objective identification/planning within my own line of business has historically been shaky at best, largely due to understaffing/lack of resources and multiple reorgs. I have noticed some positive movement in this area  over the past 2-3 months - I do like what I'm seeing/hearing - but will reserve judgement for another few months.  If this changes significantly for the better, I'll up my rating from 4 to 5 stars.

Predictably, mentoring of associates is not what it should be in my line of business given the staffing challenges.The company does pair up a "buddy" with new hires who request it. While I had a buddy, I didn't find it useful because the buddy was not in the same location or same role as me, and so was not able to answer many of the questions that I had.IT has been switching over to agile-based methods (not just for software development), while also shifting to a federated model in which IT resources are assigned to a particular line of business rather than a centralized pool of IT resources. While there are some distinct advantages to that approach (e.g., IT resources are intimately familiar with the applications of their line of business and the associated network infrastructure; fewer issues with prioritizing needs across different lines of business), it makes it difficult for the remaining "central" IT organization to keep track of everything that is going on. Time will tell how this gamble pays off.

Associates in general don't like the performance management system, but overall I think it provides a decent measure of fairness. Everyone that I've known that has received a promotion truly deserved it.. 360 feedback is strongly emphasized as part of the performance management process. Forced "cross-calibration" sessions amongst managers of all associates at the same level are performed biannually as part of the performance management process to ensure everyone uses the same standards to rate associates. This can be a little awkward if you are at the same level as your manager (yes it happens). Your manager's ability/willingness to advocate for you during these sessions is key. If the managers participating in these cross calibration sessions don't think highly of you, you're sunk...You need to be *very* aware of that in your daily interactions with other associates. One of the main criticisms of the performance management system is that it emphasizes individual performace more than team performance. Some steps have been taken to shift that, but too soon to judge the effectiveness of that change.

headline: A lot of potential but middle management stifles growth and innovation
pros: Great benefits, competitive salary, very intelligent colleagues and a great mission.
cons: Culture especially in IT is competitive and lacking strong leadership or accountability. Middle management in most cases doesn't truly understand how to deliver or what they need to do to motivate their employees. There are "lifers" who are in director and sr. director positions just trying to lay low and not rock the boat; they stifel potential and innovation.

headline: Positive
pros: Capital One cares about their employees and their customers. The work atmosphere is positive and they encourage continued career growth. Great benefits.
cons: Compensation is below average. Review process is poor and there are limited opportunities to advance. Raises were very minimal, even for a top performer.

headline: Taught me what I know
pros: Great benefits. I started working there in sales in 2008. When it was still ING DIRECT. B/c of that I not only had a great 401k  (with no waiting for a year like most companies now) but I was also one of the last lucky ducks to get in on a pension.
cons: After 5 years there, I still wasn't where I wanted to be and should've been in my career there. And I was going to train for my AML test thru them but when it became Capital one 360 a lot of options for employees went bye bye.

headline: Compliance and  Risk Mgmt
pros: Opportunity to participate, be heard, pro-active;  open work environment and open schedule;  driven and inspiring;  good people - great company culture
cons: constant press - frantic pace - deadlines

headline: Good choice for young professionals
pros: flexible work hours; fast promotions for college graduates
cons: frequent changes, re-org; not good for seasoned professionals; forced performance distribution

headline: Great
pros: Great healthcare, great management team, great culture
cons: Needs a better way to manage talent.

headline: Horrible
pros: Bonuses, locations, products, service, customers
cons: Old systems, micromanagement, gossip, unprofessionalism

headline: Terrible.
pros: Seemingly easy to get promoted.
cons: Condescending upper management, very sales focused.

headline: Difficult culture
pros: Capital One pays relatively well, but that is what keeps you there because it is hard to find similar compensation.
cons: There is no job stability; people get laid off routinely as the bank seeks reduce spend, but then they spend a lot of money on consultants to set their new direction.  Direction though changes every year.  The review process is not fair, and "calibrates" associates against other same level associates, even though they do not perform the same tasks.  At the end of the year, the review is always a negative surprise because even if you do what you are supposed to have done, and do it well, they always come back with "but you should have know to do something else...."

headline: Best company
pros: Work culture is top tier, I have never worked at a better company.  Great benefits and work/life balance
cons: There aren't any cons to working at capital one. They are by far the best employer.  I would recommend this company to anyone looking for a new career in financial services.

headline: Decent company to work for
pros: The work/life balance is reasonable. The benefits are pretty good.
cons: There isn't much opportunity for advancement, at least in the IT department (other departments seem to get way more promotions). Most high level positions are hired from external candidates. Managers don't provide any help on moving up in the company.

headline: Horrible management
pros: The people who work there are great for the most part. Credit card division is the best in the business.
cons: The retail bank within Capital One is horribly run top to bottom. It is a second class operation compared to others within the industry

headline: Great Experience
pros: Flexible work schedule.  Good benefits.  Good to average pay.
cons: Lots of layoff.  System for yearly evaluation needs work.  Lots of politics when it comes to growth within the company.

headline: Capital One is a great Company to work for!
pros: Great pay, benefits and incentives. Capital One truly cares about their employees and will go the extra mile to ensure that the voice of the employee is heard.
cons: No Cons to list at this time.

headline: Team makes all the difference
pros: I liked the fast pace and hard work required.   Pay was average, but bonus structure was good.   Benefits were average.    I liked my supervisor (Director-level), who was challenging to work for.  But he really appreciated my hard work.   We were a great team.
cons: Unfortunately, I was transferred after several years to a senior manager who was basically incompetent.   My team became very slow-moving, and it was painful to get anything done.   I looked for other positions internally, but HR is little or no help.

headline: A company going in the right direction
pros: great benefits, smart associates, wellness program
cons: work life balance is not there if you want to move forward

headline: Fraud Intake Coordinator
pros: Stable, reputable company with aggressive strategies
cons: High turnover, slow growth from within, areas of poor management

headline: Worked there when it was ING Direct.  Terrific place. Fast paced. Hopefully as Cap One it will get even better.
pros: You are made to see how your contribution matters. Performance reviews actually matter.
cons: Sometimes the work load could be insane, too many tedious meetings that added not a lot to the tasks being performed.

headline: Good place to work, not great
pros: Decent pay, great benefits, 401k, stock sharing, fun enviorment, hires within.
cons: 16 different programs to work with, QA and associates not on the same page, not fully organized.

headline: it was pretty okay benefits were great but the job pretty much wasn't so great
pros: benefits , the shift dif , the site itself is beautiful and the employees are great
cons: no room for advancement , the pay isn't that great and they  play favorites

headline: Great place to work
pros: good scope for work. Many domains give varied learning opportunities.
cons: Since I worked as a vendor, there were certain job related concerns.

headline: Small Business Portfolio Manager
pros: Good Pay and Great benefits
cons: High work volume was high and at times hard to keep up with. Frequent lay offs for performing employees.

headline: Awesome Place!
pros: GREAT benefits! 5 weeks of PTO up front every year, monthly bonus, monthly prize giveaways, upper management cares about employees
cons: frontline management is overworked and sometimes spills over onto employees.

headline: Overall good company to work for
pros: Benefits start day 1, hours of operation
cons: low work/life balance for managers and up, not much internal opportunity, hard to move from retail to other divisions

headline: great experience work as contractor there. coworkers are nice and nice food discount on lunch
pros:
work flexibility
discount on food
next to high way
neat work environment
cons:
contract salary make less
not access to fitness center

headline: My experience was not the best working for this company.
pros: You have the opportunity to learn alot about the business of banking.
cons: A major challenge is having to get 8 closed referrals per month.

headline: sr. loan admin coordinator
pros: great benefits, great pay, great people
cons: internal posting is hard. promoting culture outside.

headline: Great Company, Limited Movement
pros: Compensation, Benefits, Work/Family Balance, PTO, culture of company, everything..... is amazing.
cons:
Once you are accept a position (ie. I am in the call center line of business in an hourly position) you will not be able to make more than 2 pay grade jumps (even if you are qualified fully for a salaried position in another line of business ie. IT). 

My advice: apply for what you plan on doing in the long run, this is an easy company to move around in (as long as you are in the same pay grade), but if you plan to get your foot in the door with an hourly position just to move to salaried because you are finishing your degree in a year, think again. You will have to leave and come back to Capital One to be taken seriously, just as I am in the process of doing. 

Some call center departments are being run to the ground, and floor managers don't always have best interest of their people at hand.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Incredible work life balance. Able to complete all of my work and spend a lot of time with my family. Amazing training. Company really takes care of you
cons: Nothing to complain about. Amazing company

headline: Unorganized Organization
pros: Good benefits. Able to take time off as needed for sick kids, dr. appts., etc.
cons: Constantly undergoing re-organization. Lately, lots of 'budget cuts' as well, mainly laying off more senior workers to make room for 20-somethings. Cuts costs and raises the stock price. But very bad for morale.

headline: Fantastic Company for Young People
pros: Capital One's a great place to work right out of college. They give tons of training, they have wonderful development programs, and an awesome culture. I've never had any real trouble with anything here.
cons: Like most large companies, there are some wait times for things like access to software, etc, but these are not a big factor in the long run.

headline: Customer Service
pros: Ok Pay, Great Incentives, Great Benefits
cons: Stressful Job, Always Changing, Work at home is the worst

headline: Awesome Experience
pros: Capital One cares about their associates and customers very much. This company truly listens and improves where needed in all areas.
cons: Great  company values that you live by each and every day, awesome work-life balance.

headline: Progressive and technology focused company
pros: Company culture is very forward thinking and extremely technology focused, especially for a financial institution. Very open communication structure – senior leadership listens to employee concerns and ways to improve culture not only internally but for customers as well. Seem eager to promote development of minorities as a leading initiative.
cons: Burnout seems to occur often, but may depend on department/job role

headline: Great company
pros: Benefits.  Vacation. Opportunity to grow.
cons: Low salary for internal promotion

headline: Great company, lots of opportunity
pros: Feels entrepreneurial given size, lots of on the job perks, smart/humble coworkers, competitive compensation
cons: Changes are slow to implement, but that is to be expected given the scale

headline: Very good company to work for. Company really lives the Excellence and Do the right thing policy. Time off and benefits
pros: Great Company. Great Culture; very collaborative and entrepreneurial. A lot of cross training. Time off and Benefits are really good and make the place work it. Solid leadership, especially the Canada office.
cons: It is difficult to move from a Data Analyst to a Business Analyst. That is probably the only issue

headline: Capital One, changing careers for worse
pros: Compensation is good, and the company has a lot of great values on paper. Unfortunately, very little follow through on that
cons: I worked as a senior business analyst and have to say I was tremendously disappointment with the development opportunities, culture, and overall experience. If you are looking into the analytics department, ask about their turnover.  If they are honest, it's above 30% because they are incapable of developing talent and provide a horrible work life balance

headline: It can become very mundane.
pros: The company has great values and is making an effort to provide better customer service in the branches.
cons: Customer support  isn't very helpful wit customer issues.

headline: Good location, decent pay
pros: Good for college or graduate new hires. Training well structured. Diversified work culture, Many locations to choose.
cons: Slow salary increase for low to middle level people. Work life balance is dependent on the team and personnel structure.

headline: Capital One loves its Associates
pros: Good pay; Business casual environment; Innovative
cons: Promotions & vacancies may be difficult to come by, even if highly qualified.

headline: QA Manager
pros: Enjoyed working with my peers and customers. There was a lot of constant change, but that made the work interesting.
cons: Lots of change made it hard to keep track of the 'current process' and also wasted time. Several different departments  with unclear names / descriptions. This made ti challenging to understand who they were or what they represented at times.

headline: Bank Teller
pros: Great introduction to the retail banking industry.
cons: The job was too repetitive.

headline: It was job stability
pros: Benefits and time off were great
cons: No room for advancement unless you know someone.

headline: Good Benefits, but Leadership needs help
pros:
Good Benefits.
Great work life balance.
The company is trending to become a leader in the industry in terms of it's use of technology.
cons: Leadership in many key roles tends to stay for 6 months and then moves on to new roles, or is replaced.  This leads to initiatives never getting off the ground, or never being completed.

headline: Great overall culture, but not immune from some negative pockets
pros:
Development Programs
Especially the Analyst Development Program
4 weeks of 'training' (more like summer camp for business geeks) over a year allow friendships and networks to develop
Those running the program are very receptive to feedback and actively seek it out

The company in general is very good to its main office employees (not so much contractors, call center workers etc)
Quarterly fun days are great team-building and general fun
Cheap Gym
Multiple subsidized cafeterias
on-site clinic
on-site bank (which should really be expected given that they're a bank)
free career counseling
generous severance forewarning and pay
free job search services after termination
cons:
Leadership of my customer department
Would often jump to conclusions before getting data (the company is actively against that sort of thinking, but it happened)
Officially rewards the value of work produced over effort put into it, but in reality a bigger emphasis on looking like you're working hard

headline: Solid Company
pros: Excellent benefits and work environment.
cons: Lack of upward mobility unless  you relocate.

headline: this is an awesome company to work for
pros: culture, work life balance etc
cons: nothing i can complain about

headline: Sr. Business Analyst
pros:
-ownership of work
-good benefits
-fun, young culture
cons: -slower growth at middle management level

headline: Great Company to work fo!
pros:
Benefits are very fair and inexpensive
Support from the branches is fantastic
Management is not micromanaging
Salary is fair
Friendly staff
Wellness Center is a huge benefit early hours and spin classes
Work life Balance is vital for my twin boys
cons:
Long hours
Commute
No where to move up
stresful
Direct Manager

headline: Customer Service
pros: They have great benefits. The incentives are great. Order food, mostly pizza, but I love pizza so that's fine with me lol
cons: Shows a lot of favoritism!!! They put the wrong people in training or nesting positions. If you don't kiss *** then u will not get picked for anything no matter how much you know or how long you been there. QA is too over the top with grading, they nitpick over everything on one call, grading is entirely too strict. They update policies and procedures almost everyday ( who does that)On almost every call you have to check policies and procedures to make sure nothing has changed which takes too much extra time. The nerve of them putting a limit on our talk time with all this extra unecessary things they want us to do while the customer is on the line. Capital One really needs to get it together, that's more than likely why they have a high turnover rate, no one I began training with is there anymore.

headline: Happy to leave
pros:
Great benefits
Good brand
Fast paced environment
cons:
Bad calibration. People with wrong behavior get promoted
Too much change with no proper planning
Bad behavior is celebrated. You may not be appreciated for good work for any goof up will be used against u. Don't end up in legacy hsbc departments which has bad management and people with huge egos. Don't expect capital one culture there. HR is non existent and I seriously don't understand why they are paid.

headline: Great company. Lots of learning oppotunities
pros: Great Culture. Good place to develop professionally.
cons: Performance management process is still not a fit for the culture.

headline: Associate Experience
pros: Great benefits including on site fitness center, doctor's office, and cafeteria.  Facilities are modern and new.  Significant training information available with Capital One University.
cons: High production environment makes it difficult to find time for training and developing skills.  Facilities are well utilized and congested.  Compensation in some areas is well below market.

headline: n/a
pros: Good benefits and good work environment.
cons: Bad work like balance and very political

headline: Choose better management
pros: The job was easy and the hours were ok.  They feed you alot. Good security.
cons: Irving location needs better management, high turn over rate.

headline: Program Manager
pros:
They tend to pride themselves as having a high bar to get in but some of the Senior Management (Director +) are a joke and how they got to that level is a suprise to most people. 

Nice Gym
Like the idea of being able to have a high concentration within one campus
Close to lots of restaurants
cons:
There is so much politics it is ridiculous in order to move up. Promotions are not based on results but rather being best buddy with manager and there is so much instability with management if you happen to get momentum you will have a new manager that will not have any history on you. 

Compensation is far below the market in the same industry for similar job. A lot of focus on levels as a way to get things pushed. 

Claim to be about front line people engagement, however only a few areas actually live this and rest is lip service. 

Exodus of people close to happening like did before when people left to competition. Playing favorites is common here: a few select few (not actually any better) will get promoted every year to 2 years, the rest will never move up and those moving up will give foolish reasons why others shouldn't.

headline: Great place to learn and grow as a business analyst
pros:
Super office and work culture, good benefits and high emphasis on recognition.
Also has good opportunities for training and learning new skills.
cons: Compensation could easily be better, especially considering the critical wok that business analysts/strategy folks do here. Relatively flat organization with a plateauing growth also means promotion and growth opportunities may be relatively low.

headline: Good teller experience
pros: It pays more starting out then other banks. Greats benefits .if you are full time you start earning paid vacations after 3 months. They offer  a lot of difference incentives.
cons: Its not easy to get promoted, they are very aggressive with referrals, you have to become  a robot when talking to customers.

headline: I promise the calibration will screw you
pros:
AMAZING benefits
AMAZING work life balance
AMAZINGLY GREAT education and learning opportunities
cons:
1 You can perform like superman but unless you work at HQ in Virginia you will get shafted on your bonus and performance.

2 The HSBC acquisition has made many leave

3 tooooo many reorgs

headline: Capital One knows that they are asking you to do a demanding job.
pros:
They actually try to make you feel welcome when you become employed. They care about your well being and do a lot to make sure that even when you are being screamed at by customers that you have outlets to be okay. 
They feed you all the time.
They make sure that morale is up with all of the competitions and prizes they can give you.
cons: Customers are absolutely terrible and you cannot defend yourself in anyway. They are the worst part of the job.  I do not know how to explain how bad the card holders are, especially as a supervisor in the Fraud Department.

headline: Disputes Correspondence
pros: Great Company, Great Pay, Flexible
cons: was cutting jobs and sending out of us

headline: Revolving Door
pros: Good benefits, flexible work schedule, ability to work from home depending on department, lots of energy in the company, CEO seems open and honest
cons: Constant re-orgs so people get hired then laid off.  Very difficult to move around to other areas or to get promoted.  Growing too big, too fast.  No respect for legacy talent or "older" employees.  There is a sense of age-ism.  Raises are terrible.  Not even keeping up with cost of living.  Different departments operate very differently than others as far as the culture and values.  Very inconsistent treatment

headline: capital one interview
pros: The benefits are great there and the working culture is friendly. Capital One does try to brunt the pain of the high deductible by offering free health clinics on site at major locations
cons: It always have big changes in the recent years. So, if you are willing to be static for a long time, it is not a good place to go.

headline: Excellent place to work, focused on employees
pros:
Work / Life Balance
Flexibility
Benefits (401K, PTO, etc.)
Innovative environment
cons: Rapid Change,  you need to be agile

headline: Retail Bank Review
pros: Good brand name, large market presence, good software, good salary with compared to other major banks.
cons: No West Coast presence, fewer states than other major banks  which limits opportunity for relocation.

headline: Run
pros: The company is successful at keeping people in debt rather than working with customers to try and help manage their debt.
cons: HR doesn't exist, no transparency, benefits are horrible, misleading advertising about committment to diversity, political and very white.  Company values are not aligned with the current economic climate.  The people are petty and lazy.  This is not a proactive company, it is a reactive company.

headline: A bank that actually works to change the status quo.
pros: You truly feel valued working at Capital One. The culture is inviting, encouraging and progressive. If someone has an idea, it is implemented and acted upon. When working directly with customers, you feel empowered to do the right thing regardless of what it'll cost the company.
cons: The benefits are great but compensation isn't competitive. I would never have left the company if I could afford it.

headline: Worst decision in my professional career
pros: Great benefits, 401k and vacation options.  The corporate heads have a great vision & great ideas.
cons:
No appreciation for employees, the vision gets lost the further down the chain you go.  There are way too many politics at play.  They do not value long time employees.  I've seen employees who have been with the company for 40+ years transferred to another location and then the branch closes & the employee laid off.  They lay off employees when they close a location,  employees are encouraged to apply internally, but are rarely hired.  Capital One is looking to going "digital" so they want very few branches, so that mean very few employees, so if you want a company for the long haul, avoid here!  They make big promises to get you on board and then there is no follow thru.  In my 4 years, I've seen so much turnover, everyone below the CEO to me has changed.  I've had 5 different managers in less than 4 years.  
I've seen older employees pressured and pushed out and managers advised to push older people out In favor of younger employees.  

There is very little career growth.  Every person above me who was hired the past 4 years was external and very few people promoted, the ones who have been promoted have been "in" with leadership.

headline: One of the best companies I have ever worked for.
pros:
Great Work/Life Balance
Great office and location
Laid-back but professional environment
Awesome Benefits
cons:
Pay is not very good
Sometimes it's about who you know and not what you can do that allows you to move up in the company
Training can be improved

headline: Good.
pros: benefits are good.  inherent value system is good
cons: needs to get better at Job recognition

headline: Youth over experience
pros: Generous benefit package, In-house learning opportunities, various cultures, forward thinking
cons: Promotes youth over experience, Not all teams open to remote teamwork

headline: Good place to start a career
pros: Great campus environment if you're fortunate to work in VA.  Other facilities are sketchy
cons: I find it ironic that the company always say's "We only hire the best an brightest" BUT they only pay market average.

headline: repetitive
pros: money, peers, team meetings, outings.
cons: Theyve somehow managed to reduce the incentive each year with a new call grading scale. every year. other than that, the only con left are the customers. at least the rude ones anyway.

headline: Ups and Downs
pros: Good Pay, Good benefits, Depending on your job good job flexibility
cons: Constant policy changes as it relates to customer service, associates are more knowledgeable than the supposed "leadership," difficult to move up

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Progressive, great work-life balance.  Competitive pay, open friendly environment.
cons: Beginning my role was a difficult transition.  I had worked in more traditional, old school environments.  Once I adjusted, it became the best place I ever worked.

headline: Good as a start
pros: good management, highly skilled at delivering
cons: they could be better at listening to new ideas

headline: Account Associate
pros: Great benefits, and good company cultures
cons: office policies and hard to grow

headline: It is a good company to work for.
pros: Capital One provides a good salary and benefits.  It was a good company to work for with competitive pay.
cons: I cannot think of any cons to working at Capital One. It was a good compny to work for.

headline: Ok
pros: Benefits, Employee activities, dependent care
cons:
Lack of communication
Unit managers are unprofessional
Lack of career advancement

headline: Overall great company.  Progressive, fast-paced
pros: company values, compensation & benefits, smart people and great culture
cons: work-life balance, people put in people manager positions that do not have that skill set

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great work life balance in corporate. CEO values associates opinion in order make the company one of the best places to work.
cons: People on the same position salary variation is tooooo vast. E.g. same role same location 30k difference in salary

headline: Principal Fraud Investigator
pros: great work environment, very employee friendly
cons: unstable job situation, layoffs all over

headline: Great benefits
pros: Great benefits, and a equal opportunity work place. Doesn't have a lot of negativity like most call centers, everyone is like family working here.
cons: Working here and having medical issues or children is a down fall due to there attendance policies even if you have a note

headline: Excellent place
pros: Great benefits, great work family balance, flexible schedule
cons: Very difficult promotion process, inconsistent performance management

headline: Hiring Proces Has Disparate Impact and Lack of Diversity in Senior Management and Board
pros: Great Benefits, On-Site Wellness Center, Capital One University
cons: Ratings process is very political rather than merit based and Board of Directors/Executive Management is predominately white male. This lack of diversity is disappointing for a company that offers sub-prime products targeted to minorities.  Company believes it hires the best and the brightest because of its extensive hiring tests; however, that is not the case. Instead, it hires people who don't necessarily have the appropriate experience but are good test takers.

headline: Account Manger
pros: Good environment. Good management. Opportunities to move up. Bonus w pay. Vary of hours and great benefits.
cons: Customers can be very rude and hard to deal with. Meetings get goofy and seem kindergarten at times.

headline: A great experience
pros: Great benefits at this company
cons: Advancement is hard to come by

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
* Work-life balance
* Smart People
* Room to move
cons:
* Somewhat stagnant management
* Less easy to move around now

headline: Overall excellent until massive disruption of work life balance
pros: Great benefits health & education. Great work at home opportunities.  Nice pay increase due to meeting industry standards.
cons: A week after the "you deserve this" increase and submitting required vacation submissions for first half 2015, they announced we would be forfeiting our schedules and would be required to bid on new ones that would not be disclosed until mid January.  Required days of Monday, Friday, And one weekend day would ensure no opportunity of consecutive days off that included weekend without using vacation hours. Shifts also for later in the day.  Therefore rendering just completed vacation bid useless and upending work life balance for the majority involved.  Disrupting class schedules for college students who've been registered and paid for and with results not being available til mid January, unable to make timely adjustments in class schedule. Happy holidays.  As an employee, the need for weekend coverage is understood and would be easily implemented.  The complete upending of our personal/family lives at short notice does not coincide with their mission statement "do what's right" but is an unfortunate reminder of our place in the organization.  When questioned as to why the added measure of no concurrent day off that would include one weekend day beyond the new work hours and weekend the answer was that most companies would not even warn us.  I think most LARGE companies would and may have taken, possibly, a more measured approach.

headline: good company
pros: fun to work at, work-life balance, compensation, company values. This is a fortune 500 company that treats their employees well.  Fun to work at.
cons: work loads can be excessive at times. I feel like I am lost in the sea of employees. The commute sucks but at least sometimes I get to work from home.  Mostly good things and the bad things are typical at most companies.

headline: Work life balance
pros: Work is project-based. You have good work life balance although sometimes some overtime.
cons: The culture is Not very aggressive

headline: Heading in the Right Direction
pros: The company is moving in the right direction. For a while, I was worried about discussed culture change being just talk, but the investments in fully moving into modern technology and design have been profound. I expect the company to be a lead player in financial services technology in less than 3 years.
cons:
Still getting over some of its old bureaucratic ways. Really depends on the department you're in. The more traditional, legacy business units have a much longer way to go in terms of modern methods of work. I'm lucky enough to work in one of the newer organizations, where the status quo is constantly being challenged and we're pushing in the right direction.

Could run a little lighter. Seems like there are plenty of "lifers" that are content to push paper vs. really come in everyday and make change. The company could easily cut that workforce and notice little to no loss in productivity.

headline: Good Company

headline: Associates and Contractors
pros: Flexible work schedules and opportunities to learn and contribute to the overall success of Capital One.
cons:
About 75% of employees are contractors with low wages remaining stagnant for the past 20 years and no benefits.  If there are benefits offered by the 20 to 35 agencies, the deductibles are prohibitively too high and having such benefits will immediately make your salary equivalent to minimum wages.

There is high job turnover as employees have the good fortune to find employment elsewhere that does have competitive living wages rather than subsistence wages.

headline: A great place to start a career in banking
pros:
A fairly new bank which was established after the financial crisis of 2008, so they are growing at a fast and healthy paced without worrying about paying hefty penalties as other banks continue to do do for their mishandling of bad mortgage investments.  I worked in the branch and I had left before the bank was launching a new training program and beginning to look after their employees by providing them more promotions and opportunities to move up. 

The benefits are great, especially their 401K and tuition reimbursement program.
cons:
Your experience in the branch will mostly depend on who you have as a manager.  I'd say most of them are talented, dedicated individuals, willing to work as hard as their subordinates.  But like in any other company, there are a few who could make your days miserable and contribute little to the success of the company.  All they do is sit behind their desks talking to friends and barking orders, instead of creating a plan to get more business.  

What I also noticed during time at the bank is that it's easier to get a job in the corporate office if you apply as an external candidate than if you are an internal candidate (branch employee).  You could be a branch employee for several years, but even then, the recruiters would pass up your application. Hopefully that has changed.

headline: GREAT
pros: Easy to grow within the company, great benefits, great work environment.
cons: Very strict policy, nothing else to say

headline: They don't care about you
pros:
Decent pay
Opportunity for incentives
Opportunity to leave early if available
cons:
Unreasonable 
Difficult standards

headline: Good Company
pros: Capital One is fast for a bank, on the cutting edge and an industry leader in analytics.  The company has been using data before 'big data' was a buzzword.  Training is great for college new hires in the Analyst Development Program
cons: After acquiring banks, has started to slow down a bit.  Like most businesses, many of the processes are known through tribal knowledge only.

headline: Capital One is the Worst Company I ever worked for
pros:
The benefits are very good.     The heath insurance and 401k options are better than average.
In many departments, they allow people to work from home when needed.
cons:
1.  There is no job security and no stability in management,
2.  There is always a large amount of staff turnover.
3.   They encourage people to move around from one position to another almost every year.
4.   If you stay in one position more than 2 years, you will be considered stale and a candidate for their redeployment process which really is another term for layoff.
5.   In the banking side of the company, they rely 100% on vendors to do all of the IT processing and changes.   They even hire contractors to do the unit and system testing.
6.  There is very little in depth knowledge at Capital One about how the  IT system that is used for their retail banking operations works   
7.  Every new hire must pass a 'personality test'.    This leads to an environment where everyone is alike and very boring.
8.  Since all of the day to day operations work is outsourced to vendors, the Capital One employees really just work on meaningless task to please the directors.    Nobody below 
executive management does any 'real' work.
9.  The review process is an example of HR gone to the extreme - it takes up a ton of time for both the employees and managers .
10. If you have any morals and try to treat others as you would have them treat you, you won't survive at Capital One.

11.  The environment for the day to day non executive management staff is a model of survival
of the fittest, but since most of the work is outsourced to VENDORS, it is more like game of
survival.

12.  You job becomes navigating the review process and changing positions quick enough to keep on keeping on.

13.  The executive management team makes very good decisions on what banks and credit card companies to purchase.   But they have no idea on how to run the internals of daily business.

14.  Everyone who worked with me at Capital One had the same point of view as I did.

15.  If you want a career at Capital One, you should be prepared to step on people and basically your main task will be to navigate through the yearly performance review process so that you survive another year.

headline: Customer service
pros: Friendly nice environment management is ok
cons: Their pay scale is pretty low. If they paid alittle more per hour the job would be fantastic.

headline: Capital One Summary
pros: Positive, diverse work environment; time off is valued and respected; flexible remote work policy.
cons: Opaque and loosely-defined advancement policy. Communication disconnect between management and front-line employees. Management purports to seek honest dialogue, but can turn hostile when negative feedback is provided.

headline: Good Company for new graduates
pros: I worked here for a number of years, end enjoyed my experience. My colleagues were great and management was very helpful in fostering a good work environment. There are opportunities for growth, you just have to put in the work and show interest. Overall, I enjoyed my tenure at this company.
cons: Starting salaries were lower than expected, but there are performance bonuses.

headline: Horribly Political Environment.
pros: Salary and benefits were very strong and exceed anything I had experienced elsewhere especially with regard the medical premiums which were fantastic.
cons:
The induction to the company speaks to the core values and competencies.  The CEO of the company also reinforces these aspects.  Yet sadly those messages and behaviors are completely lost once in the business, especially at the SVP level down, where I mainly interacted.  

It is a completely political environment no matter what the location, and I found more weak SVP's and VP's in COF than I have ever seen or would have believed.  Owing to their weakness they live in the blame culture but do this in deceptive ways, i.e. make emotive statements of unhappiness, but have no evidence to back it up.  However the damage is done as the other weak line management would react to the statement and not be strong enough to stand up and ask for proof.  Hence most of the time is either fire fighting, or trying to politically CYA or deflect these statements without substance.  Trouble is it is endemic within their organization and will take  a significant clear out to change things.

I tired of incorrect statements constantly being made to me of my staff and any attempt to not act in the way the rest of the company, i.e. demand proof, is met with accusations that you are not a team player and didn't I know that if an SVP expressed their concern at person X, they didn't need proof, their comment was more than enough.... Serious.

Coupled with this, sadly their promotion system is so convoluted and without credibility is is actually causing great people to leave, rather than retaining the talent.  They run a system know as cross calibration, where all line managers from a team sit together and discuss every member of staff and rank them accordingly.  Trouble is how do you compare a lawyer with a financier?  Much less if I want my team members to be ranked at X then I need to argue down all of my peers until I 'get my way'.  A horribly amateurish and unprofessional way to determine pay raises, bonus and promotions, which in themselves take at least 12 months to achieve from an exceptional rating. Needless to say many many great people got fed up of this and would leave, meaning the attrition rate was shamefully high and the loss was of the top caliber people.

Needless to say after 18 months I found an alternative role outside of the company in a culture much more respectful and transparent.

headline: Good company for career growth
pros: Capital One offers a wide variety of career paths with the ability to move around internally.  The work-life balance is good with standard hours from 8-5, although some jobs require more than that.
cons: There is a high degree of focus on career improvement within the company leading to a very competitive promotion process.  Its not uncommon for people to sing their own praises in an effort to get promoted.

headline: Great place to work for driven people
pros: Ability to work from home, benefits, work-life balance, compensation, and a lot of opportunities to learn and grow.
cons: Very difficult to overcome lower performance ratings if you fall in the lower 10-15%.  Demands a lot from associates to change and adapt without training.  Roles are no longer well defined so career pathing and moving up the corporate ladder have become far more difficult.

headline: Great Company, Minimal Growth Opportunities
pros: Great employee benefits, flexible work schedules (depending on the position), bright open work environment and extensive development opportunities via Capital One's internal Capital One University.
cons: Capital One is constantly changing the organizational structure which can leave many employees either moving around ALOT, or pushed out of a job. I was lucky during many of the changes because I was valuable to the business in my role, however the constant changes leave you looking over your shoulder. The environment is also very difficult to advance in. I chose to leave after applying for a role above my "title", got offered the position, however was advised by HR that due to company policy I would have to accept the new position laterally with no pay increase or title change. I had enough so I went somewhere else to get my promotion.

The political games have increased as more people means more competition, making it less about your work and more about how well you can sell it.  Lots of growth as more work has been sourced back in-house, meaning at some point there will be the mass exodus again.

headline: Excellent place to work. Innovative culture & benefits are second to none.
pros: Live our mission statement & values. Ethical company. Incentive-based programs to promote healthy lifestyle like discounts on healthy food at cafés on campus, doctor/pharmacy onsite, gym onsite with personal trainers at no extra cost, beautiful campus & building facilities,  not bureaucratic at all. Access to senior & executive leaders so even though we're large,  we all feel like we know Rich & our top-of-the-house crew.
cons: Benefit package is so amazing so compensation can feel a bit on the middle to low end of indusrty scale - but where else do you get 3-4 weeks vacation your first year and access to so many on campus amenities?

Political, beaucratic, and money hungry.  They don't like older employees but want their deposits.  The perks don't make up for the stress and aggravation they put employees through.

headline: Work environment

headline: Salary and Benefits are Great. Performance Management Process is not.
pros: You are exposed to some of the most intelligent, dedicated professionals on the planet. Hours can be flexible depending on what department you are in and working from home is an accepted practice in most professional roles. The company is very active in the community and sponsors volunteer events regularly for associates to participate in. The salary and benefits package is competitive. Taking on new challenges is encouraged and once you have been in your role for a year you can post for any available roles at your level.
cons: There are reorgs frequently. There is no rhyme or reason to the cadence with which they will shake up your work life, job or reporting relationship. In some cases these reorgs result in folks losing their jobs. Also, coming to work every day and doing your assigned job is not enough to be successful. Going above and beyond is the minimum standard. Be prepared to take on more and work outside of your role if you expect to keep your career with this company. The performance management process is the most convoluted I have ever seen. You are pitted against people at your same level within your department and your manager has to go into a cage match twice a year to fight for your ranking. I have never had a problem navigating the process. It is just something to be aware of before you sign on.

headline: Good work/life balance

cons: The compensation is below market.

headline: Loved it.  Great benefits.

cons: Right now,  under staffing is an issue and it can be stressful at times.

headline: Smart people, nimble org but limited growth for non-superstars (80% of people)
pros:
Very smart high calibre people to work with, at all levels in the company. CEO is a true visionary. 

Excellent work/office amenities and location flexibility. 

Nimble and high paced vs. traditional big banks, so quicker decision making and relatively less red tape. 

Logic and data driven thinking, resulting in rigorous strategies and decisions. This DNA runs across all levels (at least in credit card division). 

Focus on people development and training. Good internal training curriculums.
cons:
Career advancement dependent heavily on your manager and his manager. Perceptions matter much much more than your actual results. If you don't have a god father backing you at xcals you can't get promoted or get best ratings. 

Management shows much bias to develop and promote superstars (identified as top 10 pc), they will get all meaty projects even when other qualified people exist. It's a vicious cycle. Unless you are superstar you will stagnate at mgr/sr.mgr levels and get frustrated. 

Pay is below par at most levels below sr.director+, so you will see more attrition at junior levels and almost no voluntary attrition at vp+ levels.

Very easy
Compensation is fair
company values are excellent

Too easy

Sometimes feel unprofessional

headline: It's ok

headline: Very poor management of service levels and a culture of shaming
pros: Its easy to get hired on at the COAF call center near Tulsa Oklahoma and the insurance is good.
cons:
The COAF management cant figure out how to manage service levels in the customer care call center. 
And there is a strange culture of shaming that they think drives performance. Every employees individual statistics are posted on boards around the Tulsa call center. The poor performers are humiliated and shamed because their metrics are highlighted in red. The young generally uneducated managers that COAF hires think this practice drives better performance but all it does is demoralize employees. Even the best employees have bad months and their hard work is rewarded with shaming. It is very sad that such a large organization has such a basic lack of understanding of how to motivate and drive better performance.

headline: Excellent work environment, interesting people, many good challenges

cons: Changing review structure and no ability to change to part-time.  I left due to family commitments.  I would have liked to have continued part-time, but that was not available.

headline: Great face lift to site overall, compensation for working hard. Not so good.
pros: On site gym and cafeteria
cons: When capital one acquired HSBC in May 2012, everything changed for the better, especially with the $10 Million face lift the call center got, however the company failed to budget for annual pay raises! From May 2012- Sept 2014 (under Capital One's management), I received a total of $.35 raise. This was after 3 years of service! Then when inquiring why we weren't brought up to Capital One pay scale for same position withing the company elsewhere, we were advised it was to keep benefit cost down!  When your working full time and paying $600 per month for on-site daycare and $500 for a family of 5 to have medical benefits, this smaller hourly wage just wouldn't allow ends to meet financial, which ultimately forced me to quit my job.

headline: Poor Culture

headline: Would not return
pros: Given five promotions in six years for work above and beyond. Found anyone wanting promotion had to press the flesh with the right people and work the politics. Hard work and awards alone weren't enough. Leadership was sometimes lacking. I went four months on one team and we did not have a manager in that time. Team was eventually absorbed into other groups. Corporate perks that can be used in the community are great, if you can afford them.
cons:
Not family friendly, despite what you hear. I was written up and nearly fired for missing one day to bury a family member. Missed one day of work and immediately let my manager know and returned with an obituary. Nearly fired again when child hospitalized for serious illness. Shared news immediately with my then boss and he threatened to fire me, as my child was struggling for life in the PICU. 
Company values performance more than anything else and nobody in leadership wants to hear about problems or issues. Many colleagues came to me almost daily for answers that should've come from managers.

headline: Great experience good pay and OK benefits.
pros: Overtime easy monthly bonus easy to move up
cons: Hr department sucks do not do there job before hiring someone then fire them 7 months down the line because they didn't there job.

headline: Analyst
pros:
Work life balance
Work environment
Talented co workers
Compensation
cons:
Reporting work mainly
Poor job rotation scheme

headline: Good Company
pros: Great values and great management
cons: The push to do good on surveys

headline: Good place to start your career
pros:
ADP is great way to meet new people, gain skills, and learn about the business
Employees are the most important part of the company
Work life balance is fantastic
People are very bright, very credentialed (MBA’s, consulting exp, elite universities etc…)
Other employers understand the level of talent of ex-Capital One associates
cons:
The company isn’t growing anymore, but there is massive pressure from Wall St to grow profits
There are fewer dollars for investment in business ideas or personal growth
Perpetual reorganizations; expect to get moved every 6-12 months (esp in Bank)
Projects take FOREVER to get done – get ready to sit in meetings to discuss planning a pre-planning meeting 
Annual review process is somewhere between ‘alright’ and ‘a mess’ 

Ultimately, your experience will be highly dependent on the specific team you are on. Some teams are growing quickly and have the support and visibility of senior leadership, others are not. Guess which type of team is more fun to be on.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great benefits, Family life, treated with respect.
cons: In the Mid Atlantic Market one of the challenges is the commute.

headline: Very satisfied
pros: World place emphasizes the company culture/values, very friendly employees, senior leadership is transparent with decision-making process and open to change to improve workflow
cons: training was a bit inconsistent but other more experienced associates were open to helping the newer ones. Can be stressful due to supervisors ensuring you have a full work load

headline: Get rewarded for working hard.
pros: Great benefits and the people that work the hardest are the ones that get promoted.
cons: So many different departments it is hard to decide which opportunity to go after next.

headline: Software Engineering Manager
pros: Great people from top to bottom!  Work environment is low stress with a great work-life balance.
cons: Culture of analytics can lead to very slow decision making process, with expectations that technologists can run extremely fast after spending 7 to 12 months slicing and dicing the data.

headline: It All Depends on Manager and Work Unit
pros: Very bright people to work with and very interesting work - if you are in the right place, and that seems to be getting harder to do according to my friends who still work at Cap One.
cons:
Career advancement highly dependent on your manager - they can make or break your career.  You will probably change managers frequently.  The 360 review process and dreaded "cross calibrations" make the review process more like getting into a college fraternity than properly assessing your performance.  You can easily get "blackballed" by a manager other than you own.  You will have to spend time on political tasks that advance your "brand identity" to as many managers as possible.  This, however, is a fact of life in the modern corporate environment at Cap One if you want to advance.

Cap One is now so top heavy in risk management and process management that it really is becoming "just like any other bank."  Additionally the work environment, at least at the West Creek campus, is like being in kindergarten where everyone sits around a big table to work.  Great if everyone is polite and considerate, but not so great for those who talk on their cell phones or hold conference calls on speakerphone.  Invest in a good pair of in the ear, noise cancelling headphones and bring your favorite play list with you to work.

headline: Humble opinion
pros: Tuition benefits, vacation days, retirement benefits are great for employees. Company also has great competitive products.
cons: There is no balance between work and personal life. It was always a hassle to request day offs. Employees works 6 days a week, at least in retail branches,. Company or at least my district terminated people left and right. I saw 7 people let go with in one year that I worked for the company. There is no sense of job security here. I felt as if managers are not interested in developing their employees or may be they are just not competent enough to know how to develop associate and employee retention is just not their concern. There was no Exit interview when I left.

headline: Finance Manager
pros: Bright, innovative team members and TONS of training opportunity and very good pay
cons: No work-life balance whatsoever.  Lots of movement in management positions leads to a lack of consistency and knowledge transfer.

headline: Analyst Track
pros:
Organized crime - well established program with progressive schedules of training, networking and calibrations
Competitive culture - surrounded by high caliber professionals, intellectually challenging and excellent career development for younger analysts
cons:
Legacy culture and bank culture clash that calls for constant reorganizations, turmoils and insecurity
Recently lost several key women leaders, persistent work life out of balance
Although not an investment bank, the number of hours and the amount of work feels like one except for the pay

headline: Lots of money for very little productivity ..stable? yes, innovative? no.
pros: Awesome SF design team, remote engineering team, and overall good people in the office.
cons:
Lack of leadership 
Lack of management 
Lack of resources 
in the wrong game (trying to out innovate the start ups while working with an old bank infrastructure)

headline: They think their a bank but not so sure that Senior Management agrees.  Focused on return from Credit Cards.
pros: Close to home. Salary was good. Former Chevy Chase employees are dedicated to their customers & customers are mostly loyal to the Bank.   Lots of branches & a great local ATM network.
cons:
For a company that prides itself on Technology the branch systems are antiquated.  Product line is weak.  When you sell a Real Estate secured product it will close in 8 to 12 weeks. Process for processing loans in Plano TX is ridiculous & Senior Management  did nothing to fix it.  I don't think anything happened but the addition of another layer of management. 

Keeps its Internet Bank separate but deceitfully tells customers it's OK for them to use branches. The only that works regularly is the Credit Card company. Very frustrating wasting the acquisition of several good banks.

headline: Great place to build a career.
pros: The company takes care of its people - competitive benefits, takes care of people who roles are eliminated, strong ethical people culture. There is a strong culture with talented people, collaborative atmosphere. The is consistent leadership with founder CEO, an inspiring mission, a progressive agenda and a lot of opportunity for career growth.
cons: The company and its various business units go through frequent reorganizations. This is generally for the right reasons to position the company strategically for the long term, but the frequency of change can be frustrating and inefficient. the company is going through growing pains as the it tries to reinvent itself as a technology company and digital leader. This leads to uncertainty about job function and what skills it will take to be successful here going forward.

headline: Capital One is a great place to work.....if you live in Richmond VA or Plano TX
pros: process oriented organization.  They say people are first but actions are contrary to those sentiments.  If you like constant change (reporting manager, teammates, schedule bids) than this is the job for you.
cons:
since i've been here so long the problem is that i compare everything to the way it use to be.  Which was much better.  Gone are the days of biannual incentive trips (all expense paid for you and a guest to Cancun, Jamaica, Cabo, etc...)

Gone are the 1000 + monthly bonus of a PT employee.

headline: Great experience working for this company.
pros: No weekends or holidays.  Nice facility that is clean.  The cafeteria has great food and the convenience and ATM are also available at the facility.  Got along great with co-workers and my supervisor.
cons: Changing policies that effect your job creating stress.

headline: Work culture in Capital One
pros: Best place to work,great work life balance
cons: Not very much challenging work

headline: It's a great company
pros: bonuses are great if you do your job well.
cons: getting promotion within will not get you a great enough pay.

headline: One of the Best Companies to work for
pros: Very flexible work timings, good leadership and very good career growth oppurtunities.
cons: Still working on development in latest technology stack

headline: Bank Manager
pros: Great benefits and work life balance
cons: The Company  mentality is changing.

headline: soul sucking
pros: The benefits are good.  Some locations have better perks than others.
cons: constant fire drills, long hours

headline: Get hired in the position you WANT because upward mobility is not what they promise...
pros: The benefits (health insurance, 401K, fitness center, on site cafeterias, fitness center, medical office...etc) are great with this company.  There are a lot of surveys and opportunites to give your opinion on the culture and management.
cons: There are very limited opportunities for mvoing between departments and roles.  From my experience the company would rather offer an open position to an external hire with No experience or training in the role versus take an average performer in another role within the company whom they have already invested in training and orienting to the culture.  There is very little mobility in this company outside of the top 5% in the prodution based roles.

headline: Political sans constantly shifting
pros: The company offers good pay, good bonuses and good benefits. There are gyms, cafeterias, medical clinics, and other benefits at some of the locations.
cons: The performance management system creates a dog-eat-dog culture...actually more like rats eating rats...even their young.  Instead of people working together to collaborate, they compete and work against each other.

headline: Great Company that allows associates to try new things and be engaged
pros: Salary, Benefits and Company Culture
cons: Reorganizations and moving to new systems

headline: Customer Service
pros: Training and opportunity for growth in current and new departments. Great managers with the knowledge offering support and suggestions for success.
cons: The goal quotas we were given to make seemed to get higher each month. The lack of promotions was also an issue for me. Switching departments was with intent for positive change and possible a promotion.

headline: Good first job, but bureaucratic climb to top
pros: Employees are treated well by management. Work/life balance is generally good in most groups. Great health care and savings benefits. Remote work flexibility is typically available. Vacation and holidays are respected.
cons: Slow climb to the top. Hard to stand out even as a high performer. Tenure is king versus performance in promotion decisioning. Often the reward to the hardest workers is gaining more responsibility without increase in pay.

headline: Customer Service Rep
pros: For the most their benefits were good. The start off pay was ok.
cons: High call volume. Not easy to move up.

headline: Operations Risk Management
pros: Capital One is an excellent financial services organization with a good reputation, great opportunity for growth, and a strong focus on employee satisfaction and happiness.
cons: The challenges of working at Capital One are similar to those at other major financial institutions in Corporate America, e.g. high expectations, corporate hierarchy, office politics, etc.

headline: Work at Home Agent
pros: Great atmosphere,  the management and staff work together and are all very much like family. The pay is great and work/life/family balance is awesome.
cons: I have to cons for Capital One

headline: The "Best Place To Work" in the UK
pros: Fantastic culture, top quality people, great working environment. You will trusted to deliver your tasks without being micro-managed and well rewarded for your efforts.
cons: Sometimes the environment can be quite high pressure. We are all expected work hard, but work-life balance is considered as very important so this should not continue for a long period of time.

headline: Run away!
pros: There weren't many pros about working here. The only ones I can list are paid time off/vacation, great company training, great coworkers, and decent medical benefits and 401k program.
cons: Everything else not listed above. Such as, management lack major communication skills, often times employees were forced to work over 40 hours a week but not paid for overtime because often time the amount of overtime allowed was exceeded. The location was horrible, huge branch with very few tellers and RB's to assist large crowds that frequently visited the branch. Very difficult to get time off because of the lack of employees hired (company preferred to overwork current employees rather than hire more).

headline: Great company
pros: Great co workers and management. Flexible and room for growth
cons: None evrything seemed fine for me

headline: Great Company, Great Values!
pros:
Great benefits 
Monthly Incentive 
5 weeks of PTO
Holiday Pay
Tuition Reimbursement 
Great work life balance
cons:
Decent base pay 
Limited growth opportunities 
constant changes

headline: Terrible communication of best practices.
pros: Pay is decent and the hours are easy to work with.
cons: Was hired as part time but because of how understaffed (because of firing and quitting they were ) I ended up working overtime many weeks.  The training was extensive and unneeded as the policies and best practices were polar opposites when actually in branches and they vary from branch to branch also (I know this because I was sent to different branches to cover from my first week at the job).  Many of the systems and programs we used in branch were also unavailable during the two weeks training so we had to just wing it when we got to our home branch.

headline: Poor management
pros: coworkers at best, some perks if you hit sales goals.
cons: Banking Center Managers will use and abuse you until they do not need you anymore. Management wants more than what they give back to employees. Managers would promise promotion to top tellers without any REAL intent to promote them to maximize production.  I've seen cases where employees are against being used and abused by management and are accused of not being "team players".

headline: Love it here
pros: Great company culture and benefits
cons: No cons that I can think of

headline: Capital One Bank District Mngr
pros: Good benefits, salary for most levels are competitive.
cons: Retail banking leaders are disconnected from branches. Very cut throat/micro managed. Big bank wanna-be.

headline: Capital One has been great and is an excellent place to start a career.
pros:
-Work Life Balance
-Company and people genuinely care about you having and enjoying a life outside of work
-Great benefits
-Managers care about your career development in addition to your performance
-Workout center and indoor basketball court (richmond)
cons: When its time for annual review and promotion considerations, you have to keep in mind that everyone is very analytical and smart, so its not always easy to be a rock-star. Still, managers do a good job of letting you know where you should work to improve/get promoted

headline: Good Place to Work at!!
pros: Great place to work!! Relaxed  very professional environment to work at.Great Work life Balance. Decent salary.
cons: HR team is not up to mark, Laid back.. Immigration team is very slow.Not much transparency.

headline: Technology Company
pros: Company is pro technology and tries to reinvent it self all the time
cons: Things keep changing constantly all the time

headline: Great work life balance!
pros: The flexibility is amazing - real opportunities to move up even in roles that are 100% remote.  Great on boarding program, really prepares you to understand how they do business and ingrains a real loyalty from day 1. Lots of internal mobility.
cons: An organization that thrives on change but without material change management efforts, which means that things change quickly, and often without taking the time to explain why.

headline: 4 years as a teller
pros: hours, benefits, company is awesome to work for. During sandy they gave us a bonus for the storm.
cons: none that come to mind

headline: Very rewarding satisfying and a great place to work. I enjoyed learning and I was excited about growing with the company
pros: Great company to work for. Great benefits and great training. Also I enjoyed the people I worked with.
cons: Some that were in management positions were not dedicated to the company and were not fair to each employee. This was not the companies fault . Just an employee that needed more training.

headline: Be on your toes
pros: Great co-workers, great peers
cons: Major lay offs, no job security

headline: Culture is Hit of Miss! Need better people managers
pros: Overall good culture. Nice work life balance.
cons: Limited opportunities if you are not in the right areas, easy to fall through the cracks, constant re-orgs do not promote stability or reliable utilization of skills.

headline: LOVE this company
pros: The staff did have some problems at first but once you have a great team that understands each other, you can achieve anything. Love the benefits, salary is really competitive compared to other banks, recognition within the district is also wonderful. Teller are regularly recognized for their hard work. If you want to be something, work hard and you will get there with this company. Extremely sad to be leaving this company.
cons: Provide more opportunities for tellers in the growth areas.

headline: Call Center Enviroment
pros: Very lay back and a fun place to work
cons: Not  alot of opportunties in the chesapeake site

headline: Funding Analyst
pros: Capital One had great incentive programs to help motivate funders to be more productive. If you like to work in an environment that strive on collaborate team work, this is a place for you.
cons: Although there were incentive programs for performance, sometimes the work load was unmanageable. High turn over as Capital One Auto Finance likes to hire contractors.

headline: Company offers good benefits to entice you into employment , then fires you when you start to earn too much.
pros: Good benefits and work Hours.  Location OK
cons: Absolutely NO Job security or loyalty to devoted employees

headline: Good growing company
pros: Good learning experience, recognition for accomplishments, they pay up to 5k for school. Innovative company and paid vacations (2 weeks per year) good retirement plan.
cons: After the first six months a little discouraging, feels like any other bank. Only 2 dollar raised when promoted within the company, unless you leave and come back. The medical insurances are the not best. You always end up paying when going to the doctor.

headline: Slow to advance
pros: work life balance, compensation, benefits
cons: favorites get promotions, poor training

headline: Overall positive, but more senior management needs to live by the same values as the general population.
pros: The Corporate culture and values
cons: Don't always live by these values.

headline: Culture is hit and miss
pros: Strong social responsibility, flexible work schedule and location
cons: Limited opportunities if you are not in the right areas, easy to fall through the cracks, constant re-orgs do not promote stability or reliable utilization of skills

headline: Great place to work!!
pros:
Good work-life balance, smart people...very flexible setup..
Interesting place to be right now with the space evolving so much now.
cons: Performance is monitored closely.. Layoffs, attrition etc..

headline: Senior Teller
pros: Great benefits even if your a part time employee, and depending on the branch your in your either going to get along with your co workers and be successful or your not.
cons: Tedious tasks. And low pay for the amount of work that you do. The company has become more focused on sales and less on customer service.

headline: Great
pros: Work environment, Work culture, staff/Peers
cons: Salary Negotiation is not very professional

headline: Great Company, Awful division-Specifically Atlanta Office
pros: There are absolutely no Pros!
