cons: Good ole boy network.  Unqualified managers.  Ineffective Senior management.  No room to advance. Low pay.  Low incentive.  Discrimination.  Prejudiced.  Extremely low office moral.  Ran like a slave ship.  Don't ever let your children get sick, because you'll have to bring them into work with you!

headline: Great place to work for working mothers
pros: benefits are great, the option to work remotely (flexible)
cons: growth in the finance side is a bit slow compared to the associates who work directly in the business

headline: Awesome company to work for
pros: Atmosphere, teamwork, work-life balance, culture, people
cons: Wish benefits were a little better if I had to choose a con

headline: Overall a great employer!
pros: Co-workers, decent salary and benefits
cons: As is with many large cororations, too many layers of management. Micro management in some areas.

headline: It was a great experience working at Capital One Bank
pros: good benefits and opportunity to advance your career
cons: Annual ratings are on manager discretion. No set guidelines to follow.

headline: Beware of biased Performance Evaluations!
pros: Good pay and benefits. Brand recognition. Nice facilities.
cons:
Bad rep for churning through employees. Firing the higher paid and refilling same positions with younger, lower paid professionals. 

Do not always walk the talk when it comes to their values. Their official and PR events certainly sell those values but behind the walls, in the confines of a department/team/group, it's a different story.

headline: Destroyed my career.
pros: Telecommuting.  They also took me to Austin.  That's it.
cons: Disorganization, frequent layoffs, pretentious attitude, culture of complacency makes it difficult to incentivize people to improve, tolerance and acceptance of mediocrity and intolerance toward those who want to bring about positive change.

headline: It all depends...
pros: The pay, if negotiated appropriately, is great! I adored the people that I worked with, even my direct managers(although were switched multiple times through the years). Loved the accrued PTO. Loved the engagement days that were for all the employees. Depending on your manager, you were often given opportunities to prove yourself if you wanted to take on more responsibility. There are leadership programs that are offered if you want to consider management. Peer coaching and observing is often encouraged.
cons: Just like any other corporate job, its all politics and "Who you know". Well qualified individuals would get looked over  for opportunities that were given to a friend/favorite of the one in charge. You are overworked to the point where SEVERAL individuals(including upper management) would go on leave or just depart the company. There are so many hands in the pot of taking charge that it becomes so disorganized & miscommunication is frequent. One individual is expected to wear the hats of 10 associates all because no one wants to hire additional people.

headline: Good company to work for.
pros: Very open, yet competitive setting. The company takes good care of its employees. Competitive pay, very flexible work schedule, great work-life balance, "opportunities" for growth and great location.
cons: Large company, so promotions are not easy to come by. The process is not consistent across the organization. Software Engineering jobs have higher pay than analyst jobs of the same job-level.

headline: Okay
pros: Good benefits and advancement possibilities
cons: too much emphasis on managers, lot of jockeying for position

headline: Capital One is a great company to work for.
pros: Flexible and collaborative environment. Easy to manage work/life balance. Amazing benefits and competitive pay.
cons: The company is focused on bringing technology to the customer by improving their remote banking and reaching customers that are not near a branch site, however internally they struggle with having teams or departments at different sites and don't focus on applying the same technology or remote team management to their employees.

headline: Great to Horrible
pros: There are no good reasons to work for this company.
cons: Hired back to back every 2 weeks, then laid off 400 employees soon after.  Before severance was given out, they fired half of those layoffs so they weren't entitled to severance.  In those cases, employees came to work then lined up to be fired and not allowed to gather their personal items from their desks.  Not even 20 steps to the lunchroom to gather their food.  Think twice about an employer who cares so little for their employees.

headline: Capital One has provided a great environment for me to develop professionally and to sharpen my technical skills.
pros:
Associates are encouraged to "Live the values" by volunteering in the community, helping others internally, and giving back to open source projects.

Capital One fosters technical development with ample growth opportunities and encouragement to take ownership of your own development.

The pay is very competitive. The benefits are comprehensive including very generous 401k automatic contribution and matching.
cons: It's challenging to "Live the values" by helping others and being selfless while also endorsing yourself to be competitive in cross-calibration for performance management.

headline: One of the best employers in Northern Virginia
pros: Capital One has an amazing culture where there is a lot of respect for its employees and there is a strong focus on collaboration. While most companies say that "our biggest asset are our people", Capital One actually means it. They strive to bring in the best people and have strong performance management processes aimed at helping people maximize their potential. Capital One offers lots of really interesting opportunities and also has great work/life balance.
cons: Capital One had rapid growth in the early years and as a result of its size and maturity the pace of growth has slowed down in recent years.

headline: Good pay, bureaucratic nightmare
pros:
- The pay is generally in the top 25% for the industry.

- They usually promote from within.
cons:
- The bureaucracy is far crazier than anything I've seen in any other company.  It can be very difficult to get through the red tape and get things done.  Half of the people who work here are there to prevent the other half from doing their jobs.

- They hire smart people, but most of them don't have any other experience.  So they only know the Capital One way of doing things.  They're convinced this is always the best way.

- High Potential Program.  There is an official "high potential" program they arbitrarily choose people and treat them differently.  This creates a bit of a self fulfilling prophecy, but more importantly breeds resentment.

- There is a weak approach to expense management.  As a result.  Most of the office is traveling at any given time even though they don't need to be.  People will habitually fly from Toronto to Richmond Virginia for a single short meeting.  People go on trips simply because they are young and like to travel.

- Some members of senior management are religious fundamentalists and it shows.

headline: Fraud Identity Coordinator
pros: Perks, benefits. Great place to work if you're fake and pretend to be satisfied with your current position and salary for the rest of your employment with them. Also, a great place to work if upper management is a family member since you're most likely to be promoted faster than anyone else that works harder.
cons: Promotions, personal growth, company values, ethics, employee morale. Management is directed as a bureaucracy. If you use FMLA you will be looked as lazy, and management will attempt to find patterns (using FMLA during the weekends) to insinuate that you're not being truthful. Salary increase. I received a 2.5% after being one of the top performers during 2012.

headline: Great Company to work for.
pros: The leadership teams cares for you. They believe in standing and delivering what is best for you and supporting you in your endavours. They offer opportunities to be flexilble and work with you and around your family.
cons: The job can be demanding with some un-expected exceptations. Training classes offered for many of the programs, may require trave

headline: Easy to get hired with good pay but you are only a number
pros: Good pay easy to get a job
cons: Upper management worried about themselves only

headline: Could be worse.
pros: The other tellers were fun, friendly, and welcoming. Some of the bankers were of the same mold. The majority of the customers were pleasant and great people to get to know.
cons: Branch manager was unnecessarily aggressive towards employees. Despite our top-performing customer reviews and excellent ratings in the area, the manager felt the need to treat the employees (specifically the younger ones) as though they were children as opposed to adults. BM also talked down to anyone holding or in pursuit of a college degree as though they were unfit to operate as a member of society.

headline: good company to work for
pros: good benefits from the company
cons: work life balance could be better

headline: Great culture with wonderful development opportunities.
pros: They really invest in their employees's development, with extensive training classes, exposure to higher level management, and a focus on employees growth.
cons: Many teams require extensive travel between McLean and Richmond. Offers great starting salaries but often does not provide sufficient bonuses and/or raises.

headline: NOT WORTH YOUR TIME
pros: Good work-life balance, good benefits, nice atmosphere
cons: Compensation not near high enough for the demands, management given too much power. My time spent here (3 years) was one giant popularity contest. I got fired for "violating a code of ethics" meaning my numbers were too good, my performance too consistent and my attitude too positive that they determined I was cheating and fired me with no real proof. Go to any other bank, this ones not worth it.

headline: Horrible Company
pros: They offer an excellent benefits package, as well as incentives for practically anything and everything that you do.
cons: Working for this company was ok. Everybody's experience is different. They don't value their employees. They are more worried about retention rates that development. They don't value their employees. They are more worried about retention rates that development.

headline: Good opportunity! Overall, enjoyed my time working there!
pros: Good benefits and perks for those that meet individual and branch goal. They give you the tools to succeed as long as you put in the time and effort. Hours of operation is in par with the industry and travel time between home and branch is pretty reasonable.
cons: I believe that Capital One overall is behind in the technology field and needs to focus on catching up to the rest in the market. It would also be beneficial if there were better career opportunities outside of sales and this is with the understanding that the company is in the banking industry.

headline: Positive experience
pros: Culture, people and core values
cons: Lot of work and difficult to manage the expectations.

headline: If you want to work for a big corporate, this is an okay company
pros: Big company, lots of opportunities
cons: performance management, waterfall mindset, hierarchical driven

headline: Only okay.
pros: Health, 401k, dental, vision, vacation and days off per year.
cons: Pay could have been better, rigid culture

headline: The benefits and perks are pretty good.
pros: The Benefits, and perks. Opportunities for growth often available.
cons: Management is a challenge, poor HR. Can be stressful at times.

headline: Great Company
pros: Company values are excellent. They believe in helping the community, treating employees with respect and investing to make the customer experience the best. Never been at a company like this one before - amazing place to be.
cons: Promotions are few and far between - company is good at targeting talent for advancement but lousy at enabling the rest of the resources who weren't selected.

headline: So far so good; Fraud Intake Coordinator job review
pros:
I just finished classroom training so my review will be based on that and updated later on. Classroom training is eight hours a day for four weeks long. It is A LOT of information, but the trainer is really good at her job.Also, being in the classroom with people who had experience and with people who didn't made it easier to learn things. There's a lot of managers, and each one came in multiple times throughout training to meet us. So far, management looks laid back and personable. 

BENEFITS BROKEN DOWN:
All benefits including 401k matching,health,dental,vision,education assistance,adoption assistance, start on DAY ONE!
The benefits cant be matched elsewhere. Yes, hourly isn't anything to write home about, but you're offered a "differential" to work a later shift of about 10%, over time is given if wanted and theres monthly bonuses that add up to $1250 that agents can get. From what I have heard from current agents, they aren't too hard to get.
Health care: This is the best health care I have seen for hourly employees. Again, it starts on day one, and their most expensive plan for one person is about $30/month, which includes no copay and free walk-in clinic visits. Add dental and vision on for about 2 extra a month.
I didn't get insurance, but purchased life insurance. My $138,000 policy is about 3 dollars a month.
Education assistance is $5500 for Bachelors and Masters degrees


Capital One as a company is really cool. They pride themselves on having personal relationships with their customers.
cons: It seems to be very difficult to get promoted

headline: A decent place to work
pros: This company has some great things to offer. good benefits, and extras like an onsite gym and cafe.  Very nice work envionment and they do a lot of fun things like have company sponsored trips or lunches.  You even get 3 weeks of paid vacation your first year, which is more than most other companies.  Some of the managers are helpful with career planning, and can be flexible with scheduleing if you are responsible about it and don't take advantage.
cons: Nothing is stable as far as business processes, procedures and systems.  Things change constantly and you better pay attention to the signs because they seem to layoff quite a bit or just move you to another position with little or no advance notice and no increase in pay, but more and more job duties.  They don't really keep you informed about changes that are going to be made. Some of the managers are micromanagers, and of course you typical office politics and people in positions that know absolutley Nothing!

headline: Management for the N.E. Regional Neighborhood lending team is terrible!! Work elsewhere!!!
pros: The benefits are good, the base pay is convenient, but if you can't close loans, you will be forced to live off of a low base forever.
cons: The management is horrible!! Run !! They will promise you one thing and then do a complete 180 degree spin around on you. Very weak on products, little to no marketing. Major H.R. complaints against management, and no action.

headline: Teller
pros: Fantastic company to work for, benefits are great only bank in my area that matches up to 7% 401k. if you work hard you get promoted from with in right away, i started as a part time teller and with in 2 months got promoted to full time, 6 months later and im currently up for another promotion to be a banker.
cons: everything so far is fantastic

headline: Meatgrinder of Greed
pros: Hire young people - high school grads and college students.
cons: Only care about the bottom line, which is probably true of any bank. Treat clients poorly.

headline: Project manager with technology operations
pros: people get paid good money
cons: They only care about making good oney

headline: typical customer servie
pros: benefits, training and pay was good
cons: not a lot of room for advancement, last minute changes to policy with out notice

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Work/life balance, great pay, good culture
cons: There can be times when you have to work weekends

headline: Exciting and forever changing.
pros: If you are at a busy branch, you have a chance to make great incentives. If you are that lucky, the sky is the limit on your incentive pay.
cons: Policy and procedures seem to change weekly and without notice. Nothing is consistent.

headline: good enough to start with
pros: low stress, easy to get time off, people are generally friendly,
cons: salary is not at industry standard, you are slotted into a particular career path based off what school you came from (i.e. UVA vs. Yale)

headline: Amazing Company
pros: family environment, culture, fun outings
cons: pay, hours, managment, advancement, training

headline: Overall a good place to work.
pros: The benefits are great. Health benefits are available upon your hire instead of making you wait 90 days. PTO is available after 90 days. Lots of opportunity to advance within your department and also to move to other departments. Classes and computer based training made available to learn or improve skills. Managers work well with employees to move onto new positions or to obtain promotions.
cons: I have noticed that some managers will not provide employees with feedback concerning their performance and will either penalize or terminate that employee. Bonus pay out for some call center jobs means despite having a great month, your bonus may be small if your department is set up on a tiered/competitive system.

headline: Easy work, good pay but hard to advance
pros: Good pay, great experience with a Fortune 200 company and a very recognizable Brand.  If you are looking to build your resume as a brand strategist and get great hands on learnings the Brand Department is good.
cons: Too many lifers, too top heavy, narrow thinking and passive aggressive management. No one leaves and Capital One does like firing people so there are very limited spaces at the top of the department.  I have been a 'top performer" for 3 year, getting the highest bonus you can but still not advancing.

headline: Call Center environment is very stressful
pros: Meet a lot of hard working seasoned employees who are very nice and professional.
cons: Being tied down to the telephone the entire & hours.

headline: I was a TDP intern and it was excellent.
pros: Many fun activities, work hours were flexible, everyone was very nice/genuine, and management was excellent.
cons: Onboarding took way to long for an internship, however this is being resolved.

headline: Greta Place to Work
pros: This company has great employee benefits. If you need a job that cares about you this is the one to be at.
cons: No CONS great family culture. Management is really intune with their agents. They promote moral on the floor

headline: OK in the right position, on the right team, with the right management.
pros: Work environment, good benefits, discounted stock purchase.  Diverse associate population with a significant number of women in senior leadership roles.
cons: Politics.  Working after hours often expected ...  Very youth oriented.  Capital One has a tendency to re-organize every couple of years, hiring younger associates, and laying off experienced, higher paid associates.  Many of the senior management positions are filled from outside the company.

headline: Young, energetic company, with huge emphasis on developing associates.
pros:
Great culture, not like your typical financial service company. 
Benefits are really good.
Decent work-life balance
Company has a true mission to provide quality service to customers.
cons:
Promotions are available, but depends on the line of business
Compensation is a little low for the DMV area. 
Still learning how to become a bank

headline: Not what it used to be
pros: Culture is great along with flexible working environment.
cons: Career path was great a few years ago but has been more difficult to move up the ladder and promotions are scarce. More work with no compensation...

headline: Pretty good company to work for overall
pros: Work/life balance is great.  Very rarely is someone required to give up extracurricular activities in lieu of work projects.
cons: Constant change across all levels of the organization.  I have been with the company for 3 years and am on my 4th Director and 2nd VP.

headline: Experience totally depends on branch manager
pros: With hard work, you can grow your career pretty quickly. It seems as if the company really takes their time to make sure that the right employees are hired and get along great with coworkers. Great benefits as well
cons: Some managers can set you up for failure in regards to sales. The branch is 100 percent dedicated to sales, and some of the goals are completely unrealistic.

headline: Banker
pros: Good benefits. Good company. Tales dare of employees and cares. Good work life balance.
cons: Sales jobs are always a pain bc of the rat race

headline: Wonderful place to grow
pros: Honest and nice people work here. Many managers are advocates for their reports.  It is a great place to build a career.  Capital One is making smart and aggressive moves to become a technical powerhouse. CEO is a legit nice guy with vision.  Capital One has hired a team of very, very smart people.
cons: Tough rating system. It it a challenge to get promoted. (It should be.)  It is tough to "fit in" socially in some departments.  Sometimes, quirky people are left behind because they are different.  Highly competitive environment can be stressful but is rarely negative.

headline: Overall good
pros: Lots of training opportunities. Company is trending up.
cons: Large organization with lots of process

headline: Long time for promotion
pros: Many company benefits, decent hours
cons: Low pay rate, promotions based on network and NOT quality of work

headline: Awesome place with great analytics
pros:
- Analytics
- work life balance
- fast paced
cons: - Tons of meetings. Hard to find time to work

headline: Great legacy, but culture has changed
pros: Comp is higher than in almost every other Richmond area company. Plus, the people are great - not average, but great!. Constant change makes for an exciting workplace.
cons: The culture has changed markedly. Capital One has become a big bank - with all that it entails.  Internal competition has created a political climate. And the company, more than most, values youth - older workers have a difficult hill to climb.

headline: Coordinator
pros: Flexible work schedule. Benefits for insurance and time off
cons: As a phone associate you're expected to adhere to a lot of rules, can be very stressful.

headline: Was a good company to work for before merger with HSBC
pros: personal time off, health benefits, 401k, learning new skills, career development resources, cafeteria, fitness center
cons: favoritism, lack of pay raise, hard to move up within the company, high turnover

headline: Good work life balance. Data driven decision making.
pros: Good work life balance. Great campus. Flexible work from home policy. A data driven culture that has really improved my ability to analyze various marketing initiatives.
cons: Company is very hierarchal. Takes a long time to get a promotion. The company encourages outspoken people for management positions.

headline: Great company. Worst branch to work ins
pros: Hours are great, the COMPANY cares about it's employees. Fun events. Pay is one of the highest in banking.
cons: Branch management/leads are HORRIBLE and disrespectful! Rudeness and cattiness all around the branch. Have no shame in offending employees. Referrals are hard to obtain. Cut throat environment. This was my worst job(and I worked in McDonalds at 15!) it's sad to see a branch ruin such a great company.

headline: Great experience
pros: I like the campus and the people I meet with.
cons: Nothing that I can think of.

headline: Used to love my job
pros: It's an OK job. Better than others I have had. Pay and benefits are ok but not top. Some great people. They talk about implementing new technologies and there is some light at the end of that tunnel. Preliminary use of cloud, though limited in scope. Some people get laptops to work at home. Starting to let people get Macs. Work life balance. Office has pros and cons but nice in some ways. The work itself, when given freedom to implement the best solution, is very satisfying. The mission and all the words management says are really great. It would be nice if that was reality.
cons: Don't feel can work to full potential but not sure that would be different anywhere else. Too many people trying to tell teams what to do and not enough technical people to get the work done. Too much dictation of process and technology which stifles innovation. Not very much recognition for results that help the company bottom line and high quality deliverables completed in a timely manner. Used to be able to do this more consistently when we were left alone to get our work done how we saw fit. People's expertise is not well utilized.

headline: Great place to start.
pros: Casual working environment with lots of variety in your daily tasks. Both day and night shifts to fit most schedules.
cons: Located in Northern Tulsa County, bad lighting on streets and most people will work the night shift. Only collections or customer service on premises. Not much room for advancement.

headline: Good place
pros: good up to date technology stack
cons: less growth oppurtunties in Cap1

headline: Customer Services
pros: Great company to work for
cons: no  problem, great place to work

headline: Working with smart people, doing cool things always got me out of bed in the morning.
pros: The people are great, they are very smart and the culture is empowering.
cons: It is very dynamic, change is rapid and constant.  Organizational changes happen about every 9 month, don't expect things to remain static for too long.

headline: Fairly positive and mostly customer centric company
pros: Recruits competent employees often with at least basic experience and good common sense. Salary is in a decent range for retail banking, room for commission at busier branches.
cons: Difficult to get a real salary raise once you're hired, even with a promotion. Programs, especially platform, are outdated and use way too many systems to accomplish one task.

headline: above average
pros: good place to start a career
cons: Political infighting among numerous departments

headline: Culture needs a refresh
pros: The company is big on movement within Capital One. There are many opportunities to change departments or expand skills in a different area of the company.
cons:
They talk a lot about work/life balance but have shut down work from home programs for many departments. Company vision is myopic, believing that Richmond is the center of the universe and the other locations don't matter.
Meetings, meetings, then more meetings to discuss the meetings previously held.

headline: Company where employees all really seem to support and mimic company mission.
pros: Work life balance is unbeatable and lots of opportunity to collaborate across company
cons: Richmond (largest campus and hub of jobs) isn't really the greatest place for a twenty year old to start out career if looking for big city life.

headline: Great Place to Start your Career
pros:
great career development, great tools to help you succeed. Stock purchase, be well 401k matching good for associates.
lots of exposure to senior leadership
cons: not very diverse, upward mobility it hard, lots of change going on, favoritism. its what you know and who you know

headline: Still trying to reinvent the wheel.
pros: Very flexible with hours. Here you find balance with your personal life and work.
cons: Goals are not reasonable! The goals set for Relationship Bankers are not attainable. They promise a very good bonus for employees who are able to hit their goals... but, this never happens!

headline: Underwriter
pros: Vacation only reason I stayed
cons: Don't pay as well as other companies

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Great training; intelligent employees; strong corporate culture of excellence; very proud to work there; thorough review process which was taken seriously with good feedback and plan for development
cons: political; perception is often more important than reality; too many reorganizations

headline: The Company is okay...not the best
pros:
Pay/Bonus       Promotion
Benefits            Career Growth
Open door policy
cons: The management is horrible.  All the managers care about are there numbers. As soon as you bring there numbers down they will try and find a way to get you fired. There compliance and signed in for a call center is ridiculous. Oh and I hope you never get sick because they do not accept doctors note. The managers fraternize with bankers and gossip...the list goes on. This company's turn around rate is the worst i have ever seen for a company.

headline: Unique and engaging yet repetitive.
pros: Plenty of benefits like tuition reimbursement for college students, Insurance,  401K, bonus incentives, opportunities to move up within company.
cons: Very repetitive, can get difficult with day to day calls. Systems aren't smooth for operations for employees.

headline: Great place to pick up many different skills
pros: Once you're in, you can explore different areas of the company. Great for people open to change and picking up new skills
cons: I have none so far

headline: Great Company
pros: Capital one is a great company to work for and they take pride in the diversity of their work force.  Training is very thorough in order for employees to provide the high quality service that Capital One is know for.
cons: I honestly have nothing negative to say about my experience working at Capital One.  It is truly a great company to work for.

headline: great company
pros: co-worker, work-life balance, incentives, morale, great place to work.
cons: incentives are great but wish base pay was higher

headline: It was an OK experience.
pros: Large  Company, well known in the industry.
cons: Not enough opportunities for advancement.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good culture and fun environment. Strong focus on Customer Experience
cons: Constant changes in procedures; Limited opportunities for growth

headline: Great place to work. Challenging atmosphere
pros: Always changing.  Always different.  Lots of money
cons: Not careful in how they spend their money.  Won't listen to the people who know.  Do not accept change even tho it is for the best.

headline: Working at Capital One
pros: Job has many incentives and benefits.
cons: Policies, procedures, managers,processes change frequently.

headline: My experience has been good
pros: pay check every 2 weeks, you can receive money for living a healthy lifestyle, company gym
cons: performance appraisals are difficult, gym closes at 8 and is not open on weekends

headline: HVS CSR
pros:
Benefits
Not bad for a call center job
cons:
Working weekends and holidays 
hard to get time off on weekends and holidays
back to back calls at times
too many metrics to meet
pay is pretty low
I am not sure how they got voted top workplace in Tampa

headline: Very Good
pros: Great Benifits and HR dept
cons: Goals oriented company. too much stress sometime

headline: No room for growth at Tampa location
pros:
benefits
tuition reimbursement
good employees/co-workers
company creates a lot of fun/unique events to please employees
fun place to work
cons: This is a job for someone in or right out of college. The place is operated like college campus. It may be appealing to young graduates but no one trying to build a career. It is good for resume building and investigation experience

headline: Enjoy working for the company.
pros:
Work/life balance
Benefits
Rewards critical thinking
Team oriented
Training
cons:
Beauracracy
Salary
Constantly changing management structures
Changes are slow

headline: Great Company, Extremely poor People management
pros: The IT Platform is great, leadership does go after most of the right things with regard to software, hardware, procedures. Work-life balance is also okay. While compensation is not as great as other companies I have been at or know of, perks such as low cost Fitness Center in basement, free parking, ability to work from home, cell phone and data plan for certain managers all combine to make a nice package.
cons: People management is where Capital One loses in a big way. Quite a few managers that I worked with do not know how to coach, provide feedback and help grow and retain resources. There is also a lack of "common culture" across managers and directors. For example, completely different messages are given by different managers/VPs/Directors about dress code or if a child can be brought in if school / day care is closed unexpectedly, Agile processes. Capital One is big on BSAs for every Agile Team and this causes significant confusion: Who owns creation of Stories, Acceptance Criteria - the BSA or team members or Product Owner.

headline: good
pros: good payment, good work-life balance
cons: no idea, i may write it later

headline: Great Company
pros: Great work environment and ability to grow as an employee
cons: As a call center agent, some of the demands of the job are unreasonable, especially coming from a manager who does not have to be on the phone all day, nor are they being "clocked" like us regular employees.

headline: HR Consultant
pros: Great culture, growth and change….strategic vision of Sr. Leaders is best in class.
cons: Change, turnover of management, working through too many recent acquisitions

headline: Horrible Place to Work
pros: the benefits other than health, your getting a paycheck and not standing in the unemployment line
cons: pay, management is horrible especially in HVSD department in Tampa, there is only one good manager in this department that everyone cross the board feels is fair and manager material, the favoritism is ridiculous I have never seen anything like it and yes every company has this but this place and department takes the cake, some people get written warnings others get a pass which keeps the morale very low, mostly everyone is unhappy but pretends to be happy. Upper management could care less what goes on and seem to cater to the bullies and troublemakers, as long as the numbers are good they could care less.

headline: No advancement potential
pros: Nice sites, nice work out facility, nice cafeterias.  For the most part, co-workers are all pretty decent too.  Rich Fairbanks seems like an honest,, decent person,  but he needs to have more sympathy for what people are going through with the Company he loves so much.
cons: The ever changing Managers you will have and shift bids.  You cannot have a normal work/life balance at this Company.  If you have kids, do not work here.  Also, very cliquey! This is due to the number of young Managers this Company promotes.  They must do this for monetary reasons.  Too many young kids running Capital One which makes it very High School-ish.  If you're not in a clique, you're not a "favorite."  Also the micro-managing is a joke and will drive you insane.

headline: Good Company
pros: * Good culture, well meaning employees, work life balance.  I enjoyed my time there.  My supervisors were good and I appreciated the training.
cons: Roles are very boring. traffic is slow. lack of infrastructure to support some branches, no exceptions to policy for promotion.  Time in must be 1 year to move to any internal position.

headline: Great Company
pros: Employee recognition is great. I am always being recognized, awarded or invited to recognition breakfasts and luncheons. The moral is awesome as well.
cons: Under staffed branches make work environment a little hostile. I do a lot of opens to close. I have very few lunch breaks.

headline: Bank Teller
pros: Very fast process, interview was a very easy laid back environment. Everyone is really nice and helpful.
cons: The training process is a classroom area, very long and boring. ALOT of book work.

headline: Good
pros: Chicago downtown location, work responsibilities, work life balance
cons: Less salary, less bonus, corporate politics

headline: Capital one
pros: Good benefits nice friendly environment. Applied online received a call back in one day completed a phone interview and was the scheduled for my in person interview received a call back with my offer about 9 days later
cons: Pay is horrible no where in comparison with other call centers in tampa will be quitting after one week of training because of the pay 13.03 horrible

headline: pay
pros: bonus if you get great qa scores
cons: they will fire you for any little thing good luck :)

headline: relationship banker
pros: flexible schedule. good benefits and hours
cons: sales pushy and unrealistic numbers

headline: Changing Banking For Good? I think not!
pros: Decent starting base pay and good bonus/incentive structure. Good Aetna benefits. Direct management seems to be caring but never seems to have opportunities to help as much as they would like.
cons: Training doesn't adequately equip phone reps for things they will actually encounter on a daily basis. There are a lot of questions the training staff cannot answer. Team/unit managers are rarely able to give actual tips and guidance. The bank itself seems to do more harm than good regarding essential aspects for its customers (i.e. giving customers beneficial and accurate information at the branch level). The website and mobile app have constant issues but there seems to be no qualified employees in place to make timely fixes. Certain departments are expected to go above and beyond and do the job of other departments quite frequently, without compensation. The company takes more stock in "metrics" and telephone software numbers than the actual performance and contributions of the employee.

headline: Project Manager
pros: Great work/life balance, lots of travel available if you want it, values are good, fun people.
cons: Company is HQ-centric making it very hard for other offices or branches to feel appreciated/connected.  Company is too process/control heavy - it limits flow of ideas/changes.  Too many meetings.  Review/promotion process is terrible and based on a 20:60:20 scale meaning there always has to be bad guys and very few qualified get promoted/recognized.

headline: Call Center Sales Manager
pros: Very competitive in salary vs other banks
cons: The way they determine managers annual bonus doesn't reflect ones true work.

headline: Great Company to work for.
pros: Everyone is very friendly and the monthly bonuses are awesome, if you qualify.
cons: There have been many movements lately so it doesn't feel like there's enough job stability.

headline: Good company to polish your skills.
pros: Strong analytical and research focus.
cons: Disconnect between main site locations and satellite entities.

headline: Senior Risk Associate
pros: Pretty decent pay. Good company to work for. Pretty decent benefits.
cons: Hard to get promoted off the phones. Can become complacent. Pay increases for new positions keep you trapped in current positions where monthly bonuses are bigger.

headline: I have grown and developed skills within finance at Capital One
pros: My managers have generally cared about my development.  Moving around is encouraged.  Good work-life balance and compensation.
cons: Obsolete technology, compliance and the need to collaborate all can make getting things done difficult.  Finance is very FP&A and Accounting focused.  Fewer seats in Corporate Development and Treasury.

headline: A good place to start your career
pros: Energetic colleagues, good cafeteria, still has some entrepreneurial spirit. If you can prove yourself to senior management (by doing good presentations and have good business ideas), then you definitely will have a good chance of getting promoted.
cons: As it grows, the company runs into many problems facing big companies including bureaucracy, managers who can't manage people, layoffs for "efficiency." Also, year-end reviews are graded on a curve, so only 5-10% of people get above average.

headline: Relationship Banker position is customer service, nothing to do with financial planning or sales.
pros: Benefits and PTO package is excellent
cons: Management structure and pressure to open set number of accounts monthly.

headline: long interview
pros: good people, good for the community
cons: lots of politics with reviews

headline: Excellent company to work for but very strict change process for Information Technology
pros: Great work/life balance, great work from home options (twice a week), excellent pay / career opportunities.
cons: Very strict change process for Information Technology which restricts work flow.  Agile is used for project management which helps keep track of work and eliminate shoulder tapping but a lot of employees still don't follow process.

headline: Positive employees, teamwork, not the best systems
pros: positive & supportive coworkers, team environment, plans one-on-one time with employees to make sure hitting targets and goals and then creates strategies for success
cons: not the best systems but the pros outway the cons at this company

headline: Good place to work
pros:
One of the best work cultures
Young population
Nice people
Foreign relocation opportunities
cons:
Promotions may be politicized
Work stream in India may not be challenging

headline: Great
pros: Capital One is a great place to work for moms!
cons: Could have a Better work/life balance

headline: To many changes
pros: Good benefits, okay pay, good hours, holidays off
cons: Managers are very rude and disrespectful and when you call HR to report them they do nothing and they tell the mangers everything that was said.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Very laid back and have great benefits. Managers are very supportive and don't believe in stressing you out. They also have a very nice package if you get laid off.
cons: Systems aren't very advanced. They don't let you do anything on your own. You have to submit a ticket just to connect to a printer.

headline: Sr Coordinator CAAT
pros: Great mission statement and employees are empowered to assist. Feedback is provided through 360 feedback.
cons: Networking is what is important.  If you are a hard worker and don't network you will not go far in your career.

headline: Good in theory, Poor execution
pros: Company has good values. If located in Richmond, VA then you are good.
cons: If located outside of Richmond, VA, then you are treated very poorly. They speak about really taking care of employees but they don't practice it. The performance review process is a more a popularity contest than an actual evaluation of skills and results. There is no clear path for people looking to get promoted. People are constantly moving around so there isn't any stability... they know a little about a lot of things.

headline: Ok
pros: Good benefits. Good people. Lots of perks
cons: Really large company hard to stand out

headline: Overall, great place to work!
pros: Pay, benefits, overall advancement opportunities, culture is awesome, great values and most management live the corporate values.
cons: Frequent leadership changes, occasional inconsistent management decisions.

headline: Great place to work if you fit into the culture
pros:
Very fair compensation
Good benefits
Excellent campus in Richmond
Tools are very effective such as wireless internet access
Very intelligent and professional employees
cons:
Performance Management process encourages competition, not cooperation.
Company culture is very specific - conservative, more formal interaction with team members.
If your approach is "get it done and tell it like it is", you may feel out of place at this company.

headline: Iffy.
pros: Great benefits and Great vacation.
cons: Stuck in your position permanently unless your best friends with management.

headline: Awesome place to work..
pros: Smart people, great culture and very supportive of associate's growth. Flexible work timings at Capital One helps to maintain work life balance. Senior leadership is very approachable too.
cons: A lot depends on your manager, so you need to be lucky to get a good manager in order enjoy all that is mentioned as 'pros' above

headline: Great Company
pros: Great Benefits pays wells !
cons: Management... These district managers hire branch managers that were previously relationship bankers and/or branch managers at other banks, however, you can teach someone to sell but that does not mean that that branch manager knows how to manage people. I would never work in Central Queens

headline: Not much room for advancement
pros: Friendly, work-life balance, company culture and values, team building allowances, random bonuses, paid training, good products,
cons: Poor leadership, little room for personal growth, policies change often, high turnover, slow to hire, very few opportunities for advancement

headline: Great Place To Work
pros: Great benefits, Amazing personalities, Suitable work environments, Awesome corporate values and community involvement, Challenging work
cons: Process overtakes Customer Focus, most of the time.  Vast differences and inconsistencies by site, Sub Cultures, Lack of people focus on the Senior level, Less emphasis on work life balance in management roles

headline: Competitive work culture and controlling cliques bad for software developers
pros: Competitive salary,  decent benefits
cons: The company rewards competition amongst peers which create a hostile and vicious work culture. In fields where collaboration is crucial for success, such as in software development, the competitive process inhibits creativity, risk-taking, and fails to build support and trust amongst teammates. Cliques of managers work together to give less than average ratings to those outside their circles.  The bar is set high to get in the door then they grade on a curve once you get in. If everyone was very good to begin with then who is graded low on the curve? Those outside the cliques or those who failed to make side deals with key people.

headline: Great job, little opportunity in Austin
pros: Steady job, great training, amazing coworkers
cons: Not many advancement opps in Austin

headline: Good benefits, bad management
pros:
Great part time job for students getting through college
Nice work atmosphere, they always being food
Up to $1100 monthly bonus
cons:
Call center job, it gets extremely busy
Expect to be micro managed. Management watches you every second. They even hand out stop watches so you an " ensure" are breaks and time off the phone is counted
No upward mobility. Company will hire outsiders more often than promoting from within

headline: If you dont mind be lied to.....then youll LOVE IT!
pros: The benefits are really good for this level of a position.
cons: Management will lie to get you to perform and then will make all kinds of excuses to not follow thru on their promises.

headline: Positive feedback as a former Capital One Auto Finance position
pros: The pros were the extensive training and the ability to work independently with no supervision as well as with a team. I believe my outstanding drive, loyalty to the company, and an impeccable work ethic allowed me to shine as a terrific asset to the company. My co-workers and upper management thoroughly impressed me with their knowledge and willingness to make sure we all strived to the best of our abilities.
cons: I would have to say the most dissatisfaction I felt with the Capital One team was the lack of promotions throughout the company. With such an enormous turn over rate, instead of letting hard working employees move up in the company, move them to another department where they can benefit the company the best way fit, instead were let go.

pros: good culture, benefits, work life balance
cons: there is politics as is the case with any other company

headline: No direction & poor management!
pros:
This is an ok job if you want a check and benefits. You're more likely to get more compensation at Bank of America or Chase. Where most customers were closing their accounts and leaving to.

1)The benefits are pretty good. Health care is good, the CEO honestly likes his company and its obvious. They want employees to be involved in the community.
2)Coworkers can make or break your experience (like most jobs). However, coworkers are usually amazing. I'll admit that.
3)Company has simple yet positive values which do not come across as phoney.
4)Bonus structure, you get paid your bonus every month.
5)If you could somehow make it out of retail banking, this is a pretty good company to work for.
cons:
1)District managers treat those below them like crap.
2)No one ever has an answer to any problem and makes employees look silly in front of customers. Simple tasks require you to call a hotline, where they place you on hold and customer gets frustrated. 
3)Technology is the worst I've seen in the industry, makes for a frustrating experience for workers and customers alike.
4)Managers can be rude to employees and customers.
5)Inferior products and rude service reps.
6)Tons of paperwork for simple/mundane tasks which frustrates workers and employees alike.
7)Very high turnover due to poor hours, high levels of stress and low pay. 
8)Company has a lot of rude workers as customer service reps. Made me uneasy to recommend company products because the customer service reps seemed to encourage and or dare customers to close their accounts.

headline: Exciting but got boring fast
pros:
Medical and dental benefit
Competitive 401k 
Market rate wages
cons:
Unrealistic and ever changing sales goal
Limited personal and business banking products

headline: Great culture, atmosphere. Fun place to work!
pros: I work for Capital One in Sioux Falls, SD. There are a lot of things to love. Benefits (PTO, 401K match, Stock Purchasing Programs) are awesome. Capital One works really hard to try to be different that "just another call center". Casual environment is a plus. One of the biggest pro's is that it is a customer-centric organization from the top down - and they mean that.
cons: If you get hired in at a good salary, you will do very well. If you get hired at a low rate, you have no chance of getting to where you want to be. Policy is to give a small raise with promotions, but not what you are worth. A lot of middle managers don't care and kick their feet up. Frustrating, but I guess you see that anywhere...

headline: So Far So good
pros: -flexible work arrangements, culture, decent pay, fun, good company outlook. good for working moms
cons: same old corporate stuff you would find at any other company, dislike working downtown but that is only my preference

headline: Master Testing Specialist
pros:
A bank that has strong IT roots.
Great People who help each other and great leaders.
A great place for college graduates to learn and become SOLID in the IT Workforce.
Always evolving and always changing.
Management values new opportunities and new ideas through open door policies
cons: I have no cons for this company, I love it here.

headline: Flexible work arrangement, but too many re-orgs
pros: Impressive flexible work schedule. People all have different work schedule, people pick up at 2 pm in the afternoon and tells me they have to pick up their kids. Really great place for working moms. Good health benefits, great 401K (up to 7.5% of your salary), average paid time off, great on-site cafeterias with healthy options, on-site gym.
cons: Unwillingness to change or accept new ideas (even for the better), too many re-orgs and layoffs (not based on performance), interesting performance review style, too many meetings, inefficient (takes forever to do something, gazillion ineffective meetings before something is approved), promotions hard to come by unless you're a super star. There are people who have been here for 20 years and is still a principal!

headline: Okay - great benefits!
pros: Great benefits - Capital One contributed to my 401K without me having to.
cons: Management always trying to push numbers/sales onto employees. Management not on same page.

headline: Good working environment but difficult to maintain relationships
pros: Good benefits, great work-life balance, up-to-date technology
cons: Because they are so spread out, it is difficult to have face to face meetings with everyone that needs to be included. It is also difficult determining who you need to be connected with throughout the company.

headline: Branch Manager
pros: Technology was good. Worked with amazing colleagues & partners from other departments; many fired or pushed out.
cons: Job security!. Excessive amounts of people fired and/or placed on corrective action; reason given was for not being able to reach unattainable goals. Poor support from district managers: More interested in promoting themselves & protecting their jobs than supporting their teams. Toxic & negative environment.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Award winning benefits and notable employer, casual work environment, excellent location, opportunities for full time and contract work, and much more
cons: Former start up company with roots of innovation now part of the sixth largest bank in the nation has its challenges

headline: Sharp management and a company at the top of its industry
pros: Surround yourself with smart, efficient coworkers
cons: Pressure to work long hours...

headline: Changing banking for bad
pros: Its a job with insurance
cons: No work life balance, you are just a warm body

headline: Not a place for people who have worked at other organizations before
pros: Good facilities, nice perks, great gym
cons: All they care about is whether or not you know SQL. Company is being crushed under the weight of analysis paralysis

headline: Lack of recognizing the best talent
pros: Location, benefits, salary, distance to home,
cons: Lack of recognition towards the producers, too much group-think associated with performance reviews as opposed to recognizing individual work-ethic,  based on the team-concept too many employees get away with not pulling their weight forcing more work on each individual worker, lack of leadership from upper management or direct management

headline: Cool
pros: Health & Wellness Benefits, Paid Time Off
cons: Work Demands could be a bit much

headline: Dysfunctional Culture for Software Engineers
pros:
- good total comp for junior engineers/developers
- adopting Agile/SAFe/ART
- stable balance sheet, forward business prospects
- nice campus & public facilities
- 401k plan
cons:
- forced ranking per performance management
- results are not rewarded ... "competencies" are valued more than the actual work product
- senior leadership has very little engineering background or IT delivery experience
- culture is counter-productive to delivery

headline: Ok company
pros: Nice Working Environment, Nice Location and good benefits
cons: Less Pay. More work and hectic shifts

headline: Las Vegas Call Center
pros: Great benefits! Very customer driven. There is a lot of empowerment to do what you feel is right for the customer. They are also big on volunteer work and encourage you to volunteer even if it's during your work day they will try to get you time off. Most managers are invested in their agents and are eager to help the succeed.
cons: Micro managed. Every moment of your schedule is monitored by your phone activity. Small queues make it hard to get time off. Favoritism is alarmingly apparent with leaders from the former bank.

headline: Unique Culture
pros: Some of the people are good.
cons: Very "cliquey".  While every company has a unique culture, COF is very different than others.

headline: Can't Trust them
pros: When I first started I had a great Trainer,(Anthony. H). He cared and trained us well. The best trainer that I ever had.
cons: Other Trainers and Manager for the trainers are rude. They make stuff up. If they do not like you they will get rid of you. Training manager has a major problem. Managers don't know what they are doing and they are to busy flirting with the staff.

headline: Not proud to work here
pros: They offer a relaxed work environment, at least superficially, where jeans are ok, there's a ping pong table, and a gym downstairs. Depending on your manager, flexible hours or working from home might be available. Health insurance is expensive, but has good coverage.
cons: Since being purchased by Capital One, benefits and morale at our local office have sunk to all new lows. Few of our technology systems are integrated, and after two years it looks like we are nowhere closer to being so. Communication from management is more about generating a feeling of inclusion, than actually passing along useful information. And while a few original processes from our company remain in place, anything new introduced by the corporate office bring additional layers of inefficiency which prevent workers from completing normal job assignments.

headline: Here one day, gone the next. (A company that doesn't hesitate to remind you how expendable you are.)
pros: Good Benefits: health, dental, vision, stock purchase etc.
cons: Work-life balance sucked tremendously because the questionable shifts they have you work. Very Cliquish, only people who get promoted are the ones who suck up to superiors or make the company a substantial amount of $$$ in a short period of time. My former colleagues and myself made this company about  20 times what they pay us. The rewards for your hard work seems non-existent. Just a small merit increase and hope for a well deserved promotion. (or at least a job that relevant towards one's degree) Emphasis on "hope."

headline: A good company
pros: The company offers competitive salaries and bonuses, a stock purchase program, and a vast number of training opportunities.  Another plus is relatively easy to move within the company into different groups and jobs.
cons: I feel like that while management outwardly encourages input from their subordinates, it is rarely embraced and in the end you end up just doing what you are told.

headline: Decent and still growing, but confining
pros: The company offers outstanding benefits from a 401k with a match up to 6% along with 160 hours of paid time off. The campus life and culture within Capital One is amazing, you can and will find a wide array of people.
cons: There is not any advancement opportunities once you get into a department. The pay for the work that you would do is very mediocre and not really worth it.

headline: It was an educational experience
pros: The salary was pretty reasonable. The benefits were also very reasonable. The management were decent and I didn't have any problems with them. I felt treated fairly.
cons: Some of my co-workers made it difficult to work with them. But other than that my time at Capital One was pretty decent.

headline: Overall positive experience
pros: I was located outside of VA.  The total compensation package at the Sr. Manager level for non-retail positions is generous.  Also, there is the availability to work remotely when needed, which is great on those snowy days or when the kids are sick.
cons:
Salary increases and bonuses are scaled to yearly performance.  Current performance management system makes it is difficult to be anything more than average. All departments must fit into a bell curve, with only small percentages falling outside the average range.  

Few training opportunities available to associated outside of VA or Plano locations.

headline: Sr Process Manager
pros: Great flexibility and time off
cons: Too many re-orgs, upper management not appreciative of those who execute the work

headline: Dada Analyst
pros: Earning pay checks for food and shelter.
cons: The company says good words like "changing bank for good", but realy not walk the talk.  Senior management make asscociates fear losing jobs. They keep hiring young people, and at same time lay off older people. It is totally numbers game.

headline: Great Work/Life benefits. Insidiously competitive and rigid culture contrary to the professed 'open/honest' culture
pros: Flexible work schedules, interesting office spaces, great life benefits, strong salaries.
cons: Culture has become like many other large corporations where popularity outpaces actual performance metrics.

headline: Auto Finance was a very educational experience.
pros: not many, except for steady work
cons: it is very racist in the georgia branch

headline: Great atmospher, Little weak in training but over all good input..
pros: Great benefits. Vacation Pkg, Reasonable work schedule, Friendly people. I enjoye talking to our customers from all over and helping resolve them with thier issue.
cons: No up holding of Dress code. Not training or traing to early before the project starts so we have issue with agent retention and product knowledge. unresponsive floor support creating long hold times.

headline: Over worked and under trained
pros: Good pay above average for work at home and good benefits even if part time
cons: Not trained well enough, constant back to back calls with not enough breaks ( 1 break for 9 hour shift) not enough employees for work load, will remove 1/2 hour of your only break without notice and not given option to keep full break. They work you to death.

headline: It was nice before the layoff
pros:
- Most teams take work-life balance seriously and working from home is a legitimate option
- Good benefits like an at-work gym, decent cafeteria options, and good vacation allowance
- A Diverse culture -- people from all walks of life
cons:
- Some teams/departments are competitive, judgmental, and catty but the company culture is one of acceptance, collaboration, and lifting each other up. I guess it's pretty normal workplace politics. 

- Large company means lots of red tape to get anything significant (or almost significant) accomplished. 

- Every few years they do a large round of layoffs. Some people on my team who were laid off had been there for more than 10 years.

headline: Risk Associates
pros:
Cubical environment (shared) environment, super fun sometimes, and relaxed managers. (purely dependent on manager)

The bathrooms are clean, nice break areas (building management is the reason for this).
cons:
It's a collections job, you have to meet monthly quotas or else your on PIP. Once your PIP is over and you aren't improving, you'll be let go. I've seen it happens many times, sometimes it can become stressful with the monthly quota necessary and the stress they put on collecting money. Most of the time it's luck, some people will get out of the ditch they are in and be able to pay, where as others are living with their parents, homeless, jobless, and simply cannot pay even if they want to.

The supervisors and managers look for kissing ups, otherwise you have no success of moving up. If your daddy has a high position there, expect promotion fast. Otherwise, you're a sitting duck waiting for a promotion. No growth and advancements. 

Previous employees will tell you that they do not like the job they are doing and the job is beyond stressful after 3-4 months working there. You will learn real fast after all the positive talking in training, they don't tell you the real things that awaits you. 

Oh did I mention pay is horrible?

headline: Underwriter
pros: Company culture was very positive. The company holds a lot of events to promote morale. Employee wellness is also very well supported.
cons: Like any company, the department in which you work makes all the difference. The company is not afraid to make changes and this can sometimes leave you feeling a little lost.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Fun and enjoyable atmosphere. Everyone is very nice and provides a lot of feedback and knowledge.
cons: Compensation can be better. Growth opportunities need to be more clear. More hands on training.

headline: Many jobs to choos from, not so easy to move up and very volatile
pros: The tuition reimbursement is nice up to $5000 a year, great 401k nice matching program, discount share purchase program, many different departments to work in, if you are looking to relocate there are sites in VA, NV, DE, and more.  During layoffs offered career developement services and no cost.
cons: 1.5% City Tax in Wilmington, very volatile and unstable industry, many restructerings and layoffs, there is a lack of communication between sities and management.

headline: Principle Coordinator
pros: CCB was sold to Capital One and it went down hill from there.
cons: upper manager would change minds due it one way and then say do it another

headline: Good place to start, hard to grow
pros: Learning opportunities to pick up skillsets
cons: Not a good place to learn leadership and decision making

headline: great training and really values its employees
pros: quantitative, analytical, good work-life balance, values its employees, good training, good opportunities for internal mobility. not like a "bank"
cons: not as much dynamism and as many promotions as the old days. Many acquisitions threaten whether the good culture can be sustained.

headline: Richmond Centric
pros: benefits are standard, health, 401k, paid days offs...  Unlimited sick days (even if your child is sick) for salaried employees.
cons:
Capital One didn't seem prepared to manage a staff virtually since the bulk of their staff is located in Virginia.  As part of the HSBC acquisition it was difficult to stay up to date with the fast pace environment.  Something as simple as phone etiquette during conference calls (one person speaking at a time) was a lost art; having a conference room in Virginia big enough to hold the required project team, with a phone (literally I was on calls that an iphone was being passed around to try and keep the conversation flowing. 

Tons of red tape for day to day operations, and the promotion process is unlike any organization I've ever worked for.  You have to have a champion submit your request for a promotion, then IF you are selected for the "stretch" opportunity you work the role for at least 12 months, at which point you will be told if you get the promotion or not and that is when you will see the increase in salary.

headline: Awful Ever-changing nightmare
pros: Great people, fun atmosphere, onsite caf, and onsite company store
cons: My schedule changed drastically four times in two months. I went from 8-5 to 10-7 back to 8-5 to 12-9 oer the course of 8 weeks. They changed my department with one day of training for a month on my last week of training, and then was sent back to nesting.

headline: Great Company, if you work in the right place.
pros:
Great Benefits
More high tech then you would imagine for a Bank/Brokerage
Very smart people 
Nice work/life balance
Great vision and values
Lots of training opportunities if your in the right location
cons: Unless you are in VA or Plano, TX you are not going anywhere. Very hard to get opportunities because they don't offer them to remote offices. Unless you are willing to move.

headline: Good Place
pros: Nice team work, understanding supervisors
cons: Converting a contractor to full time is really difficult

headline: Not a good place to work, especially the San Francisco branch
pros: Good benefits but not worth it if you have to work in a caustic environment everyday.
cons: Politics, power-struggle, de-valuing employees are a norm. I would not recommend anyone to join the San Francisco office.

headline: Overall a great company to work for.
pros: Paid time off exceeds industry standards.  typical benefits of a corporate setting but they really care about their employees in this regard.  Tuition reimbursement and school schedule flexibility is great for students.  Love working with everyone like it's a second home.
cons: Salary is the biggest issue.  No where near the competition with other big corporations.  Tampa's call center is growing but not enough for much advancement.  Turnover rate is quite high for this reason.

headline: Good company
pros: Smart people, highly analytical and data driven
cons: Very inward focused, limited growth

headline: overworked
pros: pay is good except when you calculate what you are making when you are working on-call in an it production environment
cons:
on call, means to them whenever, whatever you doing -stop, you better answer your phone 
seriously.  had managers that were not professional and micro managed you to death.  if you like having a manager snap fingers at you to work when they wanted something.  the managers will call other managers in other states  to ask you to complete an assignment, even when they are sitting near by in another cube.   i never had a warm fuzzy feeling and my team was promised all these special events for team building...always cancelled at the last minute (you still had to complete all work anyway before going)  other folks on the team got awards for things that i did but i was passed over many times.

headline: Loan Services Accountant
pros: little above average pay for area
cons: poor management, everyone wants to be the boss

headline: IT - a great place for high school politics
pros: Fairly flexible work schedules, pay and benefits are ok.  Work/life balance for the right groups is great.  The business leadership is very sharp.  A lot of the rank and file are genuinely good people.
cons: Most of the senior IT leadership is incompetent, with most of them being unprincipled Peter Principled project managers promoted way, way above their competency level who know little about technology, less about leadership, and nothing about building and fostering a healthy organization.  But they are really good at playing politics and deflecting blame for their failures onto suitable scapegoats.  If you aren't in the right clique - your career will go nowhere.  If you are technical, your career will go nowhere (but don't worry, they have been working on a career track for technical people for the last 6 years that will eventually take it beyond the manager level, honest, it's coming any day now).  Unless you come in fresh out of college, it's unlikely you will leave the company with a better set of skills than you originally came with.  If that's not enough to dissuade you, here are a few more cons: they have a meeting driven culture - as in all day, all meetings.  Nothing can get decided without several meetings involving up to a dozen or so people to discuss it.  Even if it involves only one person actually doing something.  The "anonymous" opinion surveys...probably aren't anonymous.  If you aren't already tagged as being targeted for promotion, you probably won't get a great rating, no matter how great of a job you actually did.  And if you aren't in the right clique - guess what, you probably won't get tagged for promotion.  If you are in the right clique though, get ready for champagne wishes and caviar dreams.

headline: Very unique culture, not for everyone.
pros: Offers some good benefits. Starting to go in the right direction with regards to customer service.  Tries to do right by employees. Good work-life balance for most.
cons: Very passive aggressive culture.  Analytic testing results in a group of very smart people who don't always have the best social skills and can be very arrogant.  Very bureaucratic and hierarchical.

headline: Long hours but quality work
pros: Competitive pay, aesthetically pleasing buildings
cons: Long hours, resource challenges, open workspace

headline: Great experience with a strong management team.
pros: Direct managers always willing to help they take the time to know their staff so that they do not feel like just a number on the balance sheet.
cons: Dedicated employees get lost in the work life balance as they tend to want to overwork to make their plan and overachieve. Keep goals with in reach set in the start of the fiscal year and don't keep changing the goal. Allow the staff to reach a consistent target.

headline: data analyst
pros: friendly people，location，good to learn new skills
cons: learning to use new software

headline: nice place to work, flexible work arrangements, interesting work
pros:
flexible work arrangements, nice cafeteria
great and inspiring CEO
cons: pay is about average, below inflation annual increases

headline: Great Company
pros: Good benefits and great values. Facilities are wonderful.
cons: Communication can be poor at times

headline: Glad I got the experience with different departments; however, do not approve of management's handling.
pros: It was a decent company to get your foot in the door or just to have employment. You get to experience different departments, learn different managers and people, and earn incentives.  Team work is a big focus here as well as having ownership of ones development.
cons:
Management can backstab if you aren't in good with them. They will take credit for things you may bring to the table or they may not protect you. There was a couple times I came in to work and was told that I would be in a whole new department, without even my consent or interviewing and they would make you go through the whole training and nesting process. IF you didn't pass the nesting process, you were terminated!  There were employees who worked there for 15+ years who went through that scenario and were fired because they couldn't get passed the nesting stage!!!

It can be very cutthroat.

headline: Doing the right thing
pros: Inspiring vision, Great people, Good benefits
cons: I can not say anything bad

headline: Very erratic corporation. Too many reorgs.
pros: Size is big. Uniformity across the footprint. Technologically advanced.
cons: Too much bureaucracy. High-sounding nonsense. Those who can BS, make it big. The quite ones, not a chance! Very little diversity beyond mid-level management. Jargonism rules. No career pathing. One has to blow one's own horn. One comes across people of color often complaining that they are kept behind since those at the helm would not work for their advancement and not allow them to move forward. The management often boosts about diversity - yes, there's plenty to be found at the lower level but not much when it comes to management.

headline: Great place to start a career
pros:
I only worked at capital one for about year, but felt that I gained valuable experience in analytics that I've been able to apply in future roles.

The culture is also great for analytically-minded folk. Ideas are argued based on their merits, and you can have a big impact as a junior analyst if you're good enough.
cons: Capital One makes basically all of their money off tricking poor people into using products they can't afford. They're better than they were (after some big settlements with the federal government) but in most areas of the company you'll need to be comfortable with the fact that you're the type of banker people protest.

headline: No opportunity to grow
pros: The people who work there are great
cons: Not a well run company in many aspects

headline: Good learning experience
pros: Good company to workl for.
cons: Too many and frequent process changes.

headline: Good Place to Work
pros:
Decent work environment. 
Great work life balance.
cons: Promotion in place is near impossible.

headline: Good benefits and opportunity advance ments
pros: Over all good atmosphere, the referrals where easy, only 13 per month in my region. I easily doubled that, they provide great hands on training for two weeks and pay for the drive time. I worked with the company for one year, I would have loved to stay with them longer but i moved states and there was no Capital One I could transfer to.
cons: They are trying to expand across the United States but there are still mostly a eastern coast bank so if you move often (military spouse) it will be difficult to transfer. They didn't offer a pay difference even though i was hired as a bilingual teller. A times they will micro manage and get very pushy, they will would actually sit next to you, make sure you push products even when those customers dont need them

headline: I would have a better opportunity in Prison
pros: Pros? This one is hard?
cons: Cons? Conned is a better word to describe my experience; As in I felt conned every step of the way. No one seemed to be able to think on their own. Everyone seemed to be okay drinking corporate koolaid and being in compliance with stupidity. Everyone acted like cardboard cut-outs or Lythium enduced Zombies!

headline: Good company, Trying to be an innovator which is unusual for a Financial Firm
pros: Trying to be an IT innovator which is refreshing.  They pay pretty well and they do a lot of small spot award recognition
cons: Unrealistic project time lines, many expected to put in extra hours on nights and weekends

headline: Apply some where else
pros: Benefits for Part Time Employees, Work from home opportunity
cons: They pay is not worth the headache, absolute horrible raises 17 cent raise after two years, (and I was exceeding expectations in my review)  .  You have to put in bids for PTO, there is only a certain amount of hours allowed for the department each day for PTO and you have to put in a bid 6 months in advance.  Managers can take PTO anytime they please, but representatives can not.  Everything is very micromanaged, and management promotes not being honest and being very vague to customers.  There is also no room for growth, no opportunity for advancement.

headline: Rewarding.
pros: The compensation is actually on the lower side of the competition.  Aside from that, the benefits are great and the company itself is always striving for change which can keep it interesting.
cons: There is high turnover in collections and the atmosphere isn't the best.

headline: cap one
pros: good company, to me anyway. I thought it was a good work life
cons: not good work life balance

headline: Great company to work for if you want to make a difference using your analytical skills
pros: Great benefits, corporate culture and values, and work-life balance. Great environment of team work with smart colleagues. Great senior management team
cons: Continuous change in economic and regulatory environement

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Great People, Great place to learn and grow in your career.
cons: No Cons at this time.

headline: Great place to grow a career and develop.  Good place to work as a mom.
pros: Flexible; Fast-paced and smart; collaborative and development-oriented.
cons: Flexibility has translated to working 70 hours a week but you can do it at home; too much assessing and feedback; expecting associates to take on 3 other people's roles as we lean organizations

headline: Frought with politics...
pros: Very competitive pay, very hardworking employees, some very competitive products for businesses.
cons: Senior management (below Divisional Presidents) are very "political" - they clearly have their favorites and insiders. Too many segment initiatives that prevent any real local management or direction. Everything is micromanaged in the Business Bank. While they talk about work/family balance, it doesn't come through in practice.

headline: Overall good company to work for
pros:
-great work life balance
-great salary and benefits for college hires
-clear career advancement opportunities
-interesting and challenging work
-lots of smart people
