cons:
-takes forever to get anything done if IT is involved (which is always)
-not particularly fun environment
-easy to get pigeonholed into one small area of expertise
-training is highly touted but relatively useless

headline: Great Company
pros: The training process was thorough, and the office culture offered a very team-oriented environment. There were also incentives to perform at your best. There were also fitness initiatives and discount programs offered to employees.
cons: Pain customers, meeting referral goals, getting called out for bad reviews

headline: Company Changed
pros: Good work life balance for now
cons: Thru mergers is slowly evolving into typical company. Performance management is all politics

headline: Great company for young professionals
pros: Competitive pay, good work life balance, good people, growth potential, job security is high if you are a high performer and the company is very receptive to moving around departments or geographies
cons: Some departments can be challenging to partner with and slow to make concession that require additional work, low performers seem to stay around too long as well

headline: Great company
pros: Flexible. Worked 4 days. Off 3. Job Security.
cons: Mangement wants to tell you how to do your job, but can't do it themselves

headline: Overall Positive
pros: Nice environment and upper level management
cons: Too much of after hours work for contractors. No work life balance

headline: Great Company!
pros: Great Benefits, room for growth, in various cities so you can move with your job.
cons: New to banking, a lot of legacy ING employees have no real idea how banking works.

headline: Unit Manager
pros: work/life balance, clear levels establish ability to grow in career, employee stock purchase plan, 401k match
cons: complexity of job process, slow to change and enhance process, financial services division is not moving in the right direction, majority of the time the company is overly analytical

headline: Lot of turnover at management level
pros: The benefits were good and the environment was fun and most of my colleagues were great to work with.  The compensation and time off policies are excellent.
cons: It seems there are frequent layoffs without a lot of explanation/reason.....

headline: Mid level Manager Finance
pros: Great company if you are a Director and above...
cons: ...lower level employees don't even earn enough to afford lunch on the premises or afford to reside closer to work. Large bank offering no incentives for employees to bank with Capital One.

headline: Typical big corporation
pros: Opportunity to try new things, latest technology, work life balance however that is not as good as it use to be, benefits again not as good as they use to be, medical staff on site, culture and values are changing as well.  All use to be much better and are declining.
cons: POLITICS! Capital One use to be a big company that behaved like a small one.  Now they are a typical corporation with managers who have no business managing people, force distributions when it comes to reviews, pay is mediocre, not all jobs in the same role are the same but are compared to each other at review time.  Company has a bad habit of jumping on bandwagons and forcing huge change before understanding the ramifications, then jumping on the next new thing before the dust settles from the last.

headline: Great company, flexibile work schedule with a rewarding career path
pros: Great culture, good pay, good work life balance, for those that are willing to go the extra mile, there can be good rewards, easy to move around to other jobs within Cap One
cons: Some roles are not very analytical, but since its easy to move around, cant really consider it a major drawback. If you don't like your job role, network and find another role which is more interesting.

headline: rp
pros: was easy going. good pay. good work life bal. starting to change
cons: the next wells fargo...no place to grow at least at wells u showed ur numbers her its all politics

headline: Great organization or just Good?
pros: Work life balance.  Smart people.
cons: Passive-Aggressive behavior.  Lack of talent and actual experience of leadership.

headline: I love my job the work i do but its time for a new start with career growth.
pros: I used to love going to work enjoying my job and the atmosphere..
cons: The leadership is poor.. Its so negative til im ready to let 10 years go

headline: Too much beauracracy
pros:
- Great pay and benefits
- Good work life balance
- Smart co-workers
cons:
- Big company bureaucracy
- Office politics

headline: No room for growth
pros: I have no pros for this company
cons: Lack of room to aspire to a hirer level. Pay increases were minimal and they very rarely promoted from within & would hire unqualified people from outside the company who you spent time having to train because they did not know the in’s and outs like the senior reps who had been with the company for years.

headline: An incredible balance of challenging work and flexible working conditions
pros: Kind, smart people; Accommodating to lifestyle preferences; Competitive pay; Interesting work always kept me engaged; Excellent office environment
cons: I don't see any major cons with Capital One, but if I had to choose one, I would point out that new Business Analysts don't have FULL autonomy to choose which function they work in. That said, BAs that perform well do have a full range of opportunities.

headline: Dragged down by bank acquisitions
pros:
Many trainings provided, sometime too many.  
Work-from-home policy is dependent on team individually, but is generally flexible
Relatively good work-life balance.
cons:
Bad bet on bank acquisitions, at least so far.
Size of promotion pool shrinked year over year.
Company benefits and perks have gone downhill for a couple of years
Too much talking on strategies

headline: Great company, growth has slowed down
pros:
Good work life balance, 
good  and smart people
A lot of opportunities for training
well managed processes
cons: Lack of career growth, getting bureaucratic

headline: Great place when I started however has lost moral significantly
pros: Pay is great, bonus structure, co-workers are awesome, great benefits and vacation
cons: Trainers suck (my initial trainers were great, however after they left it went down hill) and can't answer any questions when asked, team manager is NEVER around to assist,  continue to push for OT but don't have any incentives for employees who do, Floor walkers treat you as if you are stupid when you ask a question, QAs are usually done within the last week and a half causing no roo. To improve scores in order to bonus higher, Manager never used team budget while other managers teams had team outings and food catered in almost monthly

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good work-life balance - I work 9:30-5:00. Good healthcare benefits and compensation. I also find the work interesting. I get opportunities to work on cool high tech things like Hadoop.
cons: I dislike that people are rated on a bell curve and some people must always get a bad rating, even if they are doing fine.

headline: Growth and change
pros: Employees are given lots of responsibility, and have a voice in the decision making process.  You work with a lot of bright individuals.
cons: Lots of meetings.  Decisions are made by consensus very often, which can lead to a long decision making process.  Lots of change in the organization structure and senior leadership.  Not easy to get hired - it is a lengthy process with several interviews with different levels in the company.  Not easy to get promoted.  Standard policy is that you perform in a role for six months when promoted to prove yourself.  At the end of 6 months you're evaluated to see if you actually receive the promotion - at that time, your title and salary kick in.  So, they essentially have you busting your tail for 6 months to "earn" your new salary.

headline: From an innovator to a me-too
pros: Meritocratic, empowers junior analysts to make material business decisions, strategies usually based on data, scientific tests and sound analytics, good benefits, encourages movement within the company across businesses and job functions, good internal training program, smart people.
cons: Getting more political and losing its core values as it grows through acquisition, lack of innovation in businesses other than the "bread and butter" US Card business, very limited advancement opportunities at mid management.

headline: Great first job out of College
pros: Friendly, collaborative environment with lots of benefits and great amenities. The maverick Financial services brand
cons: For a 20-something, you may butt up against the 9-5 mostly married culture. This is not an ad agency or a startup, so if you're looking for that you should think elsewhere.

headline: Now a former employer, Capital One did take good care of us as they closed our location.
pros: Commitment to communities they had a presence in was good.   Promotional opportunities existed throughout each department, even as many consolidated.
cons: Capital One is behind with grasping the benefits of remote working and focusing on large footprints in existing locations.

headline: One happy employee!
pros: Capital One has some of the best people. Talented, bright, friendly and always willing to help you develop your skills. The benefits are unmatched and there are a plethora of growth opportunities.
cons: I have no cons to discuss. I am very pleased with my experience with Capital One.

headline: Great business, people management has not kept up with growth
pros: Emotionally healthy work environment. Flexible vacation time. Great underlying business, lots of smart people, you can get really lucky with a role that sets you up for professional success.
cons: Very limit growth opportunities at entry level position. No financial rewards outside of promotions, and promotions are not available unless your role fits narrow categories that are counted in the performance management process.

headline: Ok place at best
pros:
won't terminate you without just cause
good chain of command
good hours and schedule
good work/life balance
cons:
poor recognition of employee achievements
poor starting salary
poor bonuses
poor promotion structure
poor growth (in houston market)
poor promotion opportunities

headline: Capital One is an amazing company to work for with plenty of growth opportunity.
pros: Associate investment, competitive salary, great benefits, an amazing team
cons: Standing out takes not only effort, but talent and tenure.

headline: wonderful experience
pros: Excellent training throughout the entire life of position
cons: Limited growth to be able to promote

headline: Great culture, good flexible place to work
pros: Good people that truly try to do the right thing (company motto).  Co-workers typically respect each other and are good teammates.  Work/life balance is encouraged.  Company is really good about encouraging individuality.  Pay is decent.  Change is a part of the culture, so if you're unhappy in your role, there are always chances to get into a better situation.
cons:
Senior mgmt leadership isn't that great.  The CEO is extremely well liked and motivating, but the leadership within the businesses doesn't provide much vision.  Many of those folks have risen through the ranks and have been here a long time.  Many times people are promoted for delivering a project that wasn't well planned.  All that's recognized is that the project was delivered, but few remember how poorly planned it was.  Enterprise and supporting IT groups are not well run which makes interfacing with those groups difficult.  While change is good sometimes, it also leads to learning curves in every new project.  No one really knows how to get something done because the process has recently changed.

With all this said, it's still a great company to work for.  Everywhere has it's frustrating attributes.

headline: Soul draining experience
pros: Compensation, state of the art tools, cafeteria food. Getting to the 20 word minimum for this posting has proven difficult.  There is no more to say.
cons: What you have to give up in return for compensation. Extraordinary performance is considered the norm and a bell curve is pushed, regardless of performance.  Interaction is not based on doing the right thing, it is based on whether that person will give you good 360 feedback.  Lip service is paid to culture and values.

headline: 4 years, Data Analyst
pros: Smart people all around, opportunities to learn everyday, doing cutting edge things all are mentally fulfilling
cons: Big organization, sometimes can got lost on what the company was up to. Commuting to Richmond can be too route at times.

headline: Job
pros: Not difficult.  Good people.
cons: Limited growth outside of sales

headline: Great place to lear about Banking
pros: People, location. Environment, Cafetera, Benefits.
cons: Schedules, Promotions, perks, Values, Some Customers.

headline: ABOVE the average
pros: nice working environment there. There is a small gym at the first floor.
cons: salary is not very high.

headline: Great company, but highly competitive.
pros: Lots of work life flexibility, benefits are amazing, very supportive of volunteering and supporting the community.  Lots of support of moving around within the company.
cons: Performance review process can lead to ineffective measurement of associates.  Associates are ranked against peers on a bell curve, so it's beneficial to a peer to provide negative feedback on others to increase their positivity.  Company prides themselves on hiring the best talent.  However, that means that you have a ton of smart, strong skilled individuals all competing for promotions (average promotion time is 5-6 years per level).

headline: Good Company
pros: They have great benefits and make you feel like you are an important part of the team, they have great team building excercises and you meet with your manager once a week to improve performance
cons:
No schedule flexibility
Too many managers on their high horse and are stuck up

headline: The company is true to it's values and cultures
pros: I work for Capital One 360 (formally ING Direct) and the company has done a great job transitioning ING Direct to what is now Capital One 360.  Management encourages us to be creative and think of sales strategies to boost sales and I am recognized for my accomplishments from the company.
cons: Shifts vary from week to week however management is very accommodating to my shift requests.

headline: Average comapny
pros: Many opportunities for growth in title and responsibility, but not salary.
cons: Serious salary caps and undereducated managers.

headline: Bad culture
pros: Their 401k match is pretty good but the salary isn't compatible with the market.
cons: They don't treat people right and people who's been with the company for a long time runs the show regardless effectiveness or efficiency. All power of IT is in Richmond so if you're located other than Richmond, it will be hard to be recognized.

headline: Wasn't there very long
pros: Training was very informative and not rushed
cons: Scheduling was horrible after the training period

headline: Very fun company to work for!
pros: Fun people , very smart people to work with.
cons: Line of businesses are very separated from each other, no integration.

headline: Beware
pros: depends on what supervisor you get as to your success. always hiring because there is high  turnover (aka fire people).  last summer was all over the news and web that are firing 200+ people.
cons: They will dangle the bonus of $1100 per month in front of you, but you must get 100% on your monitors to get it--and they try hard to find fault with every little thing you say so that you do not earn it. always hiring bc always firing. 4 weeks training not enough.  you get dinged on your monitors for stuff that was NEVER covered in training.  This company makes tons of $ and none of it is going to you.

headline: Capital One FRAUD DEPARTMENT, Tigard Oregon.
pros: Average insurance plan, dental plan is poor. Typical benefits of a large company. Possible future growth at Capital One, just not here in Oregon.
cons:
Pay that is below par. $12.25 for "professionals", people with experience,  people with college degrees, and people with years at the company. High turn-over due to this unbelievably low pay. Many leave for better jobs, and see Capital One only as a temporary job.
Capital One still uses cheap out sourcing of employees in Costa Rica and the Phillipines. Employees who have trained the Cap One employees there say the conditions are horrible (Manila). This company make BILLIONS AND BILLIONS of dollars in annual profits, sponsor high paid actors, NCAA tourney, have constant ads, etc.,...but can't pay wages that keep employees above Oregon's poverty level. They still mainly profit off of high interest credit cards.

headline: Principle data analyst
pros: The payment is high and the benefit package is good.
cons: The work is challenging and the people is very smart here.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Places emphasis on individual merit.
cons: Middle management can be tricky to navigate through.

headline: Awesome
pros: Great Company to work for
cons: I can not think of any cons

headline: Cool
pros: Pay location co workers hours
cons: Quotas management regional team company direction

headline: decent pay but frustrating work experience
pros: Capital One is a decent paymaster
cons: The organizations is constantly going through change. It does not let people settle down or establish long term career development goals. There are just too many people doing small components of the work, with very few understanding the end to end picture or the overall issues. It can easily downsize to 1/3 of their size if they operate in a logical, structured manner.

headline: Excellent Org
pros: Pay was decent, Great Paid Time Off, Fun Team Environment, Opportunity to work from home.
cons: Long hours. Possibly due to department new.

headline: Best Place To Work
pros: You will not be bored in any role at Capital One.  The work is fun and challenging.  You will work with extremely smart people, and you need to be just a smart. Lots of great perks
cons: For many associates, work-life balance is almost non-existent.  You will be glued to your smartphone and laptop, even on vacation.  HR consultants are wonderful, but they tend to side with their clients instead of the associate.

headline: Good place with all things counted
pros: diversified; values analytics/information driven decisions; flexible work schedule
cons: not lots of growth; My department at least has confusing management chain, teams with not clear roles and responsibilities, which end up having several teams pursuing similar initiatives.

headline: Closing in on 10 years - Pretty good ride so far, but slowing a bit
pros: Intellectually rigorous, minimal BS, For the most part meritocracy reigns !
cons: At least in the analyst community- super competitive as ambient smartness is very high !

headline: Spirit Crushing Experience
pros: Compensation - salary and bonus plan is very competitive
cons: Humanity seriously lacking in Partnership IT.  For an organization that aspires to be a high tech with a focus on mobile & digital, vision & strategy for Associates is very antiquated.

headline: Wonderful
pros: Team work wonderful work environment
cons: difficult customers, and technology wasn't up to speed with companies demand

headline: Day to Day
pros: Capital employees are outstanding to work with.
cons: Continually changing direction without thinking through how the changes will impact current processes of the business units and customers.

headline: Employee oriented company, with a culture of open communication
pros: The company has good benefits and perks for a financial services company. Management stresses on open communication. There are a lot of training opportunities for employees, and  the company wants employees to develop to their full potential. The company lives by its values.
cons: Capital One is still a very Virginia centric company, and you have to be in Virginia is you have any hopes of growing in the organization. The company is a financial services company with a consulting company's soul. So, for continued employment, you have to prove your value constantly.

headline: Ok but difficult
pros: The work itself is not hard. Pay is decent, benefits are amazing. Commission for sales as a teller is meh, but if you meet your goals, payout for customer satisfaction is good.
cons: Bank traffic is down, all over. Bank offers good product but accounts are not just plain free (minimum balance or direct deposit required), which makes sales tough. Management talks about the benefit of commission for referrals but many of the ones I bring from home cost me more than the commission I make for a month - I do it just to meet goals and help for when I want promotion.

headline: Challenging
pros: family oriented, diverse culture which is very welcoming
cons: moving departments and not placing people into different positions

headline: Customer Service Coordinator
pros: Great work enviroment. Everyone is friendly and respectful. Great pay and bonuses.
cons: We only get 32 hours of unplanned time off.

headline: I enjoyed the people I worked with but not the new philosophies that were put in place.
pros: Co-workers, incentives, neutral core values,
cons:
pay raises are so minimal that its ridiculous to even give them
if you are a new employee little more than a year they like to promote you for no good reason other than to make the morale in branch completely diminished
asking to much of you when u are just a teller like referrals etc

headline: capital is a good company to look for a job
pros: leadership, it really helps you build up professional as well as interpersonal skills
cons: stress, you will face a lot of challenge and tasks sometimes it will be stressful

headline: great company
pros: amazing culture, people, definitely the top employer among financial institutions.
cons: highly regulated industry means there are a number of slow, tedious processes

headline: Good company with oppurtunities to grow
pros: Corporate culture is great , products and services are very competitive , work life balance is slso good
cons: compensation could be better to retain good people

headline: Depressing
pros: Good pay and vacation time. Capital One gives you one month of vacation time which you can take at one time or however you choose
cons: they allow customers to harass the employees. unhappy employees equals unhappy work environment. They say they are family orientated but they are far from it.

headline: Great Company!
pros: Work-life balance. Great college-hire development programs that focus on professional and personal development of associates.
cons: Organizational shifts in resulted in lay-offs.

headline: A fast growing company still working out the kinks.
pros: Great benefits package; 401k, Medical, Dental, PTO and option for discounted stock purchase.  Competitive salary if coming from the outside.
cons: Upper Management Bureaucracy. Limited opportunities for growth. Very little career advancement opportunities.  Most promotions come from the outside.

headline: Absolutely great
pros: Everyone here is very approachable and easy to talk to, makes coming to work more fun that it deserves.
cons: Tough work that demands a lot of you.

headline: excellent salary, horrible review process
pros: If you have an honest boss, you'll know where you stand and what you need to do to perform. good volunteer opportunities. great equipment to have access to. Facebook, twitter, internet access is not restricted. If you know how to talk, write and agree, you have a future.
cons: The 10 to 20% of chance of being flagged as inconsistent, as that is a mandatory ranking for each team. Do not get on a team required to produce tangible results, those are just trouble, but get on the team over seeing them, and you'll do well.

headline: Great Company a lot of emphasis on sales
pros: I loved working here the customers were great and my branch felt like a family. The management were really understanding and everyone looked out for one another
cons: There is a lot of pressure on sales. Full time and part time employees had the same sales goals and large branches and small branches had the same goals.

headline: Worst experience ever
pros: Good people working under bad management
cons: management have no idea what they are doing, system is old, behind in banking technology. unethical sales practices.

headline: A mixed bag
pros: Informal working environment,  Very relaxed.  Casual Friday is every day.  No confrontations.  Much collaboration,
cons: Too much emphasis on PowerPoint and "hanging out your shingle."  What that means is, you spend a lot of time trying to convince everyone of how valuable you are.  And if you did not get an MBA from a business school, you are out of the club,  Everyone wears their alumni status on their sleeve.  Comp plan tends to look good on paper but will disappoint when the annual bonus time come around.

headline: Best decision I have ever made!
pros: Compensation, Gym, Cafeterias in buildings in some locations, PTO policy, company events for employee morale, Onboarding program for new hires, career development resources; employee discount program.
cons: I don't really have a con it's more so feedback. There could be some adjustments to procedures in my particular dept to have things run a bit more efficiently. A lot of things are manual when they could be more automated.

headline: It was a good overall experience.
pros: Work/Life Balance.  They have excellent health benefits and promote various charitable initiatives.
cons: It's very difficult to get promoted from within.

headline: great for new graduates
pros: good training and nice working environment
cons: high turn-over rate and too many re-orgs

headline: I love my company
pros: Many opportunities for growth, easy to advance.
cons: No cons as of yet.

headline: Great company with great values and commitment to giving back to communities.
pros: Leadership More interested in revenue than relationship.
cons: Large company culture/politics created consolidation of departments leading to job loss.

headline: A company for extremely introverted
pros:
Great work-life balance: You can find your level of commitment with respect to balancing career growth with personal interests.
Hire talented folks: They hire from great programs and consulting firm; but they do not use that talent well.
cons:
Values internal experience extremely disproportionately: If you come in with a lot of external experience, then be prepared to fail. An ideal career path is to come in out of undergrad and stay till retirement.
Very hierarchical: Operates in a very regimented top-down culture that entertains very little out-of-the-box thinking. If you are someone who wants to think strategically and tend to ideate a lot, you are likely to make enemies.

headline: Good place to start, but don't throw your talent away here!
pros: The company offers great starting salary for anyone with a Master's degree. You are given tons of training up front (in fact take advantage of an entire library of web based training). Its a good company to get your bearings of Corporate America. Their benefits are good with generous vacation and work from home policy.
cons: You are stereotyped by the role and projects you have participated in. Senior management is mostly male and are isolated from day to day activities. Expectations are high but the worst part is the tendency to focus on weaknesses and to induce anxiety over trivial details. Your talent and skills will atrophy if you stay in this company for long.

headline: Great place to work overall, management could learn a few things though!!
pros: When I worked there, I loved the culture and my co-workers.  There are also great opportunies to give back and serve the community.  If you are looking to learn and grow this is a great place to do so.  I started as a bank teller and was able to transfer to an administrative role within a year.  There are many days I miss working there, and even though it was a cutback in my department that led to me losing my position there I am forever thankful for the wonderful opportunities I had while working at Capital One.
cons: Their hiring process can be long and a bit crazy with multiple interviews on one day.  I lost my position due to cutbacks and even though I had tons of internal people trying to help me get a new position, and had excellent performance reviews, I wasn't able to find other work within.  So, even though they talk about retaining quality talent, they don't mean it when it comes to the bottom line.  However, you find that at every company.

headline: Rubbish
pros: Education Assistance, Generous PTO, Bonuses, It's a Job
cons: If you are a bully or street like in mannerism you will be favored here. Upper level management is highly incompetent and this place has extreme favoritism, Some people get to come in late everyday and not meet metric requirements, while others or stressed and worried about making good scores. Systems are always down and operates extremely slow. Pay is not great.  To sum this place up, highly toxic.

headline: Great experience and great company to work for.
pros: This is a very employee oriented company. There are a lot of opportunities to move up quickly. Great work-life balance. Great benefits and work culture.
cons: The salary is not the best when compared with competitors (other banks). There are not many opportunities with this company outside of Texas and Virginia.

headline: Excellent Opportunity
pros: Great place to work and learn
cons: Pay below levels for Field.

headline: It all depends on your direct manager....
pros:
Gift Cards & Surprise Rewards Are Frequent
Great PTO & Holiday Package
Work At Home Options In Florida, Virginia, & Deleware
cons:
There is an "in-crowd" within management. If your manager is part of that "in-crowd" AND they love you -- you are set for a fast moving career! However, if you manager is part of that "in-crowd" AND they do not like you -- your time will be short lived. If your manager is not part of that "in-crowd" then feel very lucky. 

Employee experiences vary greatly based on who your unit manager is. 

Limited opportunities for growth. 

Training seems very good and thorough while you are in it. However, once out of training, you realize it is not relevant. 

If you are hired July or later, you will not receive a raise (of any sort) for 18 months minimum. 

Each manager perceives the QA requirements very differently. So based on your team, you could have very high QAs when really your QAs should be average. Of course the opposite is true too. You could end up with very low QAs when your QAs should be very high. Bonus is based on what your QA is compared to everyone else in your department. So this issue often leads to stress in some departments.

headline: Great culture!
pros: The company provides an excellent atmosphere and leadership tries to make the job as fun as possible. Overall Capital One is a great company to work for.
cons: The pay is a little lower than is it should be for the amount of work you are required to do. Also handling escalated calls all day can wear on you when not being compensated properly for the amount of work you do.

headline: Part-time Teller II
pros: Working environment/culture is very good.  Great coworkers.
cons: Constant push to sell new accounts with daily sales goals.  Some sales goals are not based on individual but only paid if branch reaches the team sales goal.

headline: Mixed Bag - Great if you are LGBT
pros:
BENEFITS - I don't think any company's benefits are better than those at Cap One in Tampa
Onsite gym, cafeteria, garage parking
No dress code - if you wear jeans you are dressed up at this location
If you have tattoos that is considered great and acceptable - you can be yourself.
If you have a LGBT lifestyle there are many promotional opportunities, no discrimination and some departments seem to favor 
Flexible schedules for students, pay for college classes
Innovative company, great CEO, although Tampa location is not innovative, very backward
Young, inexperienced workers are promoted fast - great if that is you
cons:
You are never good enough - constant 360 feedback focuses on deficiencies not what you are doing right. 
Incentive Pay is subjective not based on customer satisfaction which you are told is the main goal
24/7 operation -  not many get weekends off - most schedules will give you a Sat or Sunday but not both off, no availability for weekend vacation time unless planned six months in advance or more
No dress code - if you wear jeans you are dressed up at this location
Managers not required to have degrees, shows in decision making
Gridlock to move ahead, not much movement - many stretch roles that require additional workload with no pay and accepting undesired schedules
Promotions are subjective based on behavioral interviews, not successful experience or education. So experience means nothing and not discussed in internal interviews.

headline: A place that never stops
pros: I would return to CapOne in a heart beat.  While I worked harder than I have ever worked there, I was rewarded with many extra perks that were immeasurable.  I have found that they expect a lot of you, but will take care of you in the process.
cons: There were times when my job required a couple of all nighters as the staffing of the team was short to cover different shifts.

headline: Good but short, declined relocation.
pros: Good pay, nice people, very collaborative environment
cons: lots of directional changes and reorgs

headline: Great place to work if you can play the game
pros: The compnay has great advancement opportunities, and if you are self motivated you can devleope a great career.
cons: There are political games, and lost some quality employees becasue they were not the favoriate.

headline: Effected by California Site Closure
pros: The benefits, work/life balance, flexible schedule, salary, bonus, were all great. I would have worked through retirement for Capital One. They are awesome and helping you grow and taking care of you
cons: At the end of the day, even though they are great to their employees, they still only care about the bottom line. I was part of the site closure in california and I am still looking for a job to replace what I had. I was a loyal and hard working employee, I think they should have been more involved in keeping the employees and repositioning us in another role.

headline: Fair company
pros:
Great benefits, decent pay for young adults just starting out, great place for career opportunities.
I enjoy working at Capital One Bank working and interacting with customers. Teaches you a lot of structure in professionalism. Co-workers and managers are very supportive, everyone works as a team which makes the environment feel equal. Also I love the fact they have a "open-door" policy which they strongly encourage employees to take advantage of.
cons: The contact center is a Business Critical Operation center where when the whole city is closed down due to inclement weather you still have to report to work. I would prefer to work in a branch where the hours are less stressful and more manageable. The company should expand as far as contact center and branches to better assist customers.

headline: Company on downward Spiral
pros: Vacation time great and benefits not bad
cons: Management, sales goals are unrealistic and customers are only a number. High goals are set when their is no difference to the competition. The customers are not valued and they only want the business, they do not care about really helping the customer by consulting with them to assess what financial products will help them verses hurt them.

headline: Analytically rigorous. Cutthroat environment!
pros:
If you like rational decision making - that's the place for you.
People are sharp, and many of them are friendly.
Nice campus.
cons:
Slow-moving environment. Be ready to tell stories through PowerPoint. 
Cutthroat culture, with very limited opportunity to move up. If you got lucky, and you are on a right project - you have a chance... AND your manager has to be ready for a fight. Otherwise, no one cares about your effort.

headline: Great like minded team
pros: Good quality team, takes reasonable good care of the team. Analytics based decisions. Flexible work schedule. Flexibility to move across teams until one finds the right fit.
cons: Promotion process while scientific is not consistent across divisions. Some get stuck at a position and some get promoted very aggressively. Took years to apply for green card because of one reason or the other

headline: Not what I was told it would be!!!
pros: A paycheck, discount at Café and Gym
cons: Pay, call volume, internet access, cell phone usage, days work has to include a weekend day, UGH!

headline: Representative
pros: Good Program for the undergraduate to start their career
cons: The upper management should work more on helping the interns

headline: Don't count on getting that $1100 monthly bonus
pros: Cardholders are nice compared to other companies I have worked for.  Few irate callers.
cons: HIGH HIGH TURNOVER. I asked one of the reps there why there is so few people and I was told "people leave". They present it as a simple job in training, but there are potentially thousands of complex details and you don't know them going in and are marked off on them. Management evaluates 5 calls per month and you don't find out until the last day of training that you have to score an 84 consistently to keep your job. They say there is no script but you are shown a basic one in training.  What they want is much more than that, and if you don't do things in a specific sequence they mark you off, and of course it is subjective according to who is grading you. I think it is so they don't have to pay you the $1100 per month bonus that they dangle for those who score 100%.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great and health work place, possible ways to grow.
cons: Too much of a red tape

headline: Capital One Auto Finance (COAF)
pros: Energetic and fun team environment, good benefits, great training.  Upper management is excellent in my experience-very dedicated.  It's a good opportunity for career auto industry people.  If you aren't 100% committed to auto finance or the auto industry in general, not only will this be a temporary gig for you but it will also have a limiting effect on future career opportunities (and good luck trying to get a Capital One recruiter to help you with an internal transfer: they are simply not interested in helping current employees).
cons: Work on the weekends, call center environment, open cubicle layout and it's business-casual despite the fact that you work over the phone all day.  Your success in the role is highly dependent on a lot of other people, i.e. teammates, customers, managers, underwriters, employers, etc., so a lot of things (including your success in this position) can be and are out of your control. Career opportunities rapidly diminish past the senior relationship manager role, so be prepared to relocate to Plano, TX for COAF advancement.  "Senior" Relationship Managers are mostly young with little to no prior management experience.

headline: Very depressing place to work regardless of the benefits!
pros: Benefits, schedule flexibility, paid training at regular salary.
cons: The type of work is beyond depressing, its a call center no matter how the company tries to tell you that its totally different than any other call center. Being monitored constantly especially when dealing with angry or upset customers most of the time is just not worth the decent pay and benefits. The software used to handle customer accounts is very flawed and so is the process used to carry out certain customers requests such as credit limit increases. Employees are not given any information to explain everything needed to customers, making them angry most of the time. Just sitting in the chair all day taking calls is too depressing, definitely the worst job I have had and I understand why they try to pay decent and offer benefits because the job is so depressing! Also it seems like advancement to manager or CAT is based heavily on social factors instead of merits. The company claims to have customers service on par with Discover and Amex, but the in-call requirements and structure required to receive high quality scores completely prevents an agent from having any shot at replicated the magnificent customer service received with Discover and Amex. I have both cards so I know first hand.

headline: very stressful place to wok
pros: have good health benefits,generous paid time off
cons: have mandatory shift bids,if business needs change have to bid,shifts include every weekend which leaves little time for family,promised to make lots,bounus and raises generally small,no shift differential unless shift after 10 pm or later

headline: I wish there was more opportunity for advancement.
pros: Somewhat flexible schedules and their 401k for part-timers is a plus
cons: Takes ridiculously long to move up the ladder or get recognized for success

headline: One of the best companies I have worked for, they value their employees and their customers.
pros: Flexible with hours and has extreme integrity.
cons: They are down sizing to keep processes smooth and simple.

headline: Repossession Coordinator
pros: Good medical, dental benefits. paid time off
cons: Bad work atmosphere, lack of communication with supervisor - not much opportunity for advancement

headline: good benefits, poor upward mobility in retail
pros: Good comparative pay, easy during down times. great benefits
cons: Little opportunity to move up. Separation between retail and corporate is vast

headline: IT Manager
pros: Great management support across all towers, good work life balance, since insourcing has begun it is getting better and better as more resources are brought internally.
cons: High expectations, if that can be a con but I guess the largest challenge has been learning the internal flow if things but not too rough if you take good notes of your resources you will be just fine.

headline: Watch your back
pros: Great onsite gym. Work at home options, though not as frequently accepted since Yahoo no longer allows this.
cons: Politics, politics politics. Who you know and who you are related to matters more than results.  IT infrastructure is a joke. Capital One credit card log in page is always down.

headline: My experience was not great
pros: Good benefits, the West Creek campus was nice and had lots of amenities and the customer experience is important.
cons: Titles are vague. There are Process Managers that have zero process experience, the mobile aspect of the campus is frustrating since there's a lack of seating available and org charts aren't available for the LOB's.

headline: Capital one Tigard
pros: Benefits start on the first day, good benefits,401k. Nice employees, managers are mostly friendly. Some extra perks.
cons:
The pay is very low for quality workers with experience and degrees. Pay is just above Oregon's minimum wage. With incentives, most make mid 20s to low 30s. My coworkers need government assistance to get by. These are not livable wages in the Portland market.
There is no growth in the first year, and there are few chances of advancement at the Tigard location.

headline: risk assoicate
pros: good benefits, employee recognition, and family fun days
cons: call center environment. you are on a automated dailer

headline: its ok
pros: the pros at Capital One is the growth.
cons: The cons of Capital One is the management is not all on one accord. They are against you not for you.

headline: Company success has moved too fast for employee mindset to keep pace
pros:
Easy workloads, so work life balance is very easy to achieve
Good benefits
Nice work environments
You'll meet some really great people
cons: The company has grown fast. But, the traditional and limited real world experience of its large Richmond employee base has not been able to keep pace. Mind sets are slow to evolve and there's a total lack of real experience, but a mindset that they think they are great and better than everyone around.  A company who grew up in Richmond has to grow up and out of its old ways of thinking or it will be taken over by the likes of smarter and better players like The Wall Street banks.

headline: Mixed Messages
pros: Talented, dedicated, competitive people who are selected for the power of their ideas. The people that excel there are truly deserving and every day I realize how exceptional the people that work here are.
cons: the super-competitive people that Capital One hire are graded on how well they cooperate with others, then put into a super-competitive 360 review/forced ranking process that amplifies small errors.

headline: Below Poverty wages for fortune 100 company.
pros:
Nice employees/co-workers. Average  benefits.
There isn't too much positive to say when a company that makes BILLIONS pays below poverty wages, and just above MINIMUM wage. It's CEO's are paid multi-millions.
cons: This company pays in Portland/Tigard area employees 12.25 hourly, which isn't far above Oregon's minimum wage. Most employees receive government aid such as food stamps to get by. The cost of living in Oregon is far above what one can earn here. Many take the bus and share apartments just to get by. We constantly hear how this company make BILLIONS in profit, and how they are a FORTUNE 100 company, yet they pay wages WAY BELOW the average. Fast food workers and dishwasher make more here in Oregon. They try to sell the company as caring, and constantly give the employees their "Kool-aid". Many  employees have college degrees and prior experience, yet are still paid poorly.

headline: Slow growth, shrinking careers
pros: Surround yourself with really smart people working in a great culture. Good work life balance and interesting work
cons: Company growth has slowed after recent acquisitions, especially in the credit card segment which is the largest. If you're not working on the top 2-3 projects considered important by very senior management, you are in a career dead end

headline: Great Culture, still getting established as a bank, technology sucks
pros: The environment is great, they treat employees right, company events, competitive products.
cons: The technology is very outdated, everyday tasks are very tedious and lots of paper work, no imaging system, lots of paperwork to print out and have to keep track of, system is antiquated, have to use 3 separate systems to figure out a simple request. Online banking is also outdated cannot have the same login for credit cards and deposit accounts, don't have actual partners in branch such as mortgage and business, one financial advisor in Houston, Book of business is new to company and  is hard to navigate compared to other institutions.

headline: Great Company to start banking career!
pros: Great training program, easy systems to learn, management that care about your growth, flexible work hours, great benefits, and great team environment.
cons: Job advancement can be difficult passed certain management levels. Company looks outside to fill major job roles instead of looking within. There is also a constant shift in strategic initiatives.

headline: great
pros: good culture, atmosphere, work ethics
cons: very competitive, bad salary, too much politics

headline: Lots of perks, lots of layoffs and turnover
pros:
Perks:  West Creek gym, best cafeterias I have seen in the corporate world, good insurance, ESSP, etc.
Campus setting is pretty to look at.
Intelligent people (for the most part) to work with.
Generous severance package
cons:
Cutthroat environment.  They are in massive "redeployment" (layoff) mode.  The good news is that the severance is so good and the morale is so bad that many people like me took the money and ran.  Meanwhile, there is a constant stream of new college hires walking in.

Richmond associates are being asked, then begged, then forced (or get redeployed) to move to Willmington, DE.

Cross calibrations/Performance reviews are a year round process.  It is all based on comparisons to your peers throughout the company who are all working on different types of projects.  This means it is a back room process with your manager fighting (or not) with the other managers to see who gets what raises & promotions.  Read up on your Machiavelli if you want to survive here.

headline: capital one
pros: great culture and flexibility with working remotely
cons: limited growth opportunities for those that are not complacent

headline: Great company
pros: Smart people, fast paced, values diversity and inclusion
cons: In some cases, I have seen priorities changing a bit too fast

headline: Great company until your path crosses with one of the bad people manager.
pros: Compensation & Benefits. Nice campus on the outskirts of Richmond, VA. Nice colleagues in general.
cons: Lot of internal politics. This company is riddled with bad people managers many of them former technical staff, particularly in IT department. The performance management process is vicious and is often used for exacting revenge by these managers. This company come under a spell from time to time when senior employees get fired almost randomly.

headline: Capital One is a great company to grow within
pros: Growth opportunities, great sales goals,
cons: banking job security, low pay in banking industry in general

headline: Company with no vision for the Capital One Bank
pros: Great Medical, Dental and Vision benefits
cons:
Layoff is the order of the day. There is a regular massive layoff due to what the senior leadership describe as 'restructuring'. Capital One is so convinced they will lay people off regularly that they have a Career Development Center office in their Richmond location and works with a company called LHH to help their laid off employees transition out of the company.

Additionally, the annual  employee performance review is not based necessarily on how well you have performed over the past year but how you compare to others in the same level but who may not be doing anything related or close to what you are doing. Your annual bonus depends on how well your manager can represent you in the presence of other managers and/or how well or badly everybody in your level did over the previous year.

headline: Repo Associate
pros: Great place to work, good pay, great management
cons: None None None None

headline: Good Company for the Right Fit
pros: Great company for recent grads that network well. This is a very promising opportunity for individuals with a strong Capital One centric network before joining the company.
cons: (Richmond Campus) Company creates an extremely cut throat environment that favors cookie cutter behavior.  Capital One definitely favors individuals in their 20’s that can be groomed to fit their corporate behavior. Unfortunately Capital One favors and promotes individuals based on relationships (i.e. family members, church members, close friends) with established Associates. Also there are frequent shifts in management (new Manager approximately every 6 months to a year). Capital One is a very different company since its early innovative years, but still successful.

headline: The analyst intern
pros: For a student like me, it is really a dream place. It has good salary and develope your skill in analyzing. If I can work there, I will be so happy.
cons: I don't think I have the qualifies to say anything wrong with this company. It offers so many opportunities to students. It's really nice.

headline: Senior Program Manager
pros: Some teams allow you to work from home a few days a week
cons:
Compensation - pay is low and merit increases are horrible yet the company gave shareholders dividends last year. "Strong" and "Very Strong" ratings can net you less than 2% - with inflation you lose money! 
With it being a relatively young company, some employees have been promoted by virtue of just being here a long time. Some have held no other jobs outside of COF and are unable to bring different perspectives to the table as a result. Promotions are also garnered politically; work horses aren't often rewarded. 
Analyst turnover is high leaving many teams under-staffed and top heavy.

headline: I worked at Capital One for a year
pros: Potential to earn good bonus money.  Benefits all start on day one.
cons: Scoring of calls can be objective and this effects your bonus.  Little flexibility for time off especially on weekends,

headline: Not terrible, not great either
pros: Friendly folks for the most part.  Vacation policy is really very limited, but can be mitigated with purchased vacation time.  They understand that you have a life outside and do not try to "own" you.
cons: Management doesn't always know what's going on with their business.  Seems that there's a disconnect at times - grassroots ideas come up but cannot adequately be brought to the management team.  Often those ideas either do not get any visibility or they get implemented but after a totally unnecessary wait.

headline: Talks the talk, but does not walk the walk
pros: Very selective hiring process ensures above average talent.  Benefits are ok but not great.
cons: They hire talented people with diverse backgrounds, but once you are on board your opinion means nothing. Calibrations and forced rankings causes a "Lord of the Flies" mentality to reviews instead of evaluating people on the merits of their work.

headline: Status quo rises -- swim hard or you'll sink
pros: The majority of the associates are incredibly smart and driven. Salaries and benefits are good -- the vacation is especially generous, but it can be hard to find time to take it.
cons:
Performance management pits employees against each other, and takes up 2-3 months every year. If you're willing to put in a lot of work over and above your normal role, you can get promoted, but the bar rises every year.  

The culture is very meeting-based; it's common to find yourself without a spare minute all day, and then you still have to do your "real work."

headline: Great company to work for
pros: A lot of lateral movement within the company and tons of opportunity for promotion.
cons: Limited locations in the retail banking department in comparison with national banks like Wells Fargo.

headline: It is extremely stressful.  They talk about work life balance but it is impossible to achieve.
pros: Most associates are willing to assist
cons: Management is often disconnected from the actual needs of the position.

headline: Highly recommend working here, if someone is interested in a financial services career
pros: One of the better places to work, both in terms of work quality and work-life balance
cons: It's harder to grow within the organisation now, as compared to a few years ago.

headline: Formerly a good place to work
pros: High energy place, smart people around, quality of work
cons:
The card division had worsened over the years. Politics had taken root in the culture. From being a fair and progressive company, the place had become a joke. 
The management selects a bunch of individuals based on perception and then gives them a free pass to success. The selection is purely based on perception rather than true results. The place was hell bent on showing how open it is to certain historically disadvantaged groups and gave favorable benefits to them inspite of work not upto the mark.  (Hint: if you are from such groups might not be a bad idea to join )
Promotions especially to the dir level make no sense, its purely driven by who "likes" you!

headline: Micromanaging ego maniacs
pros: Amazing co-workers, positive pay when higher from outside
cons: Negative management micromanagement terrible pay for those who are promoted from within

headline: Just pretending to be a bank
pros: Benefits are ok and work from home option are available.
cons: Salary lags behind peers and the Company is over reliant on outside consultants.

headline: Great People. Great Company.
pros: Teamwork. Good People. Opportunities to move up within company. Quarterly fun days (team building) - think field trip for adults.
cons: Very cost focused - sometimes can lead to making decisions based on short term outcomes.

headline: Funding Analyst
pros: Good Benefits, Nice Campus , Diversity
cons: Auto Finance does not care about home life, if your not  SUPER TOP PRODUCER they don't care about you.

headline: Great Company
pros: Took very good care of their employees
cons: Didn't pay enough for the type of stress you were under  at times

headline: Odd experience
pros: Loads of great talent, you'll work with some of the best imaginable.
cons: Management is a farce. Corporate politics is the only game in town, if you're not willing to drink the Kool Aid you won't last.

headline: Anonymous Remarketing Employee
pros: Good benefits, 401k, average healthcare benefits
cons: Be ready to work without being compensated! Company profits are great, but not shared with those that produce it. Only good friends get raises, bonuses and promotions---not those that perform. I do not know who votes this company as one of the best places to work.

headline: Capital One is a "Monet" - pretty from a distance, a big mess up close
pros:
Work/life balance - associates are allowed to work from home when needed (at "manager's discretion" of course; if your manager's a jerk, good luck).  Capital One also pays fairly well and encourages associates to volunteer regularly.

I think your experience at this company really depends on your role and the organization you report into.  It only takes one senior leader to make your department miserable.  I switched departments a few years ago and was relatively happy before.  But not now!
cons:
The company is unstable, quietly laying off over 700 associates last October; this is the third round of layoffs since I began work there in 2010.  Attrition has been extremely high at the Sr. Leadership level; over half of the CEO's direct reports are new to the company within the last few years.  Of course any turnover is always followed by the "everything's fine" email or meeting.  

The health benefits are also horrible.  Extremely high (over $1k a month for a family) monthly premiums, PLUS a deductible, PLUS 20% coinsurance.  And that's their best plan!  Anyone with ongoing medical problems knows that's completely unaffordable.  

The performance management system is garbage too, forcing associates into "distribution buckets" (you could be an awesome worker, but if they need someone to go into the "inconsistent" bucket, it could be you!).  

Capital One preaches diversity of thought and it's always about "the associates" in the annual strategy meetings, but it's all a bunch of b.s.  The dumb ones just eat it up, though!  For the record, I'm super low on the totem pole.  I've always been rated a v. strong or strong and have no issues with my manager.  I'm just not stupid, I see the writing between the lines and I don't feed into the crap that others do.  

If you don't work in Richmond (their biggest campus) you miss out on 90% of the "perks" that make this company one of "Fortune 100's Best Companies to Work For".

headline: Be Warned - If You Don't Play the Game, You Will Get Booted Out!
pros: Good benefits and nice perks at West Creek - that's about all I can say...
cons:
(1) Raises, bonuses, and promotions are based on how others view you instead of the quality of the work that you do - if you are a good "politician", then you will excel here.  This leads to people being promoted into people management positions that have no idea what it takes to really manage people.  Rewarding people who do nothing but socialize with higher ups is not the way to run an organization.
(2) Very stressful environment where backstabbing and politics are common - I was placed on a PIP because I asked to change managers and the PIP contained untrue information about my work performance.  After my PIP was completed and I did everything I was told to do, I was told that I didn't meet expectations and let go - with a huge severance and the option for re-hire.  This is due to the fact that they knew I could sue them for gender discrimination and disability discrimination (I ended up having to go on stress medication due to the bullying I endured at Capital One).  Severance letter released me from being able to file legal action.  In my entire career, I have had better than satisfactory performance reviews and have been promoted over and over again - I have never been written up for performance in my entire life until now.  They have trashed my reputation and my career.
(3) This company has a known reputation for being a horrible place to work.  When I mentioned my experience to people who don't work at Capital One (such as my doctor), their reply is always that they have heard this happening several times with other people.

headline: Logistics wins over talent
pros: Great benefits, great people, great culture
cons: Low salary/bonus structure, no transparency

headline: Really great company to work for that shows support and appreciation for their employees
pros: The company believes in promoting from within.  Mangers are really concerned about their employees and seeing them grow.  Always encouraging and providing support.  Never a problem with flexibility and allowing the option of working from home.
cons: Don't have any issues.  I'm happy.

headline: Senior Accounts Specialist
pros: The recognition for hard work is great
cons: Theres a lot of favoritism and micromanagement.  Raises are roughly 18cents, mandatory shift changes, not so family friendly

headline: Great Benefits but not sure it out weighs all the other problems ...
pros: Benefits, On-site doctor, On-site gym, Great cafeteria, On-site Starbucks
cons: Poor communication between upper management and associates

headline: very comfortable and flexible environment
pros: very comfortable and flexible environment
cons: not specific cons, hard interview

headline: Great place if that's all you want to do
pros: Great people, decent management, fun activities and they like to feed you
cons: Not a good place for a single parent as you will have to work a weekend and most likely start in nights which means no time for children. Also no time for school unless you take online classes. Lots of favoritism as well.

headline: One of the better companies
pros:
Great benefits: Paid time off, dental, medical, 401k, stocks, and more
Competitive starting salary 
Good mission
cons:
The job loses the "new car" feel quickly
Policies and rules change so often, it can feel like you don't know what's going on
Upper management (at least at this site) is stuck in old ways and processes

headline: the statistician job in capital one
pros: I heard the work environment is great in capital one and the colleagues are nice too
cons: This is a amazing place to work in, if you have chance just try it!

headline: Entry-Level access provides a good start at a reputable company and lots of opportunities for advancement.
pros: The paid time off is great, the company culture is fantastic as far as the incentives and employee activities, and the location of the office is a great fit for me.
cons: The pay is low in relation to my previous employment, the weekend hours are not the best fit for my schedule either.

headline: Good pay, great work life balance
pros: Great work life balance for a job in the financial sector.  Strong pay, but not IB level.  Extremely smart people.
cons: Difficult to advance if you're not qualified or skilled enough (i.e. time spent with the company is not rewarded).  Little pay advancement without moving job levels.  Culture is shifting towards a more formal bank.

headline: Where do i start
pros: PTO, 401K Matching, Tuition Reimbursement
cons: Poor Management, Excessive meetings, It really depends on who the manager is to decide if you like the company cause they can either be laid back and down to earth or hellish and possibly be a big dissapointment.

headline: I had a very good experience working at Capital One
pros: The montly bonuses were very good,
cons: They laid off many talented  workers from California . It was hard to advance with this company.

headline: Great People but politically charged, disconnected management who seem to solve problems by changing strategy
pros: pay and benefits are good as is the work-life balance
cons:
working in silo; like knowing 'why' is unnecessary
Little information shared between groups - if you share you lose

headline: Great Company to Work For
pros:
- Highly analytical
- Excellent work environment
- Working with very intelligent people
- Flexible work environment, work from home, etc
- Ever changing environment
- Opportunity to explore new career options and roles
cons:
- Competitive
- Forced distribution performance management
- Promotions limited to 10-12% of teams (or less) depending on group

headline: Great Work Environment.
pros: Good to work if you have a great team to spend your time in the branches
cons: not really anything wrong. you get what you should expect

headline: Good and challenging work
pros:
1. Challenging work
2. Great work facilities
3. Lot of internal politics between people in Richmond
cons:
1. Forced Rankings
2. Hard to get a good raise or promotion

headline: Good pay, terrible management/environment
pros: Good pay/benefits, excellent facilities (west creek).  Also a lot of very sharp people there.  If you're the civil service/gov't worker type who thinks they can just "get by," think again. that won't fly here, which I found refreshing.
cons:
Management is the worst I have ever seen.  Oh they're sharp too, but for starters, there are are ridiculous number of managers...and some seem to exist mostly to tell other managers to get the work done, apparently having no idea how to actually do (or even guide) any of it themselves (ironically, they're usually the ones making the big bucks).  A lot of micromanagement as well, ie emphasis on creating reports/"tickets"/etc detailing what you've done - sometimes I swear half the job was saying what you did for your job.

Also it is the "coldest" place I have ever worked; teamwork gets lip service but is non-existent.  Why?  Mostly because managers care *nothing* for their employees - especially contractors, who they treat more like a disposable resource than human beings.  They have layoffs one minute, then start hiring back the next.  Training also ranges from weak to non-existent.  

Frankly I think most people hate it there (walk around the campus - you won't see many people smiling, but you will see a lot of stern/angry faces), but stay either because the pay is good or they just haven't found anything else in this tough economy.   

PS:  if you're Indian, that's a HUGE plus; I'd say about 1/3 to 1/2 of all people there are, even though they're a very small minority in the Richmond area.  Draw your own conclusions.

headline: Great Learning experience
pros: Benefits, work life balance, internal job opportunities, Highly reputed Analyst Development program for new joiners,  young company and leadership, Great company to begin your professional journey especially if you join straight from college
cons: Promotion process, Lack of clarity on goals, Not so great for experienced hires, more generalist approach to complex problems in business

headline: Good experience in knowing a variety of back end processes related to auto financing
pros:
Variety of work
Good opportunities - load, performance and automation testing
cons: Last moment changes are some times mandated

headline: I feel like I finally landed my dream job!
pros: Great job with great pay and benefits, friendly and fun co-workers, nice building with gym and cafeteria (there is some delicious food being served up!), family atmosphere because so many people here know each other outside of work!
cons: I don't personally know any but I'm guessing some jobs here might not be as fun, like Fraud or Collections.

headline: Great values, complicated execution.
pros: Great work environment. Attracts a good number of outstanding employees.Company Values as told by CEO are exceptional and quite prominent. Benefits, holidays, and hours are all very agreeable.
cons: Lower management can be fickle with corporate values. Uncertain balance of values vs. numbers. Still a relatively young bank with room for improvement. Hopefully will level out during the coming year.

headline: Awesome place to grow your career, especially for newbies
pros:
You are surrounded by amazing people, and the energy is infectious. You can came a long way very quickly as a new hire, especially because of the Analyst Development Program trainings and networking opportunities.

There is a formal review process, so if you are good, you can move up quickly. I increased my salary by 50% in 2.5 years due to generous raises and fast promotions. Capital One is a feedback culture, so you can always learn how to improve. You can tell your boss candid ways for him to improve as well (and he actually acts upon it).

Every day is different. You can keep pushing yourself to learn more, and it's relatively easy to change roles if you find something more aligned with your interests.

The CEO makes it a point to talk to the entire company once a year, even though it requires him renting out huge theaters all across the country and spending several days repeating the same speech. Capital One also has the most ethical practices in the credit-card industry (i.e., we don't want to make money by tricking people into fees), and they are always pushing to get better.
cons:
Job roles can be siloed. Data analysts can code without knowing the business context, and business analyst can try to do their jobs without having a grasp of coding. That said, if you are motivated, you can switch between teams / job roles here easily, or expand on your current responsibilities.

You will work with many people from the HSBC acquisition who aren't the same caliber of talent / motivation

If you live in Northern Virginia, you are sometimes the only person in your office working on a project with 10 people from Richmond. Get used to the phone and / or the company shuttle.

headline: Data Oriented Culture with really smart people.
pros: Puts an emphasis on hiring smart people - definitely leans to more mathematical intelligence than interpersonal/innovation.
cons: Very model driven to the extent that other opportunities for improvement or gap identification are missed

headline: Great Company
pros: Work/Life balance; Compensation package; Excellent training
cons: Like most large companies, can be very bureaucratic.

headline: Equity Research Analyst
pros: Good exposure to coverage companies by virtue of analyst role
cons: Poor brand name. Pay is less than 25% of the street. Hours are terrible, sales/trading staff are mostly mentally handicapped

headline: Branch Manager
pros: Good Products, Decent Hours and Benefits, Company cares about associates
cons: Long Island Management has little care for associates.  The general ideal and benefits offered to associates does not make its way to Long Island nor through Management.  Mostly prior Chase associates being hired - becoming Chase One.

headline: Good pay, horrible environment and incompetent mgt
pros: They pay is very competitive, as good or better than most other IT places (at least in the central VA area), though not by a huge margin.  Their West Creek "campus" is a nice place to work, facilities-wise.
cons:
Management, mostly; it's a joke.  They swap contractors in and out in this perpetual revolving door, treating them like 2d class citizens (if even human beings at all).  Worse, they're constantly shuffling positions, cutting them short out of the blue, laying off people one minute and hiring the next.  Further, most managers and even some of the more veteran staff are very stand-offish, with their little cliques and nothing in the way of genuine friendliness to outsiders coming in - again only barely enough for CYA purposes.  To them, "team spirit" is nothing more than annoying cliche they give a little lip service to, if that.  

It is - by FAR - both the least stable and "coldest" place I have ever worked.  The little extra money one might (might) get working there is not worth the stress of working at a place you hate - and unless you get REALLY lucky, you'll hate it, trust me.

headline: Capital One is a great company to work for!
pros: People that work here are smart and like their jobs. Very collaborative environment. Easy to manage work/life balance with flexible schedule and ability to work at home.
cons: Company doesn't really value "ground up experience." After reaching the Associate/Sr. Associate level, a lot of people leave Capital One to work someone else for a year and then come back to make $20-30k more a year.

headline: good exp
pros: very good work environment which helps in long term stay
cons: not a good one for IT guys

headline: Great
pros: good company to work for
cons: Not many opportunities to relocate

headline: Data Warehouse Manager
pros:
Work/life balance is emphasized and co-workers are pleasant
Time off when needed is viewed positively
cons:
Management does not provide a cohesive vision
Long time employees do not share knowledge readily
To much hiring and Layoffs every 3 or so years  even the most experienced are not spared

headline: good stable company, good benefits, poor growth
pros: people are great to work with
cons: hiring too much, no room for growth, lack of communication from upper management

headline: Great experience in the retail bank. Just bought ING Direct. Should be a positive for that business. Credit card busines
pros: People were smart and like their jobs. Opportunity to change roles every year to try new areas, even across business lines. Job is very flexible to personal needs or work from home desires.
cons: The culture is a little political. Difficult to get the ball rolling on something new/different. Many layers of management before getting to a decision maker. Headquarters in Tysons Corner, not a desirable place in my opinion.

headline: Above average! Loved working from home!
pros: I love that I was able to work from home from the date of hire, the pay is good for the job that is asked, and the job is really easy. I love the fact that Capital One is all about the customer, I love that they encourage employees to have a genuine conversation with customers.
cons: I understand that dealing in customer service you get the occasional jerk, but I don't believe that an employee should feel that they have to listen to a customer that is berating them.

headline: Intellectually strong group of people with a culture of doing things the Capital One way.
pros: Strong group of associates (the COF term for employees) with keen analytical skills - usually recruited from tiered colleges. Salaries are OK. Work life balance is good. Culture of intellectuality is pervasive.
cons: Rigid culture that does not readily accept ideas from the outside. Advancement is highly dependent on being a club member; use of COF nomenclature; college you came from.

headline: Relaxed place to work
pros:
Work/Life Balance 
Focus of individual development
Very easy to change roles
Flexible work hours/work from home
cons:
Very competitive
Opaque performance management
Pay on the lower end of competetion

headline: Pay okay, Management horrible, Capital One as a company, great.
pros: Capital One is a great company with great benefits. Culture is amazing.
cons: Management is not reliable and plays favorites.

headline: An overall mediocre company with lofty goals that they will have difficulty achieving.
pros: They have decent pay, good benefits, and time off perks. Aetna health provides health incentives. The organization and policies reflect a lgbt friendly atmosphere. For me it was a convenient location, with a carpool bonus and a good severance package when I was laid off.
cons: It was a difficult work environment, with unclear policies and unsupportive supervisors. Being in a frontline phone position is demanding work, and the company is unsympathetic. In addition, the workplace is old, poorly maintained, and not very clean.

headline: Great career experiences despite mediocre people managers
pros: Quality people, ability to find new career paths
cons: Performance management process is inconsistently applied; people management not a core competency

headline: Bring your "A" game
pros: Entrepreneurial environment, passionate associates, consensus-based organization, massive investments in their employees
cons: Too many processes to get basic things accomplished, has become extremely bureaucratic

headline: Dreadful and a waste of time
pros: They had an overnight shift, the benefits were ok and the pay was about average
cons: Capital one does not care about you, they care about their bottom line. If you want job security you may want to consider another option. Capital One is notorious for laying off departments on a regular basis.

headline: Great pay, great overall focus and ideals
pros: The company wants to do the right thing, it cares about it's employees and customers.
cons: It's in transition mode with new acquisitions over the last few years; the organization is identifying how to work with individuals and teams not located at headquarters.

headline: Very Dynamic place to work
pros: Tremendous opportunity to learn, company supports lots of educational opportunities.
cons: You are ALWAYS looking for a new job - either within the company about every 6 months or you will be looking outside the company. Senior folks will be happy to use you to further their project but contribute little to yours. Performance reviews very subjective and are force fit to a curve.

headline: Customer Service Associate
pros: Capital One had very good pay and benefits package. Most of the management was very good and seemed to care about employees.
cons: Working customer service made it seem like customers were always angry at the company. This was caused by the fact that only people with problems call the center. Recommend associates work hard in order to transfer to another area of company.

headline: Great partners at Capital One Bank.
pros: Many of the Bankers, Branch Managers, Financial Consultants and TELLERS believed in insurance.  They knew that I was the only knowledgable and competent insurance agent many of their clients would ever have a chance to meet and I got to help many people who needed my services.  The Bankers and other partners uncovered these needs and made the introductions!
cons: I didn't get to meet as great a variety of the Bank clients as I would have liked.  There was no mandate to introduce, I only got to meet the "low hanging" fruit so to speak.  There were many opportunities that were left "un-met".

headline: Good experience
pros: Good team and support for associates
cons: Low salary and unrealistic goals

headline: Live in DC metro, Get paid like you live in Birmingham, AL
pros: Company has some very smart people and has upgraded finance talent over the last few years.
