cons: If you work in capital markets / risk you will not be compensated appropriately.  You would be better off looking for jobs in the South or Midwest - the pay is the same.  The company's high turnover in these roles is driven by poor / inexperienced management (in some cases), poor compensation, and poor work / life balance (in many cases driven by lack of or undeveloped processes).

headline: Horrible Company
pros: Nothing good ever came from working here
cons: It like working for a cult. They treat everyone like children. They also allow their emloyees to be sexually harassed by their employees and then do nothing about it.

headline: Ok company. Salary is competetive. Hours are manageable. If youre lucky to be in a good branch youll like the environmen
pros: Good working conditions. Good vacation and benefits
cons: Not a lot of room to move up depending on the branch.

headline: Growing company with sluggish upward mobility
pros: Smart people, rapidly growing business, great culture, prioritization of work/life balance, and high certainty of job security
cons: Compensation significantly below market level, sluggish advancement opportunity,

headline: Like most other large companies, nice people do indeed finish last.  Sycophants need only apply
pros:
Big company with great opportunities to learn and sharpen skills
You work with brightest and best people
Great regional compensation
Nice campus
cons:
Performance management process does not encourage associate alignment to corporate goals
Senior leadership's perpetual flip-flops on strategy, goals, vision undermines associate confidence
Poorly managed budgets and headcount frequently result in across the board staff reductions

headline: Overall good experience even though they eliminated my position
pros: good company with good values, generally care about employees and try to do the "right thing", one of the core values
cons: Sometimes decisions made do not make sense and are not clear.  Politics play a big part, like any big company.  Constant change in policies and proceures

headline: Great company to work for with good perks
pros: Very flexible, great benefits, good for the resume
cons: Job security, evaluations are totally subjective

headline: Pretty good depending on branch and district
pros: reasonable pay, manager wants you to grow and is willing to teach
cons: lots of gossip, unfair treatment based on personal liking, more hours please!

headline: This company really values its associates, understanding that is the best way to deliver value to its customers.
pros:
Diversity of talent and ideas
Forward thinking
Open door management culture
Focus on continuing education
Compeling company mission
Vast array of associate benefits
Very competitive pay structure for Richmond VA area
cons:
Burdensome (but generally fair) performance management process that makes otherwise 'A' players feel like 'B' or C' players.
Coordinates and incentivizes line of business behaviors, versus customer centric behaviors (but this changing).

headline: Great place to start a career
pros:
Exceptional culture, everyone seems to really enjoy working here. Great benefits, work-life balance, and  Inspirational senior management have the company headed in the right direction. Lots of very smart employees that are excited to work there. 

Strong focus on employee learning and development, career growth, and diverse experience to find the right fit for you.
cons:
This company is behind the ball digitally. Old systems and IT infrastructure make data-based decision making difficult to come by, especially in certain departments. 

The culture is not as "open" as they would like you to believe. People don't speak their mind for fear of retribution. 

Strong bureaucratic environment, tons of processes that make accomplishing anything substantial very difficult.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Wonderful company to work at. Great people, flexible hours, challenging job.
cons: Can't really think of anything!

headline: Good company, but needs to get itself together
pros: Everyone was very kind and I loved the benefits. Starting pay was great as well.
cons: Capital One doesn't do on-the-job training for call center jobs, so it can be difficult if your first phone job. Management seems disconnected at times and I have seen some people in positions they really weren't qualified for, which makes it hard on everyone.

headline: Fantastic work-life balance, if you are willing to do the sales grind.
pros:
Work-life balance is phenominal, they want employees to be rested and have a life
Constantly training so you are not doing this alone
Great sense of district-wide comradory and competition
Management seems to only get on your case if you are failing to actually work
Capital One really strives to be a different kind of bank, it's fun to watch the company constantly evolve
cons:
Several different systems needed to perform daily functions will drive you crazy
Don't have down-time to catch up on the mountains of paperwork
Interdepartment collaboration is non existant, everybody uses a different system
Your "big money" success depends on your business and investment partners, if you have a good one they will help you, if you have lazy ones you will absolutely fail

headline: Overall a great experience with the company and management.
pros: Very open and creative environment
cons: attenuated growth, stiff competition landscape

headline: Very good, fast paced company
pros: Great people, benefits & pay
cons: Heavy work load, a lot of change, regular layoffs

headline: Okay place, but not great.
pros: Great co-workers, while they were still there.
cons: A lot of employee turnover. And some of the customers were dreadful, but that's just how the public is.

headline: Great Company
pros:
Work/Life Balance
Great Company Culture
Cares About Employees
Transparent
Great Benefits
Career Advancement
cons: Pay is lower and takes a while to get a raise

headline: My experience was fair. Several times took me several emails and calls to get a hold of someone in the HR department.
pros: Not working hours on Sunday.
cons: Retail banking salary is very low.

headline: Mortgage Banker
pros: Good incentives like Heath, FSA and 401K that company contributes.
cons: Poorly trained Managers with no skills. Training Is not needs based but based on old course modules.

headline: The worst ever performance review system and a massive amount of politics.
pros: Modern facilities, clean and well kept.
cons: Nearly everything after the initial 3 month period

headline: Long hours low pay. Overwhelming amount or work in relation to staff level
pros: Room for advancement if you can put in the hours
cons: The hours needed to put in are enormous to get work done and the pay is not equal to the work

headline: Great company.
pros: Talented group of people.  Company strategy and senior leadership has been spot on.  Excellent career development with opportunities to rotate.  Company invests in associates, and there's good work/life balance.
cons: Performance management system is overwrought and time consuming.  At it's worst can contribute to decision paralysis and discourage innovation.

headline: A quality company to work for
pros: Capital One values employees with a strong analytical skill set.  Company leverages that analytic skill set to effectively drive business decisions. Sustainable business model and compensates fairly.
cons: Decision making model requires input from a large number of people. Lengthy documentation is often expected, but that documentation is not always used to make the decision.

headline: Decent first job, hard to see path to career
pros: Depending on branch, building relationships with daily customers was rewarding. Decent starting salary. Some flexibility in work hours. No need to bring work home with you.
cons: Such a large company that it was hard to see opportunities for advancement. Very rigid structure, but was decently efficient. Pretty average compensation.

headline: Overall positive experience
pros: Resources, collaborative culture, growth opportunities (if you fight for them)
cons: Competitive Environment, moves slowly, held hostage by IT groups, fragmented,

headline: Capital One is a great place to work but it's not perfect.
pros:
*very collegial
*not your typical bank - culture is more like a consulting firm
*great place for a college hire to start their career in one of the many college development programs
cons:
*people management - some managers lack the training & tools to coach their teams effectively
*Need professional development programs for non-College hire associates
*Lack of Diversity 
*Selection process for a candidate is very rigorous and heavily focused on case interviewing for analyst candidates.  Does one's performance on a case dictate their success in the role? Is our process too rigorous where it could be screening out good candidates? Just because a person fails a case doesn't mean the person is not a great fit for Capital One.  They still maybe able to perform the core duties of the job.  They just need to sharpen their case interviewing skills and that only comes with practice and time.  That's not innate.

headline: Good Management
pros: I applied  online and was contacted by a recruiter in one week. Have to give the assessment over the weekend.
cons: nothing as such. have to wait and see.

headline: Join the company, benefit from training but don't stay too long
pros:
Capital One is a good employer, the pay and benefits are good, the business training is solid and executive communications are beneficial. The people are young and smart and I have made wonderful friendships during my 12 1/2 year tenure.  I have worked in diverse areas such as the functional areas of HR and Finance and US Card and the Bank in various positions.  It was easy to move around until the past few years when the company became flatter (limited promotions) and horizontal mobility was determined to be a business risk requiring at least 12 months tenure in a position.  Potential candidates should consider their postings, as they may be enjoying the role for a long time. 

Flexibility is a big benefit as it is the culture to work wherever you are, from home, from the office, from the cafeteria, from Panera.  Hours can be flexed as well to suit a work/life balance.  Get to work early, as sometimes it is difficult to get a seat near business partners, as work tables fill up fast in the morning unless your department has assigned seating.
cons:
This is a company that recruits the same type of people - young, smart, analytical, results driven and integrated thinkers, managed by the tests that candidates must pass to get to the interview.  Sometimes diversity of opinion is not valued and there is pressure to succumb to popular opinion.  

The burnout factor is high, as the annual performance management process is highly competitive. It's hard to have a family with after hours activities and remain competitive from a performance standpoint with those that are young and career-focused 24/7.  (I'm not saying that there is age discrimination but my situation was curious.  A few months before I turned 50 I was redeployed and my role was given to a younger male with less experience, even though my end of year rating was in the top 10%.  My attorney commented that this is a common practice for the company but the way that Capital One redeploys in small batches and since that statute of limitations is short, it's difficult to prove illegal practices.)

The company reorganizes frequently and I have been redeployed three times, two of which I stuck around and found an internal role but the third time I took a package. There is a glass ceiling and career progression can be limited to the selection of assignments received.

headline: One Happy Capital One Employee
pros: Great benefits, great work environment, awesome management
cons: Deal with customers' complaints and on the phones all day

headline: Great company to work for
pros: benefits are great, you can earn up to 1000 in bonuses per month
cons: some management aren't very patient with new employees

headline: great company to work for
pros: great company because they always want their employees to succeed
cons: always changing, issues with incentive plan

headline: Great company
pros: I worked there 10 years and learned a ton.  Cap One provided many opportunities to learn and do different jobs.  The rewards were great -- large bonuses and stock opportunity.
cons: Lost the small company feel as it continued to grow and become a bank.  Began to feel more like a number and disconnected.  While the rewards were great, performance management was a big dissatisfier as there was a forced rating distribution.  This pitted employees against each other.

headline: I was laid off.
pros: Great benefits, good work life balance.  There is a lot of consideration and thought given to the work environment which makes going to the office relatively comfortable.
cons: Some managers do not know how to manage.  They take the approach of "I'm always right and you just need to accept that" and they are not open to discussion or an alternate view.

headline: Application Developer
pros: It is a good company and have started to chance the structure to be more like an IT company rather than a bank. As a developer we get lot of opportunity to enhance our skill set.
cons: Lot of Management structural changes, you would not be doing the same thing you want to do for long time.

headline: Good Benefits
pros: It is an enjoyable environment working here. Lots of fun and energy.
cons: My particular department doesn't really participate in any of the activities that some of the other departments get to take advantage of. And part time benefits don't start for 6 months which is a bummer.

headline: Too many politics and not enough knowledge
pros: Great company with extraordinary benefits. Nice people and rapidly growing. They offer some of the best facilties for employees that i have seen. Great gym, great cafe, and personal trainers are some of the small perks for those who live an active and fit lifestyle.
cons: constant broken promises, uneducated managers, sexual favoritism. These traits cast a heavy shadow over the company, at least in the mortgage department and through several other LOBs

headline: A very ugly culture
pros: Salaries are high. People are smart but can forget their values in the survival atmosphere. Richmond campus is beautiful with good amenities. Richmond is a very affordable town to live in. Give the company a try if you already live in town, but don't relocate as there aren't a lot of other high paying jobs there.
cons: Company hires, fires, reorganizes, hires, fires, reorganizes, hires, fires, reorganizes... Mandatory performance management bell curve creates a Survivor like atmosphere. Improvements and best practices have to be rediscovered over and over because churn causes backsliding.

headline: Slow moving company. Great for people who are okay with status quo.
pros:
Great work life balance
Decent benefits
Relatively good people to work with
cons:
Management is so slow that decisions never get made and competition is passing the company
Most jobs are booring due to the over "importance" of analysis (aka analysis paralysis)
Employee motivation is relatively low
Profit is the "end-all be-all" for everything

headline: Great company, great benefits, and care for the employees
pros: The company has great vision to be a step ahead of their competitors. They really make the due diligence in making changes based on the adequate information.
cons: There is room for direction for growth and expansion.

headline: My least favorite workplace...
pros: The pay and benefits are good.  Most of the people are very intelligent; but the type of intelligence where they need a whiteboard to explain their point.
cons: I found the company's values to be quite sketchy.  Trying to push customers with a 500 FICO into expensive car loans seems like a selfish way to earn a profit.  Also, the corporate environment was extremely sterile (the most of any company that I have worked for) and terse.  Lastly, I didn't think that the training provided was sufficient in my particular line of work.

headline: Client Service Support Specialist
pros: Learn treasury management products from the ground up.
cons: Upward movement seems to be slow.

headline: Just Started
pros: Corporate Values, Work/Life Balance, visibility in the market, competitive pay and awesome opportunity to make incentive, positive culture and atmosphere
cons: Overall everything is great, but company is catching up to some other banks around technology. VERY confident we will catch up and be better in the near future

headline: Great entry level job
pros: Great entry level job. Great pay and benefits while in school full time. Mgmt willing to work around school schedule. Relaxed environment.
cons: Limited room for growth once you obtain a degree in business!

headline: Senior Business Analyst
pros: Very smart people, good advancement opportunities for some. Relatively relaxed culture, good work life balance for the most part. Overall solid
cons: Promotions a popularity contest, some roles you can get assigned to really stink. Some of the people there are overly competitive, vindictive.

headline: Depends where you are
pros: Gives back to the community;  flexible work schedules;  great people
cons: Role fit isn't always great

headline: Longevity and upward movement not a factor.
pros: People, climate, and location.  Love the daycare center.
cons: Headquartered in VA, different climate.

headline: Enterprise Architect
pros: Great Place to work, nice campus
cons: No flexi time, they need to be more flexible with remote working

headline: Best job ever
pros: Everything about this job is great. Coaches and Assistant Coaches help you improve and personally invest in you.
cons: Some days can be tough, but with the right mindset and team around you, it's an easy place to be successful.

headline: A conscientious company with strong, value driven leadership but need to do a better job recognizing internal talent
pros: Strong leadership at the top; flexible work hours
cons: Promotion process is inconsistent and arbitrary. Company needs to do a better job recognizing and promoting internal talent.

headline: Not a typical bank...
pros: Flexible work environment, good benefits/pay/vacation time, smart and driven associates,  opportunity to move around and try new things
cons: Frequent reorganization,  limited promotion opportunity

headline: More like a Silicone Valley tech company than a bank
pros: The work place at West Creek is very modern and more like a college campus or a think tank than a structured bank environment. There are lots of young and highly intelligent people there.
cons: If you don't live up to expectations you may not last long. It is a very competitive environment.

headline: Work at Home
pros: Everything so far is wonderful
cons: I have none at this time

headline: Great company if you work in Richmond VA....
pros:
*Work life balance, people oriented, new ideas welcome
* Onsite daycare, great staff
* Regular "one up" meetings with your manager's boss to network
* Great severance package!
cons:
* If you work outside of Richmond you're not one of the cool kids and will never be "in the know."
* The promotion process is extremely ridged.  If you are coming in I suggest you push for the highest titling, because it will take an act of God to get a promotion to increase your salary ceiling.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good culture, strong diversity values, good benefits
cons: not a lot of advancement opportunities out of call center

headline: Fast Paced and Challenging
pros: Great people to work with!  Very knowledgeable groups that work together well to put out excellent results.  Their work/life balance philosophy is top notch.  Flexible with schedules so you are able to take care of your family life as well as your work life.
cons: Not a lot of opportunity for promotions at the Las Vegas site.  But at their Richmond and McLean, VA sites that is not the case.

headline: What I think about Cap One
pros: They offer great benefits to employees
cons: There is no real work/life balance

headline: Analyst
pros: Peaceful Environement to work. Takes good care of employees. Headstart for a financial career
cons: Often work is repetitive in nature. Hierarchy is too much to handle

headline: Great company with consistently strong talent
pros: Smart people.  Good people.  Constant learning environment
cons: Industry and regulation can make work challenging

headline: Competitive Environment
pros: Great people great benefits. Open supportive working enivornment
cons: Office politics used to be minimal but it is gradually getting worse.

headline: Funding Fundin
pros:
Love the environment, people, management, resources, and the constant food they provide. 
It is mostly a fun environment where you can develop yourself and listen to your peers, help your peers and management, strive to learn and reach out to management who will help you establish a good career in the company. 
Great benefits.
Good pay... Could be a little bit better.
cons:
Upper management needs to listen to people and don't take others idea and make it their own by tweaking it a little bit. 
Favoritism in few departments.

headline: Capital One is a very good "large" employer with very good benefits
pros: Benefits, competitive salary, flexibility, and multiple locations.
cons: Networking across multiple offices and time zones

headline: A nice place to work?
pros: There's plenty of room for collaboration and they are very big on training and consulting. Its good experience for anyone looking to gain more skills in a consulting atmosphere
cons: It's very much a hero culture. Upper management boasts of collaboration and team work but rarely do they reward for these skills. Individual achievement at any cost is the unwritten rule.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Capital One does care about the associates, invest in training, compensation, new technologies, methodologies
cons: Culture is a bit arrogant, everybody knows more than the other and they say so, but not many can show it.

headline: Political mayhem, turf wars and sociopathic mismanagement
pros: A beautiful campus in a wonderful town; also, a generous income is helpful.
cons: Career-wrenching output; HR is not your advocate—ever; misguided "open door" policy is a fallacy. So little gained at the expense of one's soul.

headline: Learning experience , but very frustrating
pros: Analytical work culture, Data oriented decision making, Flexible work hours
cons: Immature leadership , Middle management is light weight in experience of the non credit card business lines, Tendency to insist that what works in Card has to be exported to other areas of the company , Excessive focus on presentation skills and not enough focus on the matter being presented

headline: Customer Service is customer focused, Collections Dept is sexist and not employee focused.
pros: Commitment to community.  Will allow 4 hrs paid time off to volunteer, including onsite opportunities yearly.  Customer service department focused on customer experience and quality. Happy and fun work environment.  Quality is rewarded.
cons: Collection department focused on numbers and not customer experience  Employees who i.e. hang up on low paying customers to boost their numbers rewarded at the expense of employees who go the extra mile to provide quality service.  Expect employee concerns to be disregarded on the Collections side.  Fewer opportunities for female employees on Collections side.

headline: Some pretty smart people lead the charge!
pros: I have met leaders who think they are smart because of their position. However, at Capital One during my 18 year tenure I had the chance to see some really smart leaders in action. It was always a treat to see the CEO present the strategy and the case behind. I did not see that in any other place I worked for,
cons: Fast paced but worked for me.

headline: Capital One is a great place to work
pros: Good Co-workers lot of learning opportunities. Good managers and senior management.
cons: None i had seen in my stay in the company.

headline: good work environment
pros: good for working mothers and fathers
cons: naah. No Cons as far as I know

headline: Customer Service Unit Manager
pros: Great principals, lots of awards and recognition, good opportunities to crate exposure.
cons: No much room for promotion. High employee / manager ratio. Development is focus on your employees, not on you.

headline: Sr. Data Analyst
pros: very nice, smart people around you, learned a lot
cons: not good career path, simple routine work

headline: System lacks transparency, performance doesn't count
pros: Brand name, onsite be-well center
cons: There is a recent review describing nepotism and I fully agree with that. It's so prominent and constantly demotivates people who are deprived of recognition just because of it . Even though there is a term of 360 feedback but it's just on paper. In reality, neither HR nor management bother about the actual performance or real feedback from team and peers but completely rely on the statements of supervisor. System lacks transparency and if supervisor is not honest, only option is to move on instead of dealing with frustration.

headline: Awesome company
pros: Culture and benefits are terrific.  They care about their employees and even in redeployment situations went above and beyond what was required
cons: They do not yet understand the virtual space and continue to make decisions based on what they consider a need for all to be co-located

headline: Try somewhere else
pros: Can't think of a single one, except corporate culture.  They couldn't do anything right.
cons: Horrible processing, underwriting, management non-responsive, more focused on over-charging customers on credit cards that doing mortgage loans, and held a huge employee meeting to tell us exactly that.  They ask for feedback, but then ignore constructive criticism and dismiss it just the same.  No customer experience focus at all.

headline: capital ones
pros: this company was good in plano thier back offices
cons: some mangers can get off by bieng the cool guy there

headline: Instructional Designer
pros: Great smart and hard working people.
cons: Too much work, unrealistic expectations, slam-dunk approach, over work FTEs.

headline: It was a great experience to work with Capiatll One. I got scope to learn manythings and showcase my technical things.
pros: The team that i have worked with is very motivating.
cons: The project has very tight deadlines.

headline: Good Company to work for but..
pros: Excellent benefits, opportunity to advance or relocate, job security.
cons: Training, lack of concise and clear communication, almost impossible for bonuses.

headline: Politics trump all
pros: Great work from home options, onsite gym, onsite dining options
cons: Much nepotism in the Manager and Sr. Manager roles. No emphasis on people management. Yearly reviews rely too much on politics and not on results. Frequent layoffs.  A chicken-little mindset in response to quarterly stock results. They often sacrifice long-term stability and strength for short-term benefit. Expect to work 60 hour weeks all too frequently.

headline: Wonderful place to work - really cares about employees.
pros: Employee engagement is really phenomenal.
cons: Communication could be a little better.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Learn a lot
Great career development
Good work/life balance
Although it is a big company, they do what they can to make it feel smaller
Nice team events
cons:

unique corporate atmosphere

headline: Great Company to work with

headline: Too many changes
pros: The compensation and benefits package were competitive with the standard here in Dallas, TX and they rewarded hard work with professional advancement and raises.
cons: Too many changes in upper level management. In the 4 years I worked there I had 4 different managers and watched other departments go through the same disconfiguration. What was worse is the managers were almost always replaced with someone less experienced and knowledgeable.

headline: Capital One used to be a good place to work when it was Hibernia.
pros:
I really can't think of any pros to working here.  Once in a while there were good incentives.
Nothing else I can say about this place.
cons: When Capital One was Hibernia, it was an awesome place to work.  They really cared about their employees, then Capital One took over and jacked everything up.  They stopped caring about the "little people" who put in the hard work and started caring only about the bottom line. The opportunities went away and laid off began to happen.  They would outsource the work to the home office and use temp services instead of hiring within to build morale.  They treated people like crap and because of that , after the 2nd time I was laid off, I left the company.

headline: Here its very cool work culture

headline: Good, fair, and well balanced

headline: One of my best experiences so dar

headline: Good place to work.
pros: The people are great to work with at Capital One.  Your ideas are accepted and considered and sharing is encouraged.
cons: Can't think of many cons.  The work pace is slow but that just depends on your perspective.  Communication could be better, but I haven't worked any place where there wasn't an opportunity with that.

headline: Awesome company that lives its values
pros: A great company, smart people, beautiful work environment, they really take care of employees, collaborative, fun...I actually like to go to work!  Love that I get to be very independent and that my work is appreciated.
cons: The pay is just okay. The performance review process is weird and pits associates against each other by calibrating (comparing) associates at same level/job function.  In theory this would be okay, but they expect it's hard to compare when roles within a function can vary so widely.

Fun place to work

Senior management engaged

headline: Mid management
pros: Probably good salaries; someone takes atleast a yr to ramp up.
cons: Politically it is a maze. Lower worker layer are technical and happy if you can bring technical stuff with you. As you move layer above towards mgmt it is highly political. Need to mesh and play your politics . Else your 360 will be screwed up totally.

headline: Great Place to work

headline: Great place to work, but you have to be very careful

cons: Not a cultural fit for everyone. While you do get to work with great people, sometimes these same people feel like they have to review everything and provide input into every solution which doesn't work in all cases and actually causes things to move very slow.

headline: Capital One
pros: Positive employee culture, good benefits
cons: HVS Management is the worst and the Director has no clue as to the nasty games, employee mistreatment and unwarranted firings that they do. The reputation of management is very negative from managers of other departments in Cap1 overall. When they hear of the games they shake their heads in disgust.

headline: Terrible commercial banking arm
pros: As the name brand implies, this is a mediocre company. Average intelligence puts you well above the average employee at Cap One
cons: low pay, terrible work/life balance, inequitable treatment of employees, mouth-breathers in management

headline: Great bank to work for
pros: I had worked for other banks prior to Capital One. Overall it was a great improvement. They were flexible with my schedule while finishing college, but still allowed me to get as many hours as possible. I had great co-workers, but that can vary depending on the branch you work at. Just like any bank they want you to sell, but aren't pushy about it. There is opportunity for advancement if you show some effort and initiative.
cons: Some managers can be difficult to work with, but that goes for any company.

headline: Brief but good so far
pros:
Capital one is not only focused on the customers but the employees as well.
They go out of their way to make a fun and interesting environment
cons: Need more colors in the workspaces in the building.

headline: Great company to work for, but highly competitive
pros: Analytically rigorous culture makes for an intellectually challenging place to work. Great development program for young analysts.  The West Creek campus is a lovely place to have an office as well.  Lots of opportunities to move up the ladder.
cons: Performance review cadence can lead to backbiting.  While work/life balance is often touted, this varies greatly depending on the culture of the specific team you're on.

headline: Started out good...
pros: Lots of days off, friendly staff
cons: low pay if promoted internally...over worked and under paid, I felt taken advantage of

headline: Overall positive but kind of confining
pros: The door is wide open for women at Capital One. The hours are great. During the week the branch closes at 4pm, so a late night is 5pm and you can't take the work home with you. Also no uniforms.
cons: The technology is fairly old and not very well streamlined, there's a different system for everything. Very few spanish/english bilinguals, it's not a priority. The branches are understaffed so time off for sickness and emergencies is tough. Incentives are not generous.

headline: Senior Business Analyst
pros: Great work life balance, smart people, pretty casual and fun culture for a big bank, nice perks and benefits.
cons: It's getting too big to the point where it is difficult to grow and develop new skills. Everybody tends to think the same way so there's little diversity. Company is reacting to a bunch of regulatory change. Many layers between you and executives, lots of process and red tape. Things move slowly.

headline: Great company, but experiences varies by team
pros:
You can publicly look for other roles within the organization
Great benefits (onsite gym @ $15/mos, nurses office, subsidized meals, car wash, 401k)
Decent bonus (~25% of salary at sr. mgr title)
cons:
Politics within teams are hefty and memories are long.
Average tenure in some teams exceeds 10 years

headline: Good until the end.
pros: Great benefits, good corporate culture, team atmosphere.
cons: Lack of managerial expertise  by middle management

headline: cap
pros: Senior leadership is good, however they are preparing a clone factory. Dont understand the meaning of diversity
cons: Lot of marketing to show how good they are....

headline: Frustrating
pros: Good people to work with, excellent talent pool.
cons: Management is weak, more concerned with corporate politics than results. There seems to be a disconnect between what senior leadership desires and what middle management practices.

headline: Bad hours and overworked
pros: Benefits and stock options are why people work here
cons: Required to work every weekend and workload was exaggerated

headline: Good work-life balance, inconsistent opportunities for career progression
pros:
- Great work-life balance (can be busy at times but schedule is very flexible)
- Good pay and benefits
- Leadership is accessible and approachable
- Some smart and fun people to work with
- Can be exposed to different areas of the business
- Great place for those who are highly analytical and willing/able to completely cater to your surroundings (see below)
cons:
- Very hierarchical official reporting levels
- Experience outside of Capital One largely doesn't matter, in terms of its value to the company (i.e., none) and how you've been used to getting work done
- Some managers are no good at managing people, but by definition they have to. No option to progress with hard skills.
- Direct manager plays too important a role in a person's career. All your eggs are in one basket. No avenue to get around it unless you want to officially complain about your manager.
- Promotions are very political, despite efforts to make it transparent. It all comes down to how much the aforementioned managers are willing/able to fight to get you promoted, and your ability to suck up, for lack of better word. No consideration whatsoever for experience/tenure (they pride themselves on this).
- Re-orgs are way too frequent. While they don't as frequently let people go, there's a good chance you or your manager have no control over drastic changes to your actual role.

headline: Good income and benefits if you don't mind being a robot
pros:
Excellent income potential
Great benefits
Extravagant offsite meetings
cons:
Micro-managed
Live and die by their processes
Heavy work load
Inaccurate data collection leads to faulty goal setting methodology

headline: I love the people that I worked with.
pros: Capital One has great people working for them and I really enjoyed the teamwork. Capital One has great compensation and benefits.  There care about the community as well and provide lots of volunteer opportunities.
cons: Capital One is too much about the numbers and not necessarily what is always best for the people.  Upper management can tend to have expectations that may be unrealistic.

cons: - Work culture does result in "not so ideal" work-life balance, esp. if you want to be in top 5% of your peer group, you have to work hard.

headline: Comfortable for many people, but not necessarily everyone
pros:
Great culture! People are very nice. Managers are well trained and professional.
Have opportunities to try different positions, find the best for yourself!
Richmond is a great place to live for many people.
cons:
Culture in different team could differ vastly. You might feel very comfortable in one team, but totally wrong in another team. 
Capital One looks for very specific type of person and promote well - if you deviates a bit from that bar, things are not going well.
Capital One has a huge campus in Richmond - for those who are curious about outside world, location is a big con.
Salary not very competitive.

headline: teller
pros: not really much to say

headline: When growth slows all the dirty linen is exposed
pros: Quality of intellectual talent - still among the best and brightest although erosion of average intellect has continued from its peak in 2004-2005.
cons: Its just like any other bank now - no growth anywhere - dog-eat-dog politics.  Political maneouvering trumps meritocracy.   Some of the most unprofessional managerial behaviors have started to creep into the culture.  Executives make noises from time to time but largely adopt a 'Look away and dont tell' position on such happenings.   Some quality does exist at the MVP+ levels but thereafter, its all downhill VP and below.

headline: Disappointing experience, overall
pros: Competitive pay and benefits (health insurance, 401K matching, on-site banking, fitness center, etc).
cons: Politics, confusion and broken promises among/between upper management.  Corporate leadership wants change/innovation/growth, but individual leaders generally don't want to change anything in their departments because they are so entrenched in the unique "Capital One Way" (even if it's no longer "the best way"), leading to mixed messages and conflicting direction at the implementation level.

headline: An Unusual Place to work
pros: Great benefits, generous vacation policy, beautiful campus, nice amenities, lots of training opportunities.
cons: Performance management is more of a popularity contest. If you are someone who just quietly does a good job it is unlikely you will ever get promoted.

headline: Great company
pros: Excellent company that invest in their employee development. Numerous development opportunities, in the form of courses and/or on the job growth.  They are on the aggressive in their expansion of the business, as well as nimble in the market place.  They are extremely innovative as well.  The number one pro of working with the company was the growth opportunities and development. Benefits, 401k, and stock purchase is also very strong.
cons: Although the growth opportunities are great, it takes an substantial amount of time to move upward. There is a lot of politics that are played and a lot of red tape in order to get projects or initiatives across the line.  Also, very high demand - in order to be a top performer you must manage a team as well as manage initiatives. The work life balance is not ideal...Merit increases and bonuses are also not that great.

headline: Overall working at Capital One has been a great experience
pros:
Capital One offers great benefits, including non traditional benefits outside of dental/medical categories. They have a gym with personal trainers (for a small fee), a doctor's office for you and your family, a post office, and a bank all on site (at least at two of the corporate locations that I have visited).

Capital One is open to flexible work arrangements. Some groups are more flexible than others, but there is a general push towards ensuring that everyone feels that they have a good level of flexibility in the workplace. I have been lucky enough to benefit from this, as I am allowed to work from home some days ( i do it at least once a week!). This is one of the reasons that Capital One has been consistently ranked as a top workplace for working mothers.

In general I feel that Capital One hires great people. Most people that I have encountered are intelligent, driven, collaborative people. Most of them are friendly as well, which makes coming to work a lot easier!
cons: I have noticed that there is a tendency in the culture to want to meet about everything. This is good from a collaborative point of view, but it seems to me that some meetings are scheduled "just to be had." This eats up time to actually do the work- there is a lot of talking but not a lot of actual process! Some groups have a tendency to over-complicate. Some groups seem to expect a high level of multitasking ability, which is proven to be an inefficient way to work.

headline: Very political, less focus on work
pros: Business casual dress code is nice.
cons: Promotions appear to be based on the buddy system instead of merit.  Focus on just getting work done instead of getting it done the right way.  Too many project managers controlling the organization who have little insight or knowledge on any particular subject.

headline: Fast-paced work for Corporate Finance role, lots of opportunities across a variety of job families.
pros:
Good entry pay
Accessibility to executives- horizontal status structure
Variety of opportunities across many job areas- treasury, reporting, specialty areas

cons:
Personal work-life balance isn't great- others in the program have better balance however
Limited locations (largely just Richmond, McLean) but expanding to other locations

pros: Interesting work and approach. Very strong bent toward strategic planning. Lots of ability to contribute to discussions and have your voice heard.
cons: Change their mind and org structure all the time. No solid ground to stand on. Frequently reorg so that owners of poor strategies are no longer in place to be held accountable when a project doesn't succeed.

headline: Very open-minded company

cons: bad pay for tellers ($9/hr in Louisiana); too much focus on upselling for tellers and bankers; terrible evaluation system for hiring at corporate in Richmond (beware of the behavioral interviews!)

headline: good place to start
pros: good place to grow after education, convenient to travel to, supportive in parts, interesting insights, good climate, nice colleagues, good facilities,

headline: Pretty good company in general but office politics and big egos are rampant
pros: Generous benefits - time off, 6% match on 401k, mostly flexible with work/life balance but it can depend on your job type
cons: Lots of favoritism abounds, promotions and appraisals are geared more towards how showy and glorified your personal projects are and how much of a type A personality you have rather than the substance of your work.

headline: Really Great

headline: Worked at Cap One for over 3 years
pros: Ability to work from home.
cons: Mobile work environment - you have to take your laptop with you everywhere.

headline: Great job for college student
pros: Great benefits and work environment
cons: The pay is not the greatest.  Incentives are offered however you have to receive 100% monitoring on all calls, and the call flow as well as management is always changing.

headline: My experience at Capital One is neutral due to certain reasons.
pros: Salary is negotiable.  Capital One Bank has a great training program for employees to open up and share their common values and goals and where they can succeed in the banking field.  Capital One has a career development program where you can take certain steps to achieve your goal and management is willing to help/
cons: Hiring part time only for tellers, Poor career development program, Customers at bank get frustrated due to ATM deposits withdrawal failure.  High turnover rate.

headline: Good company, but weird sense of collaboration
pros:
- Good benefits
- Fair advancement potential
- Great career-training and competency development opportunities
- Encouraging of diversity, to a large extent
cons:
- Team environments and/or project-team environments often felt very finger-pointed in nature, vs. a true sense of genuine collaboration I've seen since employed there. 
- Emphasis on perfecting weaknesses vs. fostering development of strengths.
- Certain satellite offices or sub-groups within organization don't get same bonus-perks as other teams (i.e. quarterly offsite team-building activities, etc.).

headline: Am just starting next week.
pros:
Seems like a wonderful company to work for.  Everyone I met at the open house that they had for us new employees had nothing but praise for Capital One.  I will work from home, they even supply a computer and all necessary equipment and the job will start at 13.03 per hour.  They put 3% into your 401k.  All medical, dental, vision are available after 6 months.  WOW!  I can't wait to start work for them!  I am really excited about this job.  Working Monday thru 
Friday (weekends off).  They have various shifts available.  I picked 12pm to 7pm with an hour off for lunch!  Woopie!  My favorite shift.  I have ams available and evening available.
cons: There is absolutely nothing negative to say about this wonderful employer.  I'm in love with my job already.  I always remember that if your love what you are doing, you never have to work a day in your life!

headline: GReat company to work for
pros: incentives, rewards for everything, helps with school, 401k
cons: If you have horrible managers it is hard to get out the branch. its hard to move up in capital one fast. not located everywhere

headline: Brutal
pros: It was a job when I needed one.
cons: The department I worked in didn't support their people and kept throwing them under the bus.  I would be careful about who you report to as the company is growing rapidly and there are a lot of unqualified individuals in management and senior leadership positions.

headline: Becoming a big corporation and all that entails
pros: Great hiring process and tends to land well above-average people, especially in M&A. Depending on the role you land, work-life balance can be very attractive, and benefits and pay are competitive. Problems tend to be interesting to solve, and very cooperative and helpful culture compared to other large organizations. Excellent place for either college student looking to work at a great company for a few years before their next step, or a middle management type with family priorities who can accept a good work-life balance and great culture in return for marginal career growth. Roles and org structures tend to shuffle every 12-18 months - this can be an up or a down depending on the situation. Credit roles are overvalued to a fault, but if you can land one its an excellent way to accelerate career growth.
cons: The last five years have brought a few changes: First, a number of extremely competent senior leaders have left the company. In addition, career advancement at all levels has slowed significantly and, as at many large companies, become more based on executive favor than competencies or results. Depending on your role and your management chain, you can have either a favorable work life balance or find yourself working I-Banker hours but without any commiserate recompense. Promotions lately tend to be based more and more on political positioning and executive favor; as a result senior and middle management tend to lack fundamental management skills, leading to low morale and turnover in middle and junior buckets. If you're ready to play the game you can do well, but don't expect much career mileage out of the quality or quantity of your work.

headline: Ok but could be better
pros:
-Great work life balance
-Mclean and Richmond offices has good facilities - gym, showers, sauna, bike racks, access to personal trainers 2x/month
-Depending on which team you are on, work can be interesting
-People are passionate about their work
-Lateral moves within the company are easy to do after being in a role for 1 year
cons:
- Very frequent reorgs (every 2-3 years), as a result people get displaced, but company takes good care of them
- Promotion cycle is slow - even with stellar performance, the "who you know" matters for promotions - not a merit based culture
- Low employee morale due to recent cuts
- Options for international mobility are limited as the company is located in the US/UK.
- Raises are poor (1-3%), but bonus are good (remember there is a higher tax on bonuses)

headline: It failed me
pros:
Good work life balance
Compensation
cons:
Reporting work in the name of analytics
No recognition
Promotions are slow
Inefficient leadership

headline: Dependable company

headline: I really enjoyed working for Capital One.

cons: You will work hard.  Will sometimes have to work weekends and holidays.

headline: Good company

cons: Lots of favoritism when it come to promotions. Friends of managers have more opportunity to move into leadership positions vs. many hard workers. The pay is also... interesting. Many tenured workers who have been employed for 12+ years are still making 50k or less.

headline: Great flexibilty and great people.

headline: Culture is everything
