cons: promo process is a bit confusing, analysis paralysis, overstaffed in support roles creates too much red tape

headline: Great place to start
pros: Great environment with plenty of long term opportunity
cons: Overall I cannot find any cons.  I am very satisfied with the opportunity I've been given and the guidance to succeed along the way.

headline: Instability
pros: Great people to work with
cons: The company does not understand the mortgage business

headline: Good place to work, depending on your priorities.
pros: Great people, autonomy in spots, work-life balance, compensation and resources.  The people I work with on a daily basis are the smartest people I know.
cons: Bureaucracy, slow promotion timelines, forced distributions during performance management.  Getting decision makers to act can be frustrating.

headline: It is overall a good company to work for
pros: There are a lot of hard-working and smart people. The company cares about associates' development
cons: Job has a lot of pressure, it is also very hard to get promoted

headline: Fun and relaxed environment!
pros: This is a fun and relaxed environment to work with teams. Overall, the pay is good and the way one is treated here is positive.
cons: Benefits are OK, not great. There is no sick time pay, must use PTO. No consistent bonuses or recognition here.

headline: Customer Service
pros: Growing company with opportunities.  Treats employees, customers fairly.  Pay is average for the job. One of the better call centers at which to work.
cons: The company is fine.  The job is not for everyone.  It's like sales without the sales.

headline: Great Company to work for. Unfortunately down sized credit card services in Tampa, FL
pros: Benefits, work-life balance, great pay. Teamwork and training. Wonderful support from management in call center. Never a dull moment. Wish they were still in operation in Tampa.
cons: Outsourcing caused the layoffs of many excellent employees and they moved most of the credit card operations to India. I wish companies realized the importance of keeping jobs in America.

headline: Great Company, Horrible Default Department
pros: Great bank to work for, wonderful Plano campus, high morale.  If more opportunities were available for associates - it could arguably be the best bank to be work for.
cons:
Limited opportunities for growth:  management in the default area does not express and groom direct reports for growth,

Management is nonchalant and seems to only care about the numbers,

headline: You'll get a solid paycheck, but don't expect loyalty from the management
pros:
- Campus in Plano is very nice
- Pay and benefits seem to be good, though you may get better elsewhere
cons:
- Business doesn't seem to 'get' the need for operations excellent
- If you're not a favorite, don't expect to get promoted
- Sizable pockets of questionable people management including managers who blame their reports when things go wrong

headline: In general, a great place to work
pros: Great people, great work environment, great culture.  Good place for training.  The company has changed in the 12+ years that I've been working here.  The people are the best I've ever worked with but policies are getting tighter due to the external regulatory environment.
cons: Performance management is an annual competition, sometimes a popularity contest.  Some supervisors are immature.  Female discrimination for upward movement; stretch roles are a great way for Capital One to get more out of associates without pay.  Long hours and 24/7 connectivity is strongly encouraged for performance rewards.

headline: Laid back culture but can get frustrating at times
pros:
-Fast Paced but laid back
-Challenging problems to solve
-Work on developing analytical skills
cons:
-Very Large company
-Work fluxuates greatly depending on role
-Stifles innovation

headline: Capital Headache
pros: The people are great to work with.
cons: Pay is very low and it is extremely difficult for anyone to make incentive each month.

headline: Authentic company with a diluting culture
pros:
Authentic- one of few Fortune 500 that founder is still acting as CEO
Fast growth and expansion
cons: Diluted culture with bank merge introducing more hierarchy

headline: Customer Service - Don't Do It
pros: Not much.  You are just a number.
cons: Managers not worried about customer service.  Only worried about sales.

headline: One of the few Good Employer in Northern VA
pros:
-Great Business model ready for prime time growth 
- Good Benefits and experience working for a growing FS/Banking Company
- Smart coworkers
cons:
- Red tape & bureaucracy that comes as part of working for a larger organization 
-Top heavy management

headline: enjoyable
pros: good benefits, good management excellent staff
cons: very competitive and management can be a little strict at times

headline: Great Company to work for!!
pros: nice benefits/ excellent bonus/ good work environment
cons: closed various departments and moved process to other states...

headline: Review Of Capital One Bank
pros: Good staff incentives like 401 and Health Coverage.
cons: Poor management styles shows lack of prerequisite skills. Senior Managers too involved in front line matters instead of managing the managers.

headline: Excellent work environment but requires significant initiative for promotion
pros: Excellent work environment and colleagues.  Very strong corporate culture of support and development.  Numerous opportunities for enrichment.
cons: Very little guidance for advancement and career tracks.  Too much reliance on contractor support.

headline: Sink or Swim approach to new employees -- they are happy to see you sink
pros: Work-life balance is pretty good, but I found that I worked on weekends more here than any other job I had before.
cons: They do not do a good job of setting expectations for new employees who did not start working there fresh out of college, nor do they do a good job of giving people the tools and guidance you need to meet the expectations they never told you about.

headline: Hard work, low reward, poor management
pros: Good people and culture in the office. They try their best to make a bad job fun and rewarding, but fall short of actually doing that.
cons: Low pay and inflexible work hours are my biggest complaints. This was an entry level customer service position, but requires much more dedication and working under pressure versus other companies for the same pay rate and benefits.

headline: Good benefits, terrible management
pros: Benefits are hard to be beat! 401K match, FSA contribution, and PTO rather than vacation/sick time. The values are good, but they are not put in place my management so what is the point in having them?
cons: Management is unprofessional and extremely difficult to work with. I'm sure that's not the case in every dept but it has definitely made me consider going elsewhere. It's almost impossible to be promoted too - even for top performers. Appears to be the only way to move us is to quit and be rehired. Bad business practice.

headline: Smart people, Good work yet slow paced
pros:
- Recruits very smart people from top MBA schools/consulting firms. 
- Analytical rigour in all decision making
- Great work life balance
- Opportunity to create an impact
- Work and interact with senior leadership
- Freedom to voice opinion
cons:
- Very slow paced, decisions take lot of time
- Constant restructuring
- Goals and resources are not aligned
- Cost pressures and hence head count reduction happening for last 3 yrs

headline: Great oppurtunity for growth
author_position: Senior Ops Coord- Reposession Department/Loss Mitigation/Recoveries
pros: The pay is good at COAF. There are several great managers in the corporation and also really great oppurtunities to move up within the company.
cons: Like most companies immediate managers have a great deal of power over their associates or workers. Here there is too much power given to managers and also so many changes being made without the proper training being provided. They will hold you accountable even had they not provided the proper training to you. I have also seen people fired for personal reasons between a manager and employee. Not a great example of ethical responsibilityffrom a manager. The turn over is more consistant then it was 4 years ago with all the changes in the company and also the people that are being hired for entry positions are alot less professional then 4 years ago.

headline: It's better to serve the devil you know...than to work here.
pros: Capital One seemed to offer decent benefits and job opportunities for its employees.
cons: It betrayed the trust of employees of banks it took over: gave golden parachutes to executives, but tried steal the packages of the workers. Security, Accounting, and other divisions signed on with "the new" Capital One, only to be let go 6 mos later with 2 weeks pay or they would offer the employee a meaningless job on the other side of the country at 1/3 of their pay with a pay freeze for 2 years.

headline: Great opportunity
pros: Work life balance is great
cons: There is Nothing to add

headline: Not what they claim to be
pros: Small increase in salary when they bought out the old company
cons: Very corporate....claimed that they would not be making major changes but that lasted only a few month. Have their own way of doing things and they do not deviate from if. They even have their on vocabulary and terms that the use and would send out terms and words for you to learn and use

headline: Teller at C.O.
pros: Great training, the pay is average. The vacation time is FANTASTIC and you get eight paid holidays off. You get to know your customers and co-workers well. Many people stay for years.
cons: You must get a set amount of referrals and that can be hard if you are part--time. If you are full time it usually is no problem. Who you manager is makes a big difference in how much you will like this position. One of my managers was great and one was really pushy. You can't refer if you are always nervous.

headline: Great company and culture
pros: Flexi timings, performance oriented culture
cons: lack of space to sit

headline: A great place to work.
pros: Equally focused on business and employee development.
cons: Some growing pains in establishing direction as they expand business model.

headline: Sr business analyst
pros: Good benefit, flexible hours and good work life balance. Embrace analytics and fact based decision. A good learning environment to get exposure to new tools and innovations.
cons: A level of hierarchy exists. Management perspective can be difficult to change. Can take years to get promoted if not on a fast track.

headline: Great work life balance
pros:
1) Great work life balance - Departmental fun days to theme parks
2) Relaxed work schedule
3) Pay is unmatched
cons:
1) Easier to move up in the company if you leave and come  back
2) Analyst positions are assigned mainly on the target school you come from
3) Most DA positions have little to no actual data analysis. Glorified report puller.

headline: Unofficial Hiring Freeze in Richmond
pros: Onsite gym, the ability to work from home, great co-workers
cons: Super political environment, nepotism, and poor leadership in the mid levels.  Managers will use assorted data to hide behind making any true managerial decisions. There is a hiring freeze in Richmond, making mobility very difficult. Capital One cannot stay out of the news with their shady business practice. The work from home option really just means you are going to be working about 12 more hours than you would in a normal work environment every week.

headline: Not the greatest products for customers and about the same quality benefits for the employees.
pros: The part time job opportunities at Capital One were great for someone who already has another job or is attending school.  Managers could be very flexible with scheduling for both full time and part time employees.
cons: The bonus structure was changed frequently.  Also the managers for my particular team constantly changed during the year which affected their understanding of the job role.

headline: Project Coordinator
pros: Good People to work with.  I made lots of Good Friends. Nice vacation time and time easy to get time off.
cons: Hard to get to the Associate Level.  Who you know definitely plays into who gets promoted. Good if you are in with the right people.

headline: Great company with great people, need more focus on defining strategy.
pros: Great education and training opportunities. Very associate centered culture, strong desire to be a good corporate citizen and 'win' in the market. There are a lot of great people who are professional and open to collaborating.
cons:
Ivory tower syndrome in upper management who often have selective perception regarding input from lower level staff. Lots of stress in middle management; which is the result of the daily changing strategy and the expectation of knowing what the flavor of the day is without being told. Constantly changing agenda/strategy. 
 The rating is determined in management calibration sessions which rate your performance against everyone else at your same level (not job title). So if someone at your level has gone above and beyond (which always occurs), this then creates the standard for which you should've followed. This makes it impossible to set goals and be confident that if you've met them you've performed well, since you are ranked against your peers not against goals set by you and your manager. This process leads to less teamwork and knowledge sharing and more individualism. Technology is lacking and in some ways is less than the industry standard.
Lack of communication from upper-level management.

headline: Male Dominated Organization in the Bank
pros: Competitive Pay and great employee benefits and programs.
cons: This is a very political organization that has not been able to retain top talent in the last few years.  Their turn over rate in commercial banking departments in the last five years has been 99%.  They talk the talk but don't walk the walk on career promotion advancement.  The way they treat top women performers is abhorrent and is the epitome of an "old boys club".  Women Beware.

headline: Go to every length to find,hire ,train and do pretty lengthy background check for their employee but not good in keepin
pros: Avoiding  micromanagement  and give  you space  laid back !
cons: Need to work to keep their employee for long time  whom  they spend so much money  to train  but they do not keep them for long and every time you go the branch you see new people try to save your employee help them to stay longer and work for this company and may be  give them second chance .

headline: excellent
pros: great salary benefits and training
cons: very competitive and high expectation

headline: Great culture and great people...
pros: This company is the Goldman Sachs of Commercial and Retail Bank.  It's a winning team!  Increased assets by 400% in 10 years.  Other commercial banks barely grew 40% in the same period.
cons: Same ones you're going to find in a large corporation, but with better environment and culture.  Very good work-life balance and benefits.

headline: Best Bank To Work For.
pros: Fun, Understanding, Supportive, Motivating, Caring Environment That Makes You Want To Wake Up And Go To Work.
cons: Nothing Is Wrong With This Bank And How Its Run.

headline: Business Branch Manager
pros: Hard working employees, good locations.
cons: All about micro management. All about numbers and reports. Focus should be on making a pleasant place to work and caring more about the customers instead of numbers.

headline: Great opportunity to take ownership of projects, do heavy analytics, and add value
pros: The company culture is very empoyee-focused. It is laid back and pays well for the work. The company gives business analysts the opportunity to work on real, complex, issues that make a heavy impact on the core business.
cons: Problem is just that you are working for a credit card company. You get a kick-back job and live a mediocre life. Also, the capital one brand/stigma not being appreciated in other sectors of financial services.

headline: Strange that a bank doesn't know the first thing about compensation.
pros: They do a great job in the selection process of making sure you are know your stuff in your area of expertise.  They do look out for the entry level, operational type of employee that most companies ignore.
cons: Strictly speaking from the compensation department, they have leaders at the highest levels that have absolutely no compensation experience.  You are brought in to the organization because of your industry knowledge, but when you voice your ideas about how "normal" compensation practices are in the real world you are told to be quiet.

headline: Well managed organization
pros: Capital One is very good at the things they are good at.  Tremendous leadership.
cons: They do struggle when they are involved in lines of business where they aren't familiar.  They get great people in the decision making roles for those areas, but they struggle with integrating them into the larger strategy.

headline: Very associate centric culture, strong desire to be a good corporate citizen and 'win' in the market
pros:
Culture
Opportunities to progress IF you work at a major Capital One location
Authenticity of leadership team
People are genuine
cons:
Not as progressive on flexible work arrangements as peer companies
Sometimes experienced some close-mindedness to doing things other than the Capital One way
Forced ranking performance management process not a fit for some folks

headline: Their strength is their people.
pros:
Very intelligent coworkers.
Challenging recruiting process results in hiring people with strong analytical skills.
cons: Not a lot of opportunities for advancement.

headline: All about the company and never about the workers
pros: remuneration, you get an income. job experience
cons: no room for development. they hardly promote from within

headline: best at work life balance
pros: work life balance,  culture etc.,
cons: nothing to say at this momment

headline: Rewarding
pros: Room for growth and experience
cons: Various changing systems and policies.

headline: Great Company
pros: Challenging work environment, Results focused environment, Meaningful work
cons: Demanding, Work life balance, constantly changing org structure

headline: My time at Capital One Auto Finance in Plano TX
pros: Good company culture. Good place to work for young adults
cons: Does not pay enough money! For the work they could pay more.

headline: It's a mess in the Banking side
pros: You want to work there if change appeals to you.
cons: The changes almost never make sense. They are using systems that the big banks replaced 8 years ago. Now they are replacing them this year but trust me when i say they are WAAAAY behind on technology. I had 15-20 logons and passwords just to run a center

headline: Above average compensation, smart co-workers
pros:
Well-run company at the top of the house - strategy will keep them out of big trouble in the industry
Extremely bright folks work there, making every day intellectually challenging
Pay and benefits are very good
cons:
Company has lost some of its "fun" atmosphere and is now more like a stodgy bank
Re-orgs happen too frequently

headline: Perception not reality
pros: Good pay and benefits at least
cons: 360 reviews guarantee that good work is not rewarded, being a nice guy and getting along is. As long as you give the perception that you're working, you do fine. IT staff is mostly outsourced and treated like serfs; their input is not valued. Ideas are only good if they come from COF corporate employees. Not from employees from acquired companies, not from contractors.

headline: High standards; slow decision making
pros: Expectations of individual performance are very high and are reflected in the quality of work produced. Work environment is highly competitive, magnifying the level of effort given ny associates. Mobility between roles is openly discussed and encouraged.
cons: Highly bureaucratic structure results in excess deliberation over high impact projects creating huge lags in decision making process.

headline: Dedicated to people development
pros: Capital One has an incredible dedication to your personal and career development. Senior leadership spends significant time coaching, mentoring, etc. They are very supportive of rotations to various parts of the company to continue to learn new areas and skills even at the expense of efficiency at times.
cons: The culture and type of work has shifted over time as the bank has grown. The company used to always be about growth/innovation and had retained part of its start up culture roots for a long time. More recently the focus has shifted to mostly regulatory/compliance and well managed work and the culture has gotten a bit stuffier. That being said its still an amazing place to work and to launch a career.

headline: Relationship Banker
pros: Great Benefits, Tons of education and training
cons: Low Salary for all the hats and daily changes

headline: Learned a lot - couldn't wait to get out
pros: Great learning environment - smart culture that values quantitative approach.  Lots of chances to learn, expand your skills and take classes.
cons:
The culture.  NOT team-oriented at all.  All about making yourself look good at the expense of others.  Stab each other in the back.  Need help - nope, you're on your own.  And they really need to re-evaluate the meaning of the phrase "work-life" balance.  If I had stayed there any longer, I would have gotten divorced.

I wound up taking a job working significantly fewer hours for more money and was much happier working for a company that valued servicing the client over advancing ones career.

headline: Very sound company with the right intentions, but too much red tape
pros: Very sound business strategy; smart employees; Exec Mgmt. puts their money where their mouth is in supporting key initiatives; strategic and operational focus is on long term objectives, not just the next quarter's numbers
cons: Very process oriented, decision making is slow due to highly matrixed org structure, pay is very formula driven, org structure is bloated

headline: A great two years out of college
pros: This is a great place to start working out of college.  There are a lot of young people around to meet and network with, everyone I've worked with has been collegial and willing to help me learn.  New analysts get to work on real business problems right away and can get heard right away if they prove themselves.  There is also a real emphasis on work/life balance and senior management seems to really mean it.  Nice benefits package too.
cons: Capital One has hired a lot of very smart people, which sometimes means that things are way more complicated than they should be.  Recent acquisitions means that some parts of the company feel more disjointed than others.  There is constant turnover as people rotate around to different teams- good if you like change but it sometimes can be overwhelming plus you lose institutional knowledge.

headline: Very Rewarding and very fulfilling.
pros: Pays well and excellent bonuses.
cons: Lacks risk taking and credit department and credit manager were completely against making any loans in the Rio Grande Area. Really felt like they were discriminating.

headline: Very generous employer
pros: Work from home, great manager
cons: Lots of tech issues sometimes

headline: A good place to work at
pros: I've been at Capital One for over 3 years now and have enjoyed working here. It's a pretty good place with smart people, great work life balance, good compensation, great benefits and flexibility in work location.
cons: One of the best things about capital one has always been the bottom up innovation in the strategy setting and product development. However, the recent spate of acquisitions has added a lot of beaurocracy and moat of the work being done is driven by senior management with the ground level employees simply finding ways to do what they are asked to do. Also, the performance appraisal process needs more transparency. The way it works today, its a popularity contest. If people above you like you, you get to be on the high profile projects and get promoted as a result of that. The others just get stuck in a viscious cycle of getting the same vague feedback again and again.

headline: A rudderless ship in the retail line of business
pros: Large Cap Company, benefits, and no shortage of promotions
cons: No direction, uncertainty in the leadership roles, horrible training and support

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Inspiring CEO/founder (Rich Fairbanks). Good benefits and working facilities. Meaningful work with tangible impact on customers and bottom line.
cons: Unclear career growth. Need to self-promote for career advancement. Lack of proper orientation period when new at job.

headline: A company for college graduates
pros: Tons of great training opportunities
cons: Too much work. Average working hours per week is 50+ for everyone

headline: Sr. Business Analyst
pros:
Great people to work with
Access to senior management 
Great rotation policy
Lots of extra-curricular activities you can choose from
cons: Some times extra curricular activities take the center stage and become the most important things in your year-end review. The philosophy that everyone's equally good in their day jobs is a flawed one in my opinion.

headline: Great company
pros: willing to invest in their employees
cons: Not open to work from home

headline: Business Analyst experience
pros:
-Company is committed to living its values.
-Company treats employees fairly.
cons: -Lack of commitment to employees outside its Virginia base.

headline: I am an enthusiastic, self-motivating, hard worker with a positive attitude that enjoys working in a team.
pros:
excellent interpersonal skills- I feel comfortable talking with my customers and they share personal details about their kids, and update me on their lives every time they come in to bank with me so I know they are comfortable too.

good customer service- I go out my way to make sure my customers get what they want and sometimes they don’t mind waiting in line a little longer just so that they can bank specifically with me. I think when you provide a good customer service, in the long run its superior to any product and that’s how I keep my customers coming back.
cons: The company does not promote growth

headline: Great companies, but too clicky
pros: Work life balance is great, they are all about a healthy lifestyle
cons: Once you become coach you're kind of stuck

headline: Mired in data analysis, unable to see people or strategy
pros:
-employees are enthusiastic and believe they are the best in industry
-management has good intentions
-folks want to be collaborative
cons:
-folks aren't best in industry and it reflects in strategic thinking.  
-decisions are written in stone; there is no wiggle room to change course.
-individual teams are islands operating by their own rules

headline: Capital One Home Loans
pros: Some managers appreciates employees and recognizes good work. Nice campus and benefits.
cons: Some areas are political and advancement is difficult.  Some managers are non aggressive, and sometimes fail to execute on projects & some managers are too demanding.  Lots of executive layering and often layoff at that level are frequent. Lots of long hours and as a salaried person it doesn't balance out.  Some areas are in need of stronger more knowledgeable management.  Lots of meetings and little time to complete work task.  Not all areas have a lot of on the job formal training. Most training is sitting side by side with other associates and this is not the best most efficient way of learning new material.

headline: Business Analysis Manager
pros: Great human capital. Challenging environment. An opportunity to grow in your career
cons: The company has become to bureaucratic. New products are very difficult to implement

headline: Management has no clue
pros: the actual people that work in the branches are nice and the hours of the branch are not that bad. Tons of training to learn something new. Health plan and dental are great.
cons: Upper management really doesn't know how to succeed. There is no room for advancement because all the hiring for Branch Managers are always from other banks. With the Assistant branch managers being laid off last year, there is no place to go after you are a banker or a lead teller but to move to another bank for a higher position.

headline: So far, so good
pros: Great employee benefits, work/life balance is heavily skewed toward the quality of life side, smart co-workers, pleasant working environment
cons: Feels like a very large company, growth opportunity depends more on timing/situation than talent, some logjams of Director/Sr. Directors that aren't moving up or out and prevent the growth opportunity of those around

headline: Good Company to work for
pros: Solid company good work atmosphere.  The people I work with are great and management is also.
cons: The job as a collector just does not suit me. Every word is evaluated and scored.  Every aspect of the job is monitored.  Its too stiffeling.  If it were not for the position I would love my job. I only see lateral movement very little opertunity to move up were I'm at.

headline: Good Benefits but Non-Stimulating Jobs for Middle Management
pros:
Pay
Flexible Work Environment
Great Gym at Facility
cons:
Extremely Beuracratic
Everything moves at a glacial pace
Company isn't open to change
Policy and Procedures run the place
No thinking outside of the box

headline: Fraud Recovery Agent
pros: Decent benefits, medical, dental  and vacation available from day one. Excellent 401k employer match program and of course five day work week in fraud recovery
cons: The cons, job specifics has changed a great deal from investigating fraud to simply providing customer service to repeat cardholders and/ or would be fraudsters. The pay isn't enough for those with various backgrounds in the financial industry. The year appraisal end process for associate is based strictly on personal opinion and favoritism to managers. Some associates are promoted to other roles of recovery while others are stuck and not provided with support and coaching needed to succeed.

headline: Horrible place to work
pros: benefits are the best thing about this job. the tuition reimbursement was really good.
cons: the managers are sour people. They mess up big and cover it up or blame it on people below them. the pay is very low compared to others.

headline: I had a great experience as a contract employee
pros: Laid back environment, lots of creative freedom, great pay
cons: Lack of communication from upper-level management.

headline: Great!
pros: great benefits and compensation! very approachable upper management!
cons: Once your schedule is decided, it is hard to switch it because schedule is based on business needs.

headline: Great Place
pros: Great Place to Learn and Grow. Hires smart people
cons: Company is still grow its departments. Hires smart people, but some are not in thier proper roles.

headline: COF Senior Business Director
pros: High performance culture, solid compensation, nice environment
cons: Average benefits, average retirement / 401K, performance management system drives all kinds of aberant, distructive behavior, very negative place for people over 40 to work

headline: I've worked fro Capital One for 7 years - great company to work for.
pros:
Best reasons to work for Capital One:
• Good pay
• Excellent benefits
• Flexible work schedule 
• Exciting company with vision and innovative ideas
cons:
Drawbacks:
• Advancement is rough - very competitive and hard to move ahead
• A lot of acquisition in the last couple of years has led to some culture clash
• Constant re-organizations of staff

headline: Excellent !!!!!!!!
pros: Great working climate, excellent telecommuting experience, forward thinking, open to innovation.
cons: Capital One grew fast and is now contractings so ability to move amonst departments is a bit limited.

headline: Open culture mentality is a farce, political
pros: Decent benefits, insurance plan is through Aetna, 401k with matching, paid federal/bank holidays 20-25 vacation days and sick time is at your will (meaning it is paid and unlimited for exempt). Ability to work remotely HOWEVER it is at the discretion of your supervisor and many do not allow or encourage it.  Most departments have a good work/life balance. Pay is ok, merit increases and bonus potential
cons:
The culture is very political and all about how well you play the game.  If played exceptionally well you will go far.  Your work does not speak for itself, your ability to play does.  This is evident in the performance review process. The fact that you've successfully done your job well can still lead to an "inconstant" (below expectations) or "strong" (which is average and most common) rating.  The rating is determined in management calibration sessions which rate your performance against everyone else at your same level (not job title). So if someone at your level has gone above and beyond (which always occurs), this then creates the standard for which you should've followed.  This makes it impossible to set goals and be confident that if you've met them you've performed well, since you are ranked against your peers not against goals set by you and your manager. And these are peers in various states and locations so you more than likely will not even be aware of what others are doing. This process leads to less teamwork and knowledge sharing and more individualism.

As with most companies, your direct manager can make or break your experience.  There are good managers, however, there are a lot of managers who are self serving and not supportive.

With the numerous mergers and acquisitions, the company looks at the acquired employees as inferior and their opinions and recommendations based on experience is not welcomed. Conform or else.

The "Best Company to Work For" ranking is questionable.  I've never met an employee who felt that strongly.


Advancement is contingent on the above and can be limited or non-existent.

Job security is non-existent constant acquisitions and reorganization creates rolling lay-offs.

New to the banking industry, but not willing to learn.  Lots of federal compliance violations exist (but not widely discussed). 

Technology is lacking and in some ways is less than the industry standard.

headline: Growing company that overvalues its history
pros: Smart people who generally want to do the right thing.
cons: Lack of expertise in many leadership roles. Legacy / insulated workforce not open to new ways of doing business. Too many layers of management. Churn and burn mentality.

headline: Great Place to Start
pros: Capital One is one of the best places to start a career, because they place a lot of value on development and training.  Campus recruiting starts new hires in an Analyst Development Program that trains job specific skills and provides an avenue to network with peers for the first year at the company.
cons: While the job as a package is very attractive to college graduates just starting out, it is sometimes difficult for Capital One to deliver on its description of job role at the company.  Business analysts are supposed to drive in market strategy, but are sometimes used as a "jack-of-all-trades" to do less intelectually stimulating jobs.

headline: Great learning experience and place to start your career
pros: There's a great flexible work hours and many young people. You be given a lot of responsibilities right off the bat and will have many opportunities to lead projects.
cons: There's a "mold" you need to fit in with the culture. It can be difficult to be a part of the in crowd if you don't fit their definition of success.

headline: Capital One 360 in Wilmington, DE is not what they like to pretend it to be!
pros:
-Managers that remain from ING Direct
-What little bit of culture remains from before Capital One came in
-Workspace is nice
-Free parking (for now, but I hear this will change soon)
cons:
Capital One has taken what was a really great company with an even greater culture and, in one year, have completely ruined it.  I'm all for change and was looking forward to Capital One coming in and making an already great company even greater.  Instead, it has become an environment where everyone is out for themselves and the general concensus is to always cover your own a$$, usually by throwing someone else under the bus.  It's political and full of cliques and if you're not willing to play the games, you are tortured until it is not worth staying anymore. I was with ING Direct for many years and would never have left if it wasn't for the change in culture and the desire of my manager to get ahead at the cost of her team.  Where I used to be proud to tell people where I worked, I became ashamed and would NEVER suggest that anyone leave a good company to come and work at Capital One 360.  Its a shame, but they are very quickly losing good people.  Now other companies are benefiting from their mistakes!  Do NOT do business with this company or go to work there. I assure you, you will not be happy.

Cons:
- benefit costs are very high
- cut-throat environment
- CYA culture
- very, very political with a lot of red tape
- very meeting focused (meetings for the sake of meeting)
- if you are not a drinker, this is not the company for you; drinking is encouraged at MOST events

headline: Great Experience
pros:
- Excellent Benefits
- Work/Life Balance
- Rewards and Recognition for Hard Work
-  Alot of Opportunities to Showcase your Work
- Excellent Training & Learning Opportunities
cons:
- Too many business people bogging down IT
- Business managers pushing their agile agenda & other management gimicks

headline: Good place to work.
pros: Great benefits, competitive pay, and excellent opportunities for career advancement. If you enjoy banking and interacting with customers this is a great job for you.
cons: Poor management and bureaucratic elements abound. Although management may be lacking, they generally leave you to your own devices if you stay off the radar and do your work.

headline: Extremely Sales Driven
pros: Great place to start in sales without a degree.
cons: Harsh punishments for not meeting sales quotas, most systems are behind other banks, very old fashioned processes in place that are not time or cost effective.

headline: Confusing
pros: Fun motivating things to help employees feel recognized and important.
cons: Sales focused instead of customer focused. Employees are often ridiculed by upper management when not hitting sales goals.

headline: Ernest effort in pursuit of excellence in customer service
pros:
*All decisions are weighed against the company mission to do the right thing. Like the Golden Rule, it may create complications, it is also fundamentally clear, simple, direct and self-evident in problem-solving. 
*The guiding cultural principal of PWE, Positive Workplace Environment (which I like to call Pweh, in honor of Mel Brooks), actually works at Capital One - discouraging gossip, and bullying, and all the petty little squabbles that undermine team-building.
cons: Compensation and benefits are stable and reliable -- but only slightly above average. In the pursuit of excellence, compensation should more accurately reflect the excellence we seek.

headline: Good place to work for
pros:
- Good work environment and working ethics
- Promotion and bonuses are performance driven and based on peer review
- Benefits are pretty decent
- Stable environment
- Encourages working outside of scope and out of box ideas
cons:
- Salary is not that great
- Performance evaluation is not always true reflection of employees capability

headline: Amazing culture, great learning curve
pros: Amazing work culture, ownership of work even as a fresher, good compensation
cons: Low hike rates compared to industry, career path not well-defined

headline: highly analytical, great set of people to work with and learn from
pros: consulting like role with very analytically driven minds
cons: skewed performance management system at times

headline: Capital One seems to value its employees
pros: Capital One fosters a  relaxed working environment and Capital One University promotes continuing education for career growth.
cons: For me its the location

headline: Awesome
pros: Good Pay, decent hours, great environment
cons: Politics, sometimes can get stressful

headline: Overworked, underpaid, good people are often pushed out, incredibly low pay
pros: There were a few excellent people that I worked with on the branch and district level, and the research and adjustments department were always amazing to me.
cons: Made 15,000 a year less than the low end of the spectrum for my position on glass door.  Was illegally denied overtime pay due to a combination of company policy and poor management.  Was harassed repeatedly by manager with little actual recourse to HR.  Common course of business was to significantly understaff branches and then fire staff "for cause" for failing to meet sales and audit goals in the time allotted.

headline: Flexible working conditions and great environment
pros: Extremely flexible working conditions.  Great people that care about their jobs but provide a strong sense of team as well.  Management is approachable and open to feedback/concerns.  Overall a great place to work where you will be treated as a person and real world events (family passing, illness, etc) are reasonably accommodated.
cons: High expectations (though not unrealistic) provide a strong challenge each and every day.  Not really a con but some days can be more stressful than others.

headline: Not applicable
pros: Professional and young. Good benefits
cons: Rigid and very opinionated. Structure is kind of messy

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
Lots of bright people who are motivated to do a good job.  
Culture is good..there are department events each quarter.  Company events happen throughout the year also.
Games room is a plus.
cons:
Some jobs are seen as above others.
If management is not rooting for you or can't see your potential, hard to get promoted.

headline: an 'acquired' taste
pros:
- decent pay and benefits
- fast-paced, high energy
- smart coworkers
- career opportunities, especially for those just starting their careers
- nice amenities on campus (gym, career center, cafeterias, etc.)
cons:
- very political 
- "Good ol' boys network" culture is favored
- rewards looking "busy" and finding extraneous work opportunities that have nothing to do with the business
- expected to work around the clock (varies from one department to the next)
- managers are often very out of touch with associates

headline: fair
pros: advancement in company, great teaching, they care about employees
cons: heavy emphasis on referrals they push

headline: Great company for people who want to work way more than 40h a week.
pros: It is a very fast pace environment, energetic, young. Many opportunities for learning and advancement. Great benefits. Some jobs fairly flexible.
cons: For many positions they will squeeze everything out of you. Workload is always at 150%. The company is growing, which is great, but acquisitions create extra work on top of all the assigned projects. Flexibility causes that you "can" work from home which means that when you get home you should open your computer and continue. Very aggressive environment, abusive at times. Promotions/bonus process very aggressive and not always fair.

headline: Very Good Culture and human talent
pros: Awesome culture, great talent at the company, very open
cons: Growth opportunities and Salary structure

headline: Schizophrenic Company: Would not recommend surprisingly.
pros: Compensation is good.  Collegiate atmosphere (everything is new and exciting personality).
cons: Great public talk is opposite of actions. Lots of talk; however, little follow through is common experience.  Makes very uninformed decisions (and is proud of bad decisions because decisions were made quickly!).  Collegiate atmosphere (good for straight out of college-conceptual not reality mentality).

headline: Great company that offers a fairly flexible work environment and room for upward growth
pros:
Room for upward growth
Flexible work hours
Great place for working mothers
Invest heavily in associate development
Very good place to get a jump start on your career and develop many skills quickly
cons:
Must influence many to get anything done
IT systems make it difficult to implement extremely innovative solutions
Complexity of strategies and reliance tribal knowledge make it difficult to learn the detailed ins and outs of any part of the business; This also leads to "reinventing the wheel"

headline: Great company, works hard to make employees happy
pros: This company really works hard on making employees feel welcome.  This includes physicians on campuses, gyms, tree houses. and even a career services office.  The company is also growing, and hired 25% more people between 2011-2012.
cons: Make food free on campuses?

headline: good experience with nice people
pros: nice and smart people and comfortable environment
cons: salaries, not advanced IT support

headline: A strong and innovative company
pros: The only place I've ever worked where you have to try hard to find somebody who isn't very smart.
cons: The Finance industry is going through a lot of changes right now

headline: Job Security
pros: The interview process is short and sweet. After filling out the application, the process is very efficient.
cons: After obtaining the job, there is no job security. They give you four-five days in the call center - GCS to learn over 8 systems. They do not provide the appropriate training to maintain the scores necessary to keep the job. Capital One sets employees up to fail because they do not allow time for training of the systems available for use.

headline: Talks the "talk" but doesn't necessarily walk the "walk"
pros:
- Benefits (3 weeks PTO, sick days don't count, health, dental, vision, FSA matching...)
- Work / Life Balance
- Employee appreciation (Fun days, spring flings, etc...)
- Training
- Vision
cons: The company puts a lot of effort into hiring the "best" and "brightest"... until there is a shortage of employees at which point many of the elements designed to screen the "less desirable" people are often thrown out the window. This is a non issue most of the time, but the company's year end review process is such that people above, below, and at your level have a say and can impact your year end rating. So if politics isn't your game then this may not be the company for you.

headline: Smart people, good atmosphere
pros: Open to change and new ideas.  Leadership is always pretty accessible and open to helping.
cons: Locations are never in the actual city - commutes can be brutal

headline: Good Company
pros: Great work culture, good travel opportunities
cons: Higher management is not interested in associates growth.

headline: Great Company to work for
pros: Nice environment, happy people, good chances of advancement
cons: There is nothign really I can complain about

headline: Good place to work for
pros:
1. Good work environment
2. Great people to work with 
3. Proper Work-life balance; gives a lot of flexibity
cons: Not much growth opportunities in India office

headline: OK if you love sales pressure
pros: Paid time off after 6 months. 401k match. Benefits offered for both full and  part-timers.
cons: Management creates unrealistic goals. Compensation is below the average for banks. Meical benefits could be better.  Promotions go to faorites rather than to who deserves them.

headline: Average Payer

headline: Capital One NA Houston Texas
pros: Cultural diversity, good work life balance

headline: Typical large company of tip-toe dancing politics and lack of diversity
pros: Interaction will co-workers was enjoyable.  Overall opportunities available across credit card and banking divisions are adequate.
cons: Lack of diversity.  Typical brown-nosing necessary to be seen as a good worker.  Unfortunately, working relationships were built on physical similarities and were often used in justification of an employee being a good fit.

headline: Tough but fair
pros: Good and friendly people to work with.  They have a good atmosphere and good pay.  They are very supportive and active with volunteering.  They are very open to moves throughout the company so you don't have to feel trapped in the job you are in as long as you are performing well.
cons: Non performance means being shown the door fairly quickly.  They allow flexiblity to work from home when needed, but don't expect to get ahead while doing it (being allowed and being happy about it are two different things).

headline: Very young in organizational life
pros: - Ability to move to other positions often
cons:
- inexperienced upper management 
- organization control and management needs to be more structured
- unwillingness to make difficult decisions
- more concern with the presentation of a message versus accuracy

headline: Fantastic

cons:

headline: Good people, good projects, good exposure
pros: Good people, good projects, good exposure

headline: Good place to gain experience and then move on

headline: GREAT place to work with a diverse, inclusive culture
pros: Very inclusive, diverse culture with lots of room for advancement. Company values "bring your whole self to work" and offers lots of opportunities to provide feedback on different policies and practices to ensure it remains a great place to work. I had to leave due to relocation and was very sad to go, I would work there again if the opportunity presents itself.
cons: Departmental training programs could be stronger.

headline: Just a check!!!!
pros: Receiving a check, health benefits, Vacation hours...
cons: The pay is EXTREMELY low for entry level associates!!!!  There has been constant change before we inquired ING Direct but now it's so much worse... The change says alot about the instability of Capital One as a whole and also says alot about how  weak management is.  Most managers are incompetent!!!!! You will be reprimanded for taking too much PTO, questioning certain policies/ how things are ran.... Management doesn't care about employees AT ALL regardless of how much you help with different projects or how hard you work... There's ALOT of upper management that look down on Reps & think they are superior...   They do NOT value employee loyalty and/ hard work..

headline: Work
pros: Good company to work for.
cons: Management drama is sometimes high,

headline: great company to work for
pros: Excellent people, great upper management, fast growing company, more opportunity, good recognition and benefits
cons: less pay, some managers are not very professional

headline: Interview Process
pros: The whole interview process was very fast and the HR was very helpful and easy to get in touch with.
cons: Applied for teller position online and it took about a month for an HR recruiter to contact me to schedule an interview.

headline: A slow and steady retail bank.
pros: Great work life balance here.
cons: Limited career progression. Senior management is old school from the olden days of an aggressive capone.

headline: The experience was pleasant, not very stressful.
pros:
Low Stress
Great Pay
Good Hours
The other tellers were very helpful when I was first training.
Free Coffee
Hard to Get Fired
Overall Great Culture.
cons:
Heavy Emphasis on Referrals
Snotty Customers
Very High Paced

Needs to update machinery - pretty old in some cases.

headline: Loving it so far
pros: Salary, coworkers, friendly faces, some good food
cons: Kind of strict with rules

headline: Mismanaged
pros: Fast paced, challenging work environment with intelligent coworkers. Flexible schedules; pay and benefits are slightly above average.
cons:
Rapid change can be an interesting challenge but when change seems to occur every second of the day, it creates massive inefficiencies and frustrations at work. Work has become even more bureaucratic over the years and there are way too many cooks in the kitchen, trying to take ownership of everything. Capital One is a meeting culture, again, leading to many hours each day that are completely wasted. The collaborative environment is only good if you are an extreme extrovert, otherwise this is not the place for you as you will find yourself on the road with coworkers for hours on end, commuting from Richmond to Mclean, to the airport, business trips, etc all together. 
At the very top, Capital One is mismanaged. It can take several months or longer to roll out a new process while employees struggle to follow whatever the 'current' process may be on any given day. I have worked in the headquarters for 2 years now and have only seen execs roaming the halls a handful of times. You never hear direction come from the horses mouth, instead it comes from 5 levels below senior management at which point the message has more than likely become misconstrued and miscommunicated. 

Many wasted hours are spent on performance management which, as in most places, is a joke and unfortunately comes down to who you know/ who likes you. The "diverse" and "open" culture that Capital One raves about on daily basis don't seem to apply to the average person. Joe Schmo will never fit in at Capital One. You must come to work each day with a crazy frat boy-like story in order to fit in with the culture here. Good luck to those who don't!

headline: I worked at Capital One for approximately 3 years as a Compensation Manager
pros: Good benefits and pay, employees generally have a strong work ethic
cons: Long working hours, redundancy in roles

headline: Teller
pros: Tuition Assistance, Learning Experience, Opportunities for transitioning to other financial institutions, great for students and part-time.
cons: Lack of a flexible schedule, and limited to zero opportunities for growth. I was working at a branch near headquarters and studying at a nearby institution, and opportunities from transitioning from the branch to a department at HQ was nearly impossible. They have a very elitist mentality at HQ and many of their entry level positions recruit only at Ivy League to Top 20 schools.

headline: Great
pros: great place to work and learn
cons: Needs a wider footprint of locations

headline: Excellent  Flexibility

Work Life balance is good. 
Associates are encouraged to travel a lot .
cons:
Politics can get dirty at times.
Promotion cycles are long . Can get frustrating at times.
Disparity in pay packages among associates.

headline: capital one personal banker review
pros: bonus is in addition to salary

headline: A relentlessly positive company trying to unify diverse employee cultures.
pros:
-Excellent benefits.
-A genuine commitment to community service and charity work.
-Strong opportunities for women and minorities

cons:
-Bureaucracy!
-Ivory tower syndrome-upper management often has selective perception regarding input from lower level staff.
-Attempting (and struggling) to create a single corporate culture from a diverse set of acquisitions.

headline: its pretty good
pros:
good starting pay
friendly co workers
good benefit
cons:
co workers can be gossipy and fake
costumers can be rude or arrogant
work can be more then what youd expect for pay

headline: Extremely political environment.
pros: Competitive salary, willing to invest in order to grow.
cons: There is a huge gulf between what Leadership says and what actually happens in the company.  Leadership messaging is all too often directly contradicted by line managers.  Rewards are based on each manager's individual goals, so leadership vision has no bearing on their priorities.  Conflicts abound, and the people that come out ahead tend to be the ones that have the biggest 'win at all costs' outlook, and are willing to circumvent policies and procedures in order to do it.  Easily the most political environment I have ever worked in.

headline: Very Ordinary
pros:
Great work culture
Good peer group
Brand Name
cons:
Very less vision into career progression of an associate
Very bad upper management from random colleges
Kills all your zeal if part of some teams

headline: Great place amazing talent
pros: Great place to work. Loads of work flexibility.
cons: Not a very great incentive structure.restricted team specific travel opportunities.

headline: Good company
pros: Good culture, nice and helpful people

headline: Pay for performance
pros: They have a very fair system for ranking employees. You get paid on your performance against your peers
cons: No negatives at the moment

headline: Best employer I've ever had
pros: Company is very employee focused

headline: Till now has been an ok experience

open culture
opportunities within the firm

headline: Challenging and demanding

headline: Perfect Job
pros: Benifits are amazing.  oppurtunity to grow and learn.

headline: A great Learning experience
pros:

headline: Okay is the only way to rate
pros:
GREAT maternity leave benefits. Allow you to take FMLA 12 weeks after being employed for one year,plus they offer an additional 4 weeks of unpaid leave. Total = 16 weeks! 
Flexible scheduling... if you are lucky. 
Cafe located in building
Gym located in building
cons:
Horrible management, don't listen to employees needs. 
Like to micro-manage, send 20 emails a day on what needs to get done, spies to watch when people come in and out for lunches ETC.
High turnover rate because the management sucks and morale is low due to overload of work and no support from management/ supervisors.

headline: full of opportunities

headline: teller
pros:
- I met some great co workers as my fellow tellers
- When the crisis of Hurricane Sandy came to New York, employees had received extra pay for traveling
- new experiences with customers..  getting to know them and learning alot about them
cons:
- Some managers didn't know how to be managers, very immature.. took management to a whole arrogant level
- I felt like i was in high school with all the "grown adults" who took most of their time to gossip about everyone
- no opportunities
- make you do abundance of work for a little amount of pay
- never had a life always was at work

headline: In a subpar economy, it's average.  Great for entry level positions.
pros: Career development, Benefits and networking.
cons: Beware, once you get promoted, you may actually make less

headline: All about business
pros: Compared to some other banks, the pay is good because some other banks don't pay you a monthly incentive for sales goals (i.e. Regions).  But Capital One is much quicker to fire it's employees over the simplest thing.
cons: Management is given too much power.  There aren't rules that apply across the board.  Managers are given a lot of discretion, so different branches do different things.  You can easily lose your job over one simple, honest mistake.  They only care about you harrassing and kissing up to the customers to meet your sales goals which ranges from a $35-$120 monthly incentive that is taxed.  All the stalking and butt kissing you have to do to reach the goals is not worth it.  They treat you like a number or product, not a person/employee.  Basically, go to work, do your job, and be sure to dot all i's and cross all t's.  And try not to NEVER be late or miss more than 4 days of work for being sick (a year) because they will fire you!!

headline: Very Good Company
pros: There's a lot of potential to grow within the company, and they offer lots of ways to develop yourself. The Culture is also really different, than to other jobs that I have had in the past.
cons: Although there is alot of room for growth, it takes a bit of time to get to the next level.

headline: good benefits
pros: I stayed due to good benefits
cons: Not a lot of advancement unless you hang out with managers outside of work

headline: Healthy company core, still experiencing the growing pains of rapid expansion.
pros: Strong benefits. Generally friendly people. Excellent facilities. Strong company with aggressive and attainable goals
cons: Ratings/bonuses and opportunities tied to performance too reliant on manager persuading other managers to put their worker ahead of their workers.  Time squeeze on several managers; tied to work from home.

headline: I worked in a call center professional but laid back as a  phone banker
pros: They have really great benefits and allow you to bonus up to $1000 every month, every one there is really nice, friendly, cafeteria is great, and the job may seem overwhelming in training but once on the floor it is a cake walk.
cons: Shift bids for the shift you wanted was slightly unfair. They are done twice a year and based on quality score for your calls & your are ranked in the entire call center. I was out on maternity leave and had no scores so i was in dead last place for the bid on shifts. i got a terrible shift 3pm-12am.

headline: They will get rid of you after a certain age
pros: some flexibility to work from home, depending on the manager and department, fairly good benefits, salary
cons: inexperienced people promoted to management, lots of young people and they will "clean house" and get rid of people of a certain age (40+) although they claim that's not the case and you will be hard pressed to prove it.

headline: Smart people, fast-paced, good culture, but edging toward overworking folks.
pros: Really smart people, great culture, great strategy, CEO is a good person, all in all, a really good place to work.
cons: Due to several acquisitions and an inability to prioritize by the senior managers, the non-senior management associates are getting worked too hard.

headline: good culture but low compensation and career oppotunity
pros: Work environment/culture is very good. Friendly and smart coworkers. No bad competition involved.  Relatively flexible work style, but highly depending on your job role.
cons: Compensation is relatively low for similar job roles. You should expect to be busy most of the times. Many people leave after a couple years for higher title and compensation.

headline: Great potential, run into the ground

Excellent earning opportunity.
Great selection of loan products and the scale to negotiate custom products.
Excellent sales coaches and good CRM tools.
cons: Huge corporation took over a high-performing startup and corporatized it to death.

headline: Great company

headline: Great firm to work at
pros: Open Culture, Talented people, decent pay

headline: Great company to work for

cons: some processes a little sloppy, but working towards improvement.  No HR on site.

headline: If you want a long time job but not worried about promotions this is a great place.

headline: SO-SO
pros: Great company for those boasting and talking much
cons: How to survive in political battle is more important than your performance.

headline: Great place to work, not to get paid

- Great access to senior leadership
- Company philosophy is to be the best not the biggest

cons:
- You can get paid more somewhere else
- Can be to analytical at times
- Can be really cheap in certain areas

headline: good exp.
pros: Great job for professionals entering the banking industry
cons: I cannot say if there was any cons to this company...I liked most everything

headline: Too much work, not enough pay, and little opportunity to advance
pros: Nice facilities, good people overall, benefits from day 1, and the vacation time is better than most.
cons: Salary is very low considering the amount of work required.  Work/life balance is often talked out, but nearly impossible to put into practice.  Bonuses and promotions are awarded based on being a favorite of leadership rather than education, experience, or performance.  The most vocal get rewarded regardless of actual performance.

headline: Great experience at Capital One
pros: Great people, analytics focused culture, collaborative environment
cons: Work hours can be longer than other banks

headline: Solid, slow-moving company that cares about its employees
pros: Great benefits. Good salary. Good facilities and getting better. Smart, sociable co-workers.
cons: In such a large company, things take forever to get done. Often it felt like my work wasn't having any impact or even getting to the customers; it seemed like it was getting entangled in bureaucracy. When I had an idea, often the response would be "Good luck getting that through legal/brand/etc"

headline: Customer Service Associate II, Work-at-Home
pros: The best part of the job was working from home and not having to commute on a daily basis.
cons: The plethora of information conveyed during training is very overwhelming.  The training format is convoluted.  Expectation to retain knowledge in a limited period is illogical.  Use of a strict "informational/conversational" flowchart to provide technical assistance to customers defeats the company's objective to impress customers that services provided are unscripted.

headline: Capital One
pros: Great work life balance, Lots of opportunities for those who seek it, Location had good benefits like gym, nurses office; Smart group of people
cons: Career path can depend on what group you're in, too much focus on profitability per user instead of maximizing value of user.

headline: One of the best places I have worked at!
pros:
Great benefits - 7.5% match on 401K (on base and bonus), 1K match on FSA, Discounted stock purchase program.
Flexibility, open work space, Wi-Fi at work lets you work from anywhere you want in and around the building. 
Really smart intelligent colleagues who make it a great place to work. You are always challenged and motivated for that reason. 
The company is always doing the right thing for the employees/associates. (eg: they pay bonuses even when they didn't make much money or had layoffs and doesn't make that an excuse for cutting down on benefits). 
With the acquisitions of ING Direct and HSBC Cards, growing even more and unlike most other financial companies is well managed and growing, but very carefully with a bright future ahead. 
One of the rare places where I have seen things work the way they are supposed to and if not, you could find a way to work to get that changed.
cons:
The performance management system is good overall, but the forced ranking system can be painful. Not sure what can be a better option here, but good to think about it. 
Lots of type A people which can sometimes be annoying. 
Good individual contributors get promoted to people managers which sometimes leads to lack of focus on coaching/mentoring, but rather the people managers just trying to continue to be good individual contributors at their new level.

headline: Working at Capital One has been rewarding, flexible & free-spirited..
pros: My manager and team has allowed me to work autonomously while continuing to foster a collaborative work environment. The worklife balance at this company is amazing - working from home is more of a norm than any other employer I've worked for. There are 2 values at Capital One - Excellence & Do the Right Thing. It's doesn't get much better than that, wouldn't you say?!
cons: So far, I haven't experienced many cons with working at Capital One. So far, things have been extremely accommodating for me. Maybe I can report back on this later during my 1 year anniversary :)

headline: Focused on customers and employees
pros:
Customer focused
Willing to engage employees
Willing to do the right thing even when it costs them money
Care about their brand
cons: Not as analytically strong as some companies

headline: Great place to work if you can keep your senses..
pros: Top notch talent sourced from the best colleges and industries. Very open culture - individual opinion matters and not very hierarchical when it comes to sharing feedback/ideas on projects. Very results focus.
cons: Constantly changing agenda/strategy. You will be unique if you have the same manager for more than 6 months. Re-organizations are very common.

headline: Rip off company!
pros: some good people work or worked for the company but had to leave due to several number of reasons
cons: Very aggressive sales oriented business environment! Hard to survive if you don't have large book of business or connections. After 10 months got a letter that they overpaid my PTO. Accounting system is sucks!Customers complain all the time-very stressful environment to work in. My Manager would not let me go home till I get some accounts in.

headline: Best Company to work for In Oklahoma
pros: And the reason why?  Because COAF and Capital One care about their employees.  I have worked for at least 5 call centers over the last 12 years.  This one is by far the best of the bunch.  The managers we have on the floor care about our developement.  They take the time out to go over your areas of strength, and work with your on your areas that need improvment.  The encourge us to work thru them.  They reward us all the time with little things, that may not really mean much to someone else, but it just shows they care.  They have several programs in place to show case our best.  They do Town Hall Meetings to tell us where not only our group, but the other groups in Capital One stand.  They lavish us with great meals, and gifts.  We have a Rally once a month to celebrate our accomplishments. and our CSAT's (Customer Satisfaction Surveys).  And we have recently worked to get JD Powers Certified.  That says alot about a call center.  The overall enviroment is wonderful.  Its a fun and vibrate enviroment.  Management is constantly doing things for us.  I am proud to say I work for Capital One Auto Finance.
cons: We need more help.  We are hiring.

headline: Making referrals is a must!
pros: If you lke customer service, this is the right job! You get 4 weeks of PTO on starting with the company. Great incentives!
cons: If you dont have a good team, it will be tough! Team work is a must! Sometimes you will need to motivate your peers!

headline: upper Management did not have a clue about Banking
pros: Having nice customers, that understand the changes are not the banking floor staff
cons: The sales program is not the correct way to gain happy customer, pushing productions on customers, and if the staff doesn't meet high goal that are set they are put on warning.

headline: Seems very structured and orgnized, place enormous value on core values.
pros: in the onboarding orientation, the company spent almost the entire day going over company history, core values, and culture.  Seems to me this company really believes in it.
cons: Typical large organization, lack creativity.

headline: A great work experience
pros: Very smart staff; very disciplined management; very empirical decision making process
cons: You have to determine the group(s) that have decision making power and get their buy-in.  Without that, you will have a tough time getting action.

cons:
Company reputation from the amount of mail the company sends
Commuting to the office in McLean

pros:
-Growth Within

cons:
-They will lie if they need to get rid of you.
-Goals are set so high that majority of associates cant meet them.

headline: Very satisfied with the employer
pros:
Growing company
Great company culture
Family oriented
Competent Leadership
cons: Still a growing company and is facing competition from the big players.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great corporate enviornment, employees are really nice and there is a sense of community within the corporate setting
cons: No real cons to speak of...

headline: I have not started yet.
pros: Work life balance is great
cons: Can't think of any. They are awesome.

headline: Great place to work with top tier talent.
pros: Great, intelligent, motivated employees. Compelling and impactful work. Extremely strong developmentally based culture. Little internal politics (but there is some).
cons: At times self select to work long hours -- management chain will stay on sidelines while it occurs. At times can feel cyclic within staff functions. Upper management's concept of easy versus difficult in relation to other tasks is at time non-existent.

headline: Amazing Workplace
pros: Young Bank on the rise with endless opportunities!
cons: Young Bank therefore out of date technology and process management.

headline: Can be a GREAT place to work!
pros: Opportunities to network across financial services divisions, positive environment for collaboration, focus is on hiring top talent, and a wide array of special events to spotlight the employee.
cons:
Focus is on too many projects. Each division has their goals to achieve, which requires cross functional teams. The result is managers are mired in too many meetings and the time it takes to complete is lengthy. Most projects take 8 to 12 months to complete because of all the levels to approve and committees that need to review. The focus is on top talent, but there are some employees that have come on board from acquisitions and have their heels dug in on how processes should be even though they are outdated compared to the marketplace. The recognition program is focused mainly on front line staff, leaving out the mid level managers 
who feel sandwiched between some employees who feel entitled to be recognized and their manager who continue to push down on mid level managers for recognizing staff without giving them recognition.

headline: Experience at Capital One can be valuable, but highly dependent on your background
pros:
There are some very talented people to work with, and great skills to learn

Good company values, although the competency model needs reviewing.
cons:
Good ol' boy network. Lack of diversity at Capital One is very apparent. And as rightfully pointed out by another reviewer, diversity goes beyond ethnicity.

Most people working here are smart, but not "elite".

headline: Great work life balance
pros: Cap One is located in Richmond, which is affordable and extremely family friendly. One of the best jobs in the city. Work-life balance (flex hours, vacation) is valued very much, which I loved. Decent salary, with room for promotional bonuses/yearly bonus and salary raises. Terrific employee training.
cons: Cap One is famous for its junk mail - thus, many hours are spent creating work that many people may just throw in the trash = not inspiring. Processes are often drawn out (it may take 3-6 months to create such a letter). Day to day work can make you feel like cog in machine.

headline: Has gotten too bureaucratic and too collaborative in recent years
pros: Great work environment and perks. Good benefits and pay. Genuinely "nice" company culture. Decisions are backed up by data rather than just being the "highest paid person's opinion."
cons:
The culture has swung toward being too collaborative and committees and group meetings are way overused now. When I started, you could come up with a good idea, run it by two levels of management and then at least get it tested on a small group of customers. Now I have to go to my manager, all of his peers, several other department's managers, a steering committee, (at least) two "project prioritization" groups because none of them alone are allowed to sign off on anything. Implementing good ideas can take 6-18 months over all.

And the "cross calibration" system the company uses to hand out promotions and bonuses has completely devolved into a political bargaining exercise between managers.

headline: It's high school all over again.
pros: People are great, salary & benefits good. Telecommute/flex time a big plus. Great campus, lots of freedom.
cons:
Performance Management is a disgrace. Promotions based on popularity and how good your manager is at presenting you in discussions. Decisions already made in advance of "360 feedback".

Very political. Pretty young college girls do well and move up, but veterans suffer. Lots of cliques.I did upper-level work for 3 years and never got the offical promotion (or pay).

Much talk about "open culture" and diversity of thought -- but be vocally opposed to something and you're banished from the kingdom.

headline: Sr Risk Manager
pros: benefits, work hours, management, upbeat positive atmosphere
cons: Salary, career opportunities, work hours,

headline: Love my Career
pros:
Benefits are awesome!
Great People
Colorful Atmosphere
cons: Lack of empathy for employee personal situations

headline: not a bad work envrionment

headline: I wish they did better with transitioning from HSBC!

headline: The experience has been fulfilling including change, development, and opportunities working on high impact business goal

cons: Depending on your role, your day could be filled with meetings and presentations. Sometimes the culture is too collaborative and it is hard to get anything done unless its scheduled in a meeting environment.

headline: Stressful, Hypocritical, Nitpicky.

Benefits

OK pay, not great. Barely a living wage.
Aetna health insurance doesn't cover anything
Upper Management doesn't connect with employees very well
Management is making an effort to hire new people and get rid of older employees who have been there for 10+ years.
High stress environment
Minimal resources for mental health.

headline: Uncertain
pros: Lots of opportunity for movement
